Pours a nice hazy orange colour, finger of bright fluffy egg white head with decent retention and no lacing.

Smell is fruity yeast esters, cloves, bananas and a touch of caramel.

Taste is bready yeast esters. Surprisingly bitter with some leafy green hops having a definite presence. Caramel and toffee notes come through on the finish with a bit of a peppery clove flavour.

Quite light on the tongue, heavy carbonation, goes down smooth, with a perplexing finish that starts off dry, but finishes wet.

A tasty tripel and definitely worth taking for a spin. The high ABV goes completely unnoticed, and the flavours are uniquely balanced between spices, caramel malts and leafy hops.

Aromas of lemon peel, pine, spice. Fantastic fresh bitterness in the taste, this beer is very well hopped for a tripel. Some spicyness in the aftertaste and surprisingly little alcohol. Amazing for 9.5% ABV. Maybe less balanced than some other tripels but surely the most refreshing.
Pours hazy yellow with a medium head. Aroma is citrus and yeast. Flavor is bitter malts, alcohol and some hops. Dry and unexpected flavor. I like it.

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2014 Aroma: Vanilla sweetness, a bit of sour funk, quite spicy/yeasty, citrus fruits, oranges, apples, pears. Complex. Also vinous notes as well. 

Appearance: Murky but bright, golden yellow with a bright white head thats somewhat determined to stay. Very lively carbonation. Pretty.

Taste: Its amazingly sweet, but thats countered by spices, and a hoppy and boozy finish. Lots of light bready and grassy notes like a pils.

Palate: Very crisp, very smooth, and it has a nice dry spicy finish. Carbonation is perfect. Body is quite light for the ABV.

Overall: The #1 tripel. The only problem I have with this beer is that it gets you wrecked in no time.

Tot u spreekt een grote westmalle tripelfanaat.
This beer is unique in every way imaginable. From the taste to appearance and smell. Poured into a big glass youll see the true color of this beer, bright golden-yellow with a slight touch of brown.
The smell is sharp, its just the beginning...
After this delicious golden liquid enters your mouth youll experience thousands of flavoured sensations, one even more exquisite than the last one. Goosebumps start to rise all over your body, your tongue enjoys a tsunami of deliciousness. After youve swallowd and fully tasted this beer youll crave for more.
The best way of consuming a Westmalle Tripel is to serve half a bottle at first, drink it, and then, pour the rest of the bottle -including the yeast (saccharomyces cerevisiae)- into your glass, this gives you the ultimate Westmalle Tripel experience, it ads a bitter and very barley-like finishing touch to your aftertaste.
Drinking this beer will truly expand your horizon concerning beer, not only by taste but also, and maybe even more, will provide you with a whole new perspective on this ancient brewers tradition. 
Nothing will be the same anymore. Period.

And the best is yet to come; order your next glass.

April 20, 2011; large bottle acquired from MikeB.  Cloudy, golden pour; exquisitely-fine head; zesty, lemony aroma; citrus hops, while dominant, are balanced somewhat by malts that give this brew a full body.  Palate is dry & somewhat astringent.  The 9.5 ABV is very well-hidden; not a boozy brew at all.  Ive yet to become well-acquainted with the Tripels (and am still developing a taste for them), but this is certainly a good place to start.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2012 A good Belgian ale. Well balanced, very drinkable but also interesting enough to make you keep reaching for it.

Update 10/28/2012: Had bottle aged or about 17 and the experience was noticeably different; and better. Aging brings out more spice and more fruit notes. I was pretty impressed with this beer, and would have to say that was the best Triple Ive had. Rating is based on the aged bottle, bringing it up from 3.7.

33cl bottle. Golden/orange colour, a bit hazy, a big lacey head with a steady stream of bubbles. The nose has flowers and lemon zest and is extremely intense. The taste has a dominant sharp yeasty/floral note which finishes with a huge candied lemon note. The palate shows a huge structure, a rich texture throughout and a zingy finish which makes you ready for the next sip. Excellent multi-dimensional beer which improves as you get down the glass!

21 Mar 2010, bottle. pale yellow and hazy. smells of yeast and bananas. aroma is like a weizen but taste is definitely a tripel. slightly fizzy finish. light sweet opening w/ slightly acidic middle and finish. faint hints of bananas throughout. light to med body. watery texture. not my favourite tripel

Bought to drink on a relaxed Saturday night doing absolutely nothing. I had high expectations of this beer, and my exp. were met indeed. It has a hazy yellow-to-orange body with a thick white head. Citrus dominates the smell, but I immedialtely thought about champagne. Tastes of fruits, especially orange and peach, but also banana. I also detect some honey which I found very interesting and added much to the overall impression. In terms of alcohol, it does not taste as strong as it says (9.5% - beware!:). Dry finish, but still sweet like candy. I enjoyed this one! Damn, wish I bought one more...

Cè tutto...non di tutto...cè, in questa birra, tutto quello che è necessario e sufficiente per fare una splendida triple, anzi, la madre di tutte le triple, per universale riconoscimento. Molto alcolica, bionda, alta fermentazione: le tre condizioni (o almeno, le tre principali) per le quali si dà vita ad una triple, e che in questa birra (dalla ricetta pressoché immutata dal 1956) sono presenti al top. Bel colore oro antico, schiuma compatta, cremosa ed abbondante. Al palato ricco e complesso, molto pronunciato, con sentori fruttati (banana), un luppolo vivacissimo e un tocco di malto nel sottofondo. Il corpo è robusto, strutturato e caldo: il luppolo la fa da padrone, in un contesto fruttato, e la potenza dellalcool la completa nel finale. Moderatamente frizzante, da vita ad un finale secco ed asciutto, mediamente astringente e nettamente amaro. Linvecchiamento la fa variare nel gusto, fino ad una preponderanza del fruttato ed abboccato.

Poured from a bottle into a tiny plastic stein at Brew Fest in Athens, GA. This straw-colored liquid raised a mighty head and gave off aromas of pear, green apple, and straw. Flavors followed suit, but with the straw coming on strong in the finish to impart a long dry ending that evoked a fine saison. These Belgian monks seem to know what theyre doing.

Bottiglia - De Shutter Pub - Amsterdam.
Una tripel belga con i controluppoli! Bionda dorata carica, rifermentata in bottiglia, con lieviti depositati sul fondo ma comunque limpida allaspetto, alcoolica al palato, sentori fruttati al naso e piacevoli note amare. luppoli ben bilanciati, ottima tripel, migliora sorso dopo sorso

Deep orange with a spitty white head that takes some time to take its true shape.  Nose is apricot, peach, metal, grass, sweet citrus, honey.  Flavor is super dry with more fruit, citrus, and spice.  Finishes slightly boozy and chalky. This is the opposite of what most American brewers interpretations of the Belgian Tripel style turn out like, so, so dry without even a hint of cloying sweetness. Pretty amazing tripel that deserves its high stature.

toast, resin, bread, golden, hazy, minimal head, light sweetness, medium bitterness, full body, creamy, lively, long finish, outstanding beer that met all the hype Ive heard about it. Well worth the trip to Belgium.
bottle; hazy golden with large white head; aroma-yeast, mild citrus; taste- mild sweetness, heavy carbonation and mild bitterness. It has a rich mouth feel, strong alcohol. Hard to beat

pericolo sbornia!
bellissima da vedere color oro un po opaca con una abbondante schiuma fine cremosa in superficie e persistente
aroma intenso alcolico fruttato (banana) e molto luppolo!
in bocca è unica e inconfondibile calda morbida con sentori di agrumi e di grano.chiude subito verso lamaro (forse un po troppo velocemente) che domina per parecchio tempo 
non si sentono i gradi mentre la si beve ma occhio a quando vi alzate dalla sedia!!!:-)

Bottle from Zyn Calgary, poured into a trappist glass. Pours a hazy gold colour, really nice pillowy white head initially, that recedes to a ring and a little climbing lacing (but not much). Aroma is spicy a little boozy and bread, and some fruit. Taste is spicy again. and sweet, fruity, a little bite a little bitter and a dry finish. What more could you ask for in a beer?

33cL bottle in Brussels. Pours a golden yellow with a very nice thick foamy white head. Smells of banana, yeast, and alcohol. Taste is of pepper corn, alcohol, and spice. Hides alcohol well but feels warm going down. A classic tripel. Excellent.
750 to tulip.  Floral with a sour note.  Taste is sweet.  An excellent beer.

Golden beer with a creamy white foam. Overwhelming, exotic scent of dried fruits, apples, spices and honey. Not quite as opulent and rich in the mouth, where a finely tuned, slightly drying bitterness gives the beer a perfect finish.

Bottle, poured into a weizen glass. Creamy head, white with moderate lacing. Turbid body with an impassioned fizz. Particulate matter notable in the pour. Amber hue with hazy appearance - almost reminiscent of an orange or maple cousin to the mystical Victorian absinthe. The aroma teases the imbiber with an undertone that is delicately sweet, nestled beneath a predominant aroma of fresh bread. The palate is oily with a muffled effervescence. The finish borders on slightly chalky. The taste is tantalizingly bitter, with the alluring hint of a flirtatious sweetness, and fresh herbs. Like a number of quadrupel beverages characteristic of the Belgians that I have tried, this libation carries with it the suggestion of anise or liquorice.  The finish is pleasantly lengthy and warming.

poured into a snifter. pours a gorgeous straw yellow/orange with a huge white head that hangs out for a while. Aromas of spices are the lead, with honey and grapes close behind. Outstanding carbonation. The honey flavors are definitely present. Tons of spices in this as well. Tastes like fall, with its hints of apples and pears and spices. Warms the mouth with its complex flavors. As with all trappists, try it.

Bottle:  I was expecting a little more flavor.  That being said, this is a great, easy drinking beer.  It just does not seem that complex to me.  I have no idea how someone, anyone, could not really like this beer.

Good, but after having some of the other stronger abbey ales, its not the best. Reminds me of Chimays cinq cents but a little different. Nose is spicy and yeasty with a touch of sweetness and fruit lingering after. Flavor is citrus, plum, spice, alcohol, yeast, and slight malt. I definitely enjoyed this one but prefer some of the others Ive tried. One more trappist checked off the list.

Pours with an opaque golden color, boasting a fluffy and well retained head. The lacing is thin, but sticky. Much of the aroma and taste reminds me of cider  maybe apple cider. The nose is dominated by fruity smells  e.g. citrus and apple  along with a mild hint of alcohol and clove. The flavor is essentially the same as the nose, running from a bitter-sour taste in the front and finishing out with an alcohol taste in the back. While I could do without the alcohol aroma and taste, in my view, this is one of the better abbey tripels

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2011 This may be the original tripel, but Im nonetheless a bit disappointed. It looks great, slightly hazy with a medium amber colour and a creamy, white, fully lasting head with plenty of lacing. The aroma is also good: plenty of floral notes, herbs, yeast and pineapple. The taste is initially light bitter with a hint of vanilla sweetness, but then the alcohol kicks inn and threatens to ruin the party: the finish is bitter in an unpleasant way, and the flavour is dominated by the alcohol. In the Chimay Triple the alcohol in the finish creates a warm, mouth warming honey sweetness, but in the Westmalle the alcohol doesnt do anything to enhance the experience.
[33 cl bottle, from Vinmonopolet]

33 cL Westmalle Tripel bottle from Noble Green Wines poured into a Westmalle glass.  Loved this beer for years and Ive finally got around to rating it.  Left the best of a centimer left in the bottle to stop the sediment going in.  It looks the business, a dark blonde beer with a healthy head.  It smells slightly yeasty, malty and strong and a little spicy.   Good if not amazing.  Tastes a bit sour and dry.  Certainly has a sharp and distinctive smaak.  Its a fine trappist ale, but not as complex as the Dubbel, which eventually Ive grown to prefer.  This a fine sipper of a beer in its own right though, a must try and its had me coming back for years.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2015 (17/03/2011) [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */: plenty of hops, yeast, plenty of spices (prob. incl. coriander), medium bitter bite, lemongrass, crisp with graceful carbonation, referential but not the supreme tripel in my opinion, I have come across a bit too many, seemingly infected or where something appears to have gone wrong with it //////////////////////////// Tried some older vintages of this, early 90s, didnt take any notes, no influence on score, one was totally gone & rubbish. Other one was quite oxidized but held up, interesting sweet, almost cereal notes. Either way, wouldnt age it.  ///////////// 2015. Clear golden, egg-white head. Bubblegum sweet nose, almost Hefeweizen like with a dash of sugar. Taste is esters, banana, yeast, lightly boozy, banana sweetness, faintest of sugar, Lively in a good way. Really good, I dont get why in the past, I was never fully into this. 3.7 -> 4.6 for now.
(bottle) clear, light amber colour with tall white head; aroma of fruit, toffee, pineapple; balanced flavour

Strong aroma of a bouqet of flowers. Ginger and banana are also noticable. Copper in color with a bubbly, white head. Constallation lacing. Taste of rotten lemon. Medium-bodied beer with a thin texture. Has an abrupt ending. Overall aroma awesome flavor average.

330ml bottle.  Pours a very light gold with a large head.  Aroma is sweet candy, clove and some banana underneath.  Subtle.  Taste starts with some clove and lemon, more clove and banana on the finish.  Warm alcohol on the afertaste.
Outstanding tripel by the trappists at Westmalle. Do not hesitate to order one when you find it in a pub.

750mL poured into a snifter.

4.0 A: Hazed light to medium yellow. Nearly three fingers of frothy white head with good retention and loads of lacing.

4.5 S: Good spiciness going on here. Plenty of clove and black pepper with some other unidentifiable spice in there tying things together. Hay, lemon rind, and green apple. Theres a general earthiness and a moderate amount of yeast. Pretty good!

4.0 T: Clove and pepper again. Sweet maltiness, peach and wild apple, hay and and earthy funkiness, and a good helping of yeast. Surprisingly bitter for the style, but is welcomed to even out the fruitiness.

3.5 M: Medium body. Carbonation is a bit higher than Id prefer, but okay. Carbonation is active, but not quite to the "spritzy" level I like from a good Belgian beer. Goes down easy and leaves a footprint of both bitter and sweet in the aftertaste.

4.0 D: Good beer. I like the earthiness of the Trappist beers that seldomly manifests in the American counterparts. No flaws with a good complexity.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-28-2011 00:04:40
Quite foamy and fizzy.  Had floaties in it (not that thats a bad thing).  Initial tastes werent great, but as I drank the bottle, it grew on me.

11.2 oz bottle.
Hazy orange color with a small amount of white head.  Smells very floral and spicy - taste is slightly bitter with a defined belgian yeast.

Floral aromas combined with yeasty bready aroma.  Pours hazy golden yellow.  Pillowy tight white head that lasts.  Sweetness at first with warming alcohol.  Some  honey and peppery spicey notes as well.  Strong bread malt flavors.  Very richly carbonated.  Overall very enjoyable.

Cloudy orange with a huge white head. Aroma is sweet fruity, yeasty and spicy. Flavor is medium sweet and fairly bitter. Smooth with a dry, bitter and spicy finish. Warming alcohol. Very good Tripel. 240810
Pours into an straw colored cloud with a massive head. Very dry with some floral notes. Nicely balanced beer, its hard to believe its 10% alcohol, but not to my taste.
Cloudy golden body, huge white head. Yeasty, citric and spicy aroma. Light alcoholic palate, interestingly quite bitter taste, dry finish.
UPDATED: AUG 14, 2011 dry, spicy, fruity craft belgian tripel, light yellow. Going off memory and dont remember too much more, enjoy!
Strong alcohol, but ok it is a triple. A tasty beer with a fruity taste, a delicious foam as no other. Thick delicious foam that lies like a rug on the beer.
orange, citrus aroma, decent foam particles floating . strong alcohol taste. bitter. low carbination. at the bottom end of abbeys tasted.

Must say I am a little disappointed in this Trappist beer.  It had a mild aroma, nothing like a Delirium.  Has the traditional Trappist appearance in its golden look, small white head.  Taste ok at best, but nothing that blows your socks off.  It has a bit of a bitter after taste.  Drinkability is ok, but the price is to high for a beer I just kind of like,
Shocked I had never rated this before.  I had this on tap in Belgium.  Pours hazy dark yellow with a white head.  Aroma of spice and Belgian yeast.  Good flavor, good Tripel.

33cl bottle at the Evening Star, Brighton. Pours a hazy straw yellow colour with a creamy white head. The nose is pear drops, hay, grass, daisies, honey and quite spicy. The taste is initially of honey/mead, which leads to hay, varnish, decent alcohol warmth, orange, sweet tangerine, lemon sherbet, soap and starch with a bitter-spicy finish. A top-notch Tripel.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2011 One my note (while drinking this beer) i wrote; Bitter and fresh?!

And this:
coffee, little roasty, alcohol, 
golden, clear, white foam, 
light sweetness, very bitter, lightly sour, 
medium body, creamy, lively, long finish, bitter,
I really enjoyed this one. Fluffy head. Had some spice to it. This one I will try again. It surprised me.

33cl Bottle with very little head which disappeared instantly leaving little lacing. The color was a cloudy light or pale amber. The aroma was truly the best part of the experience, wafting pleasantly from the glass, easily enjoyed a full foot from the glass. Notes of fruit, mild banana and alcohol, maybe whiskey. There was little carbonation, a bit too flat on the palate so the flavor was a little unbalanced. Floral, light hops and yeasty bread. It concealed the high alcohol content nicely with a mild bitter finish. I was expecting to enjoy this beer more as the other Trappist beers I have tried  thoroughly impressed me, even with their massive reputations, but it is without doubt a well made and high quality beer.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2011 one of the best triple beer in the world!
Fruity, strong blond top fermented beer.
Nice yellow/goldish color,sprankly carbontation.

Slightly opaque yellow with a fluffy white head fed by bubble streams.  Aromas of light citrus, grass & grain, bread.  A very natural beery smell.  Flavor is of light malt and bitter grasses, and light floral notes with good astringency.  Carbonation is excellent and balances out the high alcohol with a crisp, clean finish.  An enjoyable, classic yet intoxicating brew that is pleasing all the way around.

Hazy golden color in the glass with a white head.  Delicate aromas of spice, grain, and flowers.  Fine carbonation lends a creaminess to the mouthfeel.  Smooth on the palate with a great Belgian yeast character.  Just a tiny hint of alcohol, the 9.5% ABV is well-concealed.  Great beer.

The beer to start a nice long weekend.  Pours a standard pale yellow color but with big white head and terrific lacing.  Smells of yeast and tropical fruit.  Tastes of banana, spicy, tart and bread dough.  very refreshing.
Good poor, fair complexity, nice color, and smooth aroma. Good spice on this one.

33 cl bottle from Systembolaget. Pours large, foamy, white head. Clear, pale, golden appearance with some bubbles. Smells off spices, clove, banana, belgian yeast and sweet fruit. Taste dry with, for trappist standards, big bitterness towards the ending. Some warming alcohol. Very dry and crisp, nice mouthfeel. Medium bodied. Better than other tripels, absolutely.

Bottle. A bit hazy, pale golden with visible carbonation, large white head leaving lacing. Aroma: yeast, dried grass or hay, nuts, dryish. Taste: dried fruit, sweet malt, alcohol, tart apple, just a hint of licorice, medium bitterness, candy, some wine, some spices, nuts, dry finish. Above medium-bodied with soft bubbles.

Pours a slightly cloudy golden color with a huge fluffy white head that sticks around forever. Aroma is esters, clove, banana, Belgian Yeast. Taste follows the smell but is more intense in spiciness. Finishes with a lingering alcohol burn. Crisp massive carbonation, medium to thick body. Great spicy brew!
Bottle 330 ml. Aroma: Banana, sweet, phenolic, estery, fruity, alcohol. Taste: sweet, a bit umami, the bitterness is not balanced with the sweetness. No balanced beer.

A little thinner, less viscous than what Id expected. A decent beer, not to the quality of Rochefort or St. Bernardus. Somewhat on the sweet, ginger, candy end finishing with a slight bitter aftertaste. Very good (I wouldnt say no if someone offered me one) but not spectacular.

A - gold yellow color
S - starts with grapefruit and continues with a smell of citruses
T - smooth taste with tones of citruses, apricot, banana with light bready finish.
M - medium to low body with high carbonation
D - pretty drinkable one, however youre not "forced" to drink another one
Decent trappist beer, with a small trace of yeast within the bottle. Less aroma than excepted from a top fermenting beer

330ml Bottle.  Pours a golden yellow color with dense, long-lasting head.  Aroma is sweet fruits and honey.  Taste is also sweet, non-dried fruits with a hint of citrus and a slight floral hop flavor.  Palate is medium-bodied, creamy with nice, soft carbonation.

A cloudy orange colour with a big beautiful white head that stays until the end. Almost perfect lacing. Aroma is light but complex being mostly spicy and fruity with underlying hints of hops. Initial taste is strong and fruity but followed by a very long magnificent bitter finish. Feels beautifully soft and creamy in the mouth. Overall, Wonderfully balanced and complex. A class act

Shows a hazy pale golden colour with sediments mantled by a creamy, laceing white head, which remains thinly.
The dry-sweetish nose brings citrus-fruits, alcohol and spice along.
Tasteing begins sharp escorted by a slick and thick texture.
The dry charactered and complex aroma combines mainly citrus and resin additionally cereals and hints of alcohol, the flavours of biscuits and grapefruit.
The sweet taste is balanced by hoppy bitterness in the finish, which is escorted by light alcohol and resin. At last a sweet-citric aftertaste remains.
Alcohols well hidden, so its easy to síp, overall a complex, balanced and fine tripel.

Bottle 75 cl. Color is gold/cloudy with a firm white head. Aroma: hoppy, slightly sour (yellow fruit), slightly sweet (sweet fruit: banana). Taste:  bitterness of the hop, sweet, fruity and a little spicy. Long aftertaste is slightly bitter and slightly sweet. Mouthfeel is creamy with a thick body. Recommended!

11.2 oz bottle in a Chimay glass.  Nice orange amber pour with one finger white head.  Mild cider aroma.  Immediate flavors of apple and grape with a mildly bitter finish.  Great balance.  Excellent beer.

Date: 8/15/2010   Source:Other   Grainy with some spicy yeast character. Light citrusy fruitiness. Light straw golden slightly cloudy with big fluffy head. Dry light peach pear fruitiness with light citrusy notes. Medium body with high carbonation. Dry peppery finish that is fairly bitter.

Pours a deep gold, usually a little cloudy as its really hard to avoid disturbing the sediment unless you leave a quarter of the beer in the bottle! Yeast, cloves and peppery hops on the nose, with hints of pear drops and a drying alcohol scent. In the mouth it is big and dry, with golden fruit, toffee, more peppery hops and a touch of peaches and cream, all leading into a dry alcohol and bitter finish. Lovely stuff, though a bit over-carbonated.

Poars a cloudy gold with a firm head that dissipated rather quickly.
Has aromas of citrus and other fruits.
Tastes bitter.

A rather lager-like aroma of unroasted malt and grassy noble hops, but with a fair amount of funk. Clear amber, thick lacing head. Medium body, slightly sweet. Flavor is of malt, candi, and hints of grass. Funked up palate. Not terribly exciting, but a fairly nice departure from the sub-standard Tripels Ive had in the past. It isnt too peachy and the alcohol is not insistent.
4th February 2007  Warning! Early amateur rating! Thickish palate. Caramelly blond coloured. Nice depth of aromatic tastes. A little bitter and a little dry.
750ml bottle. Pours a cloudy gold color. Fruit notes on nose and palate. Creamy and rich mouthfeel. Nice drinkability. Finest tripel in the world IMHO.

Slightly cloudy yellow pour, little head dissipated quickly.  Light aroma with a hint of spice and citrus.  Some apricot, or maybe grapefruit in the flavor (the bitterness of the hops makes me think of grapefruit).  Its not bad, but more bitter than I like.

Cloudy.  It pours cloudy into a white wine glass, which my father proudly displays in his china cabinet.  Im not sure why he has a set of white wine glasses or a china cabinet, as he neither drinks white wine nor owns any dishes worth displaying.  Ill use this stemware in lieu of the Trappist tulip glass I wont own anytime soon.  You see, I cant really afford fancy glassware of my own, and because I move so often, it just wouldnt be practical to throw glassware in the back of my Dodge.  Or on a plane.  To that place where Ill be four and a half months from now.

Your guess is as good as mine.

This beer cannot compare to the Westvleteren 12° I enjoyed in June of 2009, though it was brewed by the same order of monks in the same region of Belgium.  Lets just hope that wherever I am in June of 2011 will be a better deal than the Office Depot gig I had when I cracked open the Westvleteren.

Cloudy.  The crystal ball is cloudy.

Appearance:  buttery, cloudy gold with a pure white foamy head that lingers throughout.  Aroma:  refreshingly sweet and spicy, yeasty and fruity, with a nice malt presence.  Taste:  as the aroma indicates:  some nice fruit (white grapes, pear) and yeast notes, with good sweet malt backbone, and judicious hops to balance and dry.  Finish:  tingly, yeasty and dry like white wine, and the malt actually hangs on longer than anything else.  Not a huge tripel fan in general, but this one is clearly very well done.  Palate was nice:  rich and creamy, yet also light and refreshing.
02.02.2007. 0,33l Bottle. Golden brown colour. Malty aroma with strong mouthfeel. Rich body with nice bitterness.
Bottle at a restaurant in Brussels (3,90 euro). Pours a cloudy deep blonde color with a nice thick white head. Very citrusy nose with a thin mouth feel. Medium body and very drinkable.

Pours a light copper with a frothy white head, which lasts for the duration of the beer. Nice aroma of apples, belgian yeast and earthy herbal hop character. Flavor has notes of pale malt, bread, a tinge of caramel, then herbal noble hops and apple/pear. Very well-balanced - pleasant sweetness level and ample hops to even it out.  Absolutely perfect, heavenly mouthfeel - lively yet not even remotely prickly carbonation - feels lush and creamy but not thick and syrupy. Quite enjoyable.
Bright golden color with a huge head and lots of carbonation.  Spicy and tangy, with a fruity aroma. A great abbey tripel.

Pretty and hazy pour, bright white head that stays. Dry honey and floral-wheat and pollen. carbonation and sweetness were understated (maybe the imported bottle). bananna, light orange, fruity. lots of yeast as it warms in to the body of the beer.
Tasty but not bold. dry and straightforward triple for me. 3.8

Bottle 330ml at home. 
Pours hazy strawish yellow with white non-lasting head.  Aroma of citrus and yeast. Citrusy tastes with malts and a bit of yeast. Soft carbonation.

A wonderful spicy/fruity aroma.   Lively head at first pour that subsides somewhat but remains to the bottom of the glass.  Beautiful golden honey color.  Highly carbonated, almost champagne-like mouthfeel.  Complex malty flavor with lots of spicy depth.

One of the great Belgian Trippels.  The pour is quite impressive, cloudy golden-orange with yeast sediment.  The aroma is fruit and the flavors are yeast, spice, fruit with some sweetness in the body and a finish of dry hops.  A wonderful beer whole flavors mask the nearly 10% alcohol.  Delicious.
Beautiful pour of golden cloudy yellow and protein head with aroma of sweet malts; taste is dry, spicy, earthy and a little sour/funky on the finish. Very nice brew
I need to taste this again.  I liked it very well and remember it having strong complex flavors.....but I dont remember much else from that night.

33 cl flaske. Gylden diset krop og med et mellemlangt hvidt hoved. Lidt frisk duft, med en snert af citron og citronskal. Smag af lys malt lidt gær og citron. God gane måske en smule tør med en snert af tilpas bitterhed i afslutningen. DK-B-72,00

Bottle. Golden, cloudy, large mostly lasting head. Moderate malty aroma with some sweetness, herbal and peppery spiciness. Body is medium, malty and sweetish flavor, alcohol and light hoppyness. Finish is average, malty and dryish, alcohol. Dryish tripel which is not over-hopped. Also quite a lot of alcohol in the flavor and in the finish.
hazy yellow with white head.  slightly malty and sweet with a taste of oranges.  good carbonation, excellent mouth feel.  very drinkable for a high alcohol ale.

A: Pours a hazy straw color with a nice white head and some pretty good lacing.

S: Nice yeasty spiciness atop some slightly-sweet malt character. A bit of alcohol.

T: Beautiful spicy character with plenty of powerful fruit coming through as well. Vague hop character in the background.

M: Nice and quite crisp. Excellent carbonation and feel overall.

D: The classic of the style, and something Id always like to have a little bit of lying around.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-15-2010

Golden Yellow with 2 finger white head. Smells of mild orchard fruits with some spices and yeasts. Taste are mild earthy mix, yeasts, mildly sweet malts, hops and spices. Lite to Med body with good zesty carbonation start to finish, nice alcohol warmth, bready and dry finish. A good tripel, not as fruity as some. A very worthy brew.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2011 Clear orange with a quickly fading foamy head. Quite a fresh aroma, with spices, leaves, hint of peach, yeast. Nice sweetness at first that fades into a very rich bitterness with a good punch from the alcohol. Tingling and foamy, it develops great amounts of flavour. One of the better trippels for sure.
Bottle. Pours hazy golden with a white head. Aroma has notes of sweet malt, and fruity hops. light sweetness and lightly bitter.
Bottle 750ml. Pours golden with white head. Malty, dont know what happened with this one, but I kind of missed something, need to try it again in another temperature perhaps. Taste wasnt appealing.

Hazy pale orange with floating chucks of yeast. Decent head on initial pour but dissipated quickly. Good lacing. Candy sweet aroma with hint of spice. Full bodied and malty. Sweet with hints of fruit (mostly orange). Some lingering bitterness. Tasty beer...a tad on the expensive side.
poured from a 330ml bottle a cloudy golden ale with a small white head. Aroma of citrus and lemon zest. Flavor of lemon, orange, malt and yeast. Palate very good with a nice aftertast.

Cloudy very pale yellow, small lasting head. Spice, lemon-lime, malt aromas, with the spice dominating, but in a good way. Lively carbonation. Very smooth body with spicy and malty notes, finishes with some pleasantly subtle hoppy-spicy notes. A very nice beer.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy medium yellow, with high carbonation and bright white effervescent head. Slight spice in aroma with citrus and hop aromas. Strong taste of higher alcohols and strength is very evident.

11.2 ounce bottle, best before end:  09/04/11.  Served in a snifter, the beer pours a cloudy golden/orange color with about an inch and half off-white head.  Head retention and lacing are both pretty good.  Aroma is bready malt, yeast, orange peel, and some fruit and spice (it just smells fruity and spicy in general, I couldnt pick out any one particular fruit or spice).  Taste is pretty much just like the aroma, but theres also a bit of pear and an earthy taste noticable in the brew.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its smooth but has a little too much carbonation for me.  Drinkability is decent, but would be better if the carbonation was lower.  But overall, I liked this beer.  Id buy it again in the future.
Hazy amber orange beer with nice huge white head.Smell sweet malt,mint,fruits,orange,spices,coriander.Flavor,ve sweet,yeast,pear,cheese,coriander,a salty feeling.Dry finish.A good trappist.

Bottle: Pours a typical cloudy medium golden hue with a big frothy white head - Huge retention and big lacing on my bottle - Nice bready spice note on the nose. This brew has a hop bitterness, but it is not overpowering. It is slightly sweet, but subdued - The spice note probably dominates, but it is not overpowering either. I find this one a bit boring , frankly. Perhaps thats the feel Im getting for Tripels in general.

bottle.  Pours peach gold with floating sediment and a frothy white head.  Aroma is both floral and fruity, with notes of apple, pear, lemon, honey, sage, thyme, orange.  Medium to full bodied, the 9% is well hidden and it is very smooth to drink, featuring a super long finish which is ultimately dry and somewhat bitter but also features notes of honey, grape.  Flavor mainly of floral notes, prominent hop profile, but while still maintaining the essence of a tripel.  Lightly spiced.  A classic rendition of the style, although not my favorite so far.

Yellow pour with a large, pillowy, white head.  The aroma is delicately floral with some light apple, pear and lemon notes.  Its a bit musty and yeasty as well with soft esters, a light honey sweetness, and some bready malt backbone.  The flavor is delicate a dry with a fair btt of honey sweetness, some lightly floral hops, touches of banana and bubblegum are interspersed with a bready body and notable alcohol.  The mouthfeel is dry, medium in consistency with lots of carbonation.
From a bottle poured a golden color with a good amount of head.  Nice light spicy malty flavor with a quick finish.
Almost clear yellow. Not impressive head. Fruity smell, I thought banana and melon after sniff. Sweet/sour alcoholic taste. A bit of hops in after taste. Mostly uninteresting, but not bad.
As tripels go, this is near tops for me.  Dry, spicy, light citrus and wheat grass.  Not my favorite style, and a bit too hot for my liking, but I can see why people like this.
Poured cloudy orange with good fluffy white head smelled sweet and fruitty. Tasted bout the same good trappist

Bottle @ home. Pours hazy, unclear golden body with a creamy everlasting big head. Nose is somewhat sweet, citrus, wheat and anonymous orange zest. I disagree with the bottle, you need to release the aromas by pouring the bottle quite hard. Lots of carbonation that tickles your throat. Starts of sweet and maltish but ends up in a nice bitter and fruity ending. You can really taste and feel the alcohol but the bitter ending camouflages it in the end.
Pours golden with thick white creamy head and foamy lacing.  Faint notes of wheat and citrus.  Well balanced taste with a slightly bitter finish.
Well,Im a huge fan of trappists but this is not something special.An average bitersweet taste,medium alcochol and a perfect foam,but its taste...Well I was expecting something more thick...
Bottled sample from Fathers Office in Culver City.  Shared with a few beer newbies.  All of us liked it but not my faroite style of beer

Lots of head. Hazy, orange colour. Aroma of alcohol is strong. Also Yeast and some fruit. Flavour is yeast and alcohol with just a little bit of fruits Some sweetness is in the mix. A pleasant beer to drink. Warming and somewhat spicy.
Big, fluffy head over an opaque and hazy organe/gold. Fresh baked bread, honey and lemon aromas. Stony dry finish.

11 plus oz bottle poured out a off golden brew into my trappist glass. Good head and slight lacing. Smells of ripened plums, apricots and grapes. Mild yeast detected but alcohol comes through as well.A quality brew, one I found myself sipping at the end.  .
Thick off white head, amber in color. Malty aroma with raisin overtones. Medium bodied, good aftertaste. Delicious tripel, but I prefer Westmalles dubbel.

11.2 oz bottle into Trappist glass. Compared side by side with Chimay White and with the rest of the Trappist beers Ive drank tonight. These two beers are #5 and #6 in tonights Trappist tasting. Pours hazy gold with some sediment and a nice long-retaining head that leaves some nice lace. Aroma is spicy, tangy, funky, alcoholic, earth. Taste is bittersweet; underwhelming compared with the aroma; slightly better than the Chimay. Soft carbonation, medium body. Not as good as I was expecting.

Poured from 11.2 FL oz bottle - Im not going to pretend Im an Abby expert, so I will focus on drinkability.  Pours a beautiful gold with a thin, fast-dissipating head.  Im not happy with the aroma--cant really detect individual aromas.  Quite dry; alcohol presence noticeable.  This is a nice sipper.

Yeast developed spice and cloves in the aroma, with a light fruitiness.  Malt is a very quiet caramel, it smells sneaky.  Theres a metallic tinge, slightly tinny.  Slight haze, light golden, beautiful lacy white head.  Lots of drifting trub.  Flavor is alcohol up front and finishing, Fusels seem out of balance.  Theres lots of yeast developed flavor, spice and the higher alcohols.  Very high carbonation.  Creamy, warming (nearly hot), and medium body.  This bottle seemed like it was a little off, alcohol was the dominant flavor to the detriment of malt and yeast flavors.

Bottle from Bierkompass. Poured hazy orange color with a thick white head. Very spicy aroma, fruity notes and yeast. Flavor is spices again, sweet malt and yeast, alcohol pushing through. Slightly dry finish. Nice tripel ,but too much alcohol in the flavor does not really do it for me.

Bottle:
Big white foamy head, disappears slow.
Hazy yellow color.
Smell fruit, sugars malts and spices.
Kind of a hard but also fresh taste: spices, yellow fruit, yeast, hops, grass and sweets.
Bitter dry in the end. Mid carbo.
Leaves lot of stuff in the glass.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: UPDATED: JAN 28, 2011 Hazy orange yellow with a huge white froth that leaves nice lacings. Aroma is yeasty acidic malty with lemon, coriander, straw and marzipan some hop. Taste is big round and yeasty and quite sweet with oranges, orange peel. apples, pear and some candy notes . Fruity, "citrusy", yeasty and sweet with a bitter touch. Maybe a bit too sweet.

Small bottle. Carefully poured into my new glass. Straw-golden body, fine head. Aroma has crisp hops, fresh citric fruits and cookie dough. Taste has mild fruity notes and good hop-bitterness. Exceptionally well rounded, the alcohol taste is still hidden at nearly 10%.

Bottle. Date on bottle says 5/08/11. Bottle opens with a slight little pop. Pours a slightly hazed golden straw color with a big bubbled 1 1/2 finger head that slowly settles. Seems more carbonated than I thought when I opened the bottle. The smell is rather clean with almost fruit like aromas like peach and apple. Some spice in the nose as well along with banana. Pretty high carbonation level that in my opinion somewhat detracts from the flavors. Pretty sweet up front with a mix of booze spicy type flavors. Ends with a lingering bitterness. Ends pretty cleanly. Good lace left on the glass. Overall a surprisingly light bodied, well carbed, nectar that drinks way easier than it should for the amount of alcohol it has. Makes me wonder how many tourists in Belgium just got rocked on this by accident!

Attractive golden coloured beer with such a great aroma - spicy and lemony and peppery. The taste is a delicate mix of fruitiness, spices and malt. Warming alcohol. Very dry finish - I love this beer as an aperitif.
in bottle; pours golden brown. I didnt really enjoy this one (maybe a bad bottle). I will try again to re-access as currently I would not recommend

The defining example of a Belgian Tripel, this is the beer that started the style as we know it today, i.e. a strong golden ale. Can be easily found in supermarkets and bars all over Belgium and is always a great staple to come back to again and again. Comes in a traditional bottle that features a ring with the lettering "Trappistenbier" embossed on it. It pours an intense orange with large white foamy head. As soon as you pour it a fruity bouquet of lemon grass, oranges and pineapple envelops your nose. The taste is a continuation of those flavours, all wrapped in a spicy full body with great mouthfeel. Theres spicy hops, coriander, organge peel, some pleasant fruity sweetness and a touch of alcohol. It is brilliantly upfront and assertive and yet very well balanced. Makes you want to move to Belgium just so you can session on that every weekend. Now excuse me while I go open another one.

Pours a cloudy green/gold colour with a nice, airy head. Much lighter in colour than my previous trappists. 

Fruitdriven nose, with a component that could remind me of gras as well. Freshly baked cupcakes is also something I´m picking up (the yeast flavour), and a hint of chocolate.

A lovely sweetnes backed up by a big mouthfeel. Bitternes is also present, and a long lasting mouthfeel. Getting a spicy pepper component on the palate in adition to the aromas from the nose. Many layers of goodness in this bottle!

Conclusion
I´m a big fan of trappistbeers, with the "wide" variaties you can get from the 7 different monastery´s. This Westmalle gives the category a nice twist with it´s lighter, fresher style, with alot of taste. Would have loved to try this to some asian inspired food!
Bottle: Pours a hazy golden color with a medium white head.  Aroma of banana and a little barnyard.  Flavor is sweet then spicy.  You can taste the alcohol.

Pours a very light hazy golden color with a full thick white head.  A nice yeasty aroma with some light bananas apples, fresh bread and a bit of an earthy barn quality.  Very lively mouthfeel.  Its a bit boozy but also a bit fruity.

Pours murky blonde with a touch of sediment and a medium, foamy white head. Nose is weak and typical tripel (light fruity sweetness, white sugar, coriander). Flavor is much deeper and very fruit based, most similar to a mix of white grapes, red apples, and banana. Decent yeastiness and coriander spice; light on the hops. Alcohol is definately in the taste. The overall flavor transitions from hops/spice to deep sweetness in the mouth. Very good.

330 ml bottle @ Ravintola Gloria, Kuopio. Rated @ 8.8.2009.
Pours a dark brown colour with a minimal white head. Orange, apricot, lemon and spices on the nose. Flavour of slightly roasted malts, dark fruits, spices and alcohol. Full bodied with a slicky mouthfeel. Not as good as Dubbel.
Bottle looks very good, beer in the glass very zippy, huge head. Starts very strong, quite alcoholic. Fruity like lemon and some apple. Finish sharp, still alcoholic. Interesting!

Notes from June 09, 2010
11.2 oz. bottle from Steves Liquor Madison

Ar: Big peach head with some funky yeast.  A bit of coriander in there as well.
Ap: Pours a beautiful cloudy gold with a creamy 1" head that actually dissipates surprisingly quickly.  Leaves a bit of lace.
T: Nice oraneg/citrus notes on the first drink.  A bit of doughy maltiness accompanies some classic belgian yeast flavors.  Warming alcohol burn on the finish.
P: Chewy mouthfeel complements this beer nicely.

All in all, a very good tripel.

Pours a cloudy muted lemon white color plus a thick foamy head.  Clean sweet aroma thats kind of creamy citrus.  Immediately dry on the palate with some spicy notes and a bitter peppery aftertaste.  Overall, this is very nice... a good sipping beer for the winter.
I really dont care for westmalle beers. this one is super thin, watery, not much body at all, hint of grain and candi sugar, hint of yeasty esters. overall just booze water.

A: The pour is a golden yellow color with an initially towering white head that eventually dies down to a fingers worth of foam.

S: Sweet malt and candi sugar come through initially with the yeast contributions following that. Pears, apples, and bananas provide some nice fruitiness.

T: The sugar component is quite strong and provides a great sweetness. Some banana bread sort of flavor along with a light bitterness.

M: The body is medium with a very full carbonation. Despite the sweetness of the beer, theres a nice dryness due to the carbonation.

D: I wish it tasted as good as it smelled, but still quite nice. One of the better tripels Ive had.

Poured a hazy orangish-yellow. Pale at the edges with a nice white foamy head and terrific lacing.

The nose was weak at first, but as it warmed and breathed, the phenols of peach and apricot mixed with a yeasty middle. There is also a spicy note that I cant quiet place.

The mouthfeel is rather light and carried by a high but not over done carbonation.

The taste reveals the real beauty of this beer. Fresh and fruity, more mustiness, alcoholic, tart through the middle, with a hint of absinthe, a crisp dry finish and a quite strong phenolic astringency and woody, clove and cinnamon lingering after.

This is an example of the style that some may equal but none exceed. Excellent.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2010 wow the head on this...incredible. a cloudy brew to say the least. tons o sediment  and ive been letting this sit upright in my fridge for about 2 weeks. 
can a tripel get more expressive? tons o alcohol and ripe tree fruit and banana bread yeast. wow. on the palate it doesnt disapoint. the length of this brew is lights out wickedly good. great carbonation and followed by classic belgian yeast and banana bread, butterscoth and maybe even ginger. really complex brew. ive never had two taste the same! A CLASSIC.
UPDATED: SEP 27, 2010 Another great autumn/winter brew that never lets you down. In fact, Im about to stock up for the football game this weekend.

A cloudy pour with visible particles remaining from the brewing process, it looks more like a fresh apple cider than a beer. But it has a tangy, sweet and sparkly taste. Doesnt look like much, but was a great beer with a lobster supper.

Bottled, bought in Amsterdam. Color cloudy golden with nice white head. Aroma, flowers, citrus and notes of yeast.  Taste fruit, hints of orange, pepper, nice light bitter finish. Alcohol is present in taste, but beer is complex and smooth. Very nice beer.

750 mL bottle as a birthday present. Pours a pale, hazy yellow color with a large off-white head. The aroma is fruity and spicy, with notes of oranges, apricots, brown sugar, cinnamon, and cloves. The flavor is sweet, with a strong citrus sourness. The spices are not upfront, but add a subtle bite. There is almost no bitterness, except for a light and lingering aftertaste. It has a medium body, with a rather creamy texture. The spices add a definite roughness to the mouthfeel. A wonderfully complex beer, well worth the time to savor.

From a 750 mL bottle. Pours an opaque, muted honey gold with frothy head that lingers. Nose is mild, of hops. Taste is nutty, hint of bananas that has a pleasant crescendo and fade. It is possible to taste the alcohol. Damn good and worthy of its marks.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2016 Hazy pale pour with nice fluffy white head that laces all the way down. Lots of carbonation, dry at the end. Taste is spicy and a little sweet and sour. Good, but not all its cracked up to be.

Bottle. Great triple. Not my favorite, but very respectable..  Deep straw color with a lot of froth. Definite floral hops and yeast in the nose. Taste is spicy and sugary with light fruits. Solid full mouthfeel with a fair bit of carbonation. The balance is spot on with the alcohol masked very, very well.

A-pours a light yellowish amber color, quite a nice haze to it, lots of pure white fluffly head leaving a good bit of lace.

S-the nose is solid, lots of lemon up front, hints of honey, hops set in lightly with notes of grassy hay and a bit of alcohol with some white peppery spice in the back.

T-the taste is quite a bit spicier.  the lemon grass is strong up front, the honey lies underneath.  a good malt body, yeasty and spicy, hints of alcohol with a fair bit pepper in the back.  the hops are grassy and hay like with a light hop bitterness.

M-good feel, highly carbonated and ctive but not biting, lighter in body with a grainy crips finish and slightly juicy.

D-this is a well balanced complex brew that is quite good.  the flavors are rich and the complexity is quite nice.  this is a great brew!
UPDATED: SEP 26, 2016 Surely one of the great tripels. Yellowy-orange color, highly carbonated, crisp and tart. Nice spice and a little dry. Serving: Bottle and Tap

Bottle (33cl) from Vinmonopolet, Oslo. BB 8.10.2011. Milky yellow/orange colour. Large white, stable head leaving some nice lace patterns. Aroma of lemon peel, yeast, honey, caramel, resin, and spices. Medium to full body, soft to fizzy carbonation. ABV is well hidden, giving a tremendous fullness in the aftertaste. Dry bitter finish, but balanced by a complexity of discrete fruity sweetness and spices. Somewhat of a grower, this one.

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2011 What on earth was this! Bought it 2 months ago, bad aging? Dunno. Aroma is alcohol, corn and hints of yeast. Taste is like a european lager but with more alcohol to it. Horrible!! (3 4 6 3 12)

Update
Better bottle? Aroma is yeast, wheat, some coriander, vanilla and sweet. Taste is fizzy, vanilla, some wheat, pommerance, estery with a dry and bitter finish.
Great head that lasts right through the glass. Golden in colour. Sweet and spicy, alcohol quite noticable but lovely balance. Super beer.

Pours a hazy golden orange with a big fluffy white head that shows excellent retention, sticky to the sides of the glass and leaving a patchwork of lacing.

The aroma is nice combination of light fruity esters, grassy notes and spices.  There are apples, dough, and a hint of alcohol burn in the nose as well.

The taste is a little less sweet with the spices really coming out - peppery.  The alcohol presence is noticeable but not off-putting with the fruits lingering in the background with the light bready malts.  The finish is very dry and peppery.

The mouthfeel is lively with strong carbonation and dry effervescent finish.

An excellent and very drinkable tripel that leans more on the dry and spicy side of things, which I like.  Highly recommended.

330 ml bottle. Hazy golden yellow colour, thick white head. Very pleasant and rich aroma of citrus, apples and other fruits. The flavour is spicy, fruity and warm, with a nicely dry and lingering bitter finish.

pours a golden cloudy color with a large carbonated white head.  Grassy citrus aroma.  Strong alcohol taste and not that drinkable.  A very solid belgian tripple, but not the best.

11.2 oz bottle

Bottle/corked bomber. Poured hazy golden with a thin white head. Has a light lemony-citrus scent. Bubbly.Taste is dry and more somplex than I expected with hints of lemon and orange. Plus some spices. Very nice. Carbonation adds to the mouthfeel. Great finish. Alcohol hidden well. A very pleasing beer. The wife wants me to hate it so she can have it all.

11.2 ounce bottled poured into my Chimay Trappist glass.  Im rating a pair of Tripels tonight, this is my second.  This one pours a bright golden color thats hazy in appearance.  Better head than I was expecting, with about a quarter inch of soap suds around the glass.  Some pear and pineapple notes in the nose.  Smells brighter than I thought it would, if that makes sense.  First taste is dry, very dry, with a light mouthfeel and a huge alcohol-infused finish.  As my palate acclimates I get more citrus, specifically lemon and orange, flavors.  Theres some nice things going on with the malt in this beer - its almost sweet, kind of like French bread.  Aside from the obvious alcohol - theres no where for it to hide, after all - theres a nice bright finish to this beer thats somewhat citrusy and grassy.  Its hoppier than I expected, but thats not necessarily a criticism, as I feel its very well balanced.  Some Belgian beers have a tendency to be overly sweet however that is not the case with Westmalle.  Indeed, its dry but not overly so.  The mouthfeel is somewhat creamy but not too watery.  This is one balanced beer, and really well done.  Maybe one of the best Tripels Ive had, and thats saying something.

Actually my first time trying this. I cant believe they use synthetic corks! A light pour reveals a large white head atop a clear, blonde body. Does truely smell amazing- spicy, some floral hops, grains, and Belgian yeast. maybe even a little musty smelling. Taste is very full flavored, lots of complex esters, and phelolic notes. lace is good. Lively carbonation keeps your mouth awake. Very nice beer. Should have had it sooner.

330ml bottle. Pours a cloudy yellow with hints of orange toward the middle. Bright white head that leaves a solid lace. Big fruit esters on the nose with hints of citrus and spice. Mildly sweet fruit on the palate with a little hint of alcohol and a nice warm, bitter finish.

averaage frothy white head. excellent lacing. mostly diminishing. flat thick medium particles light amber body. aroma: light yeasty, apple, pear, white wine alcohol. if: moderate sweet light bitter. ff: moderate sweet bitter; average duration. palate: medium body, creamy texture, lively carbonation metallic finish.bem adocicada, com amargor pungent; fiel ao estilo~; aquecimento alcoólico, presença acentuada do mesmo; toques frutados no paladar, lembrando laranja;

Nota: 210 Skol

Bottle, best before 15/07/11 - Pours a hazy golden amber with a huge pillowy white head. Dough and yeast on the nose, with floral, perfumy hops over a layer of bready malt and honey. Most of the initial flavor is hidden by overzealous carbonation, but theres some bready and sweet malt in there. Dark chocolate notes and lots of spicy hops on the finish that sit on the tongue and linger for awhile. Decent amount of booziness on the finish, with a little bit of sharpness. Too much biting carbonation, though it has a pleasant light syrupyness and a medium body. Seems well put-together, and while its fun to drink, hard to justify at $5 a pop.
Very light for a trappist ale.  Nose is light clove, yeast, banana, and alcohol.  Taste is very very smooth.  Belgian yeast accented with citrus and strong Belgian hops signature to trappist ales.
Golden pour from bottle.  Nose and taste is yeast, spices and light citrus.  Warm alcohol finish.  Another excellent Belgian strong ale (are there any "bad" Belgian strong ales??)

Bottle shared with DarkBeerChick.  Pours a hazy, straw colored body topped with some ivory head that leaves nice lacing.  Aromas are grassy hops, spicy yeast, clove and some sweet maltyness.  Flavors are immediately spicy/peppery, light sweetness, a bit grainy and slightly fruity.  Active carbonation thats fizzy and coarse.  Medium to full mouthfeel.
A very powerfull belgian beer. Liked it a lot. Reminded me of the west fleteren. Also a very nice belgian beer.

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2010 This is a very strong beer and very powerful, therefore, that this beer is known as the "triple" that made all the other triples were "blond."
The ingredients used in its preparation are partly similar to those used in double, except for the roasted malt and sugar is no longer dark, but white.
Color: Gold intense, similar to whiskey.
Aroma: Notes of spices and herbs.
Taste: sweet and fruity to start, give way to a host of complex flavors and aromas, resulting from the variety of hops used in its manufacture, and that makes this beer unique.

Bottle from Central Market. Golden yellow with slight cloudiness and a light white head. Aroma is minimal with a detection of clove and a hint of banana...maybe a little grass, too.  Heavy carbonation. Starts off a tad sweet and then...WHAM...bitterness takes over and lingers through and through. The bitterness subsides as the ale gets warmer.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2011 750 ml. at a BJCP study session. Aroma-Spicy and floral hops. Appearance- Slight hazy yellow with a nice rocky head. Taste-Soft malt sweetness with a peppery finish subtle hot alcohol. Peppery finish. Mouthfeel-Light to medium with lots prickly carbonation. Overall a wonderful tripel.
UPDATED: AUG 14, 2010 330ml bottle.  Wow this is amazing.  I liked everything about this, sugar & spice & all things nice.

Tantalising sweet aromas with hints of spice and all things nice. Foamy head, pours beautifully straight down the gullet. Fizzy, light and refreshing, strong alcohol content is only slightly apparent.

11.2oz bottle 
Appearance: Slightly hazy straw/golden with a huge white head and some lacing 
Aroma: Floral, spices and sweet malts 
Taste: Sweet malts, hot alcohols and spices with a bitter finish 
Decent Tripel, it would taste great to sip on a cold night.
quite hoppy and sweet, finishes nice and dry. fruity, citrusy, with just a hint of spice to keep it interesting
Small bottle. Big, sharp, ester floral nose. Huge, foamy palate. Piquant hop finish, ends dry. So well balanced.
Bottle. Pours golden with a white head. Flavor is candy sugar sweetness and spice with a hop bite. Excellent beer.
bottle. nice color and head. fruity flavour with nice palate. very drinkable.
An excellent example of Trappist beer. I still prefer St. Bernadus, but this is one damn good beer.

Sicuramente una delle massime rappresentanti dello stile triple.E una birra di gran classe ma il notevole grado alcolico ben evidente nel suo gusto non la rende adatta a tutti.Dal colore giallo dorato presenta una schiuma compatta e persistente.Al naso malto,fruttato e luppolo.In bocca entra morbida per sprigionare poi la sua forza alcolica con un finale luppolato,asciutto e pulito.
Pours golden yellow with nice lacing.  Aroma is a nice bouquet of friut and spice.  Taste is dry hops with some alcholol and sugar.  The ideal triple.

Drinking this beer for more than 20 years on many occasions. The taste has never been changed and thus I call it the Mother of all Tripels. I use this beer as a reference against the other Tripels. Some other Tripels have more outspoken taste and palate than the Westmalle Tripel and perhaps scores more points than the Westmalle Tripel. A good exemple is the Tripel Karmeliet wich is a great one. However, I always will return back to Westmalle Tripel. Am I conservatieve? Could be :-)

Amber brown body with a light brown head.  Aroma is slightly funky with notes of barnyard, grass and earth.  A quite carbonated mouth feel.  Flavors are slightly bitter sweet and more grass and some bready toast characteristics.  Finishes off with a bitter taste that nicely balances the grassy sweetness.
Nice light yellow colour, with white top. Aroma os citrus and banana.  Tatse of alcohol and bitterness, and a little fruit.

Bottle from LCBO. Dark yellow with very nice and lasting head. In fact, the creamy head blocks some of the noseparticularly when I inhaled the white frost up my nasal passage by accident. Still, I smelled a slight floral waft, maybe a little lemon. Taste suffers a little from the hot alcohol vapors. Very nice malt taste, honey, faint banana and other fruits. Yet, amongst this heavy malt, it somehow finishes like a pilsner.

Pours golden with some yeast particles floating around. It has a gigantic frothy snow white head with tremendous staying power. Its fun to watch it crater as it slowly collapses. The aroma has strong notes of yeast, cardboard, fruit basket, and milder notes of hops. The flavor is surprisingly dry with lots of citrus and orange zest, yeast, pepper, cardboard, banana, peach and grainy malts before a citrus peel bitter finish. A nice complex tripel. The alcohol is noticeable, but not so much for a 9.5% brew. I really enjoyed this one.

Bottle 33cl. Yellow beer lightly cloudy with good carbonation and nice creamy white head. Smell is on agrume and typical Trappist yeast. Aroma is intense on malt, bread, cereals, typical wheat malt astringence, nice hops flavor, notes of vanilla. Quite sweet very creamy long and nice bitterness at the finish, one of the Triple ever.

11.2oz bottle.  Im not a big Tripel fan.  This is one of the best beers ever.  The definitive Tripel in my opinion.  Thick yeast golden-orange.  Steady fluffy head lingers and lingers.  Sweet, sugary, doughy aroma..gets a 10 just because it is so clean.  Hides and incorporates the alcohol exquisitely.  Yeasty, spicy peppery tones.  Subdued but steady noble hop character.  Creamy and smooth.  The best Tripel imaginable.
floral, resin, caramel, alcohol, raisin, - quite fresh initially. very distinct notes. the palate is well balanced and the nuttiness stays in the mouth for quite a while
Pours a cloudy gold with a lacy, white, foamy head.  The aroma is spicy.  The taste is somewhat dry and spicy, with alcohol notes present as well.  The spice tastes remain as part of the aftertaste.

Bottle. Hazy yellow gold pour with large sized yeast particles. Flavor is coriander, Belgian yeast, and some fusels. Flavor is yeast, bread, white pepper, somewhat spicy. Dry and effervescent mouthfeel.

Served from bottle into a Chimay goblet.  Poured a nice golden color with tan sediment.  A nice three-finger white head was formed but slowly subsided to a one-finger.  The lacing was excellent throughout.  The aroma was comprised of mainly fruit and alcohol.  The flavors found were fruit, malt, and alcohol.  It had a medium feel on the palate with medium carbonation.  Overall this was a very nice and smooth brew.  If it had other flavors on top of the ones already present it could be great.  It was very enjoyable, however it was not overly drinkable in large quantities.

Bottle.

A - Hazy apricot/ honey golden orange color. Fairly large, foamy, pillowy, pearly white head. Decent retention with a thin layer of lace with it being a bit thicker and sticky on the edge.

S - Good amount of peach and apricot along with some golden fruit and citrus. A lot of vanilla and some candi sugar. Touches of pale malt and some spices along with a touch of alcohol.

T - Some citrus and apple taste comes out first. A fair amount of pale malt with some spiced flavors. Mid sip the yeast and spices come out a bit more and some grassy hops. A touch of bitterness along with some sweetness with a candi sugar type of taste. Some alcohol comes out as well.

M - Medium body with a good amount of carbonation. Somewhat smooth with a drying finish.

D - Pretty drinkable beer that is has a diversity of flavors. A little more spiced and less sweet, and the ABV limits how much you can drink. However, I would gladly drink this again, and could see myself drinking more than one in a night (sipping them of course).

Notes: Best before 30/09/11. Not as much typical Tripel flavor as I was expecting. This is a bit less sweet and fruity (particularly lacking a stronger peach/apricot taste). A bit more like a BSPA. It is tasty nonetheless though. Solid beer that is an enjoyable drink.

0.33L bottle, small head and lively carbonation, lightly hazy golden yellow colour, aroma biscuit, vanila, tea, herbs and mustard seeds, flavours of vanila, peach, apricot, pronounced, balanced hoppy bitternessmaking itself heard next to the sweetness, long bittersweet aftertaste, excellent tripel.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2012 Pours a yellow slightly hazy with a huge head, aroma of tangerine, green freshness, vanilla, esters and alcohol, flavor of malt, carob, dark bread, herbs dried apricot, alcohol warmth, quite bitter with some smoky notes, medium to full bodied, nice
Thanks Tomer, pours hazy yellow to orange with a huge head, aroma of raisins, apricots, vanilla, cheese and spices like lavender and verbena, flavors of apricot, cherries, grapes with nice lively carbonation and bitter herby finish, balanced. Medium to Full body. Nice Tripel   7/4/8/4/15 [3.8]

Bottle from Systembolaget.

Pours golden with a huge white head. 
Aroma of herbs and bananas.

Nice medium bodied and spicy brew.

So heres the Westmalle Tripel! Its appearance is apricot-golden, with moderate head. The aroma is slightly similar to a wheat beer, and somewhat citrusy as well. When I take a sip, the hops jump right out; theyre strongly pronounced, but not too bitter! This is indeed a dry beer as well. Overall, it wasnt what I was expecting, but I like it anyway, and I can tell its a well-crafted beer.

Bright hazy golden body. Even creamy off-white head. Strong yeasty aroma. Somewhat farmy. Fluffy carbonated feel in the mouth. Mostly sweet flavor, slightly bitter aftertaste. A little boozy. Not bad by any means, though I was honestly expecting better.
Appearance was a nice semi-frothy head and amber color. Has a spicy and dry mouthfeel.

Pours cloudy yellow with frothy white head, aroma is hay, grass, lemon, earth, with some spices.  Taste is coriander, pepper, clove, lemon, slightly barnyard and earth, with a nice grassy character.  Excellent tripel, all the right qualities and balanced perfectly.

Aroma: malt bread, hops citrus, leaves, ginger, chocolate
Appearance: golden clear, with frothy head
Taste: very bitter
Palate: full body, lively carbonization, bitter finish
A very good tripple beer. Its slightly dark golden beer. Lemon smell and a full tast

Pours golden with a nice large and foamy head.  Citrus, spice, malt and hops in the aroma.  Tastes very similar with a touch of sweet chocolate.  Very strong, but very drinkable.  Thought it lived up to its reputation.
Pours a cloudy gold in the glass with very aromatic head. Nose is barley and spice. Taste is bitter, raisins, alcohol, dark fruits and spice. Rated 11/3/2000

head: normal
colour: golden hazy blond
smell: bitter , yeast , hops, spices 
taste: bitter , alcohol , hops , spices , bitter aftertaste 
jummy , and even better mixed with westmalle bruin called : half n half !

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2013 Ah, the original tripel. Cloudy orange body with a 1/2 inch, finely bubbled head that is constantly replenished. The aroma has some Saaz, phenolics, banana, bubblegum, and a hint of solvent. The flavor starts out sweet and a bit hoppy, then dries out a bit, leaving carbonated foam in various places in my mouth. There is quite a bit of bitterness as Saaz flavor that blends with the yeast nicely. Somewhat bitter finish. High, soft carbonation hides the actual body of the beer.

Pours a pale golden color with some cloudinesss to it. Head lasts and nose is yeasty, sourdough . Flavor is incredibly complex: f some other fruit tones, closes spicy . I found this with a lively carbonation. Finish is bitter, but not too bitter. Nice beer for a long conversation.
trappist tripel.dark colour with persistent brown head. aroma is spicy with notes of caramel, berries and sweet malts. classic aroma of belgian yeast. alcoholic notes.medium to full body

Pours a clear golden colour with a small frothy white head. Aroma is cider like with apples being most pronounced, there is also some yeast and spice present. Fairly sweet taste that becomes somewhat bitter and then finishes sweet again. Nice carbonation and a medium-full body. Overall quite good.

33cL bottle, Trappist Tasting at Joe T.s. Pours a hazy, deep yellow-golden color; creamy white head with excellent retention and lacing; attractive pour. Pleasant aroma of white pepper, light vanilla, and honey; nicely dry, peppery, and yeasty nose. Medium to medium-full body; lots of creaminess; non-astringent, with some light, vinous, warming alcohol notes; fluffy, lighter texture overall; lots of peppery notes, vanilla, and some soft cloves; definitely yeast-driven presentation, with a bit of Belgian / candy sugar and Pilsner malt at the core; lively, moderate acidity, nice complexity that extends beyond the basic peppery, dry yeasty notes. The vanilla, creamy character here is lovely. Lasting finish of pepper, vanilla, and toasty Pils malt.

33cl bottle. Pours an orange-gold a big frothy off-white head. Aroma is bready and yeasty with some honey and spices. Aromas is a balanced, sweet, yeasty with a smoothand spicy finish. Full-bodied beer.

33 cl bottle. Beer pours a pale gold color with some cloudinesss to it. Head lasts and nose is yeasty, sourdough bread. Flavor is incredibly complex: fruity (granny smith apple-like), some other fruit tones, closes spicy. Finish is bitter, but not too bitter.
65 cl bottle, Fargo, ND, USA. Cloudy deep golden colour, thin head. Mixed yeast and citrus aroma. Velvety with some liveliness, fresh with a mixed spice and sweet flavor. Very nice finish of cloves.

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2010 Bottle pour to Trappist glass gives murky dark yellow color with great thick white head which is quite persistent.   Aroma nice with fruits and spices.  Things go downhill after that with average fruit and malt taste followed by bitter and dry finish.  A disappointment - there are certainly better Trappists out there.

Bottle best before 27/01/11.

Rich, orange-gold, turbid tripel with four fingers of frothy, dirty head. Aroma is bread, yeast, barnyard, honey, light pepper, golden apple and spiced pear. Aromas meld into a balanced, sweet, yeasty, full-bodied beer with a smooth, spicy, chewy finish. A superb example of its style.
Light and wonderful Belgian which is marred by an overall nasty bitterness.

[2842-20100417] 330mL bottle. Belgian yeast aroma with mild raisin notes. Hazy, light brown orange body with a long-lasting creamy off-white head and nice lacing. Heavy raisin malt flavour has hints of potato mash, yeast, and a lightly toasted fruit. Medium body. Nice balance, holds up well.
Overheard: "Thats a nipple reference... Ha ha, I grabbed a flag!" -- Listening to Pinball Wizard
(From LCBO; w/ jerc)

330 mL bottle, expiry 15-07-11, from Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, served in a Trappist glass. Pours foggy golden with a tall, creamy white head. Head mostly remains and laces well. Aromas of yeast, grain, lemon, banana, clove, ginger and pepper. Flavour is moderately sweet throughout. Finishes with long, lingering alcohol and spice. On the palate, medium in body with a tingly texture and lively carbonation. Quite acidic. Overall, an excellent brew. Spicier than Chimay Tripel, but at the expense of vinous complexity. Not as complex as I might expect at 9.5% ABV but quite enjoyable. 2010-04-17

Hazy orange/amber colour with a great frothy white head. Lively carbonation. Fruit aroma. flavour of herbs, spices, citrus fruit and yeast. Smooth honey texture which turns to a sharp grapefruit bitter finish.
Bottle.  Pours hazy golden orange.  Nose is more hoppy than most, some spice, citrus.  Dry.  Nice overall though simpler than other tripels.

330 ML bottle in Luxemburg. My last real beer rating for awhile. Spicy, fruity nose with some banana, hazy golden body with suspended yeast, big head. Soft, fruity body with spice; noticeable alcohol in the finish. The alcohol presence knocks the score down a bit, but this is very good.
Spicy! Nice tripel. Wonderful citrus nose, happy mix of hops and yeast. Dry alcohol presence. Crisp and easy to imbide even at 9.5%.

Pours hazy light-orange with small white head; lemony spicy aroma with hints of malt sweetness; medium body, high carbonation, but still pretty smooth and drinkable; flavor is quite sweet at front, but well balanced by spiciness and hops, holds some pineapple notes also.

From a 11.2 fl oz bottle into a water glass.  Pours with a ton of fizzy head.  Not much lacing at all.  Aroma is of pepper lemon and a little yeast.  Mouthfeel is way too fizzy up front, but after it sits a while, it gets much better (just like the dubbel).  Taste is a little alcohol up front, pepper, lemon and some bitter hops.  This trippel has a very distinct and biting taste.  Its also a lot lighter and easier to drink than most other trippels.  Very good, Id drink again!

This tripel has it all and is a favorite of the trappist tripels. The nose has a slight a honey sweetness, a big dried floral bouquet, not more than a whisper of alcohol, and some notes of dried citrus. The taste is balanced with light malt a delicate hop and the delicious Belgian yeast. The palate has that Belgian champagney feel. This was my real intro to the trappist ales and very happy it was.
330ml bottle from the LCBO.  Hazy orange pour with a thick frothy head.  Dry, dusty aroma.  Good body, and some dryness from the hops.  Very nice beer.
Hazy gold. smells sweet and spicy. Taste: complex, sweet to dry hoppy, with hops taking the upper hand. Warmth form the alcohol in the finish. Rich palate that sparkles in the mouth. A winter warmer.

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2011 Bottle. Poured a medium murky yellow almost gold in color with a huge (3 to 4 fingers) white frothy head that was fully lasting and had excellent lacing. 

The aroma was of light grain malts, a piney hop and a mild soapy yeast with notes of dried fruit, banana, clove and a mild dose of alcohol. 

It tasted a bitter-sour with hints of banana and clove throughout then had a mild fruity flavor with a slight pepper note and a rather heavy alcohol tinge at the end. The flavor stayed with you for nice long time allowing one to enjoy this brew well after the swallow. 

Mouthfeel was light to medium in body and had a dry texture with a mild to medium carbonation. 

Overall this Tripel was kind of fruity with a nice spice note and had a good kick to it at the end. Very Tasty!!!

Tried on our recent day trip to Ostend. Lovely golden appearance-crystal clear. Powerful slightly bitter flavour with a lot of body but still very drinkable.Slightly spicy and very easy to sup. It came in the proper glass and was served chilled but not ice cold. I would never think about drinking a beer of this strength in the daytime but I  was on holiday!
My wife Glenys said its just a beer which is like saying a Ferrari  is just a car. Marvelous.

really nice tripel, nice tight bubbles like champagne, great color and aroma. very vinegary in the aftertaste which is actually nice compared to the sweetness in the front of the mouth. very well balanced. next to chimay cinq cents, one of the better tripels ive had so far.

330 mL bottle.  Pours hazy golden with a large white head.  Aroma features biscuit, cloves, and bubble gum along with some vague citrus hints and a slight candy sweetness.  Theres a spicy tingle right up front giving way to cloves and pale malts, a mix of apples and citrus, and some floral flavors.  Pleasant hoppy finish.  Lots of subtleties that all tie in perfectly.

Gotta be careful with tripels like this. Despite my efforts to get it into a Trappist glass with that magic one-inch head, every drop of this brew seems to be loaded with dynamite. The thick, white head eventually settles over the cloudy, sediment-whirling (I shook the last of the bottle) orange body and the smell of hay, hops, grapefruit and wine yeast really pours into the room - I can smell this beer from half a meter away! Taste is playful and intricate: strong yeasty notes playing among bitter citrus aromas; the hops carry hints of fresh grapes, pepper and herbs. Spicy and feisty, this is the original "tripel", brewed as a counterpart to the heavy, sweet, brown sugar varieties dominating the Trappist ales. The Westmalle does an impressive job at delivering just this, but unfortunately it is simply not my favorite style. The aftertaste is almost painfully dry and yeasty, and without even the mildest hint of malt to round it off this baby is almost too much for me to handle. I did say "almost", as the Westmalle Tripel is a very nice brew. Make no mistake about it.
UPDATED: MAR 26, 2010 33 cl bottle. Cloudy golden body with white head. Flavour is sweet, malt, yeast and fruit

The beer pours a nice golden color with a nice white head....
Aroma is of strong yeasty esters, belgian hops and fruits...

It is actually fruity but also...BITTER ! My god what a bitter finish. A very nice tripel indeed.
Murky golden colour white head, full carbonation. Taste consists of yeast, bread and fruits. Ok.

Pours dirty yellow with a fizzy 1/2 inch white head.  Aroma is farmhouse, sour and a little skunky.  Flavors of dirt, spice, yeast, bitter grapefruit and a touch of alcohol.  Mouthfeel is a little grainy, fizzy on the tongue and a dry aftertaste.  Tasty, but not a favorite.

11.2 oz. bottle from Kellers IGA.  Tried side-by-side with a Westmalle Dubbel.  Pours a cloudy orange-gold color with plenty of visible sediments.  Aroma of yeast, farmhouse, pale malts, honey, apricot, and caramel.  Flavor of yeast, apricot, straw, farmhouse, honey, malts, hops, and alcohol.  Medium-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a yeasty mouthfeel.  Boozy aftertaste.  I give the slight edge to the Dubbel, which is a little more unique than this familiar brew.  Neither blew me away, both are good, but not as good as other peers.

Smells quite strongly of licorice, alcohal, tappist yeast? Some head on pour, decent lacing, thick and orangy?? Mine poured out a few chunks of sediment that I could do without, though Im sure its been sitting on the shelf a while and the guy at the till didnt help by bouncing the bottle off of the counter. Normally I like bottle conditioning but this could have been done a bit more carefully. Strong alcohal warmth in the taste. Quite sweet, not too much malt flavour left in there after the yeast and alcohol. A bit red nosey after just a few sips. Very smooth, you get a nice aftertaste of the spices and some of the sweetness of the malts, but the taste is dominated by the alcohol and yeast flavours. Pretty nice all in all, but I just wouldnt want to have it all the time, too alcoholly.

750ml bottle, poured to a murky golden color with tons of carbonation. The head is pillowy white with some lace clinging to the glass. Scents of yeast, bread, toast, and honey.
