This is a forward drinking triple with nice notes of yeast, bread, and an acidic apple alcohol taste heading toward the finish.

Bottle 330ml. Wonderful beer. Aromas of spice, bread, and alcohol. Taste has bitter and sweet notes, and long length. Palate is sirupy, and full bodied. Yellow, with particles, and a frothy white head.

Provdatum: 2000-11-26, flaska, Göteborg
Senaste prövning 2008-12-22.
Grumlig (även om man lämnar mycket kvar i flaskan) - pissgul. Maräng färgat skum.
Doft: fräsch, jäst, citrus.
Smak: dito
Bottensats: smakar dito, fast sötare
Belgarna säger att man inte bör starta med en trippel - den är lite för alkoholstark.

Det gamla omdömet:
Citrus och smörkola, kräver rätt glas (kristall) 
Passar bäst till: Belgiska praliner 
Förslag på öltyp: Trappistöl 
Förslag på liknande öl: Westmalle Dubbel
330 ml form the supermarket a golden yellow colored beer with a white head aroma hop yeast spices malts and fruits taste bitter spices and fruity a bitter finish

Sampled at Bistro LAutre Oeil in Aylmer, Quebec in good company of S8n. Pours golden honey beige-white colour with a fizzy-bubble white head. Definitely not as creamy looking as the Chimay Tripel (white cap) S8n is having. Very good retention though, and medium lacing. Tiny bubbles form the carbonation, fizzing away only at certain point on the side of the glass (not at the bottom). The aroma is creamy and reminds me of fresh milk out of a cows tit. Hints of fruit (citrus) and spices show up in the background. The taste is heavy on alcohol, but without the burn. Also in the background, dark spices are found. Some bitter citrus shape up the aftertaste. The mouthfeel is slightly syrupy, but smooth overall. Nice tripel, but much prefer the Chimay one.

Bottled, tnx Andi :). Color is dark hazy orange with huge foamy head and layered lacing. Leaves lacing. Aroma is yeasty and fruity. Flavour is very complex, sweet, spicey (very!) and yeasty bitter. Alcoholic comes through slightly but not dominating despite the 9.5% Very nicely composed beer with a perfect aftertaste.

At first I thought I stuffed the pour, the head on this beer is enormous! Long lasting fluffy white foam. Beer is a golden colour, slightly hazy. Fruity aroma, although the head does mean it is quite hard to detect. At first taste I was quite overwhelmed by the alcohol, but after settling this beer does have a very pleasant, dry flavour. After taste hangs around for a bit. Quality beer.

Aromas of bread dough, citrus, and an earthy sweetness.  Appearance is a light lager like golden color with a thick foamy head that thins out to a pleasant sticky mess that leaves lacing rings on the glass.  Tastes like honey and apples with a yeasty spice in the somewhat dry bitter finish.

33cl bottle, at Abbey.  I too prefer the 75cl dubbel but it was a very interesting tripel, especially because it is not too spicy or sweet, just in subtilities.  Very lemony with an obvious hop presence. Dry finish and pretty long aftertaste.  Im not a fan of the style but I enjoyed this one.

Pours a cloudy gold with a thick white head.  Aroma is of yeast, alcohol and a hint of bananas.  Nice carbonation.  Spicy warm mouthfeel.  Taste is of alcohol and yeast with a hint of some spices and banana.  Very good.

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2012 A nice triple from Westmalle. Grainy, good hopped and spiced, golden coloured with a nice foamy head. Edit: Aging helps with this one for sure. Tasted an aged (close to or over the expiredate) bottle a couple of times now, and only good things about it. Nice bitter-earthy dryness at the end. Enjoyable

UPDATED: APR 18, 2017 [2/10] Bottle, 14C. Pours orange with some particulates. Really lovely downy white head. Honeyed yeast/ orange peel aroma with cloves and white pepper. Theres fruity malt things going on but theyre overwhelmed. Quite hot alcohol/ pepper. Dry, spicy and salty finish. Pretty but very brash. Probably a lot better aged. [3.3][12/11] Bottle, bought with the last. So 21 months older, but still in date. Slightly hazy gold with a lovely white head thats well retained. Doughy aroma with orange, vanilla, cloves, pepper. Taste has sweet oranges, dough, slight sourness, spicy and dry finish. Still quite boozy but rather less hot. Spices are less brash. Better, but still not quite my sort of tripel.  [4/17] A few more times and once more since I liked a fresh Dubbel recently and Im rather pathetically desperate to like _the_ classic. A bit of age knocks off the brash spiciness but leaves it dull. Fresh is boozy and a bit disjointed, but cheerful and tasty.

750 split with the wife! Pours a hazy blonde with a big remarkably loose head that leaves lots of spotty lace. The aroma is honey and springtime flower with some orange and maybe a little soap. The flavor is spicy with some good mineral character. The first thing that strikes me about this beer is how hoppy it is, there are lots of what my un-skilled palate perceives at noble hops in the flavor of this beer. Pear and citrus fruitiness present themselves very well here also and there is just a slight tinge  of alcohol. Overall this is very well balanced.

has one of the longest lasting heads ive ever seen, no matter how you pour it. its like sea foam. aroma is astringent with some apple and tobacco notes. flavor is brighter than expected with none of alcohol burn i was expecting. buttery somewhat with a dark roasted rye and wheat flavor. very good.

22 oz. from Bottleworks. Yummy Belgian on recommendation from Bottleworks employee. Spicy, cloves, very un-tinny. Smells like flowers (which I eat) and cotton candy. Enough carbonation to make it seem soda-like (save for the bitterness).

bottle dated 05/2009 from metzlers in denton tx.  poured hazy yellow with a head that would not give up and left tons of lace behind.  aroma was a very good blend of lemon, banana, cinnamon, and vanilla cream.  flavor was lemon, banana, and a whip cream type flavor.  body was mediumish with medium carbonation.  an excellent beer.

Sample at the Belgian tasting at Blacklick Wine & Spirits on 1/28/10. Pours a hazy gold color with a medium white head. Malty nose with caramel and Belgian yeast. Malty and yeasty flavor with some bread character and a semi-sweet finish.

11.2 oz bottle pours cloudy amber with a literally explosive off white head into a tulip.  Very yeasty aroma with a bit of a farmhouse smell, sweet malts, clove, dried apricots.  The taste is very similar: very yeasty and musty with dried apricots and passion fruit taking the forefront.  Clove and other spices come in the finish.  Frothy, pillowy mouthfeel with low-medium carbonation level and medium body.  Booze is slightly detectable.  Seems unbalanced and its just too musty for me.  Good but not great.

Birra delicata, grande corpo, equilibrata sia nel gusto, complesso e durevole, dove malto e luppolo si sposano alla perfezione, sia nellolfatto. Dal colore dorato e dal fine perlage, ha una schiuma fine e piuttosto persistente.

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2011 Supposedly the most recognized of the Westmalle ales gives a very active though clear appearance in the glass. Foam is just as recognizable as the Dubbel though whiter and the degustation pleasure begins there. Very smooth and round for its percentage with lots of flavour. Overall its a fine trappist beer, as you notice that everything is the result of non-stressed craftsmanship. After a while the tripel took over my vote for favourite Westmalle ale over the Double, since the latter is sweeter than the zesty and more interesting Tripel.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2011 Hazy blonde with bumpy undulating thick white head like a travertine. Aroma is orchids, hops, and perfume. Dry and spicy crisp strong and great. My benchmark for dry tripel, or any tripel for that matter.

This beer tastes a lot like a dry champagne. It has a subtle fruity, ester aroma and fantastic head that lasts forever. It leaves a fairly acidic aftertaste as you sip it. I imagine that this would pair well with some some melons or berries.
Bottle. Not as good as the dubbel. Cloudy, gold color. Strong alcohol in both smell and taste. Nice, big, foamy head. Was a little underwelmed, but overall nice beer.

Pours a cloudy dark gold. huge sudsy head which eventually goes to a thick lace. Aroma is of citrus yeast and a hint of fruit. The taste is somewhat like the aroma. Alcohol is hidden at first and then gives a little bite. medium carbonation. Very smooth. A bit sticky on the lips afterward. Also a bit dry. 
Overall it is a very good brew. I recommend it.

Bottle.  Pours an almost opaque golden yellow with a frothy white head.  Tons of little floaties in the glass.  Smell is strong grapefruit and lemon.  Very pungent, biting aroma.  Taste is spicy - pepper, coriander.  Very rich texture, but goes down smooth.  Obviously a very high quality beer...one of the best.
Nice fruity aroma from a cloudy golden color with a big fluffy white head. Flavor is quite unlike the aroma with a bitter, peppery taste that is good but different. Finishes very dry.

75cl bottle.
pours golden hue, white head.
aroma, nice floral hops, Belgian yeast
flavor, yeasty, some fruit elements, possibly tropical pineapple, prickly mouthfeel, mild malty finish and a warming abv.
Good but the not the most memorable trappist.
My worst trappist beer. To heavy on alcohol. Does not have the refinement of Westvleteren or the originality of Rochefort. It is an ok beer but its a bad result for a trappist.

Bottle. Pours a murky orange with white head. Aroma has great farmhouse notes with a nice acidity that pushes out the fruitiness. Flavor has a nice malty backbone combined with farmhouse flavors and citric fruitiness, yeasty, a little alcohol spice as well. Overall, a very well rounded, tasty tripel.

golden, hazy sparkling with great white head. Aroma yeast. 
Taste - sweet yeast with markedly alcohol.  Body is medium. Texture thin. Carb is lively. Finish with lasting alcohol feeling.

Bottle from SL... Pours a light orang-ish color, monster head! Aroma of some light spices, a little perfume, banana and some yeast. Taste is a sweet but dry banana, spices, light hops and some yeast notes. Nicely done. No trace of alcohol. Texture is light, fluffy and dry. Overall its not chimay but a nice tripel to sip on.
Well done triple with a champagne-like texture, fruity esters, a strong yeast quality but I feel the dubbel has more flavor than this one has despite some citrus and well hidden alcohol.

Hazy golden, with thick pillowy head that doesnt seem to leave! Fruity taste, floral hops. Slightly dry. Nice mouthfeel. Alcohol is well present and gives a warm feeling. A beer one could appreciate all year long.

Bottled. Light orange/yellow with thinner white head. Floral and fruit aroma magnify sweetness in taste and nose. Floral hops add weird tinge and distinguished aroma. Tight and crisp as hell. A little champagne feel in both nose and flavor. Light bitter throughout but with lightly sweeter finish.
Cloudy pale yellow with good fizzy head and decent lace. Delicious combination of all typical trappist factors with floral hop, yeast presence, and warming alcohol to round it out.
Light fruity sweetness and spiciness.  A bit hazey gold with excellent white, pillowy head.  Moderately sweet and complexly spicey (nutmegy)...light alcohol finish.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2015 A good consistent dry blonde Trappist ale. Full of spices and an interesting bitter lime kick. Always enjoyable. Poured from 33cl bottle to my own Westmalle glass on NYE. I think these are better fresh rather than aged.

Update - 10th January 2015. Had a bottle recently and thought I should update my review. Fresh this beer is awesome. The right notes of clove; coriander; banana and bubblegum. Extremely clean. Drinkability is insane for the abv. it goes stupidly well with food especially Flemish stews. 

Its definitely world-class.

( 330ml bottle bb 1/27/11) pours cloudy orange with huge lastin head and some yeast particles in the head. Nose of bread, Belgian yeast, white fruits. Taste of white pepper, alcohol, white grapes, and quite bready. Finishes very carbonated, peppery and creamy. A great tripel.

From a 330ml bottle on 30/12/2009. Massive beer which should be enjoyed slowly. Typical strong Belgian ale aroma. The taste is predominantly fruity and spicy, with a honeyed sweetness developing as it warms. Quite syrupy, with a touch of bitterness and a dry finish - almost a little champagne-like. A rewarding drop, but definitely a winter warmer rather than something to quench ones thirst on a hot day.

Pours slightly hazy gold with a huge foamy white head. Aroma- yeast, wheat, clove, Belgian sugar, lemony citrus. Taste is sweet caramel and light citrus with alcohol warming the nose. Very rich carbonation with a slightly bitter finish

Very delicious beer.  Nice creamy head.  Fruit, yeasty notes.  Nice carbonation level tries to balance the beer but might be just a bit much.  Otherwise everything comes together nicely with this beer.

25-DEC-2009, bottle @home.
Lovely golden/orange color with huge white lasting head.
Very yeasty nose and the alcohol can certainly be smelled, but then comes hay, fruity notes with earthy.
Very creamy, high carbonation, long aftertaste.
In my book it is a perfect 5 in appearance and palate. I did not really think I would end up rating it above 4, but thats where it endend, and really worthy. This is a high class beer. Just very well made and enjoyable.

Golden yellow color, with compact and quite persistent froth. Perfume surprisingly rich and complex, with hints of vanilla, fruit and tobacco aroma. Strong impact in the mouth but pleasant, with the vigorous aspects of malt are balanced with the power of alcohol and dry hops. Beer that opens into the mouth with a unique alternation of flavors and a soft finish, honey bitter, incredibly pleasant and persistent.

330mL bottle.  Pours a cloudy gold with suspended sediment, and a frothy white head that quickly settles.  Subtle herbacious and slightly savoury aroma.  The flavour has a definite vinous tartness, with some grassy and citrus flavours, and also a mild spiciness and earthiness.  Medium-full bodied, creamy on the palate courtesy of the carbonation.  The finish is refreshing, mildly sour and bitter, with more lingering earthy notes.  Quite an impressive tripel.

(Bottle into trappist glass)  Poured a beautiful hazy amber color with a thick creamy head.  some sediment in the glass that needed to settle before I dove in.  Very slight grassy noted on the nose, but otherwise there was very little that was overwhelming in the aroma, which I found rather refreshing.  Medium creamy body danced a little on the tongue, helping to release the flavors of fruit, and slight pepper, ending with a nice hoppy bite at the end.  I would recommend taking your time with this one, not only because of the 9.5% ABV, but because the rest helped the flavors develop very well throughout the course of the glass.
Hazy blond colour, with a fine, white head. Rather anonymous aroma with seaweeds and oceanic notes. Strong and spicy flavour, with dominant alcohol and winous texture.

Wonderful fruity spicy aroma, apricots, light orange aroma, & spice.  Lovely head, light orange color.  Flavors do not disappoint, theyre a bold match to the aroma, perfect balance of fruityness & spice for the style.  Wonderful viscous mouthfeel, silky.  Overall lives up to the billing as one of the best Trappist Ales or tripels in the world.

Pours a cloudy orange with about a finger of slowly dissipating stark white head.  Slightly sweet, slightly bitter citrus odor.  Nice bitter spiced taste, really great hoppy bitterness with it to go along with some grapefruit and grass aftertaste.  This is a lot more complex than most tripels.  Good stuff

(Br-btl Crm-lbl/cap, 9.5%)

gl-opq, full body, ^co2 ^head, 
§spicy co2 T1, hoppy fruity T2, malt T3, maltier Tf, too syrupy

750 ml. bottle- Pours golden with a good white head, roma is of yeast and citrus. The flavor is totally Belgian, but with a stronger alcohol presence. Usually Belgium is the master at hiding alcohol in its big brews, but this is an exception. Whats great is that I went from a shit beer (Redbridge rated 0.7) to this.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2010 Refrigerated bottle poured into a trappist glass.  Pours a golden color with nice tall head that stays around better than some triples.  This one is mostly fruit malt, but also has some nice hop spice.  This beer is fairly translucent, but has some particles that float around the bottom edges of the glass and has descent lacing.  Good beer, but has some harshness.
Westamalle tripel is the clasic typical tripel. Well balanced between malts and hop, fruits and spicies, aroma and taste.

(Snifter glass)  Pours a golden orange liquid.  Has a heavy head which leads to a good amount of lacing.  Taste is malty but balanced with a light peach maltiness.  Also has a yeast quality to it.  The mouthfeel has lively carbonation.  The finish is astringent and lightly bitter.

Clear golden tripel with a nice foamy long-lasting head. Aroma is very spicy and sweet. Taste is very very nice of the malts and the hops, with a little bitterness to top it off. Palate is just awesomely refined. Overall one hell of a holy beer!

Pours a hazy blonde yellow with a thick, foamy head. Intense spicy aroma of citrus rasp, coriander and even some mint. Flavor is complex, sharp and full and has a bitter hoppyness on top of a spicy body. Although it is a remarkable beer and definitely good, it is a bit too sharp and spicy for my personal taste. Good palate feel, with lots of carbonated creamy roundness that makes this gulp down easily. Very nice dry bitter finish.
Pours a hazy yellow color with a thin white head. Aroma is "belgian" with some citrus and malt notes. Really crisp body with some nice fruity spicy hints. Very good Belgian.

Westmalles triple is an OK Belgian triple with an aroma that to smells of bailed hey. The appearance is certainly consistent with the style but i did find the taste to be a little lacking. As for the yeast... absolutely barnyard. I was not going to say it, but when i saw it as a suggestion under the yeast heading here on rate beer i thought wow, that is very accurate.

330mL bottle pours a hazy golden yellow with a huge white head that dissipates slowly. Citrus, sweet malts and banana on the nose; flavour is citrus, banana, spice and a yeasty finish. One of the best tripels Ive had.

Serving date: 2009-03-01. Served in snifter.

330 ml bottle with the Trappist collar around the neck. Freshness date (best before 2010-06-30) and glassware recommendations printed on the label.

The pour is orange colored with a two finger ivory-colored sparkling head that settles after a short while but leaves a nice coat of foam.

Pleasant sweet fruit esters (apricots). Earth and dry hay. Pepper, yeast and a gentle sting from the alcohol. The smell is somewhat reminiscent of white wine - very nice.

All in all a rather crisp taste with decent amounts of malts. Plenty of fruits - apricots, some banana, citric notes mostly in the form of lemon, and a vague taste of grapes that strengthens the resemblance of white wine I got from the smell. Rustic honey flavors. Big taste of peppery alcohol and spices. Subdued flavors of earthy yeast. The finish is rather bitter, more so than expected, and has a bold spicy alcohol character that seems to linger on forever.

Medium body that feels a bit sharp due to generous amounts of carbonation that feels very lively in the mouth.

A very good beer and as most Trappist beers, it showcases a very well balanced complexity. The alcohol is perhaps just a little too present, though. 

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

Hazy bright orange coloured with a dense white head on top. Aroma is heavy malt and extreme esters. Flavour is intensely estery with strong alcohol notes, especially in the somewhat dry and very fruity finish. Body holds a very lively carbonation typical for the style, dangerously easy to drink.

Bottle from the Eastchase Majestic.  Pours a hazy yellow with a shitstorm of white head.  Aroma is kinda spicy with bananas, bread, and alcohol.  Taste is yeasty.  Bananas, grains, cinnamon, and a touch of alcohol.  Warm mouthfeel.

Pours pale amber with a ridiculously large head despite very careful and slow pouring.
Bready yeast dominates the aroma, with some white wine, soft alcohol and sweet clean malt showing underneath. That doughy yeast is way too strong!
Flavours are horrendously sweet! Add to that the very noticeable alcohol and you end up with a extremely cloying beer. In the background theres more of that overwhelming yeast and it all ends with a sharp finish that seems to be from the alcohol rather than the bitterness.
great tripel and a go to beer.  best triple ive had so far with the exception of my friends homebrewed tripel.
Really good triple, pours a nice golden hazy color with a nice head. Has hints of citrus, banana, with a nice balance of malt and hops.

Bottle. Poured a cloudy gold with a thick white head. Aroma had notes of dark fruit, caramel, yeast and some earthiness. Flavor was sweet from the malts and yeast giving it a caramel flavor, but there were a bunch of fruit notes that made the beer enjoyable.

Pours a cloudy golden yellow color with a huge frothy head. Strong yeasty, fruity aroma with some citrus and cloves. Really nice. Taste is similar to the smell, with apple flavors and a bit of light hops. Well carbonated, and has a fairly dry finish. Its maybe a bit on the alcoholic side for my taste. Overall its one of the better tripels.

De couleur dorée et trouble, elle dégage des odeurs de caramel, dhoublon et dépices. Bière très riche qui peut devenir difficile à boire, car trop sucrée. Saveurs de miel, dhoublon, de malt caramel, de citrus.

Bottle, poured a hazy light yellow gold with small head.  Some floaters, yeast and light spice.  Esters and a malt smoothness with pepper and very light citrus notes.  Kept a subtleness throughout and only slight bitterness, a fermented treat.

12 oz bottle from the Four Firkins.  Cloudy yellow/orange pour with a nice fluffy head.  Aroma is of wheat, yeast a bit of spice and the flavor is the same.  The finish has a nice spice to it as well.  My second ever trappist beer and I think I like it!

Aroma of dough, leaves, alcohol, and clove. Poured a cloud, unfiltered pale golden color with amazing head. Primary tastes of alcohol, but notes of citrus persisted. Slick medium body texture, with a fizzy carbonation. Overall this is a great trappist tripel that you should try (alliteration unintended). Cheers to the monks!

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2010 Bottle 33cl. Pours a beautiful, hazy gold/blonde with a big rocky head. Aroma is amazing... flowers and fruits standout. The taste is fresh fruits, spices and yeast... alcohol is hidden well. Slightly dry finish. This beer has great complexity and balance... full body, great depth with a lively carbonation. Slightly dry finish. Very refreshing. Westmalle = world class beer to me.

Versata sul bicchiere a calice della westmalle, questa tripel dabbazia ha tutta la sua eleganza. Schiuma fina ma molto persistente, un bel colore dorato con sfumature sul rame, e un torbidezza che non lascia filtrare nessuna luce.. come si suol dire, anche locchio vuole la sua parte.
Un aroma non troppo forte, di banana; al gusto è dolce e fruttata. Si sente molto lalcol e un sentore di acido sul finale.
Piacevole, senzaltro.
Hazy golden blonde beer with beautiful white mousse. Aroma is pepper, yeast and malts, but also bread. taste is delicious and on the dry side. its has very good hop bitters and a perfect aftertaste.

Bottle, 33cl. A blonde beer with a beautiful lacing, light unstable head that lasts, some bubbles. Malty, light hoppy and spicy aroma. Smell is also malty, some spices, with some hops on the background and a light bitter and dry finish. Heavy body. Very nice trappist beer!

Pale orange coloured, slightly hazy. Pours very lively with big airy head. Flowery yeasty aroma. Sugary, sweetish nose, funky mouthfeel, alcohol-peppery bitterish finish. Leaves a lingering candy sugar flavour in your mouth. Good.

bottle. Poured hazy, straw coloured with an extra large rocky white head. Active carbonation visable. Aroma is spicy clove and yeast. Alcohol hits you at first sip. Medium bodied, warming mouthfeel. Flavour is peppery, grapefruit peel, perfumey. Finishes lightly dry. I just cant bring myself to like this style of beer and over rate them like so many beer drinkers do, but I did finish the bottle.
A great Trappist Tripel. Loved the dubbel too. Great balance of tart citrus, spicy clove, light candi sugar and malt sweetness, and some bready yeast.

75cl corked and wired bottle. 

Pours a hazy pale golden yellow with sky-high, frothy white head with great retention and generous lacing. Beautiful beer!

Citrusy aroma with yeast and herbal spices on the nose. 

Medium-bodied triple with heavy, but earthy mouth feel. Active carbonation.

Taste is dry indeed, with banana, yeast, herbal spices and a bitter alcoholic note dominating. Finish is dry, with a noticeable alcoholic after taste (at 9.5 %, this is hardly surprising). 

A welcome departure from the many overly sweet Belgian tripels Ive drunk (Grimbergen, Kasteel, etc), this one is for grown-ups only! ;=) I wont drink a great number of these, but theyre characterful, individual and imaginative. Very good Belgian beer!
Weird tasting. Minty dry bitterness with a plasticy undertone. I was really disappointed. For a little bit I thought it was lightly refreshing, but the flavor got more and more unfortunate to me.

11.2 ounce bottle from BevMo ($5.49).  Pours into Chimay goblet a golden honey amber with generous white head composed of very tiny bubbles.  Aroma of spice, yeast, banana.  Taste is lightly sweet and very dry with flavors of yeast, spice, banana, and citrus.  Finish is also very dry with noticeable alcohol.  Good, but not as good as I might have thought considering the source.  But then, I wasnt very impressed with the Westmalle dubbel either.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy golden color with a very large, frothy white head.  The head is ridiculous.  Aromas of bananas, toasted malts, wheat, and light citrus.  Extremely lively palate to start with a creamy, tart finish.  Flavors of bananas, wheat, and light pine.  Good beer.
Pours a dark yellow color with a big white head.  Fruity nose, same taste, finishes with a little spice and very strong.  Very good beer overall, definitely recommending to friends.
Not a bad trappiste, but nothing special.  Has a nice fruitiness to it, bananas, red berries and black licorice on the nose.  Has a very delicate taste and foamy mouthfeel.

Citrusy, strong, spicy. Very good beer with complex stages. First thing that hits you is high carbonation and citrus followed by spices and a dry finish. Little peppery to the nose with hints of grapefruit. Aftertaste is more spices. Very good tripel.

bottle from my girlfriend. pours golden with an big head. strong aroma with hinst of spices. Strong taste. Im more a Dubbel fan and I always need to get used to the Tripel taste. This one was great. Had two bottles. Will try this one again and I hope that it wil taste even better that time. Good beer.
light gold with a beautifull white head with a strong flavor and finish. One of the best beers in the world.
Hazy golden in color with white head, aroma of citrus, yest, malt and hops - tastes a little to much of yest and alcohol - was expecting better, but stll a nice beer
A personal favourite.  Delicate aroma of spice and sea breeze, perfect alcohol/malt/hop balance for such a monster - should rate higher than it gets.
Pours pale yellow with a large white head. Aroma is malt, alcohol, coriander. Flavour is caramel, alcohol, light coriander. Light bitter aftertaste.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2009 Poured a hazy light gold with a huge fluffy white head.  Has a strong floral, yeasty clove smell with some earthiness underneath.  Flavor is strong, with a honey sweetness, lemon rind bitterness, and a lot of clove and coriander spice.  A pleasure to drink.
This beer should have been right up my alley.  Seeing that it is rated 98% makes me think I got an old one or something like that....

Pours into a chalice with many, many bubbles hiding the light yellow colour. Very big, light, fluffy head. Aroma is of malts and coriander, smells slightly syrupy too. Taste is a strong alcoholic brew with lots of syrup, very sweet, slightly bitter and coriander-ish finish. Very strong, but very nice, and went well with my blued steak.

Bottle from Theatre of Wine, Greenwich. Light golden pour. Big fluffly white head. The aroma oozes out. The nose has citrus, fruity, cinammon. Lovely sweet, hoppy flavours with a zesty, candy sugar tang. Good hoppy, bitter-sweet finish. Leaves quite an impression on the palate.

Bottle, 33cl. Pours a clear yellow beer with a white head. The aroma is sweet, coriander and alcohol. The flavor is coriander and alcohol. The palate is sweet, and overall a good beer but a little heavy on the alcohol.

huge snow white head on light orange hazy body, aroma of grain, yeast and grapes, taste is strong alc sharpness, yeast, spices, cinamon, chill pepper, orange peal(a little), medium to heavy bodied, lacing stong to the end, I do not know why but reminds me of duvel and any good kristal weizen, very aggressive and mildly complex

Bottle. Golden orange colour with a foamy white head. Malty aroma with notes of spices, fruits and alcohol. The flavour is malts, spices, alcohol and some fruitiness with a bitter finish. Medium-bodied and smooth mouthfeel. Not bad, but I was expecting better, a bit too alcoholic.
small bottle. pours a cloudy orange colour. definately a sipper, not a bad alc.% taste, but you can feel it running through you with each drink. Pretty solid beer overall.

Pours a cloudy light orange with a large white head. Aroma is quite fruity (light fruits) with nice spice, also yeast. Yummy flavor of fruit and spice again, licorice, yeast, a little rye too. Nice bold flavor doesnt leave me yearning. Good funky, citric-acid aftertaste. Rich mouthfeel, upper-medium viscosity. One of the best tripels Ive ever had, simply. Near the apex of this style. Overall, excellent plus.

Bottle. Poured a cloudy orange with a strong slightly off-white head. Aromas of malt spicy and some fruit. Great mouthfeel with pleny of spice some hop bitterness and definately some candi sugar sweetness. Great beer.
Bottle. Pours hazy orange gold with a white, pongent head. Aroma of sweet fruits, spice, raisins, and clove. Firm body with a bitter finish. Very tasty tripel.

Thanks to Peggy for the hint!  Frothy head that reminds me of beaten egg whites.  Spicey aroma with hints of apple, yeast, and sourdough.  Very nice flavour without all of the added spices. As a hophead, I liked the bitterness.  This will be a repeat purchase!

Thin Frothy white head, had to hold back on the pour, [large goblet wine glass].

Very golden slight amber color.

Aroma, OK, gotta say it...  kinda like cider at first, very fruity.  Then some spiciness.

Very champagne-y,  light, airy,  lots of carbonation.  Very complex.   Clearly one of my favorite Trappist Tripels!  Maybe some banana?
did i say complex?  some hop bitterness spiciness...

I definitely get a nose of apple.

interesting complex aftertaste

good stuff, cant remember how much i paid for this,   dated almost 1 year old...

330ml bottle. Huge frothy deep and dense white head sitting atop an amber to copper hazy base. Strong spiced fruit aromas waft from the glass, sweet and inviting. Well carbonated and lively in the mouth with a warmth that spreads through the mouth and you can feel the strong alcohol content.

Pours orange amber with a slight chill haze which slowly dissapear while the beer warmsw up to serving temperature. The head is fluffy white and long lasting with excellent lacing. A fresh spicy and malty aroma. Flavor is also spicy with a faint orange background flavor. Long lasting and warming aftertaste.
great tripel, travels better to NZ than most beers but still not as good as in Europe.

Appearance: Hazy amber colour with a big fluffy white head, and very heavily carbonated.

Aroma: Fruit and yeast on the nose. Peppery spice, clove, banana, orange peel. Very aromatic.

Taste: Sweet and fruity up front, before making way for a heavy spiciness of pepper and clove. There is a banana flavour in there, along with an orangey zest. Quite bitter hoppy finish that clings to the palete.

Mouthfeel: Full bodied, and very lively on the carbonation. The texture is oily and slick.

Drinkability: An absolutely world class triple, I could drink this everyday. The flavours are perfect and moreish. This is a beer that has to be experienced.

poured a golden yellow, with a bright fizzy head (not what I was expecting). aroma is of grains and citrus notes. Taste is of grains (wheat?), citrus notes with a moderate hop presence. Dry on the palate with a sour hop finish.

the head and carbonation on this was almost too much. so thick and foamy and difficult to drink right away (tulip). i have had my eye on this and was very excited to drink this for a little while and i was not dissapointed but was not blown away by a long shot. the aroma was very modest and does not sweep you off your feet at first whiff. barely malty with barely a whiff of fruits which i cant even pinpoint, almost a bland smell... then i took a sip!! first sip was great though, it made up for my almost dissapointment on glance and smelling the brew. a unique variety of orange, cinnamon and malt sat on my mouth and i loved it. a tad bit alcohol on the aftertaste but over and under well above average and the amazing taste made up for the averageness of everything before and up to that.

11.2 oz. bottle purchased at Greens on Ponce De Leon. HUGE fluffy head. The head was ridiculous, but I am all about nice head. Haze gold/orange color. Very nice looking tripel I must say! Not so sure about the aroma. Yeast, and other subtle fruit and spice aromas are starting to surface. The aroma is not extremely pungent or nuanced. A slight fruity/spice aroma. I would say this leans more towards the subtle fruit aroma, but I am not that impressed with the aroma. The flavor is a different story; that subtle fruit aroma becomes a lot more noticeable. The beer is very smooth, but has an annoying carbonation bite at the very end to keep it away from a "5" on the palate level for me. Best thing about this beer is the flavor; it has that nice fruit smoothness with a mild spice bite helped by the carbonation. Very nice beer, and at almost 10% ABV , I am enjoying this even more. Pretty nice tripel I must say. This one is not so heavy on the yeast, which is great.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2009 Hazy peach color with an absolutely massive white fluffy head that actually got bigger as time went on; incredible appearance. Smell is really nice; nothing too complex or aggressive, but very pleasant, with clove, yeast, cinnamon, and orange peel. Flavor is extremely spicy and yeasty,and the 9.5% alcohol seems to come through in the intense spiciness, which is quite interesting. Certainly not your run of the mill tripel, and clearly well crafted. Some wouldnt dig this, but I think I do.

Dated 060208, I wonder how old that makes this beer? Hazy, bright golden color with a fluffy, huge, white clump of a head. The smell is good but subtle, yeasty and spicy. The taste is smooth, spicy, delicious but not at all strong or sweet like many American tripels I have had. The fact that this is 9.5 ABV and I cant taste it is impressive. This may be the best tripel Ive had so far, more subtle than American tripels.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-06-2007 15:03:52

Bottle at Dayton Ale Fest.  Pours a hazy gold with a fluffy white head.  Aroma is sweet malts, citrus, and spice.  Notes of cloves, sweet orange peels, and fruity yeast really stand out.  On the palate, is is nicely carbonated.  The flavor brings out the sweet malts and gives the yeast a bit of a banana flavor.  It finishes dry.  I am not a huge tripel fan, but this one was pretty good.

330 ml, from Daans fridge; still one of my alltime favorites; clear 24-karat golden appearance with an eggwhite firm head, hops and bitter with hints of banana and citruses, alcohol well balanced and a bitter finish.
From a 330 ml bottle, well chilled. I tried to like this beer, but could not handle the heavy yeasty taste. I drank about 1/3 of the bottle and poured the rest down the sink.

A hazy golden beer with a nice 1 finger egg white like head. The aroma was spicy, light fruits(pear,orange). The taste was spicy, spritzy, fruit, & very peppery with the hops coming at the end with the bitterness. A carbonated mouthfeel, & the alcohol is well hidden as I was shocked to see it is 9.5%.

Bottle. Pours cloudy golden yellow with a big white head. Aroma of lemon, wheat, melon and a touch of honey. Flavour is similar: fruity and grainy with a bit of spiciness. Alcohol is well integrated, not all that obvious. This is a very good tripel, but not my favourite.

Appearance is golden and hazy. Pours with a thick head that stuck to the glass. Fruity, banana(?) aroma. Flavor is one of fruit, spice and hops with an aftertaste of alcohol. Good beer but just not to my liking.
Poured golden/cloudy with a thick head, fruity/spicy aroma with little hop/spice finish, very tasty.

Pours hazy light golden amber with a smallish off white head.  Aroma is champagne like with hints of white grape and light fruits.  Flavor is big and malty, with big estery flavors of light fruits, and a nice warming at the end.  Pretty good.

Pours a hazy golden yellow with a white head. The aroma is sweet, fruity, and citrusy. The taste is earthy with a lot of spice on the finish. This is one of those brews that the aroma does not match the taste. I think there is some Brett in there but this spice is very overpowering. Not well balanced and a moderately strong alcohol warming. This is the first time I bought this beer and I might try it one more time to see if it was just this bottle, but I was not to impressed and could not finish this one.
Well I really wish I had written down more than numbers and "Not my favorite Belgian, but very good!"

Pours a beautiful pale gold yellow color with a white foamy, but thick, head that lingers on.  Smells like sweet bread and malts with a hint of fruits like pear.  Taste has a mix of spice (pepper), sweet bread, alcohol, and a hint of fruit as it lingers in the mouth.  Good amount of thickness, carbonation, and head.  Even for a 9.5% ABV, the alcohol isnt too strong to kill the other flavors.  This beer could be an any day any time kind of beer.
Bottle poured into a Sam Adams Sensory Glass produced a white head with golden yellow body.  Lighter than expected with taste of white grapes and spices.  Sweetness well-balanced with hops.

Bottle @ De Met, Halle.  Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a small longlasting white head. Has a fruity yeasty spicy aroma with malty hints. Fruity malty yeasty spicy flavor. Has a spicy malty slightly yeasty finish.

This beer surprised me, it was not as full or strong as I imagined and to be honest I probably enjoyed it more because of that. Lovely pear and spice aromas, poured witha typical Belgian fluffy white head.
This one poured with a cloudy golden colour, and an average-sized head.  Aroma was ever so slighty fruity, and the taste was much the same, with the high ABV not in evidence.

Pours a cloudy gold/slight amber, with a huge head. Nose is spice, yeast, fruits. Taste is quite spicy, underlying hop notes, has a sharp "bite" to it, a tad bitter on the finish with a nice lasting warmth that coats the entire mouth and throat. Delicious tripel, very well executed, and balanced.

Hazy blond color with lively carbonation. Huge airy head that disappears quite quickly. Slightly salty, cheesy, dry aroma with mild citrus and resinous hops.
Very strong sipcy, peppery mouthfeel with lasting herbal hop dryness at the ending. Distinct alcohol warming at the end that would be little bit softer.
Bottle in São Paulo and in Brussels - Golden appearance with a white foamy head. Fruity aroma and taste (little spicy as well). Easy to describe... easy to drink... very good beer!

Pours gold with fluffy, white head.  Aroma of fruit, yeast, and spice.  Taste is fruity with hint of spices in the finish.  More bitterness from the hops than I remember from last tasting.  Highly carbonated.  Nice.

Bright hazy yellow, huge head.  Smells complex, herbs, sweet spices, candied oranges, bready, dried fruits, big body.  Flavours did a dance on the tongue, all over the place.  Candy like, orange, cinnamon, apple.  Beautiful balance, strong bitter finish. Just lovely.

Straw / slightly amber. Fine-large bubble head, retained.

Very fruity aroma with nice complexity.

 Alcohol is there. Too much for me. Especially the dry after taste. Hop is somewhat nice.

 Thin - medium body. Fresh.

 Not for me. Much to alcoholic.

 Purchased in Barley Wine.

delicious pour of fruity blonde brew with a perched head of ruffles that linger atop.  aroma is intense lemony yeast, quite saison like and very fresh. flavor is peppery with more lemon and plenty of yeast.  palate is dry due to the yeast, oh so zippy.

Nice and thick and hazy yellow color. Aroma is complex.  Has a slight citrus scent.  Very carbonated brew.  Taste is full of fruits and spices.  Has a very nice and smooth aftertaste.  Im going to take my time and enjoy this one.

Top ratings for what is and has been my favourite beer for almost more than 20 years now. You can discuss about all kinds of criterias but at the end there is only one thing that counts : personal taste.

Presentation: It was poured from an 11.2oz brown bottle into a goblet. A best before date is printed on the back of the bottle.

Appearance: The body has slightly hazy appearance with a bright golden yellow color. Also there is some nice visible carbonation and lots of little bits of floating yeast in the body. On top sits a tall, stiff, white head that has great retention and make lots of slick lacing that coats the glass before slowly sliding down the sides of the glass.

Smell: The nose is full of fruity and funky yeast, sweet malt and fresh wet hay.

Taste/Mouth Feel: There is mild sweetness from the malt and fruity/funky yeast. There are notes of apple, pineapple, golden raisin and lemon zest that are wrapped up in a mild warming alcohol. Hops are very light and the finish gets slightly tart and dry with just a hint of hop bitterness. The body is about medium to full with a smooth rounded feel and the carbonation is in perfect balance to cleanse the palate for the next sip.

Notes: This is one of the finest beers that I have had in my opinion, and worthy of a perfect score as I cant find anything to improve on except for maybe the yeast sediment in the appearance but I like the yeast in Trappist beers.

Beautiful tripel, golden pour and frothy head white head. Aromas of bread dough (grains, flour and a bit of acidity) flavor: still bread dough citrus like acidity (lemon) and apple. Nice dry finish all the hops are here floral & fruity.

Pours clear golden, a little bit of sediment, with a huge creamy three-finger head, great lasting lacing.  Very fruity aroma: citrus, pineapple, green grape, and caramel.  Medium bodied, well-carbonated, tart.  Flavors of lemon, spice, gingerbread, sour apple, raisin, lightly dry and bitter finish, floral and grassy.  Definition of the style.
A lot going on in this beer. Hops, malt, alcohol, more hops! A lot of herb and orange flavors.   White head with a gold base.  Good beer!

(bottle from Cheeky Monk in Denver, CO). Medium white head. Sweet wheat aroma. Strong wheat flavor with light alcohol. Avg duration. Fizzy, thin finish. Astringent finish. Heavy carbonation. Spare lacing.

Bottle. Golden, off-white frothy head a few specks of yeast sitting on top of the clouds.  Like chimay white theres a nice dried fuits aroma, a little bitter-er and drier in the finish.  It is spicy and strong like the description states, but also slightly sweet in the back of the mouth.

Pours a hazy yellow-gold with white bubbly head. Aromas are floral with herbal spice, citrus, and alcohol. Flavors are sweet citrus upfront, followed by strong spiciness (clove and i dunno something strong used in cooking-cant pin point it). Alcohol comes through alittle strong and dries everything off but the spice lingers. Very complex! needs the right food i think

Most over the top carbonation Ive ever seen. Almost 10 minutes before the head settled enough to take a drink. Pale, hazy, cloudy yellow. Hint of spice in the aroma. Alcohol comes across very strong, negatively impacting the nice tripel flavor.

Slightly hazy amber with frothy white head.  Lively ripe fruit aroma.  Sweet and slightly tart up front.  Develops into well balanced malt.  Then very tart and biter bite, hops and apple peel taste, bite fades into the finsh.

A nice tripel, but more acidic and spicy than I prefer...as a result, I think I prefer Chimay, but I need to try a few more trappist tripels.  Color typical yellow-orange and hazy.  Lemongrass aroma, taste follows with a bit of grain, cereal, honey, and a tad medicinal.  A licorice type of burn on the finish.  Overall, a nice complex tripel that I definitely enjoyed.  No way this drinks like a 9.5%..well spiced, not too sweet.  Go monks!

.33l bottle. Poured a nice hazy yellow and the head on this beer made me blush!! For the smell and taste, once again I had to go to the wifes spice rack to figure this one out. Cardamom was pretty close and bitter citrus was prevalent. The aftertaste was very bitter like a grapefruit and burned a bit like it too. Not really a huge fan but Im glad I tried it. Not an every week drink but likeable and Ill drink it again.

Drank from a bottle in Brussels.

I like this one less than the Dubblel but better than the quad.

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2013 First rating monday, june 29, 2009: 8, 4, 6, 4 and 12 total 3.4 .Hazy orange coloured beer with a nice white head. Fresh spicy aroma.Flavour is sweet, spicy, yeast and very alcoholic. (Bottle 33cl) 
Re-rate: Hazy orange coloured beer with a huge fluffy white head. A fresh spicy, yeasty and mild acidic aroma. Flavour is medium sweet, oranges, yeast and acidic. (Bottle 33cl)

Not my favorite of the Belgium Tripels, but obviously one of the better beers in the world. A little too much alcohol in the finish for me, but a wonderful aroma and dry and spicy upfront with a nice spicy undertone.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2009 Bottle. A very nice golden beer. Heavily carbonated, very little alcohol presence despite the 9.5%. Very large head, smooth, soft mouthfeel. Dry aftertaste. Very spicy aroma and flavour. Tingles your entire mouth. Wonderful offering.

Ill start out with the fact I took a couple of sips and did a sink pour on this one.

Sour and awful.  I dont get it.  Then I took the rest of the bomber and tossed it out.

Then I drank a Hoegaarden to get the awful taste out of my mouth.

Honey pour with a beautiful head that forms a mountain of frothy goodness. Aroma is loaded with sharp citrus and spices. Clove, grapefruit, and a very defined and unique yeast character provide for an enjoyable sniff. Flavor is citrus to the max with excellent yeasty spice character that lasts nicely through the finish. Citrus is multi faceted and expertly balanced. Palate is full for the style, ending clean and very dry. A very well put together creation.

Pours a milky honey with a 2 finger (in a chalice) eggshell head that has great retention and leaves a few specks of lacing. Aroma is Sweet grainy malt, lots of grassy hops, yeasty bread - fresh from the oven, some citrus(mostly lemon), a little banana, clove and ginger, some black pepper and some ethanol. Flavor is lots of yeasty bread, I mean lots and lots, grass, cardamom, corriander, light caramel, light wheat bread, tree fruit, fruity and herbal glycerine soap, acidic citrus, passion fruit, cucumber, peppery yeast, perfume hops and artificial strawberry flavored hard candy. Finish is fruity, peppery, yeasty bread(y) and a bit of ethanol. Palate is medium body highly carbonated and has a syrupy entry that quickly transitions to a dry alcoholic finish. Good stuff overall, nice and complex, but not really that impressive.

Poured into a Westmalle chalice; blond with a good bit of haze; foamy head that lacks much retention.  Aroma is of lemon, bitter orange and something else, perhaps bergamot?  Dry, almost aggressively spicy flavor up front,  followed by a fruit (pear?) esters in the middle, and a nice clean finish.  Easily the most drinkable Tripel Ive had.

Really surprised by how light this is. Looks tasty and creates a really great white head.  Quite soapy with hot cross bun and banana aromas, very boozy.  Rich caramel with really absolutely delicious biscuit and crusty bread finish.  Lovely, savoury and bright.

Pours yellow with a tint of orange. Cloudy with a massive white head. Strong fruity esters of banana. Alcohol and yeast also present in the nose. Sweet, fruity flavors. Very yeasty. Prickly carbonation and light mouth feel. I just cant get into this beer. No hop character, very yeasty,dominant alcohol flavor.
33 cl bottle. Pours a hazy yellow colour, with a minimal white head. Complex spicy aroma, fruits as well. Lovely soft mouthfeel, as velvet.Herbal semi sweet taste, bitter end.

33 cl. bottle. Best before date 3/26/10. Pours a thinnish white head, over a slightly cloudy golden orange SRM 10) body.....nose loaded with spice, (coriander, allspice) fruit, (banana), citrus (lemon)....taste initially seems sweet, but rapidly the spice/fruit combination arrive to balance, it is dry throughout and becomes rather bitter  through the finish....mouth feel is light, carbonation high, and there is an alcohol presence in the background. The spice is wonderful, and the empty glass has overwhelming honey aromas.

Golden straw in color maybe a slight brown tinge, big flakes of sediment float everywhere, a good sized white cap floats on top that had phenomenal retention, very nice looking beer. Yeast and apples, lots of apples fill the nose, the aroma over all is soft and smooth maybe a touch of sourness is in the back ground and on big deep inhales I can detect a touch of dish soap. Sour bitter wood and yeast comprise most of the flavor and I can detect cherry in the finish, the cherry seems out of place. The after taste is flowery and bitter. This is a good beer and highly enjoyable but for a triple and the reputation it has I was slightly disappointed.

white big full head,  Golden and clear, the perfect looking beer! caramel, citrus, herbs, banana are terms i would use to describe the excelent taste. I think it tastes sweet en bitter equally. medium body, medium body, fizzy,  and light bitter finish.

i can not believe they sell this in our supermarkets!

I liked the spiciness throughout.  the flavor is dry but not very bitter.  alcohol is present but not overly so.  lots of yeast, tastes very typically Belgian.  Good, but I wasnt wowed like I was expecting to be.

Pours a nice golden colour, made hazy by yeast. Great small bubble lace head, which leads to amazing mouth feel. Slight and tasty bitter hops in the front with a fruity and mild finish. Love trappist beers.

Pours out a hazy golden apperance with a really nice fluffy white head..slight hoppy bitterness with a nice fruity aroma..has a nice soft mouthfull..this is a wonderfull well balanced trappist beer...enjoy
Very foamy head..full of complex flavor consisting of belgian sugars and fruit spices. Excellent tripel!
Very foamy and an uneven head, beautiful smell of banana and citrus. Warming but also fresh, little too hoppy for my taste.

***May 06 / 08 K, so Im chugging back a 2 yr+ cellared bottle... man, this has really mellowed. Its to the point now where I could drop this back in mere minutes. Mild flavoured as well as in the aroma dept. The harshness of the yeast has really dissapated. Still quite dry and tart (or is that tannic?). Nothing much has change except for the mellowing effect and the fact that now I could chug this. Got another one for the long term cellar experiment. Upped Appearance rating. Great pour, super clear with the cellaring and the concrete sediment on the bottom of the bottle, great effervecance, lacing and incredible retention.... nearing perfection - serious.

***Jan 25 07: Grade bumped up from 3.5. After having a few of these in the last couple of days, the Belgium Tripels (or at least this one) have started to win me over. Ill have to add apples to the aroma list; cinammon to the taste list; mouthfeel - great swish, good initial hard bitter attack and a softer bitter aftertaste that previously noted. Also I think there is also a slight nutty aftertaste too.

***Re-review July 13, 2006: Way way better this time around. Heres the improvements/modifications to the original review: Colour leaning to the orange side and there is a freaking ton of sediment that is small and white leaving a pile at the bottom of my glass. Aroma is very present and quite spicy with the same yeast and a bunch of sweetness (maybe that crummy white grape juice from Welchs). Taste is pretty strong: Lots of bold spiciness, lots of yeast and some things that I have no idea what they are. This time, I love the mouthfeel, although its no easy ride: the harsh yeast, spices and bitterness blend together to create a slight sweet start and a dry finish with a neverending hard bitter aftertaste. The whole time I want to say that I can really notice the alcohol, but it is just the harshness of this beer until the aftertaste - thats where I finally know. Man, This is a pretty harsh beer thats really drinkable.....dont really like it but really like it.?.?.?.?.?.?

Feb 5, 2006: The excitement of this beer vanished the second I tasted it. Great looking hazy yellow and poured up a really thick head which stuck around quite long. Aroma was a bit sour but mainly apricots and yeast. A little bit of light brown sediment remained (almost like really crappy milk chocolate in colour - Im not saying this was a bad think tho..). Suprisingly sour in taste, which was quite terrible, this is unquestionabally the worst Trapist beer Ive ever had. The more I drank, thoughts of pouring it out crept in my mind (total sacrilege!!!). We got his directly form Belguim about 2 weeks ago...it is possible we got bad bottles despite the expiry date being 22/12/07.The Dubbel was better. Extremely dissapointing. Need a bottle from another batch to confirm horrible review.
Wonderful beer. Well balanced sweetness, spiciness, yeastiness, with a long, dry, slightly warming finish. Cant go wrong here.

Dry fruity aroma. very estery fruity taste as well. not as dry as expected. fermentation lends very complex flavor. clear about 6 srm color. slightly warm finish. The high alcohol does not overpower taste and is balanced very well

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2009 Rating #50! This pours a sunshiney orange/yellow colour with a mountainous, fluffy white head. Overwhelming aromas of honey, oranges and lemons leap out of the glass immediately. Sugar melons, spices and honey in the flavour with a warming alcohol content and a creamy, full mouthfeel. A really characteristic long, dry and bitter finish. Although this is great too, Id prefer their Dubbel.

Pours a hazy orangish-yellow with a light but big head. Aroma - Yeasty, citrus, notes of clove and orange. Taste - spicey, sweet orange/lemon notes, hops, and it has an astringentness to it and it is very dry.  Overall - Sweet, bitter, dry and spicey. Though its not my favorite style it is still very good. The spiceyness probably isnt my thing which keeps me from rating it higher.

Bel colore arancio chiaro,bella anche la schiuma molto compatta e persistente.Potente e deciso aroma di alcool e caramello.In bocca è molto dolce,zuccherosa direi,lamaro è presente solo alla fine.Molto buona e complessa.La sto bevendo mentre sto leggendo un libro e devo dire che mi rende la lettura ancora più piacevole.

Bottle. Pours a hazy orange-yellow, with a thick white fluffy head, and a fair amount of sediment, even with careful pouring. Nose is orange, coriander, white pepper, with a suggestion of hops and yeast. Palate is dominated by a constantly shifting meangerie of citrus fruits, tempered with spices (cinnamon and maybe cardamom), behind an almost candy lemon-marmalade sweetness. Very Pretty. Finish is long, lemony, and slowly souring. Reminds me somehow of sour cream and sourdough at the same time. Wonderful beer!

Bottle. Hazy yellow pour with a good lasting white fluffy head. A crisp, light beer which I have now been drinking regularly for almost 15 years. Orangey, lemon taste, alcohol not too overpowering. This is a great Belgian beer but it used to be better in the 90s IMO.

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2011 Bottle. Dense white head, aroma with banana, citrus and fine herbs, a bit flowerish. Taste is bitter, complex, intense.
Good beer, alcohol well hidden, a bit dry finish.

Bottle - Memphis, Tulip glass
VERY dry and VERY light on the palate. So dry that I found it hard to get some good flavor out of there. Dangerously quaffable.

Sensing my melancholy, she came to me one lonely evening with a promise of a better day and a brighter smile. Clear blue skies as far as the heavens, or in her case, vivid hazy gold with heavenly clouds of white decorating her picturesque canvas. Lace paints the sides of my glass, while her nose reaches out to embrace my lost soul in her comforting embrace. Delicately sweet with a pervading sour vibrancy; sourdough, lemon zest, lively yeast and faint grass while cinnamon sticks, coriander, and ginger spice things up. White crackers and vanilla cream filling soften her already airy mouthfeel and palate for a heavenly experience. I have never tasted such a light, effervescent tripel before. Yeast, pepper, coriander, and ginger tingle across my tastebuds as delicate creaminess lingers. Ripe bananas add a bit of meatiness while lemon and grass bitters the back of my throat. As my body warms, her gentle onslaught continues. Never were there a gentler tripel with such warmth of character. Each breath whispers of spices, lemon zest, and ginger while I lick my lips wet with vanilla cream, bananas, and piping fresh sourdough. Smitten, I give up the pen and enjoy the final moments of our time together, eyes closed and heart wide-open.


I really do not like naming favorites, but Westmalle impressed me that very first afternoon with their Dubbel, and their Tripel is no exception. For each tripel I enjoy today and each tripel I shall enjoy tomorrow, I shall always give a silent nod of thanks to those inspired Trappist monks. There is always room for Westmalle in my fridge and in my cellar where she shall watch over her children like a wise mother.

bottle.
Pours a hazy light straw color, gentle pour still yields some visible sediment and a nice big inch of pillowy head.  Head lasts for a good long time and laces the glass really well.  Light crisp sweet aromas... some light candi sugar, some tropical sweet phenols, and some yeasty twang.  Very nice nose.  Flavor starts with those fruity, boozy phenols, notes of apples and tangerines, grainy yeast tartness.  A slick tamed sweetness throughout- smooth and even.  Some light booze heat shows up throughout.  Very nice, clean flavor.  Palate shows a bit of excessive carbonation, but not enough to detract.  Smooth and full otherwise, with a nice crisp finish.  Overall a pretty damn superb tripel with no real faults.

Pours a really nice golden yellow with an orangish hue. The head is large and fluffy in my Trappist glass. First thing I notice when I breath in the awesome smell is the citrus and soft fruits. This beer is bursting with fresh and acidic qualities on the nose. Top notes are bready with orange and tangerine peel. Floral, eucalyptus, vanilla, and grapefruit are mid notes. And right down in the Trappist glass is honey, brown sugar, grapefruit and a touch of alcohol. First taste is a sweet punch to the teeth. Just makes you wish every beer was as intense as this beer. Tastes much darker on the palate than what would be expected from the nose. Plums and raisins make a subtle yet lengthy appearance. Citrus shows the whole way through this beer, changing fruit but making its presence felt. Nice spicy finish. Mouth feel is excellent... Its a Trappist, what did you expect? Excellent beer, one of my favorites!

Well, I finally decided to lay out 13 bucks and grab a 750 of this stuff and, quite simply, its epic. It pours a classic tripel amber, with a thick fluffy head. and its everything I was expecting. Lots of fruity and citrusy notes, with some acidity and vanilla on the finish. Ive been a hard sell on proper abbey ales, but I think this has something extra that Chimay, or Duvel just doesnt have. Cheers!!

Bouteille de 330ml Nos yeux contemplent cette bière de couleur ambrée trouble et qui possède un col de mousse parfait. Au nez on découvre des arômes de fleurs, de levure fruitée, de fruits jaunes avec des esters dalcool. En bouche le corps est rond avec une effervescence crémeuse. Au départ on goûte des saveurs de grain, vient ensuite des saveurs florales, fruitées et subtilement épicées et pour finir une bonne amertume citronnée en coalition avec des notes dalcool. Excellent et complexe.
Hazy deep yellow with huge white head. Clove, yeast, musty nose. Sweet but dry spiced flavor. Some citrus hops. Candy sugar. Hides the alcohol well.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a hazy brownish orange with a large, white head.  The head has great retention.  Musty yeast, orange, spice, a bit lemon, and ripe fruit in the nose.  Medium-high carbonation with a medium mouthfeel.  The carbonation is very fine and quite nice.  Spice, light honey notes, orange, and a ripe fruit sweetness.  The lingering finish is sweet and dry.  Quite nice!  I must say, this really is an excellent tripel!
Bottle. Pours with a large white lasting head and a burnt orange colour. Has a bready-orange aroma and clove-honey flavour with a subtle bitterness to the finish and a pleasant alcoholic warmth
Big large bubble head, Very carbonated. golden color. Aroma is spicy, pepper, hops. Taste to match.

Very hazy yellowish-orange with a lot of sediment and moderate head, aroma is extremely orange and spicy, flavor has strong alcohol presence, coriander, orange slight bitterness, finishes dry with strong alcohol presence... I dont feel my sample lived up to the hype.

33cl bottle poured into a Westmalle Trappist glass.  Cloudy orange with three finger head.  Smells fruity, kind of like cotton candy or bubble gum.  Sweet tasting with a lot of hoppy undertones.  You can really taste the alcohol in this one.  Palate is really smooth with a bit of carbonation.  Not a bad aftertaste but you can tell youve been drinking alcohol.  Cant drink it all the time but a good beer.
Hard to think of something better.  A pleasure through and through.  I only wish I could buy this by the case without putting me in the poorhouse.

Bottle poured to glass.  Aroma is of fruity esters like apricots.  Yellow opaque brew with white head.  A bit of alcohol in the palate.  Tingly carbonation on the tongue.  Effervescent!!  Maintained fine head for entire glass.  Fermented very dry but sweetness remains.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2009 This is THE tripel. Ignore those who say not the best out there.... (as if there are any others out there) A slight sweetness, very bitter and strong. Difficult to love this drink, perhaps, but delicious for those whose taste buds have yet to be corrupted by newer, sweeter tripels. At its best, I think, a couple of years old (much drier).

Hazy and active. Yeast and spice in the aroma. Malty to start, then the spice and slight hops kick in, citrus and spice lead to a lovely dry finish. This ones for Steve, April 2009. This is already one of the worlds great beers, now it has eternal sentimental value as well.

750 ml. Cloudy yellow pour with huge white head. Highly carbonated- head overflowed the bottle. yeasty aroma with hops and malt.  taste is yeasty, very slght sweetness and a dry aftertaste and mouthfeel. Alcohol is well-hidden.

11.2oz bottle. Pours hazy orange. Head is like none Ive ever seen. Literally took 20 minutes for it the subside. Maybe the bottle was too warm. Lacing is godlike. Spicy aroma, mixed with some darker fruits. Dry, yeasty finish, good carbonation.

Probably my second favorite trappist behind ABT12. Very good beer.

33cl bottle, poured yellow with big med thickness head. Nice head, very nice looking beer. Arome is fresh hops. Quite fruity and citrusy. Head as a good retention. Finish is quite dry and warm. Not very fruity (unlike aroma suggested). Mainly spicy and bitter. Quite interesting brew. Rating #89

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy golden yellow and airy white head.  Aroma and taste are slightly citrus and spicy hops.  Flavor has some malty sweetness, but the yeast is most prevalent. Very enjoyable drink.
This is a decent tripel, has a nice color and aroma.  It has zesty citrus flavor that lingers for a while.  For the price point though Ive had better

33cl thickened glass bottle (expiry 1/10) into tulip glass. Pours with a vigorous rocky white head. A cloudy golden ale with floating yeast sediments. Nice lacing. Sugary malt aromatics dominate with yeast and spicy hops and a hint of citrus fruits on the nose. Pleasant juicy sweet malt palate with orangey undertones and those warming peppery hops. Nice dry yeasty bittersweet finish. Well integrated with a smooth drinkability. The benchmark Trappist ale for me so far.
bottle - hazy orange beer with a nice white head. Some lemon aroma detectable. Yeasty. Flavour is spicy, refreshing. Some bitterness in the end.
This is a very spicy, peppery and bitter beer with a bit of an alcohol kick that makes it less good than some other tripels I have had.
Poured golden yellow, CO2, malty, yeasty, citrus, spice, little alcohol, little hop.

Bottle at a cafe in Liege, Belgium. Hazy golden body with a fluffy white head. Yeasty aroma with notes of coriander, citrus and sweet malt. Flavour is fresh and spicy. Notes of sweet exotic fruit, malt, clove and a nice alcoholic touch. Sparkling carbonation. A classic.
Great beer, with a nice aroma and the flavor hides that 9.5 % that can make beer taste like malt liquor.

Bottle. Pours a really hazy, light amber, small, dense white head, yeast sediment swirling around. Aroma is yeast, spice and some light flower notes. Flavor is what the aroma promises, yeast, spice, flowers. A little bitter, but leaves a pleasant yeast lingering.

Not my favorite tripel or favorite abbey ale.  alcohol was very apparent up front.  slightly sour with moderate bitter aftertaste.  the fruit flavors were not as apparent as in the double.  however, it was very pretty in the glass and was incredibly smooth.  head was tall buit very thin.

Rating is from a while back...
Overall Impression: 
Really nice Tripel. Definitely doesnt hide the alcohol much, but the flavors are still there. Try this one, or enjoy this one again, I know I will.

Bottle, Dram Shop, Sheffield. A revisit to an old favourite, even drunk it from the bulky official goblet that lingers at the back of my glass stash. Poured a hazy golden colour with a decent white head. Aroma had classic belgian yeast, with spice and citrus notes. Quite sweet, but not overwhwlmingly so, and on the whole a pretty well balanced mix of fruit, spice, yeast and hop. Quite in your face booze, yet smooth and drinkable. A good thang.

Bottle from Systembolget in Umeå. Pours a hazy orange with rocky egg white head. Nice aroma of spicy marmalade, and banana. Very sweet upfront and then an assertive hot pepper and corriander middle and overpowering alcoholic finish that was too brutal for me.

Bottle from Sams. Pours bright deeply hazy golden with slight orange tint. Huge rocky, pillowy head and solid lacing. Smells like its dry, but also bready yeast, bananas, clove, some apricot, citrus, and white pepper. Similar on the tongue, but a bit of an alcohol burn. Dry finish. Very good.
Bottle. Golden colour. Fenolic, yeasty, marzipan, banana, spices, alcohol, light smokiness?, a bit of bitterness.

upon oncapping the bottle it decided to explode for no reason that i can possibly think of, it had been sitting upright and motionless for about 2 hours and nothing spectacular had happened before. a thoroughly aggravating start as i’ve never seen beer do that before, and it wasted about half of the bottle. smell is woody, dry and alcoholic. it is cloudy golden with a head that was large but receded. taste is dry, spicy, winey, and a tiny bit of rubber taste at the end. astringent and dry. the palate is harsh but it fits with the flavour. it is something that i would enjoy in a very small amount on a special occasion; westmalle is somewhat pricey but always good.

Appearance: The Westmalle Tripel pours a slightly hazy golden color  very similar to what youd see from a wheat beer.  As with most of the other Trappist beers, this comes with about three to four solid fingers of light head with minimal lacing that disappears pretty quickly.  You can tell this has a lot of effervescence by the onslaught of small bubbles swimming swiftly to the top of the glass.  

Smell: Just as I had imagined, there is a lot of spice going on in the glass.  There is an immediate blast of beautiful honeycomb that hits you first, and then it is quickly followed by banana and clove components on the backend.  For me, the real joy comes out of feeling like Ive just stuck my nose in the middle of a fresh honeycomb.  On top of what is immediately noticeable, there is a very faint amount of funk that sits way in the back of the nose.  This becomes more evident as the beer begins to warm.   

Taste: I guess one of the best things a beer can do is taste like it smells, and this certainly does just that.  Surprisingly enough the honeycomb component I get on the nose translates into the taste very well.  I also taste the yeast along with the banana and cloves.  In terms of the alcohol, I dont taste it as much as I thought I would but I certainly feel it about halfway through the bottle.  And its a small bottle.  

Mouthfeel: Overall this is an extremely well-balanced beer in the mouth.  Because of the style, the Westmalle has a lot of bite due to the sparkling qualities and the enormous amount of head.  There is a perfect amount of bitterness, too, which is paired with a vigorous amount of acidity.  Normally a beer like this would lean more toward the lighter side, but this one is easily approaching medium body.   

Overall: Lets be honest, this isnt a mind-melting beer.  However, it is classic in just about every way.  I really love the honeycomb component the most and really like the way this baby smells.  I am also a really big fan of the bitterness levels that I get from the Westmalle.  Its not as unique as the Orval (which is still my favorite Trappist ale), but it is definitely a staple and quite enjoyable.  Its proof that consistency is a very good thing.

12 oz bottle. Another trappist brew, second Ive had by Westmalle. Pours a hazy orange/gold color with a finger high white head that disappates quickly. Smells of pear,  some fresh hops, also possibly apples, and a light alcohol smell. Tastes of pear, apple, a bit of hops (though quite light), and a fairly strong alcohol bite. The alcohol makes the palate rating go down a bit, but it is still quite good, as the flavor is what does it.

11.2 oz bottle poured into a goblet. Hazy gold color with streaming columns of carbonation. Fluffy white head leaves quintessential Belgian lacing. Aromas of pears and apples with some coriander and a hint of alcohol. Flavor is lightly fruity with accents of pepper and coriander. Significant alcohol blends nicely behind the fruits and spices. Warming mouthfeel with delicate carbonation and medium body.

12oz bottle. Pours cloudy orange with a mammoth white frothy head. Aroma of bananas, cookies, and citrus zest. Flavor is earthy hops with some spice and sweetness. Alcohol is upfront and definitely noticeable. Fizzy and delicate on the palate. A nice beer overall.

creamy aroma, some bright yeast for added balance.  hazy yellow, some largish chunks in the glass.  sustained creamy head.  back and forth between sweet and dry, little apricot and peach in the finish, dry finish.

2007 Bottle courtesy of PaulHegedus.
Pours hazy golden with foamy white head. Yeasty aromas with peach and banana notes.Flavours of grapefruit, honey and coriander. Creamy mouthfeel with mild carbonation. Finish is smooth yet slightly brisk.

Sampled thanks to shawn at cool springs.  Pours a near clear yellow with ample fluffy white head and small particulate. Sweet banana, yeast, light alcohol.  Lots of alcohol on the flavor side, with a little bit of bitterness. Similar to some white wines ive had.  Overated imo.  Especially considering the price.
Pours orange.  Smells spicy with some yeastiness.  Tastes of spices and sweetness.  Bitterness is present as well.

Bottle, pours cloudy copper.  Banana, citrus, dough aroma.  Nice taste, it has a sublte dough like banana citrus sweetness complimented by a well timed dryness.  High carbonation.  Subtle citus vinous type notes linger in the aftertaste.  Alcohol not noticeable. Very complex and hard to describe.  This is quality.

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2011 Slightly cloudy yellow/goldish pour with a big head. Aroma is fruity and spicy. (Loads of banana) Somewhat bitter flavour of fruit with subtle yeast and spices. 
Thick and full palate, good carbonation. Very nice.

Apperance; light yello, Hazy with a big white head. Aroma; citrus, fruits and some yeast, pretty complex, but not as the Westmalle Dubbel, I like that much much better. You cant tell that this is a 9,5% alcohol beer.

Pours a hazy golden liquid with a big head of foam. At first the alcohol is well hidden and its hard to believe its 9,5%. Very pleasent taste, But after a few sips the high alcohol % in this beer takes over a bit. Maybe it was the temperature that dropped in the beer. But it draws down the points slightly.

Beautiful pour, golden with semi yellow/goldenrod head, nice bubbles, not too carbonated, strong but good yeasty feel, no too sticky, bread-like, light hop, alc hidden, semi sweet, nice beer, id buy again, raw beer, beautiful lacing, its the stereotypical GOOD tripel...

Enjoyed via 750ml bottle.  Pours a clear yellow, not quite as light as the industrial beers, but not as dark as a pale ale.  Head is outstanding, high, fluffy, and long-lasting.  Initial nose is one of spiciness, with additional touches of malt and a light hop aroma (and I do mean light).  This beer is a classic on the palate, a true example of excellence in the style.  Notes of pilsner malt sweetness, estery fruits, and a spritzy and dry finish dominate.

Bottle: Clear golden colour, with a big head. Aroma of citrus, fruits, flowers, and yeast noose in the end. Flavor is almost the same, with a werry nice balnced with the swet maltynes, and  the typical belgian fruity/yeasty mouth feeling. A well done beer. Medium to full body, nice medium fruity/citric fiish. Werry nice!
Nice tripel but it tastes alot of alcohol.  I could have used a better blend of other flavors.  Even still, I held higher standards for this one.
Bottle. Pours an opaque orange color. Aroma of citrus and lemon zest. Flavor is strong on the malts, sweeter aftertaste. Good beer
bottle, pours hazy light orange.  Light citris hop aroma, some alcohol.  Light malt and some sweetness ending very dry with a good hop bite.  Moderate alcohol burn.
Upon first sip, my first word was "Whoa!".  Great flavor, good aroma, strong malty flavor.  Once again, the Belgians have produced another winner.

Has a sour bitter beer smell with some florals.
Pours a slightly hazy apple juice color with minimal white head and some action.
Mouthfull of flavors including pale malt, maybe some wheat,  and some grapefruit/lime hop taste with a hint of sourness, butter, and alcohol warming.
Medium bodied, resinous and buttery, with a crisp carbonation.
Another fine product from the Trappist Monks, cheers.

Great trappist that someone brought to a party, but didnt realize it wasnt a quick drink beer.  Dirty gold pour and white head.  Tart and sour fruit aroma.  Sweeter flavor with a bitter dry taste.  Alcohol complements the finishing flavor better than the beginning.

Aroma contained plenty of apple vinegar and even a little yeast. Thin creamy head with some flecks as well in this pour. Flavor was sour apple vinegar, grapes and maybe raisins. Palate was fizzy and lively. A good tripel that has much in common with some sour ales.

Bottle. Slightly unclear golden body. White medium sized head. Sourish aroma, without yeast. Quite sharp. Sweet flavour, relatively fresh with sourish hints. Can feel the alcohol in the finish. (Gollem, Amsterdam, 08.12.08)

Bottle. Golden colour with a long lasting huge white head. 
Aroma is sweet banana, apricot and yeast.
Flavor is slightly bitter, dry fruit, yeast, acidic and with a little to much alcohol. 
A good tripel though.

The benchmark ale of tripels. One of my very favorites. Their cheese is pretty good too.  If I stood in front of a shelf full of tripels and someone told me to grab one, this is the one I would grab without a second thought.

11.2 oz bottle.  Bright golden color with a very fluffy off white head.  The palate is medium, not too heavy, and the aromas seemed subdued.  The flavors are great; there is some sweet vanilla, some strong fruit flavor and a really great deep spiciness throughout.  A great beer, the high ABV is not noticeable because it is exceptionally smooth.

Aroma tart, bananas.  Flavor is quite fruity and tart.  Very freshing, not too on the sweet side.  Frothy body, but has a smooth sticky mouthfeel to it.  Kind of has a bitter finish to it.  Really has a dry malty body, not too sweet, with a strong fruity tart character.  Lemon, perhaps.  A little spicy.

11.2 oz. bottle.  Best before end:  02/10/10.  A hazy old gold pour with tons of little floaties and a huge & fluffy off-white head.  Sweet/yeasty aroma of candied sugar, vanilla, lemons, straw, and some funky mustiness.  Medium-bodied with plenty of carbonation.  Starts off with some vanilla and sweet caramel.  Transitions to some tart green apples.  Finishes with some drying lemons, grapefruits, and hints of melon.  Some peppery spiciness is present throughout.

750 ml bottle from LCBO, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. GUSHER! DE28/08.
App.:  Cloudy golden with a nice white froth.
  
Aroma:  Quite fruity  apples, apricots, pears; yeast and bread dough, sweet honey, a touch of wood and citrus.
  
Palate:  Medium body, fairly sparse and soft carbonation, somewhat astringent.
  
Flav.:  Like the nose  plenty of fruit, some toffee and caramel, a bit of yeast and bread dough, some green, minty herbals, a little citrus; sweet with some alcohol and light fruitiness.

A bit of the Dubbel side, better for me that most Tripels.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2015 2/10/2009: On tap at Rose & Crown in Palo Alto.  Hazy golden-yellow color with a thick white head.  Yeasty aroma with a little citrus.
