Flavor is yeasty as hell with fruit notes, sweet malt, spices, and well-disguised but noticeable alcohol.  A solid, refreshing, and potent triple.

Update 12/29/2015: I was a clown back in the day. This is a phenomenal example of the style. Amazing candi sugar aroma with tropical fruit. Smooth as foooooook. Updating from 7/4/8/4/15 (3.8) to 9/4/9/5/17 (4.4).

Pours clear golden with a thick and cloudy head. Looks very nice. The aroma is hoppy, fruity (grape fruit, lemon), quite malty and some spices. The finish had something slightly unfresh. The flavor is dryish and a bit spicy. Medium bodied, smooth and dangerously easy to drink.

Pours a cloudy golden colour, looks more like a weisse beer than a tripel.

Lots of aromas coming from this the strongest being the yeast and citrus notes.

The first mouthful comes with a massive hit of alcohol and is fairly acidic; the aftertaste provides an equally large dry bitter hit.

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2009 (11.2 oz btl) Cloudy straw-colored pour topped w/ a rocky white head which reduces slightly leaving wonderful lacing.  Pear and lemon, or maybe tart green apple, combine w/ cereal for a vinous nose similar to muscat or Riesling.  Appearance and aroma are top notch.  Nicely acidic up front giving way to a bready, yeasty malt.  Finish is crisp and tart w/ notes of allspice and lemon peel.
Unclear golden with nice head. Strong fruity malte aroma of citrus and banana and some spices. Flavour is sweet with sweet finish.

This cloudy golden beer high yeast, has a very pleasent blend of spices and orange taste. With a good ballance of sweet bitter feel bit not to much.
Triple beers are normally not my favorite but this one is really excelente and full of strong flavors.

I find Westmalle Tripel to be the absolute gold standard in the category, complex but not overly saturated with multiple fruity esters.  The beer provides a combination of  ripe tree fruit along, particularly pear combined with a delicate light yeast derived peppery spice character.

The pour was a turbid golden color with hints at orange and lots of particulates ambling about.  The aroma was yeast, citrus, floral and peppery.  The flavor was yeast, tart fruit (crisp apple and lemon) with some malt and pepper coming through.  Nice medium bodied mouthfeel.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2015 Drank from a Chimay goblet: Big ass creamy top with  glowing golden orange & a  shitload of sediment swimming around.: @ 9.5 % itll get you wasted soon .The floral palate & fruit from the yeast (apple ,banana -esters)are full on with heafty peppery  spices.... .

Bottle. Moderate malt and hop aromas of grain, light bread and perfume, musty cellar for the yeast, with hints of clove and wood. Head is huge, rocky, white with excellent lacing and is fully lasting. Color is hazy amber with tiny particles. Flavor starts moderately acidic and finishes moderately acidic and heavily bitter. Palate is medium, oily, with a fizzy carbonation and finishes moderately astringent. I liked all the attributes of this Tripel, a prime example of the style.

Pours a hazy golden color with lots of suspended particulates. Good medium foamy white head, splashes the sides of the glass with nice sheets of lacing and head retention. Nose is fruity, spicy, clove, yeast. Initial taste begins fruity, clove, citrus, bready, earthy. Mid palate to finish is mildly vinous and refreshing. Alcohol is well masked. Palate duration is excellent. Fantastic triple.

2006 vintage...pours a cloudy honey color...more orange than yellow...with a thin white head and decent lacing.  very fruity aroma with apricot notes and the alcohol is evident.  flavor is mildly fruity and a touch of sour up front but is dominted by alcohol and dry spicey-grasay hops in the finish.  moutfeel is a bit thin.  not what i was hoping for in this cellared bottle.
BOTTLE: from Four Firkins (St. Louis Park, MN). Pours a somewhat cloudy, off-orange yellow. Great aroma - fruit and alcohol. Taste is a little dry, plenty of booze, citrus, hops, grass. Good tripel.
Sour, sweet, and acidic flavors limit the appeal. The finish does have some dryness to it. Alcohol is not hidden, and burns in the stomach and mouth. I much prefer the dubbel.

I bought this and the dubbel and was pumped to try them.  The dubbel tasted like total ass so I wasnt too hyped to try the tripel.  Pours a hazy, orangish-yellow with a huge, bubbly white head.  Aroma of citrus and hops.  The taste was sour and of citrus and hops.  Finish was grassy.  Not too bad of a beer.

Dry but fruity. Very flavorful. A little too much carbonation for my taste, but thats not a huge negative in my book. The alcohol taste was a bit too assertive as it warmed. Nice aroma, complex flavors. Good hop notes complete the package very well. Would buy again, although there are other triples that I enjoy more.

Crisp, dry, fruity and hoppy aroma leads to a huge, dry flavor of honey, lemon/citrus, pine. Big alcohol, great dry finish. Amazing balance and palate. Wow. One of the best. Critics say it used to be better. Wish I had had it then!

En mycket behaglig trappistöl som får snålvattnet att rinna till. Om det är något som ligger ölen i fatet (hmpf!) är det att alkoholsmaken tränger igenom och skapar en vass kant på en i övrigt välsmakande öl.
UPDATED: SEP 20, 2009 Pours auburn-brown. Aroma is nice. Hoppy and roasty. Flavor is very nice. Good, strong, balanced. Decently leaning toward hoppiness, but not overwhelming. Near perfection.

Huge pillowy head over a faded orange body. Beautiful look. Hoppy nose, grasses and flowers. Taste of fresh grass and a hint of caramel, very dry, bitter end. Quite spicy. Very fizzy palate, fills the whole mouth. NIce beer but I prefer the more malty trappists.

Bottle. Best before Feb. 2010. Gushed a little. Cloudy orange with a thin head. The aroma and flavor are both rather light, with some spices and a touch of fruity sweetness. Good, but I wasnt very impressed.
UPDATED: MAR 1, 2009 Bottle. A nice strong taste, a bit rougher than most triples, which gives it the trappist feel of a hard days work making this.

Yeast, spice, and honey rise from the liquid gold body with enormous pillow-like head.  Flavor exhibits banana, caramel malt, and a touch of alcohol.  Ample carbonation leads to good mouthfeel.  Only a touch of alcohol is noticeable.  Antoher good one.

Pours a bright hazy bubbly yellow with white head.  The aroma is sweet, of belgian yeast, spices, alcohol, funk, and good aromas I cant name yet.  Appropriate Tripel phenols hit you right away, followed by sweetness, a little bit of funk and sourness.  The mouthfeel is effervescent and warming.  Overall a very fine brew.

A wonderful beer. A bit high in ABV but you can hardly taste it amongst the spicy and fruity notes. Aroma of dry fruit and grass. Mouthfeel is slightly unusual and leaves a persistent flavour of alcohol in my mouth. Overall, a great trappist.

Bottled. Clear Amber color (orangy), with a nice white head that persist for a long time, actually until the finish. Aroma is fruity and sweety, somne honey, pineapple and malty notes. Flavor is sweet citrus with a medium carbonation, alcohol is perceptible. Mouthfeel is spicy and dry but take a long time to do.

Color is a hazy amber, not impressive - but the thick, white, rather persistent head promises a great ale. Strong aroma is creamy, fruity, malty, and slightly sweet. Flavor is crisp, fruity, malty, very satisfying, not overly complex but rather mouth-filling. Texture is smooth but edgy, and leaves a fruity and slightly hoppy aftertaste. It does have quite a bite to it, so beware - it ain’t for sissies!

Pours a yellow-gold color with a foamy white head and good lacing.  Aroma of honey, caramelized bananas, and some grassy hops.  Taste/palate is highly carbonated, with sweetness and honey flavors, balanced with a light citrus bitterness.

This is one of the most underrated beers here.
It is a verry much imitated beer , but no other brewery can create the same flavor . For me it is the best beer in the world , and i have tasted a lot .

750ml bottle to wine glass, for lack of a chalice or tulip.  Shared with brother in honor of the celebration for Christ apostrophe s birth.  His description appears below mine, semi colon, read Harsebrau apostrophe s description.  One thing I would note is that the missing descriptive taste is maybe not caramel.  I would say perhaps instead it is a yeast based flavor.

Pours a cloudy, peach/apricot syrup color.  Denser in the middle.  Highly carbonated.  Fizzy white head that left decent lacing on my glass. Sweet aroma - apple, icewine, pear, cream-cicke.  Has a sour approach, mid-sweetness and fizzbomb effect.  At the swallow something lingers...caramel?  Hops are present as well.  I like.

Pours an unfiltered dirty golden with a ton of suspended sediment.  Head is white and lasts until the bottom of the glass.  Aroma is yeast, caramel, and fruit.  Flavor is yeast and fruit with a big dose of alcohol.  Caramel and a bit of hop, as well.  Smooth as silk.  Delicious.

Light fruity, alcohol and spiced aroma unfolds from a murky yellow pour with a huge fluffy white head. Flavor is sweet bananas and hops with hints of yeast and grass. Had a dry, sharp finish. Alcohol was well hidden but I think tripels are my least favorite when it comes to belgian beer styles. Nice complexity, but the flavor just does not wow me.

Bottle at Sandbar, Manchester.  Hazy light orange colour with large, lasting head that sticks to the glass all the way down.  Aroma was spicy, vanilla, alcohol (too much), citrus and a light maltiness.  I think mine was served too cold as I found this to be a disappointment on the tongue.  Way too heavy an alcohol hit in the flavour masking whatever characteristics this well respected beer may have.  Slightly sticky, cloying palate.  Re-rate probably in order in the future.
cloudy gold blond coloured body with a white head a sweet fruity hoppy aroma a sweet fruity hoppy taste with a mettalic alchoholic bitter finish nice one
33cl bottle, golden-yellow with solid foam head, clear without the yeast, blurred with the yeast, good balanced  strong hop noise.

Pours a cloudy yellow with a white head and serious white lacing.  Banana, clove and a sweet finish. A bit of a bitter bite towards the end of the sip.  Spicey, yeasty aroma reminds you you are drinking a belgian beer.  Pretty remarkable this is the first time I have gotten to this one.  Pretty well rounded and complex beer.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2008 33cl bottle. Pours golden with a soft creamy head, exciting carbonation. Superb lacing.  
Fruity, complex nose including banana, lemon and orange. Strong aroma of sweet honey, slight hops, and alcohol.
Rich, hoppy flavour that is absolutely amazing. Malt and honey. 
Has an enjoyable bite with a zesty, clean finish with some bitterness and alcohol. 
Amazing.

Cloudy golden with a thick, lasting head.  A little skunky out of the bottle, but after it sat for a minute or so it smelled more spicy than skunky.  Banana and yeast in the nose, with the spicy note.  Flavor is almost that of a saison, with a musty, fruity dryness.  An interesting beer, and not what I expected.  A little light for a tripel.  Alcohol is well-hidden, however.

Bottle, saved for 500th rating.  Sweet fruity aroma.  Cloudy orange body, gigantic white head.  Flavor is powerful, sweet, all kinds of fruit and malt.  Spices, too, and alcohol.  Nice finish.  Great stuff.

Bouteille de 33 cl. deguste avec french tickler. Une biere de couleur blonde avec un bon collet moyennement collant. Odeur de pommes, sucre, fleural, banane et un peu dorange. Gout sucre, tres bon en bouche, picottement au niveau de la langue. Tres bonne biere.
Bottle 0,33ltr: True Trappist classic, hazy golden coloured brew from the monks and its have a load of fruity, citrus, spices and peppery taste.

Hazy golden color with yeast particles with a really thick and foamy white head. Sweet malty aroma with hints of dried fruit, flowers, soap and brown sugar. Complex rich flavor of spices, yasmin, orange, chocolate and fruit in liquor. Sweet and fruity finish with a sting of alcohol.
UPDATED: SEP 18, 2010 Hazy golden color, nutty nose, full mouth.  Citrus flavors with medium hops bitterness.  Nice dry and bitter finish.

Brewed in Belgium !!! Pours a hazy yellow color with a super foamy white head. Aroma of sweet malts, bananas, citrus, and spices. The taste is of spices, pepper, fruits, and dough. Mouthfeel is sticky and frizzy with some nice carbonation. There is however some alcohol burn at the finish.....  :)

A: Golden blond somewhat cloudy with a very thick head, lingers for some time even.

S: Smell is Pilsner like; lightly fruity w/basement aromas.

T: Lively, lots of fizz. Fruity taste is hidden, the alcohol is present. 

M: Tingles the tongue, refreshing in taste.

D: If you favor a blond Ale (Pilsner even) this is you brew. I tend to stick primarily to the Strong Dark Pale Ales.

Overall Impression: Better than average Beer overall; below average for an Belgium trappist.

33cl bottle, hazy (many big pieces of yeast in suspension) orange colour, medium white head, yeast aroma with complexes notes of fruits (banana and citrus), spices and alcohol, balanced sweet flavor with sour notes, medium body and carbonation, amazing finish with big fruity and spicy and some alcohol

Bottle at Pub Italia in Ottawa. Pours an orangey-yellow with a nice foamy head. Smell is a wash of citrus. Deep orange-citrus taste, with a hint of spice, reminds you of a prototypical witbier, but has a definite ale-like character. Finish is quick and maybe a little too thin, though the head adds dimension. Hoegaarden on roids.

330ml bottle from the LCBO as part of a gift pack with glass
The aroma is spicy orange and yeasty 
Pours a pale amber orange with a big white head 
Very High carbonation a little spicy orange flavour strong alcohol taste
Not as good as some other triples I have had was expecting a little more
thick creamy white head, golden colour. Aroma is spicy, orange? Flavour is spicy with distinct notes of orange and yeast, surprisingly light considering the ABV.

330 ml bottle - thanks to matt7215 for the trade; hazy burnt orange with slowly fading white head; very similar to the chimay obviously; aromas of fresh yeast, lemons, spice; slight tart and lemons; more enjoyable than the chimay; sweetness in the finish; candy and orange peels; soft texture; very nice
I had this right after drinking the Westmalle Dubbel and I thought that this one wasn’t as good.  Don’t remember much about it other than I drank it out of a trappist glass.

Bottle 33cl.
Pours a muddy golden colour with a great size head and good carbonation.
Have the original glass and it’s beautiful!
Smell is sour and spicy, also some hops there.
Taste is a great balance of yeast, hops, fruits and spices.
A very good abbey tripel and almost as good as the dubbel.

Aroma is bread and spicy yeast. Pours with a large rocky white head, hazy gold color. Taste is lemon, cloves, grass, yeast, and a nice hoppiness. Alcohol is noticable, but not overwhelming. Light to medium body. Nice lacing. Drinkable and good, but not worth the price.

330 mL bottle. Pours a hazy bright yellow like a witbier or good tripel. Giant, white head that stays around. Yeast particulates throughout even though I withheld pouring in the yeast sediment. Very low carbonation. Aroma is slightly grassy but with lots of yeast, coriander, orange peel, bananas, and alcohol (9.5%). Sort of like a double witbier. Taste is similar with an addition of cloves and a dry finish of spicy hops, yeast, and warming alcohol. A good tripel- similar to Chimay.

330ml Bottle:  Aroma of grass, herbal hops, yeast, and slight fruit.  Poured deep yellow/light orange in color with a medium-sized, dense white head that lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Sparkling.  Full of tiny particles throughout.  Much lighter in color than most Tripels I have had.  Flavor is lightly sweet and lightly bitter.  Tastes of malts, alcohol, spices, and yeast.  Light to medium body.  Fizzy texture.  Lively carbonation.  Yeasty, sweet, boring finish.

Pours a hazy bronze color with a nice, rocky white head.  Strong citrus aroma with a little grassy hops.  Nicely balanced flavor of citrus (orange), yeast, alcohol.  Medium-bodied, easy to drink with a lasting finish.

Not as impressive as the dubbel but still a decent trappist ale. It felt forced to be a tripel which inhibited a great natural flavor. Still a good beer. Best served in a trappist glass served by a large breasted bartendress.
Hazy light straw colored pour with a thick white head and lots of yeast floating around.  Fruity aroma with spice and lots of yeast.  Very bitter with cloves and yeast and lots of alcohol.

Nice white head. clear straw yellow colour. relatively weak aroma. Very bitter with spicy, crispy hops. Rolls back with a massive malty bisquity finish and lots of warmth. Lingering but somewhat brutal finish with elements of grass and straw.

Pours a cloudy lemony wheat color with a massive pillowy white head. Beautiful lacing, little bubbles streaming up the side. Quite a stunning site. Aroma first hits as a bit sour apple and dry, but get malty and citrus as it warms. Taste is crisp and dry, nice malt presence comes through with a spicy hop bite and a hint of citrus. Finishes a little bitter and dry, very good.

Really liked this one.  Not my favorite among trappists but at the same time I only got a small sample at the Cyclone Liquors’ tasting in Ames.  Delicious notes of caramel, toast, smoke, and malt complemented by that unforgettable and indescribable complex trappist aroma.  Nice job!

Golden brown with a moderate to light head.  Aroma of yeast, marshmallows, and bananas with a hint of spice.  Full bodied with a warming but not too pronounced alcohol background.  Flavors abound with fresh fruit esters and malt most prominent with little hop flavor.  Spice is there, vanilla, marshmallows, a touch of nutmeg and ginger. A lovely blend of flavors that is so balanced for a triple.  One of the best Trappist triples.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2009 (bottle) pours a lightly hazy golden colour with a huge frothy white head. very subtle but complex aroma of fresh yeast, spicy hops and bubble-gum, with notes of banana, apples and vanilla. flavour is similar, with dominant grassy hop spices and alcohol. strong body and carbonation, bitter finish, a nice summer-sipper.

I got this beer at world market of all places for about $7. Good appearance, a nice creamy body and smooth lasting head.  A nice spicy aroma of banana and citrus, good Tripel aroma. Good initial flavor with a nice balance of alcohol.  The finish is a little bitter but an excellent beer.

Drink Turtle Piano!

Pours a beautiful straw color, slightly hazy with a nice head, and a lively carbonation.  The aroma is floral and spicy, very pleasing.  The flavor is a nice combination of mellow hops, spicy yeast notes, sweet fruitiness and citrus.  The beer is wonderfully complex, quite solid, an excellent Belgian worth going back to again and again.

Nice aroma very floral.  Notes of grassy hops and light caramel malt.  Great head retention.  Nice yellowish gold color hazy.  Flavor is quite tart bitter, nice alc burn.  Notes of citrus banana, orange.  The spice adds a nice touch.  Very good tripel.

Bottle, thanks ekstedt. Cloudy yellow with a mostly lasting, large white head leaving a good amount of lacing. Lightly malty and heavily hoppy. Burnt notes, flowers, perfume, citrus and rubber. Initially lightly bitter developing into a heavily bitter, long finish. Medium bodied, dry, somewhat astringent, with fizzy carbonation.

Bottle 75 cl. Average size creamy white lasting head with fair lacing. Cloudy deep nice orange body. Aroam of flowers, grass, orange, lots of malt, heavy alcohol, vanilla and coriander. Full body oily texture. Very well balanced flavor, moderate sweet and moderate bitter.

Bottle shared at a tasting.  Thanks!
Pours a bright orange colory with bubbly head.  Smell is yeasty, gummy, and band-aid like.  Taste is gummy bananas, belgian yeast, and is fairly spiced.  Really just a lot of spice and didn’t do a lot for me.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2008 Bottle. The beer pours a beautiful hazy yellow colour with a thick head! Standard tripel aroma, fruity and yeasty.
The flavor is not as complex as one would think. Its a dry beer with fruit and honey. Lots of alcohol in the aftertaste.

750 shared w/ my brother.  Pours a slightly hazy nectarine color with a thick foamy 2 finger head.  Aroma of some yeasty apple with citrus, coriander, and caramel.  The flavor is surprisingly dry.  A sort of papery hop character.  Lemongrass, extreme fruity esters, A slight clove character to the flavor that almost makes way to a hint of anise.  Very bready.  As medium body, though still light enough to be refreshing.

Bottle. Hazy yellow color, lots of sediment at the bottom, big whipped egg white foamy head. Mmm, Belgian beer. Flavor is bread, bananas, raisins, yeast, hints of spice and pepper. Smooth, smooth, smooth. Medium bodied, lingering mild alcohol warmth on the back of the throat. Dry finish. Really can’t go wrong with this stuff. Yum.

750 ml bottle.  Aroma is spicy, hints of banana, and yeasty.  Pours gold with lively carbonation, small head.  Flavor is similiar and sweet.  Strong notes of pepper.  Alcohol gets stronger with each sip.  Medium mouthfeel, long finish.  Decent.
banana, bread, citrus aroma, golden, hazy, frothy, rocky head, medium bitterness, medium sweetness, full body, thick feel, fizzy, long finish, bitter,
user_location: Cambridge and Kladno(Czech Rep.), Cambridgeshire, ENGLAND

text: UPDATED: JUL 30, 2010 Bottle. Hazy golden/orange color with a nice white head. Aroma is spicey, lightly yeasty with notes of orange, mandarine and green apples - theres also some hops there. Flavour is fruity and acidic with spices, orange, apples, mandarine, banana and some light hops. Nicely dry and a bit warming with a bitter finish. Filling on the palate, mediumbodied, high carbonation. Overall a quite nice tripel, but I cant say its a favourite of mine, its a bit boozy.
UPDATED: OCT 16, 2008 Gorgeous deep amber colour. Slightly bitter start with honey, caramel and spiced notes. Sweet and bitter alcoholic finish. Improves with time and after a few sips.

(Bottle, 0.75 l bottled 240408, at Hilpeä Hauki, Helsinki, on 2008-09-27) Orange. Cloudy. Medium sized quickly disappearing white head. Citric aromas, yeast  and some tiny hints of banana in very fruity nose. Medium bodied palate with quite lot of carbonation. Fruitiness, bitterness, grapefruit, malts and some salty liquorice. Long lasting fruity aftertaste.

330ml bottle served i a Trappist glass. Bottle erupted with foam when opened, hope it isnt infected. Lots of sediment floating around in yellow-gold liquid topped by a lasting white head. Sugary nose with some spicy esters. Tastes of candi sugar, pepper, caramel. Very active carbonation, frothy mouthfeel, some warmth, drying effect. Very solid, but standard tripel.

330ml bottle. Golden, orange body with a big, creamy white head. Aroma is sweet like castor sugar, a bit spicy and alcohol. Flavor is sweet, spicy and a bit too alcoholic. I actually know a few better versions of tripel, maybe it used to be better?

Pours hazy gold, with a fluffy head that won’t quit.  lots of lacing as well.  Aroma is yeasty and spicy.  The flavors are peppery with alcohol being more dominant in the flavor than any beer I can remember off the top of my head.

Good beer, but there is a whole lot of heat going on here. nice muted sweetness in the aroma and a whole world of head in this light amber beer. Overall though, the beer is a nice blend of banana and some spice elements. Good, but not classic.

I was looking forward to trying this.  Fortunately, Islay let me enjoy this while waiting for the opening Vikes/Pack game to start the NFL season.  Aroma is light cookie, grape, and banana, and belgian sugar.  The minimal sourness is a nice touch to an overtly sweet tripel style.  Nice and tingley mouthfeel.  The carbonation aspect is perfect here.  What you have here is a top of the line abbey tripel, that all should aspire to.

Abbey Tripels are easily one of my favourite beer styles. This one reminds me why. Pours of cloudy gold with an impressive white head. Fruity and spicy aroma and flavour with some notes of yeast and bread. Hoppy, yeasty aftertaste. Quite and flavourful and well balanced beer. Alcohol is well hidden.

Tasted is in conjunction with Orval.  It lost the contest.  is very drinkable for a > 9% brew, however.  Aroma was slight, surprisingly.  Seemed yeasty and balanced.  Grassy taste that lingered briefly.

11.2oz in bordeaux glass.  Towering white head on deep gold with streaming fine bubbles.  Fresh grape and bubblegum are dominant aromas.  Sweet, warming, distantly grainy, even more distantly spicy.  Uncannily reminiscent of my homebrew Delirium clone, which used the Westmalle yeast....

330ml bottle. 11/07/07 date on bottle. Poured a clear gold in color with a massive beige head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of bread, yeast, light spices and light fruity notes. Taste is spiced, light fruity notes, yeasty, bready with some citrus.

Poured from bomber, fifth beer in tasting series.  Appearance is a murky gold-orange with a crisp white head.  Aroma is of light fruit, and a strange bit of plastic.  Flavor features notes of dry champagne, tart fruit, green grapes and sugar-candy.  Finishes slightly bitter, with hints of grass and alcohol.  Overall, this brew is a solid example of this style, but does not possess the balance of say, Allagash Tripel.

Amazing aroma.  Color was also a great golden and a bit cloudy color.  Out of 12oz bottle.  A bit of astringancy / acidty and almost sour that hits the mid in a weird way, though this dicipated after a couple minutes, I’m guessing the palate adjusted.    Lived up to the hype, classic belgium texture filled it later.  But the aroma, some salt, butter, hint of burnt sugar way in the back.  Something to behold.

Bottle.  Poured into a trappist glass.  Poured a cloudy gold color with a three finger sparse white head.  Aroma was spicy with a tinge of yeast.  Flavor reflects the aroma with abundent spices and a sweet base.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Medium/full bodied with mild carbonation.

Very good beer.  Murky golden color.  Nice size foamy wide head.  Excellent lacing.  Aroma of yeast and spice.
Great mouth feel on this one.  Starts of creamy and sweet, some soft carbination. Lots of yeast and spice on the back end. Touch of dryness.
chiara buona schiuma persistente al naso malto leggere spezie erbaceeo ma anche fruttato in boccca prima malto poi lieve speziatura e un finale nettamente tagliato dal luppolo
Now this is where it’s at. Very pleasant nose, with tart citrusy notes. The taste and the mouthfeel are impressive, bitter, hoppy, and yeasty. Carbonation just right.

33cl bottle from Bar & Cigar. Bottled 04/02/10. It poured a golden orange colour with a white creamy medium big head. The aroma is spicy and also smells of yeast. It has a very bitter flavour that tastes of yeast and malts. It has a medium long aftertaste.
cereal, herbs, floral, golden, clear, white foam, light sweetness, very bitter, medium sourness, full body, lively, bitter,
Cloudy golden orange color with a finger of very creamy white head.  Spicy aroma, perfumes and dark floral notes.  Sharp spice bite and very carbonated yet creamy mouthfeel.  Nice sweet dry finish.

Pours a light straw color from the bomber with a trim white head.  Plenty of green grapes, mild yeast, and anise on the nose which carry into the flavor.  More watery than I prefer, but a fine Tripel.

bb 1/22/10... pours somewhat viscous a cloudy golden color with  lots of floaters evident. super long lasting airy/wispy/soapy off white head. pillowy foam coats the inside of the glass as the head eventually recedes. really yeasty aroma with notes of black pepper spiciness, canned pear/fruity?, soap/flowers and a hint of some skunk. lots of yeast in the flavor as well as pears, dried grass and herbs, mild caramel and a skunky hop finish. spiciness comes on strong toward the end as the abv%  warms  up the belly. medium body. nice and dry on the palate. soft airy carbonation makes it velvety and smooth...

Thick white head that lasts, hazy yellow color, lots of yeast sediment in the bottle, luckily I poured it really well and left almost all of it behind.  The head actually gets bigger after I pour the beer and let it sit in the glass.  There is quite a bit of visible carbonation.  An easy 5.  Smells pretty darn good.  Spicy, yeast, slightly grassy and funky, definitely some fruity stuff in there too.  I’m gonna say 8.  Flavor is excellent.  Perhaps not a complex as the aroma.  Very lively on the palate.  Smooth drinking.  Real good stuff.

I would think that Westmalle Tripel should be better than Westmalle Dubbel. To me, it’s not. The Westmalle Triple is still an excellent beer though. It’s very strong yet you’ll hardly notice it until it sneaks up on you. It’s a cloudy golden color, citrus flavored, and fairly thick. Pour slowly so that the head’s not TOO thick, otherwise you’ll be waiting a few minutes for it to settle down. This is one well-worth drinking. Anything carrying the name trappist is a must have.

The pour is a clouded, hay-colored gold with long, snakey yeasty globs slithering about the glass. Giant head so typical of a tripel. Aromas of pineapple, lovely Belgian yeasties, band-aid, canned fruit salad. Thick, sticky brew. Acidic dryness to finish after ample yummy, juicy-fruit sweetness coats the mouth. Wonderful example of the style, the extra aging is evident. Maybe a bit on the syrupy side

Bottle (330ml). Poured muddy orange honey with a large, thick, fluffy, off-white head which lasted amazingly. A complex aroma with a sourdough, fennel, banana/clove notes, orange zest, pears, ginger and white pepper. Strong herby/spicy notes in the flavor with sour yeasty malts, cloves, coriander, lemon zest, dry pears, hints of aniseed and a warming/peppery finish. Medium to full bodied with medium carbonation a dry/spicy mouthfeel, syrupy texture and a great finish.

Pours a hazy gold - the color of an unfiltered cider. Huge head. Aroma is much more pungeant than I expected - the wonderfully refreshing spicy citrus that trademarks a good triple are complemented by yeast and bread. Flavor is right on the nose (pardon the pun) - spicy fruit, especially citrus and apple, with the Belgian yeast adding a full body and a bready taste. The beer is thick, but the carbonation is lively enough to clear it from your palate. Flavor is mild, but not dilute - it isn’t missing anything. A wonderful example of a style I don’t often seek out.

bottle 33cl, golden yellow, firm head, clear, strong bitter with fruit aroma, strong hoptaste with long aftertaste, also Deliciously Dangerous! :-) i used to drink it regularly, 4 or 5 a night, i don’t do that anymore.. ;-)
11.2 oz bottle which poured a cloudy blond.The nose was on the mild side, some fruit and yeast were evident. Nicely carbonated beer, with a mild flavor and a long dry somewhat peppery  finish

Bottle.  Yellowish golden that is semi-hazy with a nice white head.  I can tell this has a lot of carbonation already.  Aroma of belgian yeast with some sweet light fruit.  Lots of fizzy carbonation yet very smooth and drinkable.  Good stuff.

Beer 500 for me; bottle...  Poured a hazy orange with a thick white head that lasted throughout the whole drink.  Aroma was bread like with a nice alcohol presence and fruity esters.  Palate was pretty wild that started off mellow and then attacked the tongue towards the finish.  Flavors of complex citrus like spices with yeast, alcohol and some tangy hops in the background.

Bottle. Hazy golden straw colour with slight white head. Excellent aroma; complex and hard to define but combines a sweet fruitness with some hints of bread, hops and spices. Full bodied with excellent carbonation giving a frothy / mousse feeling on the tongue. Excellent and complex flavour. Starts with sweetish caramel malt and soem refreshing fruity tastes and quickly develops into a much richer set of flavours (including dark chocolate and spices) with a long rich and somewhat bitter finish. An excellent beer, but not one for every day.
A VERY GOOD TRIPLE HAS A VERY COMPLEX TASTE. I REALLY LIKE THIS ONE AND ITS $8.99 PRICE TAG FOR A 750 MILLILITER MAKE IT A GREAT BARGAIN.

Golden body with rocky blond head. Slightly sour aroma, sharp and acidic. Effervescent mouthfull. The alcohol is there but not as prominent as the ABV would suggest. Fairly spicy...bit difficult to identify clove or pepper, but spice is there. Quite enjoyable beer. Refreshing and sneaks up on you with its potency.
Bottled as shown. Pours to nice cloudy golden body.  Strong aroma of fruit.  Alcohol taste is present but not pervasive.  Good beer

My trappist favorite. Malty yet dry enough to enjoy, alcohol is well hidden. Hoppy with a copper color and spicy-fruit esters. Complexity grows as it warms. A near perfect effort. You will not be disappointed.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2009 Classic Trappist ale, 
Full strong slightly sweet taste, fruity aroma with fully lasting palate,
wonderful beer, one of my favourites.

Bottle as shown. Pours a cloudy golden color with a large frothy white head that lasts awhile and then leaves behind very sticky lacing on the glass. The aroma is floral hops and banana. The taste is a very dry citrus and the alcohol is very present with this one. A complex abbey tripel from Westmalle.

After the cheepbeerday i have this...Fantastic, complex beer! Delicious appearance with a hazy golden color and a nice white and stable head. The nose is spicey about coriander, liqueric alcohol perfume, tons of fine hops. The taste is complex like the body with a high gravity with spicey flavor, strong and good balanced hops like the high percentage alcohol:liqueric but moderated, not owrepowered. Smooth but powerful character, dry taste on the palate, nice dry aftertaste.Yum! Please, give me some more!
Pours a hazy straw color with alot of carbonation. Aroma is nice and clean, very fresh. Taste is rather dry with some nice spice flavor. I really enjoyed this brew and also had nice aftertaste.

Ester profile is unlike more widely distributed Trappist high gravity beers.  Westmalle yeast seems to have a reduced rotten-garbage-banana smell and increased fresh fruit aromas, maybe grape, maybe a small share of bubble-gum.  Taste is refreshingly dry without being astringent.  Nice hops in the finish.  Definitely my favorite Trappist ale.

Wicked, wicked dry tripel.  pleasant bubbliness or nice sugar notes at all.  Big crazy belgian head of white dense froth.  Looked very cloudy and suspiciously dead yellow.  Smelled of strong grains and stale crackers.  Tasted like licking the inside of a grain silo, with overpowering raw grain and minerally taste and aftertaste and super dry, need some chapstick finish.  If this were the only beer around, I’d be drinkin water.  Sorry guys

11.2 oz bottle.  Bubblegum, alcohol, straw, interesting aroma, but I’m not into it.  Ridiculously big, jumping out of the bottle, white bubbly head, very opaque, orange-blonde color, lot of particulate.  Flavor steps the experience up a bit, pretty nice hoppy, citrus, some spice, grass, fairly wet finish, sweet and light belgian style malt in the middle, some alcohol at the start, medium body, I really like the finish.  Was not appealing at first, but it grew on me, still not one of my favorites though.

Pours a solid, opaque-hazy orange. Very large and bold head. Citrus dominates the aromas as well as hints of flowering hops. Flavor has a nice balance of sweet and spices and tastes of orange peel. Finish is rather strong. Very solid Tripel though, however, I prefer St. Bernardus’

Starts with that nostalgic and pleasant aroma of banana and mixed fruit baby food, with a less banana and lighter overall than most of this variety I have experienced.  Had a very complex flavor that makes me want to try again, some spice and also a bit of scotch whiskey.  It was also a bit sour for my tastes and this lowered the score, but it may have been just this bottle so must try again.
33cl, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex Trappist, cloudy, small head, good brew, but not a topper
A very nice brew, poured on draft in Brussels. Cloudy golden with a retiring cream head. Tastes of crisp wheat, a bit of banana, shrp citrus, and a nicely biting yeastiness.
Golden colour, thick white head. Aroma of fruits, alcohol, some spice and yeast. Taste is fruity, spicy, alchohol, citrus. Never too sweet, really smooth, highly drinkable tripel. One of the best.

Certainly one of the worlds great beers.  MJ recommends a bit of age and I am certainly in agreement with the man.  The assertive banana of youth rounds out to incorporate more orange, apricot and spice, sometimes some other citrus flavours, honey and more spicy hops.  I think it is a hugely complex beer.  There are a wealth of different notes coming from each ingredient and it all comes together extremely well. A refreshing quality alongside a sipping quality.  Excellent carbonation.  The beer is truly alive!

Pours a cloudy golden orange color with a moderate white head that lasts and leaves good lacing.  Aroma is honey, dried cherries and yeast.  Flavor is complex, with citrus to go along with bread and sweet fruits.  For such a high ABV, it really masks the alcohol well.  Finish is fantastic, as the alcohol dissipates and leaves a spicy but smooth aftertaste.

A lot more concentrated compared to the Dubbel.  Aroma is complex with dark mixed dried fruit and malts, yeast and wheat bread.  Appearance is elegant and bubbles like champagne, not a typical beer head.  Flavor is strong as the aromas and the palate is crisp and acidic like brut bubbly.  A great beer, no doubt, but I’m new to tripels and dubbel so hard for me to quantify at this time. I’ll have to revisit later.
It gets a 4.9 from me only if I ever come across a beer that is better than this one. It was expensive at over $4 a bottle! But man was it worth the price tag. Best beer I’ve had so far.
Orange with creamy white head. Flowery, peppery, yeasty. Sweet flavour, spicy, toward a bitter dry end. A bit alcoholic if not aged properly.
The best beer I have tasted to date, other than a rather strange aroma I couldn’t quite place, it’s perfect!
Bottle. Hazy yellow-orange color with a medium head. Yeasty aroma with notes of stone fruit and spice. Grassy, fruity taste with a hint of caramel. Very dry, lively effervescence. Medium body.

I figured it was time to revisit this gem, and my old rating was worthless, so off it goes...Pours a brilliant gold with a well sustained pillowy fluffy head.  Smells of fruit, dry maly, touches of cookie dough, spice, pepper, a hint of ginger.  Tastes of dry malt with a touch of complimentary warming alcohol.  Lots of floral hints, notes of grass and hay, touches of spice, a nice earthiness are all present as this one warms.  Mouthfeel is tingly and waxy.  Finish yields lots of refreshing dryness and a grassy hint.  This is the standard by which I compare all other tripels.  A true gem of a beer.

Foamy, offwhite head with lively action. Pale golden in color. Nose of honey, golden raisins, spice and alcohol. A very pleasant taste once it warms up a bit. It was a little too cold to start out and it left a bitter aftertaste. Four sips in, and I was loving every minute of it.

Fruity aromas, hints of bananas, and soft citrus, with a lot spice.  Pours blonde with a thick white head.  Fruity up front, sweet citrus, some honey, with a big dryness that follows and a very spicy finish!
Great tripel. Pours a very appealing golden colour, with typical tripel sweet-bitterness. Honey nose, and round on the palate.

What does tripel mean? Three kinds of yeast, or three times the foam? The first so it must be the best, right? Golden ale, numerous small bits of suspended sediment. White foam head, lasts 5 minutes at least. Apple, yeasty aroma. Good rounded out flavor of middle of the road sugars, malt, hops, and yeast. The yeast doesn’t dominate in this one like in most Belgians. The palate is refreshing but a little bitter.
Bottle.  Pours a hazy golden color with a big white head.  Aroma of spices and yeast.  Taste is similar to smell.

Bottle.  GUSHER!  Pours a cloudy light orange with a huge, thick, foamy white head that leaves nice lacing on a Westmalle glass.  Aroma of spcies (particularly clove), lemon/citrus zest, and the typical tripel skunk.  Tastes like...a tripel!  Lots of Belgian yeast and spices, maybe some cinnamon.  As the beer warms some light fruits (especially apple) come out, but you really have to search for it.  Mostly the beer is dominated by spices.  Pretty drinkable as the 9.5% isn’t noticed in the flavor or palate.  Probably my favorite tripel, although this style is one of my least favorite.

Westmalle Tripel is a cloudy dim golden ale with many big particles and a huge lumpy, foamy white head that leaves nice lacing on the glass.  It has a spicy barnyard aroma.  It smells like a saison to me.  There are hints of fruit and possibly licorice and hay.  It is medium bodied, a bit foamy, very smooth and the finish is clean.  The flavor is peppery and leathery.  It is spicy like clove and coriander.  There is a grassy aspect to the taste.  The flavors are very well blended.  It’s a solid Tripel, but I was expecting something to knock my socks off.

Not really impressed.  Cloudy yellow with a moderate head.  Aroma is citrus, spices, wheat malt.  Taste has a bitterness that does not really compliment the malt.  It is drinkable but I expected more.

Pretty good. Complex, extremely full bodied flavor. Very spicey with some yeast and citrus fruitiness. Nice bitterness all through the taste. Alcohol and hops show up slightly in the finish. Highly drinkable. Highly carbonated, large head.
11.2 oz. bottle.  Pours a hazy orange/yellow, with a thick long lasting head.  Citrusy with some slight spice notes....you can definitely taste the yeast with this one as well.

12oz bottle. Pours a nasty hazy orange with floaties. Huge long lasting white head. Nose of spice, alcohol and yeast. Flavor is ridiculously bitter. Very unbalanced. Tons of alcohol in there thats not hidden at all. An overated beer if I ever saw one, and probably one of the worst tripels Ive ever had, and Ive had alot.

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2008 Appearance: Light golden, a bit cloudy.
Aroma: Fruity, citric.
Taste: Tangy, strong, not good.
Info: 330ml bottle, 30/8-2005, 6/300, 3/500

This is a great Tripel.  It pours a golden cloudy yellow color with a tiny white head.  It has notes of caramel and apple in the aroma with yeast as well.  Sweet and tangy in the taste, this is a good tripel, no surprises as it finishes dry, but with a twinge of apple.

330ml bottle, 06/04/07 is date on label.  Pours a clear golden with a nice bright white two finger head, minimal lacing.  Aroma is a nice blend of fruits and light spice, with some fresh dough, and candied fruits.  Flavor is more of the same, and reminds me of a tempered down Stille Nacht in some ways.  Not bad, but not very exciting and pretty tame.  Guess I was hoping for a little more intensity and complexity in this one, but maybe I just dont get this style...

Bottle, and wow.  Nice cloudy gold color with a good white colored head.  Aroma is malty and fruity and yeasty for sure.  Flavor is just beautiful.  Some sweetness, spice and more yeast on the palate.  Wow.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2008 0.33l bottle into trappist glass.  Pour hazy gold with foamy pure white head.

Smell hops, wheat, grass. Thick mouthfeel.  Taste is similar to smell with strong hops and alcohol finish.

Very enjoyable tripel.

Poured with a thick white head and hazy golden color.  Strong citrus aroma.  Aroma, flavor and palate combined to make me think of orange peels.  Carbonated feel on the tongue with a tinge of an alcohol after taste.

Aroma is much simpler than the taste. Slightly fruity/lemony with a nice simple malt background. This is beer is very flavorful. Tastes very sugary like candied nuts mixed with fruit candy (watermelon, strawberry, and bit of lemon). Some alcohol comes through here. However, the palate is surprisingly dry and crisp and the finish is nice and clean with a good amount of bitterness. Very flavorful and tasty, but its almost too much, especially for something so dry and crisp. Carbonation is nice and the body is right on, but again, the palate doesnt match the beer.

Bottle into chalice. Pours cloudy gold, with a massive, pillowy white head. Aroma is candied sugar, spicy yeast, some citrus. taste is candy sweetness, beautifully spicy yeast, overripe fruit and a yeasty, alcohol bitterness. Finish carries a clean bitterness, spicy sweetness, rich fruitiness. Sticky, but with a crisp carbonation. beautifully complex, yet balanced. Superb.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2009 Cloudy golden with floating sediment and thick white foamy cream head that lightly laces as it thins. Yeasty citrus aroma. Bubbly, crisp yet smooth, bitter alcohol yeast. Reminds me of a harsher Duvel. Clean aftertaste. Gets better as it warms.

Good looking hazy orange beer with a nice big white head. Aroma is very spicy, where hints of oranges, yeast and some spices are most apparent. First thing that hits you when drinking this is the very apparent alcohol. Unfortunately it feels a bit like theyve chosen to go with a higher alcohol presence than hops here. Not one of my favorite tripels exactly. Very good beer for smelling and looking at though...

Cloudy golden brown with good, creamy white head / Skunky nose of sour bananas / Medium to full body, sweet and moderately thick malts, with fair finish / Flavors of musty, skunky fruit with caramel and spice notes / Not at all in character for a tripel - bad bottle?
330 ml bottle. orange golden colour. big white head, quickly fading. citrus taste wih alcohol.

Hazy yellow with medium white quickly dissipating head and particulates floating in the body. Aroma of ripe fruit, citrus, banana and orange.  Taste of ripe fruit, mild alcohol, mild citrus and sugar.  Finish is fruity and mildly chalky and oily and a bit sticky.  Good but not great.

Amazing triple.  So smooth and delicous.  The pour had an off white head that was very thick.  there was plenty of sediment in the golden hazy body.  The aroma was sweet, full of citrus, wheat, and malt.  The flavor was fruits (citrus), wheat, and alc.  Very bubbly.  Great beer though.
Pours a hazey yellow body, with a medium sized white head that is full of sweet floral aromas. It starts off semi dry and finishes with a sweet toffe flavored flavor.

Bottle poured a clear gold with a large lasting white head. Aromas of straw, pear, spice and light banana. Palate was light bodied and crisp. Flavors of straw, spice and pear with a crisp bittersweet finish.

Vinous sweet pear with some vanilla spice on the nose.  Deep gold color, hints of orange, slight haze and huge long-lasting head with great lacing.  Honey soaked pear, some white rum notes, deep balancing bitterness, some tart/sourness too.  Full body, delicate but huge carbonation.  Alcohol is very present, but the complexity of this beer carries the package nicely into a long finish.  A must try!

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2009 hazy orange with white head.  very fruity and spicy on the nose.  ARoma is what distinguishes it from some other tripels.  Fuity and vanilla flavour,  alcohol nicely hidden.  Overall a nice enough beer but Im not a huge fan of tripel so I didnt find it anything to get  super excited about.  (tasting with leffe tripel and bornem tripel, this one had best nose and most complex flavour by far)

The beer pours a hazy orange yellow with a thick head that hangs around for a while. The nose is a mix a roasted fruits pithy orange zest coriander, yeast, malts and you can feel the alcohol and your eyes. The nose and taste are right in step with each other; with the addition of alcohol. I think this beer will lay down well for a few years maybe smooth out the alcohol. Not the best beer ever but it is easy to get in my  market and thus will become my go to beer

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2008 I dont think I have rated a beer this high before.  Excellent flavor, aroma, texture, you name it, its got it.  I was becoming a Chimay snob, but no longer.  I have found a new winner.  The texture is very smooth for the ABV, and the aroma will make you want to grab a tobacco pipe and sit by the fire and read Chaucer. Very elegant!

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2008 Dry, woody, fruity, sparkling hops. Mild malt, yeasty, alcohol. Candy sugar. Dark baked apples, effervescent. Not as good as other Belgian beers...I knew it, must be why I avoided it for yrs. Not bad, just not as great as others.

11.2 ounce bottle in Westmalle goblet.  Pale hazy golden orange with thick white head and full lace.  Vanilla and lemon grass aroma with very faint alcohol.  Sweet vanilla honey candy sugar peach apricot fruitiness.  Assertive peppery spicy hoppy dry finish.  Medium body and carbo.  Pretty much perfect.

I am not a big fan of Belgian beers but after seeing the rating and description that Draft magazine gave it I figured it was worth throwing down the dough.  Though this is not my favorite style this was easily recognized as a fine brew.  What I noticed most was how smooth it was.  Big fizzy head and the smell wow!  what a nice one.
A very good beer.  Rich smell and taste, goes down smooth.  This is worth the price that it is.

light colouring for a Tripel. Aroma of sweet yet spicy banana. Pallet almost Caramel with a clean crisp finish. I must confess. This is not my favourite Tripel but would still happily drink this anyday of the week and twice on the weekend.

Aroma of banna nut bread like yeast and candied sugars.  Huge white lacing head sits atop a dark orange or apple cider like body.  Just the right amount of hops to keep the taste away from oversweet or overdry.  Well concealed ABV.  Very good indeed.
The aroma contained yeast and undertermined flavors. The appearance was amber, cloudy with a frothy head.  Full body with medium bitterness.
Wonderfully thick and chunky head. Mildly spicy and slightly grassy aroma. Very solid mouthfeel . Malty, light caramel, slight clove with a rasin and spice finish. A
UPDATED: MAY 22, 2008 Bottle. Yellow/orange color. Smells of yeast,spice and som fruit. Flavor is orange and som other fruits. Finish is really dry.

Cloudy light-orange color.  Appearance reminds me of a hefeweizen.  Smells of yeast and spice.  At first sip: heavy corriander and spices.  Lemon, too... maybe.  Effervescent.  So dry it resembles a champagne.

The head is huge, I had to pour in segments because the head is so over the top. White pillowy head sits nicely over a golden yellow beer with a lot of yeast sediment floating about. Lacing is also nice. Smell is spicy, hops, coriander, bananas, cinnamon and maybe a little alcohol. Taste is a little more boozy than I was expecting from the head, somewhat astringent, and then the spices hit you. The dubbel is better, not that this is bad by any stretch.

330 ml bottle from the LCBO. pours golden with lots of yeasty sedimant floaties. spicy belgian yeast triple aromas. spicy belgian yeast triple flavours. some hops in the flavour and a dryer finish then most triples. standard and not overwhelming. ill cellar my other bottle and review on a year or two.
Brown coloured beer with medium off white head. Malty aroma a little fruity. Full palate. Malty and bitter ending some alcoholic touches. I liked this one.

12oz bottle purchased from LCBO in Toronto.  Pours a nice cloudy light gold with some rougher dark floaties.  Nice yeasty aroma.  The first taste has an initial yeastiness that quickly moves to a warming mouthfeel.  The flavour is full and rich.  The alcohol warmth is the main quality to this one, along with some associated spiciness.

Good beer but nothing impressive, Great white head pretty orange gold yellow color. There is a orange citrus yeasty spice taste to it and the alcohol stands out as well. ok palate. this is a overall good beer.

33cl bottle, superbest. good aroma, looks nice with sizable white head, strong solid taste. some soapy undertones (or not - ive been cleaning my old apartment for hours, perhaps its me who smells like soap), average to good palate, Overall a nice beer, but i sort of miss something to get really excited about. After it had heated up a bit it got markedly better, so i adusted palate and overall. 8-14 celc. is indeed the range.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2009 Pours a bright golden yellow color. Active carbonation throughout the session.  Aromas of hops, fruit, and a little yeast.  Has a light fruity citrus taste, with some yeasty notes, and a good hop flavor.  This is hands down the best Abbey Tripel on the market, the absolute benchmark!!!

33cl bottle from Beers of Europe. A golden-tinged orange colour with plenty of lively carbonation and a massive dense white head. Spicy hop aromas with some herbs, orange and yeast and an alcohol backbone. Plenty of flavourful spice with a sweet counterpart. Touches of the fruity, herbal character thats in the aroma comes through in the taste. The alcohol content definitely announces itself in abundance but never becomes overpowering. Thick, spicy and warming on the palate.

Really great Tripel.  Pour was light golden with very long lasting thick white head.  Aroma of spice(coriander and orange peal), fruity esters, and malt.  Body was medium light due to beat sugar.  Alcohol is not very noticeable.  Nice citrus and dry finish.  Good trappist.  Would buy again.

Bottle.  Pours a lovely, bubbly, hazy orange body with fluffly white head.  Aroma of orange, apricot, yeast, and grain.  Nice light, biscuit flavor with citrusy hops, clove, and honey.  The finish is clean with a pepper bite.  Faint alcohol burn on the aftertaste.  Lively, light oil/syrup mouthfeel.

Bottle.

The pour produced a huge, thick, foamy, white head and a a beautiful dark amber body. Its spicy aroma washed down well with a slightly bitter taste full of hops.  Its 9.5% was nicely hidden.  

Well done!

Poured a hazy dark golden color with a puffy well formed cap. The nose was intense with clove, orange peel,and spiced cider. The taste begins smooth yet peppery then soon transforms to coriander notes. The finish shifts gears yet again to more of a bitter and biscut flavor. This is one strong beer but none the less very drinkable and very tasty.

Bottle in Amsterdam (of all places).  This was my first ever experience with Belgian beers, and it drew me in.  I remember ordering it because it had such a high alcohol content, and then when it came, trying it, and thinking, wow, this is remarkably good!

The bottle poured deep honey color with dissipating white head. Incredible suspension of yeast. It smells kind of like an orange sweet roll. The flavor is remarkably balanced. Nothing standing out, with a mild bitter finish, but still sweat. Kind of a syrupy palate with soft carb. Its good.

Poured from the bottle into a trappist glass. Nose was dry and sweet. Not a whole lot of head on this at all, so I guess I must have poured it wrong. What little head there was still left really nice legs throughout. Taste was sweet, apple-y and overall not very unique. Tastes like any other classy white to me. Not to say its bad! I liked it very much. Pretty carbonated sharp mouthfeel. Still, it needs a little something more to it.

"Sweet Nectar of the Gods!!" 

Poured from a 750 ml bottle into a snifter. 

Inch tall, foamy head with great lacing. Beautiful golden color. 

Aroma was not overpowering; nicely balanced, yeasty, apples, pears. 

Perfect taste. Perfectly balanced hops, yeast and malt. Nothing overpowering, but everything balanced. High ABV well hidden. 

Light carbonation, not too thick. Clean palate and no aftertaste. 

This is one of the best beers Ive ever had!!! I would give it a 5 for drinkability, however the high ABV would sneak up on you.

Cloudy golden color with lots of yeast.  Spicy bready aroma.  Flavor is the same.  Bit of alcohol comes through at the end.  Overall a very nice belgian ale although not quite on the level of some others.
On draught at Elfde Gebode. Pours a near opaque dark brown with a lasting tan head. Very soft mouthfeel, early slight hop bitterness followed by dry dark malty flavors.

De mémoire. Couleur dorée avec un voile moyen. Mousse abondante qui réduit doucement en une superbe dentelle. Belle vivacité, il y avait un fantastique tourbillon de bulles. Parfum anisé, citronné, de gingembre. Goût fantastique, rehaussé dun alcool puissant, épicé, chaud. 
Bière extraordinaire. Jai hâte de faire une dégustation plus « étudiée ».
Very soft and drinkable. Subtle and well-balanced spicing, very well hidden alcohol.  Drink no colder than cool, I enjoyed it more even above their recommended temp.

Pours hazy golden yellow with a frothy white head.  Doughy and yeasty in the aroma with a presence of spices.  Flavor is excellent.  The spices and alcohol combine to just give this burn.  Its quite sugary-sweet.  Finishes extra dry with lots of carbonation.  Quite tasty brew and will buy again.
Thin frothy head, the spice does come through. A mild alcohol flavour, slightly bitter.
Hazy orange/yellow with a white head and lots of suspended sediment. Medium body and carb. Frothy mouth feel. Malty, with citrus  and a wee bit spicy. Alcohol shines through. Slightly dry finish.

Cloudy orange yellow with big chunks of sediment and a thin slightly off-white head. Some lacing. Medium bodied with fairly average carbonation. Moderately bitter. Spicy and malty. Alcohol comes through in the flavour and the nice  dry finish. 330ml bottle.

This one poured a golden orange color with medium sized foamy white head that left swirly lacing around the glass. The aroma was of oranges, citrus fruit, spices, candy sugar, and a hint of alcohol. The taste was much the same with the citrus fruit and candy sugar sweetness coming forward and then balanced out with the spices. The mouthfeel was medium bodied and almost creamy with a sweet boozy finish to it. You could tell this one was strong from the beginning, but the alcohol just added to the sweetness. This was a really well done tripel.

Bottle.
Pours hazy blonde with a thick white head but it doesnt last very long.
Aroma is fruity, sharp & spicy. Maybe a bit yeasty and it will probably depend on how much yeast you leave on the bottom.
Its very drinkable and has a dry bitter aftertaste. The warmer you drink it, the warmer it will leave your throath behind after every sip. Carbonation is average and the aroma is not very complex. Just had a piraat before this and would prefer the piraat even thought they are quite different.

Pours a peach, orange, perhaps I could call it grapefruit color. Moderate head that tapers off pretty quickly. About a quarter of the way through just a patchy head remains that does produce some lacing. The aroma is pleasant consisting of fruits, some of the sweeter ones such as oranges and some nice yeast. Semi tangy citrus flavor, yeasty and extremely easy drinking. Theres almost a clean watery note mixed in with the fruits. Nice amount of flavor but Im looking for just a little more. Perhaps Im being picky as I recently sampled various brews from St. Bernardus, Chimay and Rochefort but this one does carry the same price tag. I would never have known there was 9.2% alcohol in there if I didnt look at the bottle. Quite refreshing too but if youre drinking this you arent looking for something to slug down while sitting in the sun. As the beer warms it becomes a little more spicy with a sour grapefruit flavor and a banana note I didnt detect earlier but still, I can hardly taste the alcohol. This is a great beer but it didnt wow me.
Bottle. Pours hazy rich straw with white head. Nice spicy fruit aroma with good yeast. Spicy, slightly sweet flavor. Very good tripel.
Pale orange that appears hazy with a large head. Spicy aroma, very yeasty. The flavour is a nice balance between sweet and spicy malts and alcohol. Nice hop bitterness to the finish.
Bottle in house. cereal, toast, resin, golden, hazy,  frothy, light sweetness, light body, average carbonation,
93 cents at a supermarket in Amsterdam, what a deal! Really nice Belgain tripel with well hidden high alcohol content and light, fluffy mouthfeel. Refreshing and smooth.

Pours a gorgeous and very cloudy orange. This is not exceptionally carbonated and I needed to pour it straight into the glass from some height to achieve a decent, billowing head. This head left some nice Belgian lace, however for the most part disappeared within a minute. Has a pleasing sweet aroma, which I sense includes the smell of caramel and peaches. Taste is, as noted above, not very carbonated, but has a long finish. Slightly bitter and alcoholic. Overall, comparable to Orval, but I prefer that to this. Definitely good, though.

Bottle conditioned, aged 7yrs plus. Clear gold, white head but with big lumps of yeast. Another beer I have tried to age deliberately to try and calm down the spice, it hasent really worked with this though, the alcohol has developed but the spice remains, quite harsh really. Bitter and full, but lacking the subtleties of some Tripels. Not quite the great beer that it could be.

Golden, a bit hazy and with a large head. Aroma slightly fruity and spicy. Has a full body, slightly sweet. The alcohol can be felt in the throat and the after taste is long with some bitterness. The alcohol is though, to over whelming in my opinion.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2008 Carbonation that reminds me of unibroue with slight notes of champagne (perhaps due to the rich carbonation and dry finish).  Not too much to brag about in terms of aroma or pour - but so is the case for the majority of trips.  Taste and Palate are exceptional.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2011 What is it, the queen, king or the emperor of the tripels. I dont know, But it is one of the best tripels and maybe the standard of them. Its a golden beer. A little hazy with a thick foamed white head. Very nice aromas of malt, yeast, flowers and nice fruits like orange. The taste has also fruits like orange and some citrus, with in the back a malty taste and a nice bitternes. Its a great beer and always a feast to drink it.
murky gold with a snappy white head.  Citrus and yeast aroma.  Flavor is syrupy citrus,  yeast, some spice,  banana,  clove.  Finish was very carbonated,  no hint of alcohol,  clean.

Fredagsbaren på biologi, Aarhus
Bottled - on tap somewhere in Aarhus
Beatifull colour and head. Smells of citrus and lots of yeast. Carbonation is high and so is the alcohol flavor

11.2oz bottle.  Pours copper/orange, with frothy off-white head.  Head lasts a while, and leaves light lacing.  Aroma of citrus, smoke, and light hops.  Taste is lightly sweet and moderately acidic, and finishes a bit bitter.  Light to medium body, dry texture, and soft carbonation.  Lighter and more quenching than some other trappist ales.  Very good!

Bottle pours a cloudy golden clover honey color with a slight white head.  Aroma includes citrus peel, honey, yeast, and spices.  Has a sweet dry flavor that reminds me of white wine.  Nice aftertaste. Lively carbonation.

330mL bottle from the LCBO.  Pours a hazy, dark gold with a big, coarse head.  Very rich aroma, notes of lemon and banana.  Rich, deep flavour.  Mild spice up front, with thick malt at the centre.  Sweet finish, with a touch of herbal hops at the end.  Doesnt have the astringency of a Chimay White.  Excellent.

(33cl bottle, BBE 12/2007). Hazy golden yellow, lacing white head. Nose is fresh with honey, fruits and some wheat. A bit mineral tinge. Flavor has strong exotic fruits (banana, orange, mango), spices and some alcohol. Finishes chalky dry with perfumey hops and faint vinous tartness. Medium to full bodied, smooth and foamy carbonation. Nicely fruity, shows its ABV, but not disturbingly. I guess some bottle age has done the trick.
UPDATED: SEP 21, 2008 Fantastic tripel from Westmalle me la bevo e mi rilasso pensando a Marco Attilio Regolo e Lucio Manlio Volsone che sbarcano in Africa (al Capo Bon) nel 256 a.C.

Hazy golden with a dense head. Spicy aroma with notes of coriander 
citrus, straw, orange peels and yeast. The flavour is sweet and has a bit of vanilla and a fresh bitternes to complete the spicy base. Unfurtunately the alchohol is too present.

Pours a hazy gold with abundant white head.  Smells of fruits and spice.  Taste is spices with a bitter component on the back of the tounge.  I preferred the Double over this, but it is still a fine beer.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2009 Bottle from Regionals, which has been sitting in my cellar for a while.
Pours hazy orange/golden, a bit of sediment and a filmy lingering white head.
A massively herbacious nose, with the characteristic coriander. Big fruit, orange peel, cloves, quite sweet overall. The perfect Tripel aroma. 
Flavour is just a huge as aroma. Mouthfilling and perfectly balanced. Corriander and candy sugar dominate the palate. Some clove spice and a strong bitterness balance the flavour perfectly. The finish is mildly dry, with a fair amount of candi sugar sweetness. 
This is my favourite beer, and every bottle I have reaffirms why.

Bottled. Pours cloudy dark yellow, with a lacy white head. Nose is yeast, lemon, pears, spices. Flavor is pears, lemongrass, spices, soft malt. Finish is lightly bitter with some gentle alcohol notes. Mouthfeel was softly carbonated.
33CL bottle, a nice triple one of the easiest triples to get in Holland. Nice golden yellow color, nice white head medium bitterness, medium body, sticky, average carbonation, astringent,

Pours with a very large thick fluffy white head that persists.  Color is hazy bright yellow/amber.  Nose is sweat and bready.  Flavor is fruity and distinctly like white wine with malty undertones.  Finish is malty, like malted milk.

Bottle. The beer smells nice like bread and wine, a little bit later the malt shines through. The head is big, white and creamy, it stays long. The body is dark yellow. It started light sour like wine, later on it gets mire bitter. You dont feel the alcohol in it. The body is medium, creamy and oily whit a soft carbonation. Really a great beer!
Bottle. Pours a hazy orange colour with a white head. Aroma is  (Seville) oranges and loads of yeast and herbs. Flavour is sweet and round with loads of yeast and herbs also some oranges and alcohol.

Bottle: Pours yellow, slightly hazy, little crudniks drifting around. Thick pale tan yellow head. Nice lacing. Aromas of hops, yeast, "beer". Interesting sweet-sour taste up front, with just the right amount of bitter at the end. Rich n chewy, but not heavy either. Good stuff, real good.

Thick, creamy head.
Serious alcoholic aroma, spicy alcoholic flavor.  Some light malty notes.  Almost no aroma.

33cl bottle purchased from Willow Bend Liquors (FL). Pours a cloudy butterscotch color with a thick, creamy white one finger head. Nose: Hints of citrus, faint sweetness, grains, bread, spices. Flavor: Smooth, medium-bodied with hints of bread, yeast, flour with a slight citrus finish. Lively carbonation. Nice tripel.

330 mL bottle.  (BB 15/10/09)  Hazy/yeasty peach-orange in colour, with a medium, sticky, thick, white head.  The aroma is grassy, wine spritzer, noble hops, and tangy fruit.  The flavour is complex as well: spice/herb, yeast, alcohol, pilsner malt, green apple, hops.  Full and dry.  Not as great as I thought itd be, to be honest.
Classic Tripel. Pours gold with a little copper, thick head. Complex with malty sweetness, and spices cardamom, cloves and bread. The alcolhol is noticeable but not overbearing. Good stuff.
Drank it with Juancho at the Ginger Man in NYC.  Pours beautiful golden color, with a white head.  Spicey, and full flavored.  Let it breathe for several minutes

Bottle poured into a Duvel tulip. What greeted me was a nice finger worth of head that turned into a thick layer of lace on top of a beautiful hazy (small particles float around) yellowish orange body.

Aromas of fruit, bread yeast, hops and a light alcohol whiff 

Flavors are citric and spicy with a little alcohol warmth in the end

Good carbonation on the tongue

A great drink for a good meal. A little to much alcohol to drink a lot of these but highly drinkable

33cl bottle, 9.5% a/v

Pours a deep murky gold colour with a very nice light and fluffy head, which laces very readily. The aroma is complex and largely spicy. There are also some small caramel malt notes as well as apricots and a bit floral. The taste is spicy, and bitter, which a boozy feeling as well. A strange punch in the mouth at first but the taste grows on you. The beer has a very full mouthfeel as well, and playful carbonation dancing on the tongue.

33cl bottle, bought in NL.
Strong foamy head over a clear, bubbly, light- golden colour.
Hints of cardamom and cumin over a sweet somewhat citric, almost orangy smell. Some yeastiness.
Bitter-sour flavour with some sweetness and a hint of saltiness.
The palate is dry and especially salty in the aftertaste. Hints of liquorice and spices with a rather bitter finish.
pour clear amber. short lasting head. sharp first taste which soon changes to  bitter but then has a lasting sweet spicy effect.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2008 Bottle. Pours a hazy golden color with a thick bubbly head that stays until you are done and leaves tons of lacing around the glass. Aroma is that of spices, yeast, and fruit. It almost smells like a loaf of fruit bread before you bake it. The taste isnt what I was expecting, its dry and refreshing with more to the spice end than the fruit side of things and only a hint of alcohol. I wasnt really into it upon first taste but as my glass went on I began to think this is one fine beer. Above all else it was the aftertaste that sold me on this beer, so clean and refreshing not that sludgy thickness that some tripels can leave you with.

Bottle.  Hazy, golden color with a thick, nearly-white head that is slow to dissipate.  Yeasty aromas with herbal and floral notes, specifically anise and grass.  Pow!  Being my first tripel, this is not what I expected at all!  Great mouthfeel with wonderful carbonation.  Citrusy and spicy, the anise I smelled really comes out on the finish with an unexpected bitterness.  Im sold.

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2009 330ml bottle from the LCBO. Pours the classic triple look with the huge white head. Aroma is a little different, a lot more fruity esters than usual, with loads of Belgian yeasty character to it, topped off with actual hops which Im not used to in Tripels, and a sour touch. Flavours are pretty good, better than I was worried they were going to be. All of the above, with a great malty-ness in the finish and aftertaste. This is a really nice, classic Tripel, with everything you could possibly want in one (I guess since its the original). I cant wait to try this again in a few years when its had time to mellow and evolve.

Yeast in bottom of bottle.  Thick head, hazy cloudy dark yellow.  Spicy nose, with bread dough.  Creamy palate, assertive sharp taste.  More spiciness in the palate, coriander I presume?  Oranges, tang, really good for a tripel.

A good brew. Pours a murky golden yellow with a big white lightly sticky head. The aroma is a standard mix of spice, yeast, and citrus. The flavour is a touch sweet, lots of spice, a good but unusual black licorice back bone, finishes with a touch of orange zest. A foamy mouthfeel with a dry alcohol finish. Different, but on par with Chimays version of this brew. All and all a tasty beverage.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2008 This is a very nice abbey tripel, tasty and complex but light and easy to drink.  It is slightly cloudy gold with a very large off-white head thatis dense and lasts forever, staying quite large.  It leaves beautiful rings of creamy lacing down the glass.  Th aroma is alcoholic, fruity, zesty, flowery with hints of grape juice, grain, and banana.  The taste is a smooth alcoholic fruitiness with a bite, becoming dryish with herbalm citrus qualities and a faintly bitter hoppy-grain finish.  It is smooth and creamy but with a tingly quality as well.

Matched to a main course consisting of duck, mashed potatoe towers and fresh salad, along with La Chouffe. High amount of carbonation and a relativly clear yellow look, extremly creamy aroma along with some peach and pepper. The alchohol and sweet character stood well to the food, and overall just a great experience!
11.2 oz bottle, best by date of 18 May 2008. Pours golden in color with white head. Aroma sweet, yeasty, spicey and light fruit. Taste fruit and yeasty with very dry finish.
bottle. Hazy gold with a large frothy head. Fruity aroma, sugary yeasts. Flavor is candi sweet, green apple, spicy yeasts, heavy malts. A good tripel, but not rememberable.

Bottle. Bought in Belgian. Pours hazy light yellow and brings at first a big foamy bubbly head. Aroma is so smooth and balanced! I´t´s sweet, banana, marmalade and yeasty. Flavor is little peppry, sweet, banana and flowery. The brew feels light and fresh but is not watery at all. It´s mad with care!
Honey colored with medium persistent head. Well carbonated. Nice tripel - well hidden alcohol.

Bottle, thanks TikiE.  This beer poures a huge fine head.  The color is golden yellow.Sweet aroma of citrus.  Clean carbonation and flavor of cirtrus, spices and a little bit of hops.  There is also a good amount of yeast sediment.  Very nice, I was very impressed with this beer.
Good full head that stays on this orange hazy beer. Smells of spices and alcohol, and tastes of fruity malts and alcohol.
Bottle.  Golden pour with nice huge white head.  Aroma of bananas, bread and yeast.  Taste of malt with a slight hoppy floral finish.
Hazy golden appearance with a decent head. Citrus hop aromas. Sweet fruity taste balances well with the hop bitterness.

Has a lot going for it, nice multi-tiered complexity that draws in the floral and bitter well, though lacks a certain deliciousness that loses my interest quickly. Also, moments of the finish suggest watery elements barely masked by the bitter. Nice masked acidity and subdued caramel, however.
Gloden and cloudy in appearance with a good head.  Sweet fruity very belgian aromas.  Sweet taste with noticiable alcohol.  Medium body with some dryness.

Poured a hazy dark golden color with a white head. Aromas of fruity yeast. Flavor starts sweet and finishes dry with yeast and hops. Medium body with lively carbonation and a kind of prickly mouthfeel due to the carbonation. A very tasty tripel.

Bottle. A hazy yellow beer with a small white head. Dry hoppy aroma with hints of spices. A good balance between hops and malts in the flavor, a bit more dry and "easier" than the Westmalle Dubbel. Yeasty character through the whole experience. Bitter palate.

I am quite familiar with this lovely ale. It is a deep yellow with a creamy looking head.The nose is of pears, apples, and alcohol. 

The taste is of earthy, bright fruity malt. The hops are enough to make this a clean finishing beer. The sweetness is not cloying. The mouthfeel is one of the best I have ever encountered. It is ultra creamy and medium bodied. I have somehow put this beer down in about thirty minutes. It took no effort. I most definitely want another one.
I tasted this beer before I got my account with ratebeer, so I cant really remember all the flavors.
33 cl bottle, mild yeast and malt nose, lots of carbonation, nice flavor, some lemon on the finish, trying the dubbel next
The most carbonated of all trapists I have tried, Westmalle Tripel is a good blonde ale. With a nice appearance and a very large head, this beer feels like a champagne when being drunk.

I was checking how many of the Top 50 Widely Distributed Beers I had rated. Lo and behold, here was another one Id drunk many times without ticking. But come on, I dont rate from distant memory. So I had to go out tonight and drink a new one. Well, what do you know? Its excellent. poured golden into the goblet with a tall, white head. Pretty. Nose of oranges and spices and booze and hops. Sweetish, orange-tinged flavor rolls into a wall of bitterness, nestled around an alcoholic center. Slighty dry and bitter finish. Warming. Nice. Serious. Available as any slut, but still hot.

straw colored and hazy, only a slight white head.  not a strong nose.  flavor is tremendous with hints of candy sugar and sweet malty esters.  finishes with a nice hop balance and some very nice alcoholic complexity.  the only negative is it finishes with a little bit of a dry sourness.  overall a great tripel, one of my favorites

750ml bottle.  Pours a hazy gold with a huge frothy white head that retains well and laces the glass.

The aroma is sweet corny malts with some lightly spiced grassy hops and some alcohol.  Its almost malt liquorish.

The flavor is sweet malts with a decent grassy hop finish and some spices (coriander).  The is some noticeable alcohol in the finish and becomes pretty hot as it warms.  The mouthfeel is medium to full with decent carbonation.

Overall, Ive had much better Tripels.  This was too strong in alcohol, overly sweet, and pretty simplistic.

Aug. 2006 - Really neat appearance.  Crystal clear until the yeasties were poured in...then it was like a reverse mushroom cloud for a few minutes until the cloudiness took over.  Nice head and lacing.  Flavor is typical trippel, spices and fruity.  Really carbonated and "unsmooth" mouthfeel was a serious detractor.  Nice flavor, sweet with hoppy tart finish.
0,33 ml bottle.Sötét arany színű szép tömött habbal.Illatában érezni a komlót amit a pilseniekhez is használnak.Íze igen összetett gyümölcsös és "gyógyfüves".Valamit tudnak ezek a trappisták!

Another good Trappist brew.  Though often overrated (Trappist brews) this one is among your top choices.  Forget the Orval (unless you love hops) this is up there with Chimay.  I may even enjoy this more than Chimay on some days.............no not really because I love me some Chimay Blue.  If you havent had a Trappist because friends have said theyre not worth the price with this one you cant go wrong.

330ml bottle: pours golden light brown with a slight haze and white heade, aroma has an interesting smell to it malty but yet complex with other sweet smells. flavor is almost like orval lots of complex but suttle but with an added twist with more flavor that i like better. very well made beer i was expecting a dark beer like st.B and rochefort but this is closer to duvel and orval. would say on par with duvel and better then orval. well done.

Hazy yellow color with a rocky white head. Classic yeasty, spicy, earthy tripel aroma. Medium body and smooth. Fantastic taste same as the nose with a slight vinous, earthy flavor with nice spicy, yeasty, herbal essence. Finishes crisp and clean. An excellent Tripel .   81705
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text:
Cloudy golden pour from the distinctive 11.2 oz bottle, this triple lives up to its name with a strong alcohol note and noticeable dry finish.  However, it seem excessively carbonated. The spices hang suspended in the glass witch might add to the taste but makes the appearance a bit disquieting.  
Overall, a pleasant experience.
