750 ml bottle, marked 3/10/08. Pours a delectable honey gold with a thin but lingering mist of a head.  Nose is rich and fruity, full of honey sweetness and a scent of vanilla.  Apples and pears erupt on the tongue, along with a unique malt profile I associate with the best of the trappists.  Ends almost brackish yet lingeringly enticing, almost minty in the finish, suggesting another mouthfull.  Hops are earthy, and are present throughout.  Alcohol adds a peppery quality to the ending.  Lovely.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2012 RE: "what a spiced-up mess"... Another unappetizing tripel", etc.

??? 

Are you sure you went to the correct tasting?  I think yours was the "Better Get a Clue" one...

Sampled blind at "Better Know a Style: Abbey Tripel" tasting.  Light yellow color with slightly hazy with small white head.  Orange aroma with lots of yeast, a little spice and big alc.  Flavor is very alcy wtih earthiness, what a spiced-up mess.  Medium body and overwhelming carbonation.  Another unappetizing tripel.

Tried a bottle at this at Ashevilles newest bar:  The Thirsty Monk.  They only serve Belgian style beer.  Its a pretty impressive place.  And this was a pretty impressive beer.  The alcohol was nice, not overwhelming.  The body of the beer was light gold color, with a big, fluffy head.  The lightness of the body of these beers is always surprising.  The flavor is very fruity and flowery, with that familiar Belgian spice.

Bottle at Café Karpershoek Amsterdam. Huge white head, and dark orange/brown. Aroma and tastes of tropical fruit and spicy bitter at the end that tapers off. Great balance, and a beer ill go out of my way to drink anytime.

Bottle. Hazy golden orange. Massive white head with nice lacing. Aroma and flavor of spicy yeast mixed with abundant tropical fruits. Nice bitterness at the end. Noticeable effervescence. Warming and delicious.

Pours a hazy ornage color with a big, foamy white head.  Smells of Belgian candy sugar, some orange citrus, a little spice variation as well.  Smells like a tripel.  The taste was very similar although extrememly well balanced between the sweetness and the spice and citrus characters.  Very well done tripel, but you would expect that coming from this brewery.  Mouthfeel was pretty much perfect for this style.
Delicious! Ahh God bless the trasppistes. Nice and strong, nice head nice lace. A little citrusy and yeasty. Sweet but doesnt cloy. Nice mouthfeel, maybe a litle bite, but appropriate to the style.

Orange/yellow pour with some big bubbles and a great creamy thick off-white head.  Lots of yeast and some orange zest in the aroma. Sugary and robust, orange peel bitter, tangy yeast.  Somewhat one-dimensional for a triple, odd woody burnt bitter aftertaste.   Tastes like theres some potato vodka in it, the alcohol is showing through.   Palate is really nice, its completely different, has a whipped texture to it.
I thought this was pretty good. Golden brown with tons of sediment and a 2 finger head. A nice bouquet and light, drinkable flavour with a slightly bitter finish. Nice spice and mouth feel.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2008 GIANT sudsy/creamy white head! Yeasty orange aroma with hints of spices. Sweet flavor with presence of yeast and orange peel. The finish is dry and woody. The alcohol is evident in the taste. Pretty smooth and palatable as well. Not bad for an orange Tripel.

Yummy, yum, yum. Poured froma bottle into a trapisst. A dark pour and mine had little head. The aroma was roasty and the setup was great. The beer while one of the best was not the best. A very tasty after taste and just a plain out enjoyable beer. i wish I could afford one everyday.

33 cL bottle. Pours hazy yellow with small yeast sediments and a huge white head. Spiced, slight acidic and yeasty aroma. Flavour is the pure definition of a tripel. Smooth, spiced, slight acidic note, mild caramel malt and that yummy mellow Westmalle yeast note. All in a complex yet smooth blend - with a light bite towards the finish, just telling you that this is a 9.5% alcohol beer. Fantastic.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2009 I enjoyed this beer more than the Dubbel. Slightly weak in the nose...some sweetness/fruitiness, but nothing too prevalent. The flavor is good...slightly spicy, followed by the typical Belgian candy sugar, finished with some citrus undertones. Nice alcohol warming. Overall a decent Tripel.

An interesting trappist brew.  The Nose presented hints of honey, coriander, yeast, and alcohol.  The flavor is initially honey and sugars, followed by mellow citrus tones, and finished with just a slight alcohol warming.  Good, but not my favorite trappist.

An amazing beer.  The story I like to tell about Westmalle Tripel is that the day I drank it, I left my glass on the end table in the living room.  The next day, when I came downstairs, the lacey head had turned into almost a foam running down the glass.  Amazing.  Spicy, yet not overpowering.  Hints of orange and coriander.  Would love to drink more but at $5 a bottle, its kind of tough.  Maybe the best beer Ive ever had though.

Best Before End: 24-July-2004, Sampled: 19-November-2005Great orange coloured body, slightly amber tinted with tons of suspended particles and a great slightly off-white head that tops the beer perfectly! Aroma of wheat, yeast, coriander seed, curacao, a light spice and packed with sugars. Full-bodied; Strong alcoholic taste with yeast and wheat most noticeable. The sugars pack the beer nicely and some honey and other pit fruits seem to come up toward the end. Aftertaste shows some bitterness, but most is sweet and a bit spicey. Overall, this is a pretty good tripel for the style - definitely worth trying. I wonder what this did by aging it, but it seems to be pretty rounded and not harsh in any dimension. I sampled this 33 cL bottle purchased from Whole Foods in Vienna, Virginia about 2 years ago, sampled on the Eastern Shore of Virginia on 19-November-2005.

11.2 oz bottle.  Pours a cloudy orange with a 3 cm foamy off white head that is mostly lasting.  Aroma of bread, fruit, and spices.  Flavor is initially sweet and fruity, mostly pear and apples.  Aftertaste is a hint of spice , bananas, and a hint of alcohol.  Medium bodied, noted carbonation, great lacing, and nice level of alcohol.  More drinkable than the dubbel and worth a try.  A top Trappist pick.

pour is a hazy golden-orange with a large bubbly white head, good lacing, much carbonation.
smell of fruit, pepper, spice, bread dough, alcohol.
taste is thick, fizzy, apple, pear, grape, alcohol, end is dry and bitter.
everything is quite balance, nothing overpowers the flavor.

Golden-orange hazy beer with a big sudsy white head, leaves lacing. Aroma is spicy alcohol, light fruit/floral and yeast. Flavor is spicy, maybe some pear? and of course alcohol, but not overpowering. Finishes like a dry white wine. Reminds me of champagne more than any beer Ive had.

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2008 Pours a hazy golden color with a great creamy head and a touch of lacing.  Aroma of bananas, citrus and yeast.  Flavor is more of the same, with a touch of sweetness, and a bit of a long aftertaste.  Nice creamy medium palate.  A wonderful beer.
Bold, spicy aroma, big lingering head, sharply carnonated. Big, thick mouthfeel, A bit of alcohol heat, but good balance of sweetness/biterness.

big fruity flavor.  Banana, apple and pear.  Bready and sweet, with a candy-like quality.  Somewhat spicy.  Thick mouthfeel, but smooth palate.  Carbonation keeps it lively.  A little floral and perfumey.  Damn good beer.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2008 Poured with a very thick head that disappeared almost immediately and left little lacing. Given other comments on this beer, I suspect my glass is to blame. Color was orange-lemon, and champagne-like carbonation continually rose to the top.
Very citrusy smell - mostly orange and lemon, which also came through in the taste. A very balanced beer, the high alcohol content is not apparent - be careful.
Pleasant carbonation on the tongue, and a very soft feel.
There are better Trappists, but beyond this category, not many more pleasant drinking experiences.

Hazy yellow colour,good frothy head,nice carb,a lemon yellow colour oops!heads gone leaves good lace cover.Aroma lemon overpowering citrus hops far too much sour finish.This beer is too much like champagne for my liking.

33 cl 2 year-old sample. Golden-orange topped by a creamy head - the Westmalle glass makes the beer shine like a jewel in its case. Aroma of orange, spice, butter and a fresh note (Saaz??), a little madeira and graham cookie. More on the sweet side, finishes on citrus peels bitterness. Soft and silky texture, pretty round. The finish could be more precise, maybe this is due to aging. A classic!

The best beer in the world for me (im belgian and i live about 30km from the west vleteren abbey). You need to taste the 75cl bottle, hes some much better than the 33cl. Or you need to let the 33 rest for a few months. 
The taste is sweet, but also bitter at the end. You taste the hop, and for me thats what beer should be! n1
I likey! Thick bodied, golden deliciousness. Lots-o-head and alcohol! Watch out! Youll want more than one! Bring your designated driver!!
33 cl bottle. Clear golden color. Big white head. Spicy and yeasty aroma. Flavor is yeast.alcohol, spices, caramel malt, hops, fruit and honey. Dry and bitter finish. Strong and balanced.
very nice in the beginning but the aftertaste is quite heavy, the alcohol knocks you off! Dubbel is much better.

Golden yellow with a nice white head. First had this in large quantities in Belgium and what a drink to have a lot of! Gets you away with a mixer! Very drinkable, I like this style and I like this beer.
Cloudy yellow gold with a cream white head. Strong yeast aroma. Fruity yeasty flavor. Very drinkable.

Poured with an extremely huge creamy white head. Yellow in color with what looks like extreme carbonation. Slightly hazy. Aroma was not great, lots of malt and yeast (broth), alcohol and orange hops were the highlights. Flavor was good, ending on a bitter note with a nice warming alcohol sensation. Goes down very nicely.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2009 Bottle. Golden yellow color with fluffy head. Aroma heavy in grapes and pears, some alcohol in there. Flavor contains endless numbers of fruits, the grapes and the pears, as well as apricots, peaches, apples, lemons, oranges, then plums and getting into darker fruits as the body warms with some toffee at a warm finish. Although it was very much dominated by the fruits, the complexity and crispness of all the individual flavors made for a luscious brew, with an incredibly full, vibrant, hearty, yet alcohol-light mouthfeel for a light-colored beer of this abv. Needless to say considering my high rating, I love this beer.8-4-9-5-18/4.4Rerate 12/5/08. Bottle. Aroma of banana, pear, pepper-dominated spices, maybe some other light fruits. Flavor more in the apricot range of fruitiness, though the banana and pear remain. Big, dry, almost coarse spiciness carried by quite an ample malt base. Maybe some orange peel in there as well. Intense finish with that coarse, spicy feel. Though Im just not as enthralled with this style of beer as I was upon first rate, still world class, no doubt. 8-5-8-4-16/4.1
Hazy golden with meidum white head. Yeasty aroma with spices and oranges. Sweet flavor with yeast, coriander and orange notes. Dry and bitter finish.

Pours hazy orange with a huge, creamy white head. The aroma has tart apples and citrus, fruity sweetness, and some spice. Fruit sweetness and citric tartness, clove and bready malts make up the taste profile, with a nice finish of noble hops and spice. Medium-bodied and silky with peppery carbonation and a dry finish. This beer is wonderful and exemplary of the tripel style.

Pours a clody golden orange with a thick, foamy white head.  Pleasant aroma of grape, pear and floral alcohol.  Dry fruity taste with hints of apple, grape and pear as well as a slightly sour yet crisp alcohol finish.  Very tasty.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2008 Bottle.  Poured to a golden apricot color with aq fluffy white head,  Fizzy, medium body, cloudy.  Sweet, malt, fruit, flower, honey aroma with alcohol back-drop.  Dry & sharp with alcohol tones.  Flavorful beginning, poppy.  Medium middle, biting & fizzy.  Astringent taste with slight fruit tones.  Fast end, dry, crisp with light alcohol.  Nice & balanced but strong alcohol flavor.

Dirty yellow colour with a tinge of green at the edges of the glass and a small fizzy head.  Light hoppy aroma with a hint of plum.  Soft, carbonated mouthfeel; surprisingly slight alcohol flavor given the content and an oat-like flavor.
sampled blind at "Better Know a Style: Abbey Tripel". pours hazed pale golden white head. nose is yeasty, orange, pear, cloves. flavor of pear, musty, yeasty, dough, dry. bland, decent.

330ml bottle pours with huge foamy white head, color is golden with orange  hues. Slight citrus nose and strong banana aromas. Spiced peppery palate but well balanced, dry finish lingering bitterness. quite enjoyable.

Got this in a gift baskt for christmas and it pours a nice thick head and golden color even though it was poured into a trapist glass. The head is really sudsy and it leaves some thick laceing along the sides of the glass. The aroma is strong lemon grass and some hints of citrus hops. as you drink it the beer has a lot of carbonation mixed with orange peel and smooth lemon grass with a creamy after taste. Although it is very dry and the lemon does not last long in your mouth it wasw still a refreshing beer.

330ml bottle from Bevmo Carmel Mountain.  Brew pours a nice hazy yellow with a light orange tint.  Head was off white and big at first then, dissipated quickly. Nose of candied citrus fruits banana and some yeast.  the 9.5% was hidden very well.  Somewhat   spicy one the pallet, fairly dry as well.

Bottle.Cloudy golden pour with a big white head. Aroma is yeasty with some bread and banana. Taste was creamy and smooth with banana and spice towards the end. Very highly carbonated, but very good. Impressive.
pours a slight cloudy gold with mild white head.  sweet yeastie bread aroma.  sweet front to mild tart finish.  sweet yet mild good.

Pours a golden hazy yellow with thick creamy white head that created stiff peaks (looked like whipped egg whites).  The aroma was of yeast, banana and spice. Flavor and alcohol become more intense as the beer warms. Nice and creamy sips. I think I will be going for another.

golden yellow pour with a thick, velvety head that lasted.  My nose was filled with banana, clove, and lemon.  Definitely high on carbonation, and a bit of hops covers some of the other flavors.  Thou the banana, and clove came thru on the finish for me.  Finish was crisp, with a mix of the hops, clove, and yeast.  Quite enjoyable, definitely one ill come back to.

11.2 oz bottle.  Cloudy yellow orange with a lasting white head just short of stiff peaks.  Yeasty lemon peel nose with mild banana and peppery toasted coconut.  Buzzy carb.  Chewy and sweet, sharp and tangy lemon-lime-orange parfait.  Richness of flavor makes this stand out from all the Tripels ive tried.  Benchmark stuff.  Ill be visiting this one regularly.
More hop than I expected.  Complex and spicy, nice finish (though sharp and a bit bitter).
750 ml bottle; golden unfiltered body, thick cream foam top, and a spicy flavor.  Overall a solid Belgian Tripel, but I agree with other raters, the alcohol is much morte evident as the Tripel warms.
Spicy, gracy, hoppy taste, light palate . Its like a wheatbeer. I liked it.

(Bottle, Monks Café, Stockholm) Golden yellow colour with lasting, frothy, white head. Fruity, spicy nose with dried apricots, orange peel and slightly spicy, metallic notes. Fruity, spicy taste with apricots, citrus, herbs (thyme?) and slightly metallic undertones with distinct fiery notes in a long, warming finish with alcohol shining through. Not really balanced, but still nice and with lots of personality.
750 mL bottle.  Poured hazy gold with fizzy white head.  Mild lacing.  Yeasty nose.  Finished spicy with evident warming alcohol.

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2009 bottle.  pours a deep golden with a huge thick white head... very spicy on the tip and back of the tongue.  nice medium body with a sense of airiness to it.  aromas of citrus, belgian yeast and spice.  medium body with a strong presence... yeast driven flavor and feel throughout.  citrus, spice dominate the mouth as well.  one of the best examples of an Abbey Tripel.

Pours a cloudy golden. Aroma is strongly yeasty. Flavor is yeast and light malts up front with a bit of spice/pepper in the finish. Hops are also subtle in comparison to the yeast. Slightly dry finish. Overall, seems more yeasty than I would have expected.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2012 Extremely crisp tripel, with a dry straw-like finish. A light orange pour, with very fine lacing and solid retention. Nice flavors of spice and subtle malts (which thankfully dont get in the way), with citrus notes and a bit of pepper in the finish. Bitter but still quite warming, an excellent Trappist ale.

11.2oz bottle dated 10/04/09.  Poured a nice hazy orange color but with a lot of carbonation.  Interesting flavor with wheat and citrus.  Alcohol taste is definitely noticeable.  Finish is sharp and fairly bitter.

Pours a beautiful golden brown color with a strong head and lacing. Smells of sweet hops with woody flavors with undertones of orange and apple. Has a calming affect that is really nice. Feels slightly warm and smooth in your mouth. Goes down warm and smooth.

Hazy gold with nice white Belgian lace.  Has a fruity aroma.  Spicy in the taste with phenolics of rose and honey.  Moderate bitterness.  Doesnt finish as dry as I recall.  When warmed, has a definite alcohol presence.

33cl bottle at De Baiaard, Amsterdam, 12-2-07.   Clear gold with a a medium white head.   Aroma is yeasty and sharp, with plenty of alcohol.   Flavor is dry, yeasty, and spiced, with alcohol making itself known as well.   Medium-full body with lively carbonation.   I like the spiciness, and Westmalle definitely has the nicest of the trappist glasses, but the sharp alcohol keeps me from loving it.

Orange color with a cloud of spritzy white head.  Aroma is lemon citrus, yeast, and malty sweetness.  Flavor is refreshing despite the hefty weight of alcohol and the body.  Flavors are wheaty, with citrus sweetness, and some spices followed by a dry finish without much bitterness.

Aroma: Sweet malts. various fruits. Spicy floral notes. 
Appearance: Dark yellow. Thin filmy white head. plenty of lacing.
Flavor: Spices. Very hoppy bitterness. You can really taste the alcohol.
Palate: Soft yet full bodied. Warming finish.

Had this beer on 4/9/2007.  Aroma is a sweet fruity scent.  Color is a bright gold with very good carbonation and nice head.  Taste is fizzy, light and sweet. Starting off with a light/medium body and a fizzy mouth feel, it goes down crisp.  Finish comes out of the fizzy feel with an easy malt fruit flavor then eases out with a nice mild hop flavor and an alcohol feel.  On the very end it has a mild bitterness and leaves you with a nice classic abbey ale flavor.  Overall its a wonderful brew.  This has extra yeast and fruit flavors that make it stand out.
Really good tripel. Citrusy undertones.  Pours rich orange with a fluffy white head.  One of my favorite trappist tripels.

Hazy orange with a pillowy white head.  Aroma is mostly citrus, spice and yeast that follows into the body which reminds me of a beaujolais nouveau-like bubblegum notion... I wonder if they are similar strains.  Anyhow, banana and more spice (coriander, clove) in the body with a bit of orange zest and a dryer finish.  Alcohol is a bit noticeable but not enough to turn me off.  Quite tasty.

12ozbottle, marked 27/10/07. Poured orange-golden, with a huge fluffy white head. Big yeasty aroma, with spice, coriander, pepper, and flowers. Wheaty, yeasty flavor, with some spice, tropical fruit, and alcohol. Long, fruity finish. Nice tripel.

(330 ml bottle (stamped "18/05/08") from <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/maine/portland/ target=blank>Downeast Beverage Co., cellared for 8 mos. after purchase) A boozy treat...Pours cloudy apricot orange color. Quite perfect looking finger or two of white head that looks like a cloud. Aroma of stewed fruit, candyish malt sweetness and a light hint of cherry. Mouthfeel is finely prickly, smooth and fairly dry. Nice sheets of lacing form inside of glass. Flavor is light stewed fruit and candyish, light brown sugar malt with an overlaying boozy sweetness, so yes its kind of hot but not in a detracting way. A fine beer.
Bottle 33 cl. Pours an almost clear golden with a not so big white head. Taste has Orange, citrus, spice and a lot of hops. A good triple

33cl bottle - pours hazy golden orange with a big foamy white head. Also, in the most beautiful of trappist glasses. Aroma of yeast, peppery spice, effervescent citrus, banana, candy sugar. Flavour is very similar, very tangy, with the alcohol warming at the back of the throat in the swallow. Quite bready and sweet, with a dry finish. Fresh and hugely drinkable...probably my favourite Trappist tripel.
11.2 oz bottle. Not very aromatic. Color is hazy translucent light amber with a brillaint white head. Taste very heavy of hops, a bit peppery. Nice dry finish. A very nice brew.

Bottle split with Muenster and BossHossBikes in a blind tasting. This was the cloudiest sample and a light golden color with an excellent white head. The nose is very bready with light cloves and a wild character. The flavor is bready again with hints of rye and a backdrop of spices, earth, delicate cloves and cardamom. The sweetness is appropriately dessert like. This was excellent, my second favorite in the blind behind only Allagash Tripel.

Bottle thanks to NachlamSie. Blind tripel tasting with Allagash Tripel Reserve, Tripel Karmeliet, and Chimay Cinq Cents with NachlamSie and Muenster. This brew poured a cloudy gold with a pale head. The aroma was spicy and citrusy such as a pear. The aroma travels through the nose and down the throat creating a warming sensation and a strange tang. As the brew hit the tongue, caramel and honey sweetness as well as a pear citrus becomes very dominant. Spiciness creeps up a little as the brew passes the tongue. The citrus and sweetness overcomes the spice quickly after and continues, delicately intertwined, in the finish. This was very enjoyable and came in second in the tasting.

Fruity and spicy aroma with lots of noticable yeast. Pours hazy yellowish. Flavor is nice and sweet. Fruits like apricot, orange, and lemons make an appearance with nice yeasty spiceyness and a little bit of alcohol. Pretty damn easy to drink for how big it really is. This could get me in trouble.

Nose is a dusty and yeasty somehow reminiscent of faint smell of vanilla shortbread dusted with icing sugar, appearance is slightly hazey pale straw, Palate is paradoxically dry yet with a true edge of sweetness, and actual perceptable hop bitterness. Bring me another!

11.2oz. bottle. Pours a cloudy pale gold with a medium white head and tons of carbonation. Heavy aromas of yeast and wheat with hints of lemon and orange. Flavor is of sour hops, lemon, and yeast with a slight spicey finish. Mouthfeel is very light and velvety. Great stuff.
Bottle.  Hazy orange with a large white head.  Aroma is spicy, notes of yeast and orange.  Flavor is sweet and quite spicy and a little woody.  Nice finish of alcohol.

Pours a faintly hazy golden straw color, with a nice thick creamy looking head.  Smells of raisins and maybe some other fruitiness, with a hint of alcohol and some spiciness.  Its very fruity with some amount of residual sweetness.  Finish is spicy and fruity at the same time.  It doesnt taste anywhere near as alcoholic as it smells.  It has a big raisin taste.  Its actually really nice.  If all tripels are like this, I may have found a new favorite style.  Theres a slight hint of sourness in the finish somewhere maybe?  Carbonation is low perhaps to medium, and mouthfeel is mediumish.  As it warms up, spiciness and alcohol become more apparent, as does slight hop bitterness.  It tastes a little like a lighter version of a barleywine.

served in a glass with bottle at Irish Tunes, in Roeselare, Belgium. Nice vibrant goldeny orange color with a huge white creamy..turning frothy head that stayed til the bottom. It has a spicy and herbal somewhat raisiny aroma. I could hint maybe plums peaches strawberries. Nice dry full flavored brew that doesnt pack as big of a punch as others of its alc content. Call me crazy but this is one brew that I felt I got hints of marijuana from. Could just been my fingers? Great finish, great light aftertaste!
Bottle from Discount Liquors in Voorhees, NJ-Pours a cloudy golden/ brown with herbal/ spiced aromas with some fruits. Very enjoyable and finishes well.
Golden in color.  Big, bubbly head.  Banana and clove in the nose.  The flavor is dry, with lots of sweetness and spice.  Hides the alcohol well.
The substantial alcohol is hidden, in my opinion.  Tastes more like a 7, maybe 8 percenter at the most.  Golden, dry, and full, with fruits and spice battling in the finish.  An enjoyable experience.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2007 Pours a hazy orange brown color with a foamy, pale yellow head that sticks around quite a while, and leaves substantial lacing on the glass. Nose is spicy and citrus, with a hint of dried fruit. Flavor is also spicy, but a sweet raisin flavor is present. A subtle bitterness finishes the taste.
Bottled 33cl. A hazy orange beer with a tall qhite head. Aroma has notes of yeast and orange. Taste is very spicy and fruity, notes of yeast. Alcoholic and bitter end
Does a Tripel get any better, if so it would be hard to find, enjoyed in Brugge Belgium bottled and potent. Very smooth and dangerous as the alcohol comes thru in the end of the bottle.
user_location: 4800+ Miles from Munich,near UBW, Pennsylvania, USA

text: UPDATED: AUG 8, 2010 Bottle. A hazy medium to dark golden beer with a large, frothy, lacing, mostly lasting white head. The aroma is lightly to moderateòy malty, lightly to moderately hoppy, lightly to moderately yeasty. There are notes of toasted grains, flowers, grass, earth, alcohol, pepper, banana. The flavour is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly to moderately sour, lightly bitter. Medium to full body, lively carbonation, quite dry and long finish with something more than medium bitterness, moderately alcoholic. Very good, tasty.

Bottle from City Beer Store.  Hazy neon yellow color, cant see any carbonation.  Great, thick head with big bubbles and solid lacing.  Huge yeast aroma with flowers, plums.  Fruity taste with strawberries, floral, bracing bitter grassy finish with some alcohol.  Quite nice!

11.2 oz bottle.  Pours a clear and carbonated straw-colored amber with a firm, billowy head.  Aroma is earthy and sweet like a saison, with earthy tones of yeast and malt alongside other aromas of spice, banana, and citrusy hops.  Taste is full and sweet, with an initial taste of floral hops opening up into a sweeter profile of honey and banana, finishing with a crisp and bitter finish thats part hops, part alcohol.  Not at all what Id expect from a tripel, but still a solid brew.

330ml bottle. Pours cloudy golden with a hint of soft brown. Good size white head that dissipates not too fast but not too slow. Mild lacing on the glass. Aroma of fruit and subdued flowery hops and light malts. First sip is lightly fruity with the hops coming through more strongly. The finish is a combination of fruit, hops and malt, with an overtone of alchohol. The feeling is almsot silky, but a bit more on the watery side, with a slight tingle of carbonation. This is a great trappist.

A nice beer at room temp. Poured a somewhat dark amber, with a slight smell of raisins, and a cream colored head. The taste was smooth with a nice alccohol kick that seemed to develop in the back of my mouth. I would like to try it cold!!

0.33 l bottle. Poured murky yellow body with big creamy white head going down slowly. Aroma of some lightly sour fruits, yeasty. Flavor really nice, bitter but balanced with that fruity sweetness, full bodied, really what I could expect from a triple. Lightly carbonated, with oily texture. Finish is sweet, pleasant, cant say at all that alcohol is felt although this is not really small ABV. Fantastic beer.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2010 Cloudy straw color. Medium head. Strong alcohol in taste along with spice and fruit. Solid body.

Tried again, and enjoyed the spicy, semi-sweet taste.
A strong delicious blend of caramel and fruit flavours, spiced, with a full flavour. Traces of yeast are certainly present as well. A orangy-amber colour, good body. Quite exquisite.

750 ml bottle. Aroma of light stone fruit, yeast and caramel. Dark orange/amber/gold color with a white head that didnt persist. Medium body with sllightly fizzy carbonation. Caramel, heat, golden fruits. All that fades to a slightly roasted malt accompanied by alcohol. The spice may be there, but its hard to pick out any particular one. The finish is dry, goes a bit acidic and theres a woody bitterness. Interesting, but its not head above many others.

Bottle at the cafe across the street from the brewery.  Slightly cloudy gold, white lacing into a film.  Aroma is estery fruit, notes of booze.  Medium body, lots of bready malt up front, fades into a very dry finish that betrays the alcohol content.  Very very good, but not the revelatory experience I was hoping for.

It pours a nice white head which last for a very long time - its as thick as whipcream! The aroma has yeast, and a sour thing which I couldnt figure out what was you can also sense the alcohol. It has a golden colour. The flavor is yeasty, with a bitter aftertaste but the rest is sweet with tones of banana in the end it turns sour in a way. Its good way - I know sour might sound negative, but its actually ment in a good way.

Hazy orange, almost yellow. Fruity and yeasty aroma, kinda like Finnish mead. Flavor has lemon and all kinds of citrus, soft maltiness. Doesnt change as much with yeast added as its dubbel brother. Feels quite thick, alcohol is well hidden.

Bottle.  This Tripel is very good.  Pours a deep cloudy yellow with little yeast floaters.  The aroma is malty and floral.  This tripel varies a bit from others I have had in that there isnt the typical ripe banana flavor.  There is a good spice character to it, but not over powering.  The alcohol is almost perfect.  Very good.
This beer is delicious!!!  cloudy dark pour with disapaping head.  Light malts, slightly acidic.  Just a very nice blend!!  Great beer

A great beer that a had to get around to rating. Pours cloudy yellow-orange with frothy white head. Very nice floral nose with hits of honey/spice. Taste has nice complexity with sweet malts, fruity and spicy notes with a long hoppy finish. Great beer!

THOUGHTS: Incredible. I could barely describe the aroma and flavors because they werent quite like anything I have had before in a beer. Ive had tripels before but this is somehow diffent. While not exactly what I think of as a tripel, it was even better.  A little something in both the flavor and aroma was not pleasant to me, but it was minimal. It was underlying but kept it from being perfect. 
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a cloudy, light to medium amber, with an average, white head that mostly diminished, but did so slowly. The aroma was light malt, light to moderate yeast, along with honey, fruits, spices and a little alcohol. The initial flavor was moderately sweet and lightly acidic, whilte the finish was moderately to heavily sweet and bitter, lightly acidic and sour with an average duration. The flavor was very yeasty and seemingly hoopy toward the finish. The medium body was dry and somewhat syrupy with fizzy carbonation and a metallic and lightly alcoholic finish.

From bottle : Pours a hazy orangish color with lots of carbonation and a one finger white rocky head that has good staying power, and leaves wonderful lacing in cool designs all around the glass.  Aroma is strong, fruits, a little alcohol..smells kinda dry, alot like a wine.  Flavor is really good and mellow, hints of fruit and spice and a little yeast, alcohol is nowhere to be found.  Palate is a thin medium, it starts out smooth and gets a little lively toward the end, leaves the palate dry after it is down the hatch.  I really like this.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2009 330ml Bottle. Pours a hazy golden with a energetic head. The taste is quite yeasty, with strong apple, spice, a little alcohol warmth and a bitter dry finish. Really nice, a sipping drink. Quite like a good wine, great drink.

Bottle. Aroma has a good mix of yeast, apple and spice notes. Hazy golden body with good white head and floaters moving arround in pint glass. Flavor has a citrus apple along with the sour and spice in the mix. Thick body texture makes for a good sipping beer and less of the spice bite some tend to have for me anyway. Frutiy aftertaste on the palate good beer.

33 cl bottle.  Poured a rusty gold with a thick and large head.  Very pleasant aroma of dates, spice, yeast, musk, and citrus spritz. Complex fruit flavors and some yeastiness in the flavor with just a hint of clove.  The finish warms in the mouth and reveals a lot of complexity.  The abv is slightly noticeable in the finish and theres also some slight bitterness.  Laces beautifully.  Probably better after a few other beers of in larger quantity.
Alcohol and light Belgian malt aroma. Light golden cloudy with some sediment. Starts slightly fruity with the middle going to an alcohol burn mellowing slightly in the finish. Slightly cream palate.

11.2oz bottle.  Aroma is fantastic, notes of hay, perfume, citrus, raisin, apple, pear, peach, pineapple, white wine, wood, and slight alcohol.  Large fluffy white head that mostly diminished but left great lace.  Hazy gold hue with an average amount of tiny particles.  Flavor is spicey, sweet, with a little bitterness and alcohol on the chewy malt finish.  Palate is soft, watery, and medium bodied.  Wow, just a fantastic brew.  Complex, refreshing, with spicy malts and perfume hops.  Just a delight in every way.  Would highly recommend and will try again.

Pours a deep gold with amber highlights. Has that beautiful white head that settles into a lasting Belgian lace. Tight and excited carbonation. The aroma is fruity. the sweet malts immediately hit the palate, as do the tastes of peaches, apricots, and bread. This is a great beer.

Bottle. Pours golden with large foamy head. Nicely carbonated. Aroma is dark fruits / caramel. Taste is malty / spicy. Seems to get sweeter as the beer warms. Finish is crisp with a little bitterness.

750ml
$9.99
Sams Chicago

Westmalles Tripel pours a slightly hazy apricot golden with handfuls of tiny carbonation bubbles rising to the surface. A two finger dense white head formed on the pour that had incredible staying power. The rush of carbonation keeps the head strong. Leaves sticky spotty lacing after each swig. Really, a nice looking glass of beer.

The aroma is packed full of fresh ripe golden orchard fruits that are gleaming in the autumn sun. Yellow pears, slightly underipe peaches, and mildly tart green apples all smell fantastic. Theres a hint of clove along with the pale biscuity like malt that makes up the canvas so the fruitiness of this tripel shines through. A sprinkling of candi sugar just sweetens the deal.

Flavor is pretty much in line with the aroma but as it warms I cant help but notice a sweet, but dry, wine like character. Big white grape flavors (not a big wine drinker so not sure of variety). The white grapes go nicely with the orchard fruits and actually take the front seat. Some alcohol warmth on the swallow. Very good.

Medium bodied with a lively carbonation that makes this beer creamy and somewhat frothy as it hits the tongue. Finishes extremely dry. 

Good drinkability for such a high abv. brew. The alcohol will get in the way of this one though as it gets stronger as the beer warms.

An excellent tripel (one of my favorite styles). Up there with the best Ive been lucky enough to sample so far. Unique and very enjoyable.

9/16/07

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2016 Quite raisiny wineyness, with a subtle warming malty hug. Quite carbonated, tingles with each taste. Slightly alcoholic, but the alcohol actually helps carry all the other flavours very well - a dry maliness and a resiny bitterness. All very well balanced and almost mellow, and of course certainly winey.
Rerate: 330ml bottle (Drink Baar, Tallinn)
Wonderfully fruity winey aroma. Oh so mellow, but with lovely enlivening, but not crisp, carbonation. What I said before - wow, fruity and winey. OK, 9.5% is clearly not a light drink, but the wineyness is stunning. Oddly, it was served in an orval glass and for one sip I got a magical orval tatse and retronasals fromthis. If this had just a hint more hops this would be stunning.
Rerate: 330ml bottle - BB 2016/02 Drunk 2016/11 (7:4:6:3:13=3.4)
Classic tripel, but a little harsh.
Rerate: 330ml bottle - BB 2008/02 Drunk 2016/11 (7:4:8:4:16=3.9)
Aroma says its aged, but the taste is magnificent. Raisins.

bottle.  pours a a clear honey-gold with a huge fluffy white head that doesnt seem to want to quit.  when it eventually subsides, halfway through the beer, it remains as a film over the whole beer, and leaves plenty of lacing.  smells of raisins and berries mixed with nuts, with a slight woody note.  very complex smell.  tastes a bit more spicy and malty than it smells, with noticeable alcohol.  finishes crisp with a hint of bitter.  the fairly high carbonation and tiny bubbles gives it an almost creamy mouthfeel, with a sort of oily film.
UPDATED: OCT 28, 2007 11 ounce bottle purchased at Total Wine Fort Lauderdale, FL $4.49Very good.

750ml bottle brought as a gift from Belgium by my brother Andy.  I am enjoying this on my 4th wedding anniversary.  Cheers! Pours a beautiful honey-orange with a massive, pillowy head that sticks all the way down.  The nose really opens up as it warms - noting fresh grass, honey, straw, caramel, sour lemon and orange and a slight acidic tinge.  Full, creamy mouthfeel.  The body displays the same pleasant acidity,soft on the palate.  It gives this beer a nice edge and helps notes of doughy malt, caramelized sugar and earthy yeast define themselves.  Peppery alcohol is left on the back of the tongue in the finish.  Very nice stuff.
I had this in a flight of tripels and it came across with a hard flavor at first , but then it opened up like a flower to display of fruit and grass. The finish lingered long after the beer was gone.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2009 Sour flavor was the first thing that hit me. Poured a nice amber color, but the flavor was too sour and tasted slighly skunked. SECOND ANALYSIS: This is full of hops! Much better than the first time I had this. Slight banana nose with grassy notes in the front. Starts sweet, ends dry. THIRD ANALYSIS: This holds up to a superior Golden Ale with Brett - so what can I say? This one is awesome! FOURTH ANALYSIS: Drinking a 750 cl bomber. Yum is all I can say. I drank this after a glass of Orval and it holds up!

Non descript aroma.  Poured into tulip glass. Grassy taste with metallic aftertaste, no floral notes.  Dry, thin and bitter finish with lingering unfortunate slight skunky and wet earthy feel.  Could be a stale bottle - expiration Oct07.  Hard to finish the bottle in fact. Just squeezes into decent, but was certainly expecting much more and have had much better Tripels.

Bottle, dated 11/01/08. Pours hazy orange with thin creamy white head, lots of particulate. Aroma is lightly malty as well as spicy and yeasty and has the funky smell of old sweat socks and even a hint of banana. Carbonation is very active but light on the tongue. Flavors come in with strong spiciness throughout, full of pepper and coriander....moderately bitter to the end. Notes of fruit and citrus, specifically some orange peel in both an oily and bitter nature. Strong alcohol presence throughout. Finish is dry, very dry. Flavor improves with the temperature but so does the alcohol presence. I havent had enough tripels to comment on its stance as such a well known brew and supposedly fantastic tripel, but I dont rate to style anyway so Ill just say: I like it.

Cloudy orange body that is darker than most tripels. Not as much head as I expected from a tripel. Nice winy and banana aroma, which may I add is really intensely strong. Taste is hella spicy with some bitterness. The palate is a little too carbonated. The high alcohol content is very well covered up by the rest of the tastes. Heavy aftertaste is certainly present. Needs to be warm to drink... because it is just not good when it is cold- all the bad parts of the beer are present then, but when it gets warmer the complexity and good tastes rise above the little bad parts. Not as much bite as other tripels though.
Pours bronze with almost no head... aroma is strong and very fruity with a hint of spices... spicy taste with strong alcohol and thick smooth texture... very long lasting finish...
One of the best beers in the world.  A true abbey tripel - great carbonation and long finish, somewhat dry, beautiful straw color in a sniffer....a taste of the good life in every bottle.

From bottle. Cloudy straw color. Little to no lacing. Light apple-yeast-alcohol nose. Medium mouthfeel with a sharp fermented cider flavor that sat on the tongue hinting at much more. Had a low-level complexity that was just right with this beer.Alcohol was not that noticeable. Nice.

Pours cloudy gold with a monstrous head that lingers for a very long time. Lacing quite present. The nose is extremely sweet with strong citric tones. Even and smooth on the mouth with malty sweetness and a bit of a bitter edge that follows on the trail end. Mouthfeel is typical. You could drink a lot of this in a sitting...if you could tolerate the 9.5% alcohol. This is a great brew whose best feature and contribution to beer world is that it is so readily available and has probably helped enlighten a lot of people as to what the possibilities for beer are.

Bottle -- Huge pure white head with OK retention and a whole lotta lacing. Cloudy deep golden yellow with active carbonation stirring up the lees. Gently sweet aroma of malt and spices. Fairly creamy palate. Crisp hoppy flavour with yeast and malt there too. The alcohol comes in at the end, creating a nicely biting edge to the finish.

Bottle. Pours crystal gold with fluffy white head. Aroma is hops, grass, wheat, dried fruit, slightly skunky. Flavor is dried fruit, meat, spices, wheat, grass. Very dry and bitter finish. I expected much more out of this trippel. I dont find that this is well blended nor complex and. Its almost like a suped-up Lowenbrau.

(bottle, thanks JK) Pours a cloudy gold with a large white head.  Aroma of sweet malt and dried fruits, and a little bit of clove.  Very sweet caramel flavor with some clove and fruit as well, and a very thick mouthfeel.
Thanks to JK for sharing.  Lots of sediment in the cloudy orange body.  Sweet honey and sugar nose.  Candy sugar flavor with faint dark fruits.  Lots of yeast in the finish.
Really nice tripel. I appreciate the alcohol being fairly upfront without being hot.

Golden straw color with a thick creamy head.  The aroma yields smells of yeast and spices.  Once you get through the head the body of the beer reveals a crisp hoppy flavor that really hides the alcohol fairly well.

Bottle at LImaige de Notre Dame in Brussels. Cloudy yellow color with a stable off-white head. Aroma of yeast, spices, fruits, and some nice hoppiness. Flavor is yeasty and fruity with some spices and a bitter finish. Medium body and lots of carbonation. A very nice Tripel.

Date: 05/22/1998
Mode: Bottle
Source: Total Beverage, DC

golden yellow, fine white head, lots of tiny bubbles, soft slightly sweet floral hop aroma, highly alcoholic malt flavor, afterburn, thin body, finish with a hint of hop bitterness
-------- />
Date: 02/22/2001
Words: Bottle
Words: Chevy Chase
Words: DC

hazy dark yellow, lasting white head producing lots of lace, sweet spicy malt aroma, rich malt flavor, big body, lots of complex spicyness, 
-------- />
Date: 01/26/2003
Words: 750ml

hazy yellow, big creamy head, sweet spicy aroma, rich sweet spicy malt flavor, 
-------- />
Date: 11/12/2004
Words: 3y old

candy sweet, but not too sweet, good sweet fruity esters

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 16/20
Rating: 3.6/5.0Score: **4
-------- />
The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Hazy copper with a large white head. Faint sweet malt and yeast aroma. Yeast, malt and alcohol in the taste and a sharp bitter finish. I was expecting to enjoy this, and I did. However in retrospect I was less impressed. No wow factor here, Im afraid.

750ml bottle purchased at Bevmo. Pours cloudy unfiltered yellow gold with a big white sudsy head. Plenty of lacing observed. Aroma was light with citrus, walnuts, and alcohol. Flavor is mild spices, I detect thyme and basil, set in a grapefruit backdrop. Hops are moderately biter, and somewhat dry and astringent. Mouthfeel is creamy, silky and smooth. Finish is long and dry with an alcohol note. Overall this is a superbly well crafted beer.

This is a classic example of a Belgian Tripple; it is potent, has a nice pleasant aroma and head, you dont notice the large mount of alcohol and, it leaves you with on serious hangover if you over-indulge.

330 ml bottle 
9.5% 
I tried this beer on August 21, 2007 at the Beer Bistro in Toronto.  The beer poured a murky gold colour into a chalice glass with a thin white head that dissipated quickly.  The aroma was very yeasty, with some malt and cloves.  The mouthfeel was medium bodied, and slightly champagne in nature.  The flavour was that of yeast, malt, and cloves with a dry finish.

From the bottle.

Pours excellent with a nice lace on the glass. Has a nice apricot flavour, and pleasant bitter finish.

Ive had some bad trippels recently, but this was solid.  Nice yeasty sweet aroma, but not over the top.  Flavor is sweet and fruity, but well balanced.  Pours gold with a frothy white head.  Pretty good.

Dark amber with a giant head that lasted 15 minutes.  Aroma of malt, honey, fruit, trappist yeast.  Somewhat of a syrup texture.  The alcohol is very well hidden, nearly undetectable.  Very well balanced flavors expected in an a tripel.

deep clear gold with a lasting full head. great lacing. the aroma first hits you as apples and fruit, honey malt, and then finishes with light spices. medium thick body with a slight stickiness. nectar sweetness that is not overpowering, with pit fruits and a subtle dark fruit note, and a light pepper spiciness. slight alcohol on the finish. beautifully balanced, very full but not the least bit overpowering
A strong, dry, and spicy trappist ale.  Yes, they hit it right on the head.  I tend to like this style a TAD bit sweeter, but hey, what do I know.  Im not a monk or anything.

Pours a cloudy apricot with a big white head.  Lots of lace with this one.

The aroma is electric hops in great, bushy abundance, and faint traces of lemon peel, pennies, and whiffs of alcoholic danger.

The taste is intensely coriander and cloves, with doughy malt, zingy citrus tang, celery, and the ever-increasing bitterness of the hops (which are not as intense as this tripels smell would make you think).  The aftertaste was coppery and a bit menthol-like due to the higher alcohol content, but at no point did I ever feel that I was drinking something 9.5%.  Commendable, and, perhaps, dangerous.

While I quite enjoyed this tripel, I felt that it lacked much in the aroma department and merely came across as an okay example.

Perhaps the most illuminating point of comparison here would be the Chimay Triple/Cinq Cents. This is much like the Chimay but with more caramelization and a deeper, darker flavor (as well as a darker color). Cola-like and well carbonated. I like the caramel-without-maltiness combination (contrast with Chimay, which has neither much caramel nor much malt), so I guess its natural that I would like this beer. I cant think of a better triple.

solid golden color with nice frothy head. wonderful picey and yeasty aromas. very inviting.  flavors of honey and light citrus. alcohol has a very nice role in this beer. warming and balancing. great tripel.
great beer.  didnt have a cup to drink it out of but it was just fine in the bottle.  the taste was reminded me of the dubbel but i quickly acquired it.
Finest example of the belgian tripel style i have ever tasted.  this beer has excellent head retention. It pours a great golden colour  with about 1-1.5cm of head.

Pours murky dark gold with 1 cm of white head. Loose, oily lacing. Smells of light sour Belgian, little barnyard. Some citrus, white rice, and more orange toward the end, wheat. Lite, but rounded in the mouth. High carbonation. Big body and still refreshing. Nice brew.

Copper/golden color with a soft white foamy head that lingers like the head on a Trappist beer should.  Excellent (as expected) yeast notes and mild citrus/spice nose.  Sweeter than other Trappist beers but delicious.  An excellent beer - the monks have done themselves proud again.  A good counter to other Trappist offerings - not as heavy or boozy as a Chimay or Orval.

Maybe my personal favorite tripel. Nose is very strong with yeast and spice. Alcohol is very noticible which is the only downside but the taste is great with honey and spices and yeast. Nice warming finish.
flowery and malty aroma; small, creamy white head with nice lacing; cloudy orange beer with alcohol warmth and a spicy flavor;  finish is spicy, fruity, and flowery.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2007 Flaske. Selvom det er den originale trippel, er det dog langt fra den bedste trippel- Alkoholen er for dominerende hvilket efterlader resten af øllen lidt kuppet.

Rerate: Fik så en lagret. Og hvilken forskel. Fantastisk øl med masser af frugt perfekt afbalanceret af alkoholen. Desværre er det den eneste af de efterhånden mange westmalle jeg har fået. Men trækker op på helheden.

Appearance: golden color semi-turbid. Great head, consistent, rocky, persistent and beige color. Beautiful!.
Aroma: nice malty and yeasty. High hoppyness, fine, with floral and herbs touches. Citric-fruitiness of pineapple and lemon; sweet-fruitiness of apples and banana. Slight spicy; coriander, vanilla and clove.
Flavor: complex and exquisite!. Malty, yeasty, and slightly candy. Spice presence, such as, clove and coriander. Fruitiness of pineapple, tangerines, red apples and banana. Sweet and fruity start; herby-hoppy finish, with medium dryness and persistency. The final dryness present fruity-touches of peel-orange and pink-grapefruit. Liquory and warm.
Palate: medium body, semi-oily and creamy texture. Low carbonation.
Complex and exquisite beer, good balance and very nice dryness.
(sorry for my english)
Delightfully fruit-taste, with the powerful but not spirit-like alcohol providing the balance. The amount of taste in this beer is impressive, even for a trappist.
Golden colour with nice white head, yeasty, strong, a bit bitter, more hopped than your average abbeys, a bit spicy.  Dry as well...

Bottle.  This was the first Trappist I ever tasted, and after this Im surprised I tried another.  The beer pours a watery gold color with a prominent, frothy white head.  Aroma is largely yeast with slight spice characteristics included.  Taste is yeasty up front with spice on the end of the taste.  Overall I found this beer too watery, which I later learned is not a hallmark of the tripel style.

rating from notes: pours a golden in color with some lacing in the glass. smell is yeasty with some alcohol but not as strong as i would have hoped for. taste is spicy with alcohol for sure and some malt.
Gold color with medium diminishing head and some lacing. All around a good beer, but doesnt come close to the flavor of other trappist ales.
750ml bottle - I love Belgian Ales but didnt love this one.  A flat dry finish without the aroma and flavor I crave.  The 2nd glass was better than the 1st at least.

Ok so this started out pouring a golden yellow into my glass with a thick white head but it went away quickly. Aroma is yeast spice (tons of nutmeg for some reason), and alcohol. Now maybe I started this thing too cold but on the first few sips the stuff was nothing but a spicy yeast and alcohol bomb and it was really just not that good. As it warmed the alcohol died down a bit but still not that well and more flavors were released such as a note of lemon zest. Overall, I thought the alcohol was hidden horribly in this beer which is surprising to me because normally high alcohol content does not bother me but for some reason this one did. Oh well, first time that has happened to me, I guess you cant like them all. I am beginning to notice however that triples in general I dont care for that much. Which is again confusing because I love quads and doubles. Hmmm weird.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2007 Many nuts, pecan. Cooling, it has led, full of flavors. For me, a perfect Belgian combination between a strong ale and a tripel. Perfect........................................... nozes, pecã. Refrescante, leve, cheia de sabores. Pra mim, uma perfeita combinação entre uma strong ale belga e uma tripel.

I found this little gem in a state run liquor store in Utah. $3.99. Not bad. The ABV hit me pretty hard since I have been MIA in the beer drinking world for a little while. Very nice flavors of spice and yeast like aftertaste. Enjoyable.

11.2 oz bottle.  Hazy golden color, with a thick frothy head.  Heavy lacing.  Aroma is sweet, with a tinge of citrus.  The flavor is tart, with a nice spicy and malty flavor.  Alcohol is only slightly present in the taste, which is surprising since its 9.5%.

0.33 l bottle. Deep golden color. Fruity, phenolic and malty aroma with apple, herbal hops and honey. The same attributes are present in the taste along with some tartness and firm balanced bitterness. Fruity-spicy flavors are quite complex! Quite fizzy.

Rated 7/11/07.  Pours a hazy yellow-gold color with a big frothy head that reduces to a thin film.  Leaves behind a patchy spider-web of lacing.  Aroma is sweet and sour citrus, yeast, and spices.  Flavor is like candied orange peels, sweetened lemon, corriander, nutmeg, yeast and malt.  Body is syrupy, typical of a tripel.  Not my favorite style, by any means, but this is a very well crafted beer.

Pours a golden yellow color that looks as though it was sitting in a swamp.  Decent white head that caressed the top of the glass.  The aroma is nothing like the taste.  Its like the bastard-child of the brew, its there but doesnt quite fit in.  Tart, malty aroma with a faint sweet approach towards the end.  Nice mouth feel.  The taste totally threw me off on this because of the appearance.  Big, bold, spicy, malty, alcohol taste that has hints of cherries.  Stout-ass brew that Im glad I have access to so I can pick up some more.

11.2oz bottle.   I have been saving this one along with the Westmalle Dubbel for a special occasion and what better occasion than my 500th rating to try them both?   Poured into a heavy glass beer stein (oh well, so much for class)  It’s a beautiful pour, with slightly hazy light golden beer and a big thick white head that stays and laces everywhere.  Aroma is faint, but appealing;  hoppy, slightly alcoholic, and pale malts.   Flavor is really excellent..  wonderful triple flavors instantly light up your tongue.   I love triples.  This one is deeply complex, tending to the dry side, but with a smooth malt richness that is very satisfying.  Interesting to sip and ponder.  Alcohol is well represented and to good effect, but completely integrated into the flavors.  A pleasant, well rounded bitterness appears in the finish.  Delicious and amazing.
Dark gold color with little aroma.  A little bitter for my taste, but a long solid flavor carries into a pleasant aftertaste.
UPDATED: AUG 6, 2007 excellent combination of alcohol and yeast with woody spicy taste... very good but not top of hte line
Westmalle Tripel just a fantastic beer!  The burnt sugar notes from the fire under the kettles is detectable and gives it a great taste.  I would absolutely buy this again!!

Hazy gold, spritzy, aroma of orange blossom and quinine, lime peel, a little kerosene. Seems to have some body when it hits the tongue but quickly melts/vaporizes leaving behind an excellent spruce-like flavor with orange pith bitterness, some toasty sourdough retro nasal, cleans out the sinuses a little and leaves a fresh feeling. Still one of the best!.

Pours a bubbly amber, too much carbonation.  Smells strong of alcohol.  Strong alcohol mouthfeel/alcohol burn.  Besdies alcohol taste is somewhat watered down.  As beer goes on alcohol becomes much better, much smoother.  Unfortunately the finish is another blast of alcohol.  The middle of the beer is worth drinking, not the start or finish though.

Hazy golden body, with some yeast particles floating and a thin white head.  Aroma of caramel, banana, yeast,  some citrus.  Slightly spicy, followed by some banana, apples, and some faint citrus.  Also some yeast in the finish.  Very dry finish.  Not too shabby.

Bottle, a light but bright amber with a white foamy head. A warming sweet and alcoholic malt aroma withyeat and zest. The alcohol comes through strong at first, but then becomes smooth and fruity, and then comes strongly bitter and alcoholic in the finish. Ive had better Tripels.
Bottle.  Pours cloudy gold.  Good head formation which remains.  Smells of orange, mint, light yeast.  Pleasant flavor.  Not overwhelming with alcohol.

UPDATED: AUG 23, 2008 Coloração âmbar, turva. Bom creme. Notas cítricas, possivelmente laranja, além de mel. Leve floral. Ao meu ver, o álcool é perceptível, o que prejudica o paladar e a drinkability. Final amargo.

<b?750ml Bottle. Pours a cloudy orange body with nice head. Aroma is of spices, yeasty, dried fruit. Flavor is smooth, light fruitiness, lots of spices. This was very quaffable. Very low alcohol presence.

Pours an orangey goldy colour with a thick head which doesnt last too long. Aroma is herbal, orangey and spicey. Tastes of booze at first. Lovely and boozey. It has a strange but fun mouthfeel and leaves a sagey aftertaste. Not my favourite tripel but darn close.

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2008 I have two different bottles of this of two different ages. From their website, I understand that the best-before date is three years after the brew date, so they are one and four years old respectively.

I dont have two identical glasses, so the younger beer was in a Leffe glass and the older was in my dear Duvel glass. Served at about 5 degrees - 45 for yanks - and allowed to warm up to more civilised temperatures as we went.                    


Younger:
Appearance: sparkly, thick smooth head, small bubbles. yellow-gold, nice lacing
aroma: peppery, fruity, yeasty notes. good. as it warms, grassy hops coming out mildly - saaz? becomes sweeter and even spicier; becomes less balanced, but richer
flavour: light, peppery, balanced yeast notes. flavour develops well as it warms.
mouthfeel: light, sparkly effervescent
                              

Older:
Appearance: Darker, amber-gold, practically no head, thicker, cloudier. soapy film of head would disappear if not for etching in the duvel glass. no lacing
aroma: heavy, floral, almost cloying. not as nice as the new bottle. as it warms, syrup and floral, candied, gaining a hint of peppery phenolics, nice balance, port-ish now. less cloying than when it was cold. the hops come out more now that its warm, very mellowed, not grassy at all. english?
flavour: sweeter, thicker. not as peppery or sparkly. the fresh-fruitness of the first has become heavier, brandied, syrup. like a nicely aged cream sherry. opens up as it warms. black pepper notes. yeastier. alcohol comes through.
mouthfeel: thicker, heavier, chewy.

In short: a well-crafted, beautiful tripel, enjoyable for different reasons at different ages.

From my notes 5/28/07 - Pours a one-finger white head that fades slowly leaving a good lace. Cloudy, pale amber color.  Slight malty nose.  Good carbonation and medium bodied. Flavor is balanced to slightly sour. Finish has some alcohol and sourness.  Not nearly as good as bottle.  On-tap at Summertime Restaurant Scheveningen, NL.  5 ($6.85) for a 330ml glass.

11.2 oz bottle - Pours hazy yellow with a one finger fading head.  It has a light yeast and citrus aroma.  The flavor is similar with some mild spice in there too.  Its medium bodied and has a dry finish.  this is a good beer, no doubt about it, but honestly I expected a bit more.  I thought the St. Bernardus Tripel I had recently was considerably better.

pours a beautiful dark golden color with a generous milky head.  Fruity, yeasty aromas with a tinge of cereal wheats.  A bit hoppy for a tripel but it works well, orange zest tones are present in addition to an herbal spiceyness. Although lighter in body there is a malty chewyness to the ale which is wonderful. A crisping twinge adds to a delightful finish.  a fine example of one of my favorite styles
Golden colour, white foamy head. Rich, fruity aroma. Orange, hoppy flavors. Moderately bitter. Alcohol well hidden. Nice abbey tripel.
Golden with a thick white head.  Aroma is candi sweet with orange and spices.  Taste is thinner and more bitter than I imagined.  Finish is dry and biscuity with a bit of astringency.  $4/11.2oz

Pours a light amber, amazing aroma, citrus oranges then moves onto the flavours in the mouth, bready and quite hoppy with the slightest hint of sourness...finishes so long, very hoppy but watch out for the alcohol
Noy my usual style but I must concede the quality of this.  The head is breathtaking.  As it warms the aroma opens up and the depth is inspriring.  Not a quaffer, but a quality drop.
Bottle. Amber colour with a nice white head. Aroma and flavour of spice (coriander), citrus, yeast, hops and alcohol.

pours a hazey light amber with nice smooth head. aroma of citrus and spiceyness. mouthful is nicely hopped with a crisp finish with some lingering citrus and spice. This is a very well balanced and complex tripel.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2009 Bottled 33cl. A top notch tripel with a wonderful hop and yeast profile and hints of melon, wood, white bread and spices. Good bitterness. Complex, deeply pleasant and beautiful. Additional comment: Dry, hoppy, complex and absoluetely fantastic.
I hate that my first review is not a flattering one. I was disappointed. This was a tasty ale but there was nothing special about it. I expect more out of Trappist ales.

Appearance: Pale straw-colored body topped with a profuse, foamy white head.

Smell: The aroma is marked by citrus, green apples tartness, and candy sugar. Slight hints of the alcohol content peek through in the nose.

Taste: All at once, its sweet, citrusy, and spicy. Very much like a dry white wine. Wraps up with a rather pronounced alcohol finish full of yeasty notes.

Mouthfeel: Medium-thin body that is slightly watery with a fizzy cabonation.

Drinkability: A rather dispiriting experience. Sadly, this is one of my least favorite of the trappist beers.

330 mL bottle.  Hazy golden yellow with a fizzy white head.  Aroma of honey, flowery bouquet and white wine character.  Bright sticky palate.  Slightly tangy malty taste with a clean finish.  I wish more of the aspects evident in the aroma showed through in the taste, but they didnt.
cloudy yellow colour with a huge white head. strong smell of yeast and hops. fruity flavour and a hoppy finish. great beer.

331 ml bottle.  Pours a cloudy golden orange with a plentiful fluffy white head.  Fruity nose with hints of citrus and pepper.  Medium body with an edgy dryness and a slight alcohol burn.  Finish lingers into an every so slight sweetness as the dryness drifts away.
UPDATED: JUL 3, 2014 Appearance is slightly cloudy, golden yellow. Aroma is mix of yeast and citrus. Clean, crisp, citrusy flavour with some sweetness (banana) and a strong alcohol kick to finish.
For a belgian beer, this oarange colored beer is very hoppy. Not my favorite trappist beer. i expected more from this beer.

Bottle. pours light gold. Unimpressive aroma and flavor profile. I was expecting WAY more out of this beer. I taste malt, corn and yeast. heavy on the dry yeast. Not too bad, but I was looking for more all around.

Tap.  Fizzy, small, white head (quickly dissapates).  Cloudy orange colored body.  Very peppery/spicy aroma.  Light yeast was also present but the pepperyness was a bit overwhelming.  Light Aceticness to taste.  Highly carbonated.  Sediments were noticed at bottom of glass.  Some alcohol warming noticed.  Okay-too peppery!

Hazy hay in color with a large, white, foamy head.  Aroma is noticeable from a far.  Spice, hops, sweet, banana, citrus, hay, yeast, and floral notes.  Flavor is spicey, yeast, floral hops, malt, and alcohol.  Finshes with more alcohol and spices.  Medium, properly carbonated body.  Ive always enjoyed this tripel.
Pours gold with white bubbly head. Aroma of malt, spice, and hops. Not overpowering. Tastes was bubbly of malt, hops, spice, and fruit. Good complexity.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2007 Bottle.  Pours a hazy golden/amber with a small white head.  Light aroma of malt with undertones of light hops.  Flavor is of light spicy hops with just a hint of alcohol.  Nice amount of carbonation with medium to full body.  Very nice.
Bottle.  A nice strong beer with a tasty tickle of the tongue.  If you like the somewhat overpowering taste of a tripple, give this beer a shot.

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2012 Poured into a trappist glass from a 330 mL bottle.  Aroma was great, featuring a heavy malt nose, caramel, subtle yeast, and a light floral and fruity background.  Some spice, banana, and bubble gum tones, and maybe some grassy hops.  A beautiful appearance with a cloudy amber-gold color and a big, white, foamy and bubbly head that had good retention.  It had a lively, fizzy texture with a spicy and fizzy finish.  There was a somewhat drying alcohol finish, and it was initially moderately thin and dry, but became wetter as it settled, and had a fairly full mouthfeel.  The taste was sweet and malty, becoming more sour and then somewhat bitter with an alcohol finish; it had notes of citrus, banana, and some yeast and wheat.  A great ale, that is sure to please, but hard to justify buying frequently at $5 for a bottle.

750 ml bottle. Pours hazy pale orange. Lively carbonation. Huge rocky near-white head, slowly diminishing . Aroma is dry fruity with spices and some yeasty scents. Taste is complex; fruity (citrus and sour apples) with notes of bready malt-sweetness, piny hops, spice, yeast, alcohol and an almosty astringent acidity in the aftertaste. Smooth and vineous mouthfeel. Dry, spicy and lingering light bitter end. Very nice.
Pours honey yellow with medium head that remains.  High carbonation.  Drinkable..alcohol well hidden.

Straw type color, no head at all. Yeasty nose, darn near smelled like a Hefe. Its a little sour and not the sweetness I normally associate with Belgian styles. Looking over other reviews, wondering if I got a bad bottle?

Hazy yellow gold with a huge rocky white head.  Very yeasty nose with light spice.  Flavor has lots of orange peel, corriander, doughy yeast, and some honey sweetness.  Dry alcohol finish.  Thick mouthfeel.

I drink it from bottle and sometimes is excellent and sometimes I am not drinking so much.  But is lighter for trippel, but very clean like drinking trappist beers should be.  Hops are in it also and it is not sugar beer like much of the American beers.
Bottle. Huge white head with excellent duration. Color is hazy golden. Aroma is yeast and fruit. Taste is fruits and alcohol.

Bottle:  Pours a hazy straw golden color with a large white head and nice lacing.  Nose is fruity and of spices.  Taste is of light citrus fruits with apple and pears, some sweet malt and spices.  Dry, ciderlike finish.

Bottle. 11.2 FL OZ. Foggy, amber color with champagne-like bubbles and a nice, frothy white head.  Spicy, fruity aroma. Medium bodied with an almost airy texture and a dry finish.  Flavor is sweet with a fair amount of bitterness and alcohol. Enjoyed the dubbel more, but still an excellent beer.

Bottle. Hazy yellow to orange with a white head. A much more intense fruity aroma compared to Westmalle Dubbel. Some sweet and butter. The alochol is well hidden, maybe too well.... Also a bit dry on the finish. A good belgian tripel. But dont have too many, you have been warned :-)

Bright straw colored. Great nose, candy sugar, typical belgian .  This one was dry, but it seemed to get sweeter as it warmed.  The alcohol wasnt as noticable, but I could tell after I had drank it.  This is a solid belgian.

wonderful surprise here.  asked for the dubel but the cafe was out and only had the tripel.  tons of buttery malts and spicy bitter hops.  amazingly comlplex and difficult to pick out the pieces.  met clifford smith who is the grand champion of the 2006 season of featherbowling... yeah, his picture is on the wall.
An amazing triple.  The color is cloudy straw.  The head is white and lasts forever.  The taste is amazing, delicious triple flavor with a nice bitter finish.  Another please.
750ml bottle.  Hazy orange with a big foamy head.  Fruity and spicy.  Very good beer.
A blonde coloured ale, with a strong sour belgian hop nose, and a sharp sour hop bitter with a hoppy linger.
Trippels aren´t exactly my favorite kind of beer, but this is a good example of the class. Neither too acidic nor too spicy, but harmoniously balanced.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2007 Very nice and good ballanced beer. A beer you can drink after years. All the trapist beers are among the best beers of the world. Taste 2 older versions. One of 35 years old and 1 of about 7 years. Those older beers where still very nice. Last year drunk a bottle of 25 years old and that one was ,not good anymore

The head is white and ample.  The aroma is hoppy.  The appearance is very murky and kind of a dark gold color.  It has that special "something" that only trappists have, but I think in less quantity that the dubbel.  I am quite suprised to find that I like the dubbel better, and of course this one probably has more alcohol than I normally like.

Murkey goldenrod hue, white creamy lasting head, small yeasty particles, smells of banana, grain/hay malt, creamy texture, has some spice light and peppery, very smooth, crisp with a little bit of a sour citrus lemon aftertaste, description is mainly yeasty.  Excellent, a must try!

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2008 Pow. Zam. Zoom. This was an interesting ale to say the least. Im working my way through the trappists, and have only has Chimay to start, so this is definitely a break from that. Much fizzier and clear on the pour (a golden yellow with a fair amount (if not bountiflu) had. Thin if non-existent lacing. Grazzy citrus and apple/pear on the nose and tongue. Once in the mouth, a little fruity bubble gum and a unique yeastiness. I dont see the cloudiness in my 750 ml bottle, so Im not sure if something is amis. Likeable beer, but Im not sure Id session drink this. Pared well, surprisingly, with pierogies! (Bottle Pour 4/23/2007)

Definitely a different beer than the Dubbel. Pours a clear golden with a nice 2-4 cm head. Nice fruits, citrusy with a light apple tart. Light bubbly mouthfeell with a little yeasty after taste on the tongue. Definitely a bit more alcohol on the nose, but its very bubbly and refreshing. If I could get more of this easily I would drink it regularly. I was lucky to also get a 750ml of this at one time as well (see above). (Bottle Pour 1/5/2008)
A sweet and slightly wheaty ale, the Tripel has a lightly bitter aftertaste. Very nice.
Very nice traditional tripel. Nice cloudy yellow pour with a thin foam. Nice hayish aroma and okay balanced sweet/bitter taste. One of th best traditional tripels.
Cloudy yelow pour. Aroma of spice and slight citrus.Smooth on the palate and citrus flavors. Very tasty Tripel.

Bottle at the Bierodrome, London. Golden with one finger white head. Nose is banana, apple, some bubblegum hints, as well as some varied spices bordering clove and coriander - real nice. Slight alcohol presence in the nose as well. Taste is upfront slightly warming, with strong orange and coriander, clove, banana. The finish is surprisingly dry, after some lingering spice. High carbonation; excellent, one of the best tripels around.

If Duvel didnt exist, Id probably give my vote to the Westmalle Tripel., especially when served in the right glass. Tastes quite good after a Duvel, but definitely not a beer for all-night drinking. Otherwise you wont see the dawn !

Pours a hazy yellowish color with a small head and a little lacing.  This beer has a nice malt and hop aroma with some citrusy undertones. Very nice taste with spices, cinnamon, hops and malt.  There is a great mouthfeel with a warming aftertaste and a nice warming alcohol feel to it.  EXCELLENT Triple.
Wow, this was fabulous.  The most well-balanced tripel Ive ever had.  Has the citrus appeal but is just so damn smooth youll never even taste the alcohol
Bottle, yellow, slightly cloudy, with a thin white head. Lots spices and a strong alcohol taste. not my first choice of triples.

Bottle. Subdued orange colour with a tight white head. Lots of aroma - spices, coriander & bread dough. Flavours of citrus and cinnamon. Alcohol was rather pronounced in the finish. Good, but no world-beater.
Tasted from bottle.  Light malty and hoppy aroma, with a HUGE creamy white head that hangs around for the last drop.  Slightly cloudy.  Long lasting finish with a creamy texture.

looks and smells like a spiced apple juice..loads of particulate floating in a golden body with a fluffy white head.  the aroma is very apple filled with some grass and yeast...flavor is very much the same...all and all this is a very good tripel..i usually like a little more spicyness, but it is definitelya very enjoyabe brew.

Bottle.  Peanut at Dilly Deli highly recommended this tripel and I was extrememly excited but disappointed as I have had tripels that I have thought much more of - Chouffe, La Fin du Monde.  Still a very good belgian with a ton of character, but I probably wont repeat knowing what else is available.

Bottle.  Massive white head covers a straw colored body that is a little cloudy.  Aromas:  apples, cloves, yeast, bread, a little citrus, etc.  Its not an overpowering nose, but theres a lot going on.  Lots of spice in the finish is the first comment.  Coriander and cloves take the show.  There is a bit of a sweet sugar baby note up front.  There are moments when I think that it comes off as a bit watery, but then that banana clove finish picks up and all my concerns are gone.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
I was excited to try this beer, as Ive heard a great deal about the Westmalle brewery.  I found this beer to be good, but to be honest found myself making unfavorable comparisons to some other tripels Iike Allagash Tripel Reserve and Tripel Karmeliet due to a very mild flavor and a bit of wateriness in the mouthfeel.

A bottle I picked up from a display at Consumer Beverage in Hales Corners.  This beer pours a hazy dark yellow with lots of soft secondary-fermentation produced head.  Smells tripel-ish with some clove notes and lots of coriander.  Flavor is a bit like a white wine up front, with some spiciness on the back end.  Not as full-flavored as other tripels Ive enjoyed like Tripel Karmeliet, Allagash, and Victory Golden Monkey.  Mouthfeel is quite soft, but a bit thin up-front.

Pours hazy orange. Light fruity and flowery aroma with tones of spices, mostly clove and coriander Also some orange peel and yeast. Malty and bready undertones. Full malty mouthfeel. Medium sweet and light bitter flavour with tones of spices and fruit. Elegant fruit acid dry finish. Well carbonated. Medium to full body. A very good tripel.

Honestly, I expected more from this Trappist beer. Strong alcohol nose well hidden in the flavor.  Small white head and pale clouded body.  Fizzy to the lips with sour yeast finish and hints of spicy fruitiness.

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2008 Second Rating 7/22/2008.  11.2 oz. bottle. I felt like I needed to re-visit this beer since I wasnt all that crazy about it the first time and the average is significantly higher than my rating.  This was a bit of a gusher when I opened the bottle.  A very slow pour into my Chimay chalice revealed an antique gold
beer with a large linen white head that lasted until mid-glass and left surprisingly little lace. The aroma was mostly yeast and alcohol with hints of spice and lemon.  The flavor is again yeast with a strong flavor of alcohol and a stronger spice presence than in the aroma.  There is a definite and distracting alcohol burn at the finish.  No change in my original rating, 
 
Original Rating 4/4/2007. 11.2 oz bottle.  Pours a cloudy honey gold with a thin white head that lasted through most of the glass. Light but pleasant aroma of yeast, green apples and a bit of alcohol.  The flavor was also a bit on the light side I thought with green apples, yeast, and a bit of lemon present in the flavor. Mouthfeel was a bit fizzy. Noticeable alcohol presence.  Not as good as its reputation.
Bottle. Aroma of yeast and alcohol. Hazy golden colour with Large lasting head. Spicy and fruity flavor with a lot alcohol.

Bottle from Tuckers Maltings. Another one of those beers that Id had so often but never got around to rating so I thought Id get reacquainted with this old friend. Poured a golden colour with just some haze there, and a large white frothy head. Nose was quite yeasty and with a definite spiciness. The taste is fruity and spicy with hints of clove and coriander but the alcohol is a touch harsh and whilst this is a quality beer it seemed harsher and a little rougher round the edges than Id remembered.

Poured from a 330ml bottle into a Duvel tulip glass, cloudy yellow with a medium beige head. The aroma had notes of pear, apple, citrus and the typical tripel yeast. The taste was sweet and smooth with notes of spice and citrus fruits. Creamy and buttery mouthfeel. Nice carbonation. The finish was slightly bitter with just a touch of alcohol bite. A bit dry as well. One of the better tripels Ive had.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2009 Bottle at Hoppe cafe, march 07. Spicy, honeish aroma. Strong, spicy, sparkling, shinnny flavor. Fruity, honey and a dry ending with a quiet coriander note. MF is medium with a punch of flavor and a dry, spicy finnish. Nice, spicy and sparkly golden trippel.
UPDATED: JUN 18, 2008 Bottle (33 cl) from Systembolaget. Cloudy golden, big fluffy head. Yeasty, earthy and spicy aroma. Medium bodied. Dry finish, alcohol very well hidden.

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2010 Perhaps I got a bad bottle, I shivered when I drank it, initially a lovely cookie slash banana scent. Appearance is of a small head, golden colour and a general inviting hue. The flavour took my breath away, very bitter with strong alcoholic undertone

Still, I will drink it again!

Re-rate - 01 October 2010
