Appearance: gorgeous hazy orange with TONS of white floaties, whispy white head. Aroma: lots of orange peel, spice, cinnamon, caramel, good alcohol punch to it too, warming clove & a hint of banana. Flavour: woah - huge tangy malt bomb at first, caramel, banana, lots of alcohol, cinnamon with a long bitter sweet finish. Woah. Super complex. Beautiful.
This is one of the top trappist beers, but its not my favourite one. Fine taste, mature look and perfect flavor.

330ml bottle. Been a long year since ive tried one of these. This particular bottle is best before tommorrow, so I thought why not! Spicy aroma, slightly nutty, buttery, toffee like malts, some fruity phenols from the yeast, nothing too outstanding. Looks great poured out into my Duvel glass. Thick billowing head atop a hazy looking gold body leaving clumps of lace. The body is rich, liqueur-like at times, surupy yet not cloyingling sweet. Im bombarded with notes of cinnamon and apple, peach, apricot and citrus notes, some breadiness, camembert-like cheese mould flavours, all balanced out with good amounts of buttery caramel malts. Alcohol is apparent yet not burning or too warming, merely adding to the body of flavour. Finish lingers, tantilises, slightly drying but begging for another flavour journey. Fantastic brew, glad I got to try it in more ideal circumstances than the first time.

This beer has a fantastic head.  The aroma is yeasty, a little sour/alcoholic and spicy.
Taste-wise, I would say that it has a nice lingering alcoholic and slightly bitter finish.  This tastes different than the first time I had it.  I remember liking it much, much more the first time.  Has a citrus and apple note to the beer along with the spicy finish.   Hmm, I just do not like it as much as when I had it even a few years ago.
Very very tasty.  I loved the color, the slight alcohol bite, the spice flavor and the lingering carbonation.
Highly carbonated.  Nicely spiced.  Aroma of citrus.  Tastes of fruit and spice. Very good beer.

Sampler, Trappist evening hosted by Philippe Wouters at Lautre il, savoured on site on January 17 2007; eye: golden, hazy, good effervescence, white head; nose: alcohol, spices, orange; mouth: malt, alcohol, spices, caramelized malt, finale in alcohol with a hint of spices, creamy texture, good carbonation, full body, lightly bitter, mildly sweet; overall: tiny disappointment

FRANÇAIS 

Échantillon, soirée trappiste animée par Philippe Wouters à Lautre il, savourée sur place le 17 janvier 2007; oeil : dorée, voilée, bonne effervescence, mousse blanche; nez : alcool, épices, orange; bouche : malt, alcool, épices, malt caramélisé, finale en alcool avec une pointe dépices, texture crémeuse, bonne carbonatation, corsée, légèrement amère, moyennement sucrée; en résumé : petite déception
UPDATED: AUG 17, 2007 THE tripel! A classic among the classics. Wonderful complex aroma. Well hidden alcohol, very drinkable. Slightly sweet finish, but drier than most in the class.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2007 Bottle. Pours hazy gold/amber with floaties and a fluffy beige head. Aroma is citrusy with a nice banana/clove dance and nice spices and yeast. the flavor is more aggressive than I expected. Lots of strong citrusy fruits, a sweet candied apple note, as well as the nice spices and yeast found in the aroma. The finish is warm from the alcohol, and just dry enough to make you want to take another sip immediately.  Updated, in a blind tasting, this won over Allagash tripel, Tripel Karmeleit, and Chimay. Wonderful.
A superb beer. Hazy blond in colour. Generous head. Taste of fruits, citrus and lemon.

Bottle (hand carried from Amsterdam if that makes a difference...?)    .    .
Citrus, apricot aromas with bready hints and maybe some candi sugar.  Light malt, no hops. ..	Golden, slight haze, wildly energetic bubbles produce a growing, long lasting, meringue-like head. . 	Citusry, spicy flavor, lightly malty.  Complex yeasty flavor. ..	Light body, high carbonation. .. 	Good stuff.  Lots of flavors going on. ..
Bottle.  Pours surprisingly light, good head.  Fruity sweet taste & finish.  Different than what I expected but good.
I have heard that this is not the beer it used to be. I think it is thin and that there are way better tripels out there. Page 494 of Michael Jacksons Great Beer Guide.

A Mes rate: 
Yet another one we had to catch up on after being stunned this had slipped under our rating radar. Easily available and quaffed many many times, how have we not rated this? You just always presume dont you? Anyway, hazy golden colour with a superb and inviting white head. Citric (orange) and spicy nose, maybe some corriander and definite yeast. Rather sweet in the mouth and Im sure a lot of that comes from the alcohol which sadly is way too obvious. Still a bit of a lip smacker there is no doubt. Having had some old-ish bottles of this I know it mellows very nicely with age. Definite pepper in the finish which is dry and slightly earthy. Good beer that is easy to find.
This is a fine beer. I just seem to like the double more. I had this after I had a double, when I was in Belgium. Love the belgium beers!
Bottle. Murky, with a nose of citrus and lemon. Highly carbonated, almost fizzy. Lasting head. Flavors range from sweet honey, to deep, dry spices. Very long finish. Very, very good.

Pours a beautiful hazy pale orange-gold, with a decent viscous head (egg whites) and a wonderful fruity aroma. Wonderfully balanced flavour! Pale malting with some definite notes of apricot brandy,.citrus, and great light but substantial peppery hoppiness which lingers well into the warm, pleasant (not too dry, but dry enough) aftertaste. I must admit, I poured a few inches above the glass near the end to get the head going and release some of the carbonation, so this one is not too heavily carbonated at this point (which is perfect) and sports an appropriately present, not too thin body. This is by far one of the better Tripels I have tasted, and I think I must buy some for the summer.

Not inexpensive at $10.79 from my local North Coast Coop.    Poured a cloudy gold with big and long-lasting white head and nice chunks of lacing.  Nose of coriander, flowers, citrus, and fruits. Very smooth and clean mouthteel and flavors that dance on your tongue.  Good dry finiish,  Nice lookng, nice smell, nice palae, nice flavors, and a nice finish.  Shucks, a nice beer.

A nice tripel. I was expecting a little more but this was still above average. Pour was a hazy gold with a little sediment. Aroma was fruity yeast. Taste was yeast with some spice with the classic dry finish I love about Belgians. Nice.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
Very pale and cloudy with a big lasting head. Spice aroma. Taste is strong, sweet and tart with more spice and less fruit than other examples of this style. Long, somewhat dry finish. Noticeable alcohol, but for 9.5% its fairly well masked.

Not really a fan of this style, but as far as Tripels go, this is a favorite.
11.2oz bottle pours a cloudy piss color, a thin white head and some floaters. Overall this is a damn good beer.

Light golden and hazy with a nice and lasting head, and I pour it in my new Westmalle glass. The aroma has notes of coriander. The flavour is sweet with notes of coriander, other spices, fruit and citrus. The alcohol is present, but only just, and I can imagine this would be better after another year or so. The finish is long and the notes from the flavour is present all the way through. A really nice trippel, one of the best I tasted at this point (April 05).

bottle: pours a murkey hay colour with some floaties in it. very small and thin white head. very swett aroma with some fruits and spices flavour is pretty strong at first but mellows out and finishes excellent. taste of spices and fruit like the nose some alcohol in there as well. it tingles my palate and leaves me refreshed. excellent with each swallow and perfect slight dryness in the finish.

Sampled in the US prior to going to Brugge. Excellent beer and has an amazing color and flavor. Besides the wonderful head on it, the mouthfeel is most important as it goes down incredibly smooth and leaves a great aftertaste.
Cloudy yellow colour with large frothy stark white head. Spicy nutmeg and corriander nose. Spicy alcohol taste with warming alcohol finish.

Bottle.  This beer poured with virtually no head at all except for a few bubbles.  The aroma is sweet with hints of dried fruits and honey.  The color is a golden yellow with small floaties.  Flavor is lightly sweet initially and develops into an alcoholic centered dry fruity finish.  The palate is a bit watery with the duration continuing into an alcoholic flavor.  Ok overall, but might need to try again with a different bottle as it seems different compared to the other ratings.

Hazey, golden/pale body with an enormous white head, lasting, nice lacing. Banana, candi sugar, clove, honey and bread in the nose. Flavor is slightly sweet, banana, peach, musty, honey, dough, grassy and herbal hops and corriander. Medium body, soft carbonation and a soft, delicate texture.
Boddy is foggy gold with a thick white head.  Yeasty aroma with honey, apricots, fruit.  Taste is yeasty with peach, apricot, light alcohol.  Body is a bit fizzy.

Lovely gold, with only a slight haze. The white head lasts well. There is an AMAZING aroma of malt & spice. Not as full bodied as I expected, but still a big mouthful, fantastic flavour, I found it a touch sweet, but very well balanced. A refreshing acidity comes through on the l-o-n-g finish. A fine ale that is dangerously easy to drink for a 9.5%er.
Bottle.  Cloudy, hazy lemon brown coloring.  1" head, lacy and hugs the glass.  Crisp, tart, not-too-carbonated.  Alcohol taste noticeable.  Nice light release.  Hint of sour apple.
Pours a pale yellow with a medium sized white head.  Aroma has lots of yeast and some mild spices.  Taste is smooth, slightly bitter, with a dry finish.  Good but not remarkable.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2007 Bottle 12 oz.  Opaque yellow-amber.  Yeast, sweet fruit, and spice aroma with a little alcohol and vinegar.  Taste is similar to aroma but with more spice and some bitterness at the end.
The flavor was not at all what i was expecting.  Typically, i like beer with less of that hop bite.
Cloudy golden yellow with fine white head. Yeast, spice, fruit, malt and vinegar. Very fruity, but still very well balanced.
frothy head lacing the glass, pale and cloudy. aroma spicy. more bitter than i expected but pretty good. evenly-hopped. warming feeling. some alcohol detectable. overall good but could be better.
Poured a hazy golden color with a huge frothy white head that one would expect from a Belgium. Aroma was yeasty. This beer had a full mouth feel but was very drinkable. Good but not great.

Bottle.  Light tan color with a medium, mostly diminishing head.  Spicy and slightly sweet.
I was very underwhlemed with this beer.  It was good, but nothing like what I was expecting.  The overwhelming thought while drinking this was "this reminds of MGD."  I have had a Dubbel before and it was excellent, so maybe I was just expecting too much.

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2007 Bottle, Date 11/07/07, maybe 4 years old? Huge head doesnt fit into glass. Cloudy apple cider color. Nice fruit of the vine + toffee malt aroma. Toffee apple and peppery citrus taste. Creamy palate. Smooth and dry alcohol finish leaves a very nice, large  and long-lasting warm spot on my insides.

Semi transparent value of copper/gold in color. Very  tick head of off white and not lacy. Good triple blend of yeast ,candy and bitter citrus like. The triple alcohol is apparent so let it warm a bit before tasting.

Orangy, candy-like aroma.  Cloudy copper color with a white head that starts thick and doesnt seem to completely disappear.  The flavor has the sweetness of a juice orange but the crisp finish of cranberry.  What in the description is spiciness, I taste as alcohol.  A good beer, but also a reminder that I tend to enjoy dubbels more than tripels.
Pours a surprising yellow color with a white head for a tripel.  A peppery apricot aroma.  Flavor is very peppery spicy with a hint of fruityness.  Nice mouthfeel for a light colored beer.
Copper and clear.  Peppery floral nose.  Slightly sweet with an obvious alcohol finish.  Warms the throat.  Enjoyable.
oh man this is good!  mad yeasty aroma with a hefeweizen like appearance.  citrus bitter flavor is consistent with the smells and has a nice alcohol notes in the nose.
Murky gold , large white head.Salty yeasty nose.Lightly fruity, yeasty,noticeable hops and alcohol heat

Pours a dark straw gold with a huge fizzy and slightly frothy off-white head. Strong tropical fruit aroma, with a light note of floral hops and alcohol. Flavor has light notes of tropical fruit, a bit of doughy yeast, nice floral bitterness, and a definate hint of the alcohol (very pronounced slightly above cellar temp.). Palate is very effervescent and lightly bitter, very average tripel mouthfeel. Good, but overall on the average side. Not much complexity, but still fairly balanced with the exception of the alcohol being a little too present.

Pours a dark golden color with a rediculously thick white head that lasted the whole drinking. Lacing was sick. Smell is very fruity, and floural. Taste is very fruitie, in a good way. It really blends well with the alcohol taste this brew has. As it warms the alcohol comes a little more up to the forefront. Very solid brew.
Cloudy, yellow-gold body with a huge white head. Fruity aroma with some spice. Flavor is very sweet, more citrus peel, ginger, pine. Lots of carbonation, like a soda. Overrated and dull.
Pours a murky blonde color with a white head. Picked up a lot of fruits and hops in the nose. Bitter Citrus flavors  with a hint of caramel.
pours a murky yellow with a medium head.  graasy smell, almost can smell, the strength.     a little thick on the palate.  bitter and dry.  better than average belgian.

Bottled 2003 - Hazy beautiful golden body with a creamy white head; Very pleasant nose with lots of hazelnuts fresh as dry; Lots of soft carbonation in soft pleasantly bitter body; Quite long bitter finish, some acid has sneaked in as well.
Not up to par as far as other trappistes go.  its still tasty but lacks complexity and finish.
(from notes) Bottle. Pours pale yellow with thin head. Yeasty belgian nose. Sharp and strong on the palate. Bready, sour, bitter. An okay abbey ale, but not that complex.
Mild fregrence fruity tast and straw yellow colour,with small bubbels.Cremy head short finish with strong alc.

Beer 3 of Obriens Trappist Tasting 2/3/07.  Pours golden yellow and bubbly with a thin psuedo head.  I dont what was happening with my nose but I hardly could smell much of any aroma.  Taste is sweet with a nice large kick, the alchol starts to come through more on the tail end.

Lots of yeast and floral scents with some alcohol in the aroma.  Extremely hazy golden color.  The palate is very full and smooth.  The taste is very yeast-dominated with malts coming through.  Floral, spicey, and earthy flavors come out strong in the finish.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2008 I have many fond memories with this Abbey.  Was on a three day beer tour with close friends on the border of Belgium and Netherlands.  This was my first beer of the 3 day journey and the barman let me keep the Trappist glass which I used on the remainder of the tour.  The flavor has a mild sweetness and hoppiness to it and hides the 9.5% alcohol quite well, which makes this a smooth beer.

Poured a hazy pale golden color with a medium white head. Didnt really leave a lace. The aroma was definitely trappist, spicy, aged fruit, alcohol, and bready yeast. The flavor was sour/yeast, aged fruit, spice, alcohol, and bready yeast as well. So it looks like the aroma is a good reflection of what to expect. The palate is dry with the alcohol showing through. The finish is warm and earthy.

The color was a foggy golden/orange.  The head was white, thin, and fizzy.  The aroma was yeast, alcohol, and citris.  The flavor was alcohol, yeast, and citris as well.  The palate was nice in that the carbonation was just right and the finish was very warm.
murky yellow. big white head. aroma of dirt and spice, violet,  flavor is spicy and dry but quite balanced overall the alcohol is hidden nicely

Clear gold coloured beer. Slightly irregular head. medium stickyness.
Aroma dominated by hops and spices. I think to recognise some oranges in the taste. Medium body. Medium carbonation. Long lasting aftertaste.
Even if pricey, were lucky to get these gems here in Michigan. But in Belgium - every dive has it on tap. A king beer. Bow before it.

12 oz bottle, via Zathrus13.  Pours a mostly clear yellow gold with a slight fine yeast haze under a one finger fizzy and foamy white head that fell to a thin covering.  Aroma is the gold standard for an Abbey Triple I suppose.  Heavy thick pale malt with some yeast, alcohol, fruitiness, spices, and dough.  Flavor is floral and fruity with some hefty alcohol up front.  Finishes quite dry with lots of spiciness.  A little too much alcohol apparency for me, but I find that with alot of Tripels.  Mouthfeel is very spritzy despite the heavy thick maltiness, finishing quite a bit drier than many Tripels.  This may be the standard, but its the standard in a style that I think may be one of my least favorite.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2007 nice yellow/orange color. 
smells strong, but on your palate its not. very smooth. some subtle spiciness, and hoppines.  should cellar well.

Wonderful to look at, with its orangey colour and blossoming head. Pleasantly fresh hoppy aroma. The hops are present throughout but the beer is not very bitter by any means. Some subtle notes of orange and spiciness. This is a very good, but not a very great, beer.

[Tasted to Carsten Berthelsen, Ølrejsen in 2004.]  

Not my favorite style, but one of my favorites in this style. Strong and full of ingredients. Needs time to adapt.

Pours a golden hue, with a nice white head.  Nose of vanilla, pear, and apple.  The flavor is not as fruit forward as the nose, but carries a toffee and pear balance as well as a nice alcohol burn.  A beautiful tripel, and it should be as it was the first.  Nice sweet nose with a great dry mouthfeel.  Wonderful and under-appreciated.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: Bottle Trappist glass, great head nice hazy gold color. Alchohol was noticble. A bit grainy fairly dry finish I usualy like a bit more sweetness in my triples but not too bad. Alcohol was quite noticble.
Bottle. Hazy amber colour with a good mostly lasting whitish head. Aroma of yeast and alcohol, bit fruitiness. Bit sweet moderate malty aroma with spices, yeast, bit alcoholic. Dry finish.
Pours a light orange-yellow with a light, foamy head. This beer has a strong yeasty, vanilla, and alcoholic flavor with a slightly nutty after taste.
Not my stile. I had this beer some years in my cellar and I expected much. Too much I think. Much taste of alcohol.

BB 03-08.  Pours a hazy golden-copper color with small amout of sediment; head is brilliant white, full, and creamy with tight bubbles.  Head is mostly lasting with plenty og tight lacing, maybe the best light-colored beer Ive seen.  Strong with lots of lighter fruit in the nose; lots of yeast and banana, some pear, light apricot, light honey and pepper, faint floral with whisps of alcohol.  Flavor is somewhat of a letdown from the nose, sweet with candi sugar and not as much fruit.  Starts sweet with a honey, banana, clove, and a light bread note; moves drier and more bitter with some notes of pepper and floral.  By the finish, the alcohol makes itself known and ending quickly with some notes of herbal, but still banana, honey, and pepper.  Palate is medium full, lively, and a rich, creamy mouthfeel.  Nice tripel but the flavor didnt match the rest of the well-crafted beer.  A little less alcohol would help this one, but overall, nice offering.

Pours orange-golden with a huge head.  Aroma is floral and of alcohol.  Flavor is of candi sugar, peppery and with more alcohol.  Nice to be sure, but not the best trippel Ive ever had.  Wheres all the fruit flavor?

Light golden color.  Fruity aroma with a touch of yeast.  Flavor was a bit of a let down: Toasted malt, yeast, banana, and a bitter finish.  Alcohol presence is a bit much and distracting bitterness make this not my favorite tripel.

Pours a hazy straw amber, with lots of clumps of proteins or yeast or both. Half an inch of white head reduces to a film and a ring, which leaves very nice lacing somehow. Peach, wheat, and caramel in the aroma.

Thick sweet caramel and dark honey malt flavor. I also taste an earthy rye-like grain and a touch of green tea. Thick and sweet and deliciosly dry at the same time. Complex and tasty.

Medium to full body, ample carbonation, dry, spicy, herbal, and a little alcoholic in the aftertaste.

Pours golden with a thin head. The aroma and flavor is well balanced.
slightly bitter. A solid beer.
This had a rather flat bitterness in the flavor.  The flavor did not quite seem to live up to the  aroma.  Not that great a tripel in my opinion.

Honey, marmelade in the glass. Slightly cloudy, hazy. The head starts massize, then quickley falls to a bubbling smaller size, leaving strong lacing on the glass. Taste of malt sweetness, a porridge with treacle taste. It has strong alcohol, bananna and almond marzipan. A spicy cinamon with a citric top note. Smooth in the mouth, with long acohol lingering for ages after you swallow. Too strong for me to really love, but a great beer.

Bottle. Average head with a frothy with appearance. Good lacing left in glass. Light cloudy look with an amber/orange colour. Aroma was heavy spicy (pepper) with some tobacco and other notes as grain, straw and nuts. Full bodied with an average carbonation. Flavour was light sweet with moderated bitterness to it. Finish was long and complex. Very nice Tripel I must say.
Bottle poured into red wine glass.  Hazy shiny orange pour.  Aroma is sweet / earthy, odd combo, but thats what I got.  The taste is good, though not in any way special.  Finish was very yeasty.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2008 33cl Bottle.  Hazy golden colour with small sediment and a large white head that lasts with good lacing.  Aroma of mild spice, earth and yeast.  Rather intense tripel flavour but mellowed before finished. Enjoyable beer.
Douce et rugueuse en même temps. Fine, subtile elle picotte la langue et raffraichit même en hivers

Bottle; Nose is yeasty with a little banana, clove, and citrus; lightly hazed gold with a small white head; a tiny bit of tartness hits my tongue first, leading into the fruit and spices, ending with a nice  bitter, with a tiny bit of alcohol, finish.

Drank in a trappist glass.  Golden hazt poor with a nith thin sticky white head.  Aromas of bananas, sweet bread, coriander, tangerines, alcohol... with a hint of butterscoth.  Dry mouthfeel... creamy and balanced finish with a good bitterness to it.  You can taste the hops  somewhat creamy resin.  You definitely cannot feel the 9.5 % in this belgian beauty.
I HAD HEARD ALOT ABOUT THIS AND WAS NEVER A BIG BELGIUM FAN SO THIS TO ME WAS JUST A REGULAR BEER THAT WAS HIGH IN ALCOHOL AND CITRUS FLAVOR.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2006 Bottle shared with my friend Brian. Pours hazy golden with a nice retentive white head. Nice yeasty and perfumy aroma, with notes of clove and citrus. Very nice mouthfeel, not too fizzy or rich. Flavor wheat malt, clove, pear, and banana with the right amount of sweetness. Slightly dry, but spicy finish with well hidden alcohol. I think this is very well balanced.  A little tamer than some triples, but that is what I liked about this one.

11.6 oz bottle-Pours a cloudy golden color w/a small white head & good lacing. Full, sweet, floral aroma The dry flavor hits you right up front, doesnt have the complex flavor levels one would usually associate w/a quility belgian. Spicy & dry mostly, some hops. Very average. Kind of a thin dry finish. You can drink it, but I wouldnt seek it out. Disapointing.
Bottled. Hazy orange golden coloured with a rather large head. Spicy and fruity - notes of hops and yeasts. Somewhat sweet.
UPDATED: SEP 2, 2007 Golden yellow with a few thin patches of white head. Peachy yeast nose. Spicy with a lemon/citrus hint. Slightly bitter and dry with a thin palate. I prefer the dubbel.
From a bottle, it pours with a airey head, smells like lemony peaches, tastes like peppered wheat infused with a basket of citrus fruit, and its rather good.

Hazy, honeyed orange with a huge white head that leaves gorgeous tiered lacing.

Aromas are dry, yeasty, and malty, but not terribly expressive.

Subtly fruity (peach/berry) as it enters the mouth, but the flavor profile develops and becomes high-toned, somewhat raw, dry but not bitter, finishing with a tannin-like impression and a tiny bit of tartness.  Chewing the beer brings out a little spice, mainly pepper.  Alcohol is masked, and the mouthfeel is  medium.

A subtle, dry classic.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2007 33cl bottle.  Poured cloudy dark orange/amber with a big off-white frothy head.  Aroma of orange yeast bread, more mineraly than spicy and very subtle for a tripel.  Flavor of mildly sweet cakey malt with citrus peel and banana notes and a spicy, even peppery finish.  Noticeable yeast in the full palate but it also has a fair amount of carbonation.  While it seem a little less complex than other Tripels its in no way understated.

Golden pour with substantial foamy head and lots of yeast cloudiness.  Sweet, malty aroma with some hints of citrus.  Rich citrus malt taste that is quite bready and dominated by yeast.  A good tripel, but not as smooth as I would have liked out of a top notch trappist brew.

330mL bottle.  in a Koningshoeven (AKA La Trappe) trappist glass.  Hazy golden color.  Aromas of citrus, apples, lemon peel, yeast and lots of goodness.  Ever have a beer you knew would blow your mind just by the smell of it!  (Sound like a OT-D topic!)  Very oily texture.  refreshing flavor.  Tastes of sweet yeast rolls and bananas.  A very good Tripel.
UPDATED: JAN 3, 2010 A cloudy golden color. Slight sweet and malty flavor. Nice mildly sweet aftertaste. A little too much carbonation. Not quite spicy enough

Beer pours a pale golden color with little to no head.  The flavor is VERY, very unique and the spice is definately present from the first sip, but not overly pleasant.  The finish is stong and surprisingly bitter for a Belgium beer.  I was completely unimpressed by this beer, but it is unique.
Cloudy gold pour with fluffy white head.  Aroma of yeast, sour apple, and light malt.  Flavor is sweet malt, lemon zest, strong bold dark fruit, and apple.  Medium palate.
330 ml bottle.  Pours light cloudy brown with a beautiful white head.  Aroma of apples and other fruit.  Spicy taste with strong bitter hops that linger.  A very good, but not great tripel.

A fantastic tripel. Refreshing, strong, goes well with so many foodstuffs, and is very drinkable too, with deep & complex flavors and aroma. For me this is the tripel by which all other tripels are benchmarked.

I dont know why, but I dont feel this beer as much as others do.  It looked great, but the smell was just okay, the palate was just a bit too carbonated, and the flavor was full, but a little thin.  I will try it again under different circumstances to see if this was just a fluke, but in the meantime...

Bottled. Trappist Goblet. Thin waning head with an aesthetically pleasing color and carbonation. Round, full mouth feel. Spicy flavor with a dry and bitter hop finish. Not a personal favorite from Belgium, no guarantees on freshness but it is still enjoyable.

White head with some lacing.  Hazy, straw color.  Aroma is malty with hints of nut (almond).  The intiail sweetness is complex and fruity, with alcohol sweetness very present.  Strong bitter hop finish at end.  I found the body to be very full and the beer to give me an almost buttery feeling as well.  This is an excelent example of what a tripel is ment to be.

Hazy dark gold. Full frothy white head. Sweet musty fruity aroma with some yesty spice. Taste is a little strongly spiced at first, but it is really good after initial palate acclamation. Sweet fruity, bitter apples, estery spicy yeast, excellent. A great belgiam beer I am glad to have available to me!

Aroma:  Musty, malty, spicy, fruity, very nice.  Complex.  

Appearance:  Nice white head, cloudy, darker blond color. 

Flavor:  Silky smooth, sweetish malt is lovely.  Also, the spiciness and fruitiness that was in the nose is also present.  Some warming alcohol.

Palate:  Way to drinkable, dangerous!  Alcohol is very evident however.

Overall:  Man, absolutely excellent beer.  Very drinkable and flavorful.
A quite bitter aroma of orange. Looks like Jaffa for those who know what it is. Very foamy on the palate. Taste of orange zest and yeast.
(33 cl bottle at The Rover, Göteborg) Sweet scent. Shady yellow color, white creamy head. Fruity and alcohol smell. Sweet and alcohol taste. Warming alcohol. Low bitterness.
Very thick and cloudy in the glass. Strong mouthfeel. Variety of flavors as this beer is enjoyed.

Shes got the look... This is just how you want your little tripel mistress to look like. Unfortunately she turns out as a little, alcoholic tramp when you drink her. Just a little too much of the heavenly stuff getting through the fruity, slight malty and hoppy lady. It could have been my lifes companion if the alcohol was better hidden. Quite a shame, really...
I enjoyed the Dubbel better but this one was just as good.  Spicy aroma.  Rich and gold with a white head.  Very nice!
Spicey aroma.Pours gold with big white head.Flavor is of pepper and maybe a hint of oak.Very carbonated with a nice alcohol finish.Very solid brew.
Nice light citrus aroma. Clean, bright  white head, translucent peach color. This is a delightful belgian ale.

An orangolden pour with an aroma of coriander, spice, and fruitiness that reminds me of a dry white wine.  A very dry fruitish flavor not much yeast but a very well hidden 9.5alc that makes this a really good warm beer. I was afraid it would be hot but its not. I really like a warm abv beer. This beer has a first out sweet but quickly jumps to dry and fizzy as the style dictates. I like this little 12oz baby. An all round tripel.
UPDATED: JAN 6, 2013 an enjoyable tipple, that stays on the back of the tongue that little bit longer than most..

the triple was 1 point lower for me and that was appearance...a yellow gold, hazy and spritzy look..bananna slight yeat honeyish smell...constent pool o head....looks deep orange champagne, lots of small bubbles...smooth bitter..nice aftertaste..great masking here...even though the bitters are big, still very balanced out! i like this too!

From a 330mL Bottle.  Pours a cloudy orange-tinged color of hay with a dissipating white soapy head.  Aromas of orange zest instantly drift to my nostrils along with some sweet peach sugars.  Lots of orange citrus merengue dusted with a light layer of confectioners sugar and a hint of phenolic banana.  Light to medium bodied, crisply carbonated mouthfeel.  This is quite obviously a big beer, yet the alcohol doesnt have any overpowering qualities.  A bit of orangey sweetness starts out on the palate, but this is quickly replaced by a wave of dry, bitter herbs.  Finishes with a musty yeasty spice that lingers with some bready malts in the final smack.

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2007 Hazy golden with an ample rocky white head. Good lacing. Aroma of trappist yeast, fruit and spices. Quite complex malty, fruity (citrus ,apple) flavour balanced with hop bitterness. Dry somewhat bitter finish. This tripel has a differnt flavour quality and balance from my favourite Tripel Karmeliet, but is really very good.

Aroma is light, with some light banana malt and a touch of dried fruit, spicy citrus and a touch of minerals.  Color is a light golden yellow with a huge, rocky head.  Light bready malt flavor with a hint of caramel and  touch of alcohol.  Finish is nicely balanced both sweet and malty and bitter and dry.  Medium body with a dry finish and nice carbonation. Very nice, Im surprised by this one.  Especially when its on closeout for $2.50 a bottle!
A good, representative Belgian.  Good appearance, bright, hazy gold color with the nice Belgian lace.  Traditional tripel mix of wood and alcohol.  Nice.
rating 300: aroma is nice and spicy with hints of orange, corriander, hops, and alcohol.  hazy orange with a white head.  Flavor is dry bitter and spicy.  medium to heavy palate.  prett decent
UPDATED: APR 18, 2007 Golden Pour with fizzy white head.  A nice fruity spicey nose.  Spicey fruit, belgian yeast, citrus, some banana, and a little bitter for a belgian.  Good, but nothing special.

pours light orange and hazy white frothy head.  Aroma is complex malty, citrus hoppiness apple and alcohol esters.  Flavor is wekll balanced leaning twords the bitter side, finish is again well balanced with an avrage duration finish.  Light to medium bodied watery and lively just a hint of alcohol in the finish.
Had at Joes a while ago golden colour, the definitive triple from what i have tried, spicy sour notes some citrus, great belgian trappist triple
Sampled at Issac Newtons with Stegosaurus and Beerded_one. Hazy golden bronze pour.  Citrus/ begian spice aroma. Mild carbonation. Spicy/sour finish. GOOD BREW
Bottled at home. Very strong but easy to drink ale. I prefer a bit lower percentage of alcohol (like Orval) but this is really perfect beer. Highly recommended.

Poured from 750 mL offering.  As it is described... strong, dry and spicy trappist ale.  I let my second half of the bottle sit chilled for a few days after my original pour and it has developed a more mellow, less sharp character.  Highly Recommended Tripel.

A very dry hoppy tripel beautiful balanced. An absolute standard under the tripels. The beer is dry with a lot of fruit. Together with the hops it has a beautiful aroma. The high carbonation makes the aroma come out very well.
What I would expect of a Belgian trappist ale.  Spicy with a slight yeastiness to the smell and taste.  Smooth body with decent carbonation.  A little off flavor lingers on the palate.
UPDATED: NOV 29, 2006 Terrific Tripel.  A true classic.  Dryer and more bitter than most Tripels, which suits me fine.  Fruity with a bit of sourness as well.  Carbonation level is perfect.

Gotta pour this thing slooooowww.  Looks beautiful, a cloudy dark gold with an inceasant foamy head.  Bananas, sour elements, wheat, some spice and nutty malt come to the nose.  Flavoris maltier than expected, with some slight caramel notes and earthy nuttiness.  The finish continues this progression into a spicy, very dry, and surprisingly hoppy finish (not real hoppy, but its there).  Good moutfeel, lively carbonation fits right in.  Very good.  I never was a big fan of tripels, but this beer makes me want to give some more of them a try, and revist ones I havent had in a while.  Very nice.

Poured a cloudy pale straw color with a full and lasting head.  Aroma is interesting and is only good after a fresh pour or swirling the glass.  Earthy, vanilla, and spice, such a wonderful blend of spice.  Some ginger, coriander, cardamom, and pepper, but so gentle that they are hard to detect.  There is also a background of musty green vegtables that builds a complex depth to the beer.  Flavor Is similar to the aroma though more intense.  The spice character really comes out.  There is an earthiness that reminds me of a saison.  Some banana and other fruit flavor come through into the flavor profile but in subdued amounts.  This beer has a rich maltiness but is delightfully crisp and refreshing.  There is also a bit of hops in the finish that i am picking up as i am typing.  Wonderful beer, I am surprised it took me this long to try this one.

A fine pick for my rating #500.  Only a small pop on the cork.  Poured lightly hazy orange with a small sudsy white head.  The aroma is very earthy with lots of sharp spice.  It is drier than most tripels and has some dry vineous aspects.  Medium / full body with a good amount of carbonation.  Starts with a slick sweetness that is quickly taken over by a peppery spice, yeast and some barnyard aspects.  The finish has a sharp spicy side that comes in.  The finish starts off slightly astringent, but mellows quickly and brings in some spicy hops.  Further down the bottle when the yeast starts pouring into the glass the taste gets smoother and gains some citrus taste.  Excellent world class beer.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2006 Still, my perfect brew. Its fantastic, very good , excellent. Enormous flavours, drinkable, and both thirst quenching and enjoyment. I really really love this beer. From my point of view, the best in the entire world
Bottle. Hazy yellow with white nice heading. I thought it would be better but anyway is a very nice beer. Do not drink more than 3....
Bottle. Nice Trappiste, they do make som extremely good beers do i have to say any more.

Pours bright golden with a medium sized white foamy head. Aroma of apples, tart cherries, sweet fruity yeasty, and bubble gum. Taste is candied fruits and cotton candy. Mouthfeel is medium to heavy bodied and slightly sticky with livley carbonation. Lots of fruity zing and yeasty bite. Quite enjoyable, if a bit on the heavy side.

Slightly murky yellow body with characteristically thick off white head.  Smells malty, citrusy, and a bit spicy.  Tastes citrusy, sweet, somewhat piney.  Very tasty.  Medium-to-full  bodied.  Not my favorite tripel, but a very good one anyway.
pours a hazy yellow, high carbonation.  aromas of spice and light hops.  crisp taste, spicy, peppery very good  mouthfeel, slight hop finish, good, but the dubbel is better.
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text: Golden color with a thick white foam. Spicy with some flovery notes. Medium to full body with a slightly bitter finish.
Golden yellow with a snow white head.  Lots of spice, floral, and even citrus flavor.  Refreshing mouth feel.  Plenty bitter.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2010 The aroma is marked by flowery hops and a good amount of yeast. Aroma is very appealing, but unfortunately a little indistinct. The flavor is again marked by the yeast, and a sweet though surprisingly malty taste with a good balance between sweetness and alcohol. The flowery hops are obvious as in a botanic garden, and the quite bitter finish subdues the alcohol; by that it gives no impression of a 9,5% ABV. All in all a really nice beer.
Bottle: Pours a rich golden color with an incredible head.  A very nice complex flowery beer with unique spiciness.  Full bodied with a nice blend of citrus, yeast, and dryness.
Just a little hazy blonde with a big persistant cap of white. Very pretty. Green grapeskin aroma, cardamom, cinnamon. Slighty tart, clean, light tropical fruit. A fresh and delicate tasting beer.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2010 Well.. this is one hell of a nice triple.. just like the double its very robust.. intens yeasty aroma.. quite a complex taste.. though not as complex as say a chimay triple.. but still.. its less unique then the double but still absolutely brilliant

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2006 Bottle. First had this beer in Belgium, and have had it a few times in the states.  Pours a nice gold color.  Aroma was of citrus, bubblegum, and alcohol mainly.  Maybe a little spice.  Taste was great.  Sweet taste, almost like sugar, but great.  Some spice.  Alcohol was not overpowering.  Well balanced I thought.  I know many who rate this as one of their top few beers.
Big airey head, with flowery, necturey nose.  Taste like citrus rock candy with smooth alcohol undertones.  No real note on spiciness, but still delicious.
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text:
This beer poured a dazzling golden yellow with a thin film of white head that was sustained by a field of bubbles. 

Smelled of mandarin oranges, coriander, fresh cut roses, spicy yeast and of sweet green grapes. 

The flavor contains a smooth, creamy and understated sweet wheat and peach sweetness accompanied by a floral and pungent grapefruit and citrus yeast. The way these two flavors blended effortlessly together to create one potent, yet smooth sensation is beyond my vocabulary. Finishes pleasantly dry and yeasty. When I exhaled after a sip, green grapes became very noticeable. 

The mouth feel was light to medium bodied with a medium carbonation. 

This is hands down the best triple Ive ever had. Its understated flavor and complex blend of flavors makes this a fantastic beer.

One of the first Belgium beers I had a chance to try. Part of my mass buy anything that I have heard of once I move to Seattle beer list. Between the two Westmalle beers I enjoyed this one the least however that doesnt mean it a horrible beer. It quite enjoyable. Flavors of spice, fruit, yeast, and bananas are very nice on the palate.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2007 Hazy, apricot-hued Trappist with a few white specks of fizzing sediment. Looks a bit like a Witbier, but dont be fooled.  This beer takes you on a sensory trip before youve even supped it. A noseful of spicy banana, bubblegum, TCP, citrus, crunchy apple, and booze-drenched wood. I could go on. Then comes the taste. A surge of spicy fruit culminating in an unexpectedly intense, Orval-like hit of yeasty hop dryness. Easily the most balanced, flavour-packed and lethally drinkable Tripel Ive sampled.

Pours slightly cloudy pale gold, with a large bubbly white head. The aroma is almost thin, giving some candy and alcohol, and maybe some yeast. Nowhere near as complex as I had hoped. The mouthful is quite fruity, but again to my disappointment lacks the malt complexities.  The finish is strong fruity and alcoholic. Decent, but disappointing.

The aroma was smokey with a little of caramel. The taste was alcohol, fruit, and a little yeasty. Poured a pale dense golden color with a creamy head. The mouthfeel was very dry and tingly. I love Chimay more

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2009 Fairly fresh bottle, initially served relatively cold. 

Did I just give this a 4.5? That puts it in my top 1%. I wasnt expecting that, but I sure dont see where Ive overinflating the scores. This is a stunningly good beer in every respect, and its the best tripel  (a personal favorite style) that Ive ever had. 

This beer pours a beautiful gold with a rich white head. The nose is a delight, strong spicy yeast aromas with honey and citrus, some passionfruit, and the faintest whisiper of alcohol.
This is the sort of aroma that makes it very hard to do anything other than dive right into a huge first sip. Much to my surprise and delight, that first sip was every bit as good as the aroma hinted it might be. A lively, spicy, and relatively dry tripel livened up with a light tropical fruitiness that makes the overall beer easy to drink, almost as if it were gently sweet but without the cloyingness that can come with a strong sweet Belgian beer. The hops kick in resolutely in the finish, leaing a lovely balanced bitterness on the long end of the flavor profile, accented by the lingering spiciness of the yeasts.

The mouthfeel is exceptional: impressively creamy, rich without being heavy in any way, a 9.5% that simply hnts at its presence, adding a fullness and graitas without any heat. 

Absolutely marvellous.

06 bottle sampled Feb. 09. Wow. Glorious and mellowed at 3 years. Not sure Id go quite 4.5 but certainly close.

Pours a hazy golden with a huge white head.  Aroma has notes of banana, citrus and bubblegum, along with cardamom, and what I associate with Belgian yeasts.  Flavor is more bitter than expected at the start.  It was also bitter at the finish, which I did expect.  Flavor is subtle, mixing most of what was in the aroma with the bitterness I described and sweetness in the middle.

Hazy orange.yellow body with big white head. Fruity, spicy aroma  coriander, banana, orange. The flavor is fruity as well though the alcohol and hops stick with the flavor throughout. Plum, orange and bitter hops. Peppery, warming finish from the alcohol. Ample carbonation and a moderate finish.

This is as good as they get. A true Tripel straight from Belgium! It is more light and fruity than I would have expected but so remarkably easy to drink. 

Appearance: Pours an orange yellow peach color. 

Smell: This beer was very aromatic; filling the nose with zesty lemon, toasty malty and other sweet fruits.

Taste: Soft and fruity on the palate but with a nice mix of lively spices. Very balanced very smooth, lemony hops and sweet malts just sing.

Mouthfeel: Light weight but full and creamy in the mouth.

Drinkability: I have yet to have a better experience with any Tripel.

Hope this is helpful.
Cheers!

Bottle: in my mind, this is the definitive tripel, with all of the requisite characteristics: fruity and spicy nose, light-to-medium body, strong alcohol taste nicely balanced by the yeast and hop flavors, and a clean finish.
bottle. pale yellow color. large white dissapating head. lots of caps. hop aroma. lots of citrus. spicy alcohollic finnish.
Golden hazed nectar. Cirtus and some yeast flavors. Good hop and fruit malt finish. Great tripel.
Bottled, Peterborough Beer Festival 2006.  Cloudy and straw coloured, with no head.  Hint of apple inthe scent, lots of apple and malt in the mouth.  Very carbonated, and very dry.
golden pour with froth white head.  nice carbonation.  spicy hoppy aroma.  spicy dry finish.  very nice
Bottle, Peterborough BF 06. Hazy straw appearance, thin white head. Aroma is hoppy bitterness, apple, tannin. Rather carbonated, slightly sweet. Hides alcohol well.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2006 Pours a cloudy amber color, with a full off-white head and good lacing. A thin head lasts until the last sip. Aroma is a complex mixture of smoked citrus and yeast. Flavor is moderately bitter from beginning to end, with a long finish comprised of light hops and alcohol. Very fruity and complex. Mouthfeel is very dry, and definitely requires some lip smacking to take it all in. A very good tripel.

I can appreciate this is an excellent example of an Abbey Tripel but difficult to enjoy in a fun kind of way.  More like the enjoyment of making it through an intricately complex, detailed, well-written novel.  Very sweet and spicy but lands on the palate like a ballerina.  Definitely worth tasting.  Cheers!

Pours a golden lively color, with a solid head.  The first waft revealed little aroma, however a more full inhale followed up with a sweet and spicy smell, like spiced cookies on an autumn day.  Very dry, a slight fruity hint enters the palate but then slowly retreats into a yeasty pale taste that is generally pleasant.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2008 RE rated : 11.4.08
Bottle, 33 cl. 
Hazy darkgolden color with a creamy head. Aroma was smokey with a little of caramel. 
Medium body.
Taste was alcohol, fruit, malts, and a little yeasty, spice. The mouthfeel was dry and tingly. Good.

Bottle - very nice aroma.  Almost cider-like.  Tart - bordering on sour - and fruity.  Golden body with a soft, white creamy head.  As the discription claims, it is strong, dry and spicy.  Very soft on the palate, as well.  This is a beautiful beer!

Thanks to my secret santa for this. Seen it many times in the store, but never bought it. Pours out a nice slightly hazy golden color with an attractive fluffy head. The aroma is of some fruit, yeast and some spices here and there. Very nice mouthfeel with a complex flavor. Sweet fruit fades into some yeast with a touch of spice maybe some pepper and corriander. Little alcohol on the finish. Very solid beer

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2007 Bottle at El Irlandés, Valparaíso: Pours a hazy and strong golden color. Head is medium to big, white and frothy. It shows good retention and leaves a gorgeous lacing.
Powerful fruity and yeasty aroma with a strong alcoholic presence. There are notes of peaches, vanilla, banana, apples and spices like coriander and pepper. Its well-defined and typical for a tripel but bold. I also found some hints of brown sugar and liquor.
Flavor is overwhelming. Sweet, fruity/estery and spicy beggining. It develops a more alcoholic character in the middle, finishing full on strong bittersweet and alcoholic kicks. Complex, over the top and definitely world-class. 
Full body, big for a tripel. Creamy and syrupy consistence. Fairly carbonated. Long sticky finish with lots of alcohol. This works fine as a digestiv. A big and wonderful tripel. Awesome!

Bottle.  Aroma:  Candi sugar, pepperiness, Belgian yeast, fresh kneaded bread, citrus, and floral.  Appearance:  Deep gold in color and hazy.  Big, white head was frothy and provided a good lace on the side of the glass.  Flavor:  Sour fruits(apples and pears), Peppery, Yeasty, subtle malt sweetness, with a nice bone-dry finish.  Palate:  Medium bodied.  High carbonation.  A little alcohol warming in the back of the mouth.  Overall:  A good, solid Tripel.

Poured a pale dense golden color with a creamy head.  The aroma was smokey with a bit of caramel, almost medicinal.  The taste was alcohol, fruit, and a little yeasty.  The mouthfeel was very dry and tingly.
not enough candy sugar and too bitter for me.  i like that its light, but its too bitter for me.  gets the job done though, for two euros.

pours hazy and golden opaque. foamy head, very frizzy at the beginning, crisp and light, but the flavors evolve as it warms and becomes smoother. has a tangy yeasty and flowery taste...slight clove or cinnamon? taste. great ale
Pours a light gold with a large foamy white head. Aroma is spice, yeast, and a little citrus. Well carbonated. Starts a little sweet, goes bitter, then at the end I can taste a little alcohol.
Pours a cloudy orange colour. This is a fairly complex beer with a very pleasant finish that lasts for a long time .
Heavy malty aroma. Huge creamy white head. Excelent lacing, mostly lasting longevity. Cloudy yellow body. Heavy bitter initial flavor. Medium palate.
Pours medium gold, with a nice white head and yeast still left in the bottle.  Classic belgian yeast nose.  Some alcohol present in the flavor, with some tart/sweetness.  Great Tripel.

Beer pours a pale gold color with some cloudinesss to it.  Head lasts and nose is yeasty, sourdough bread.  Flavor is incredibly complex: fruity (granny smith apple-like), some other fruit tones, closes spicy.  Finish is bitter, but not too bitter.  Beer drinks very smooth and alcohol content blends well  -  not very noticeable until after you have had more than 2.  Stands up to food  (cheese - note brie, apple).  An excellent beer.
Bottle. Creamy white excellent fully lasting head. Yellow clear colour. Week moderate aroma. A little yeasty. Powerfull complex flavor. Long finish. Very creamy palate.

Pours golden-orange with a medium white head that last  the whole beer.  Aroma is yeast, bit of sourness, bread, apples.  Flavor is sourness with pears, apples, breadiness.  The sourness doesnt really combine well with the other flavors, especially the breadiness.
Cloudy orange and long lasting head.  Sour sweet aromas.  it begins with malty earthy flavors and finishes dry and bitter.

Very pale gold color with very thick billowing white head. The beer is quite cloudy, almost opaque. The aroma is very sweet but tinted with some noble hops and a grassy aroma. The flavor is sweet bready, doughy malt, and a mild earthy hop bitterness. Alcohol is not particularly perceptible. The aroma and flavor remind me of farmhouse/saison ales Ive had recently. The finish is a little sweet. The mouthfeel is thick but bubbly (well carbonated). An excellent beer.

Great light appearance with a great sparkle.  Bitter.  Unlike the Dubbel, this one is much stronger and sharper.  Reading most reviews it is a prefered beer but beyond my preferences.  Too much alcohol and too sharp/bitter.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2006 Bottled. Poured slightly cloudy orange with a persistent white head. Aroma is citrus with a little sourness and a spicy yeast character. Smooth and substantial body with a little carbonation. The taste has a notable yeast character with some sourness. Almost tastes salty. Notes of dark fruits. The finish is spicy bitter.

Best before date on this one: 04-02-05  Sampled late July 2006.

Peachy and opaque, with a fair amount of chunky deposit, not much of a surprise for a such an old bottle.  What was surprising was the lovely thick pearly white head, so far it seemed to have aged quite well.

Fusels seem to be a bit more tame than in a fresh sample, but were still fruity, if not a bit more vinous, but without being too maderized.

The age came through a bit more in the flavor, although carbonation was still in great shape.  It made me think of an old attic or dusty basement, but in a good, fond memory kind of way.  I was expecting the alcohol to be much more prevalent, but it wasnt playing the diva at all, even though it was bone dry in the finish.  The yeast was perfectly balanced along with it and had a great body to hold it all in place.  A classic.

Hazy, bright golden/yellow color... huge foamy, relentless head...left behind some lacing on the glass.  Very flowery, yeasty aroma... strong yeast flavor with citrus, some slight spiciness, and maybe even a little bit of hops/bitterness.  Very sweet, alcohol finish.  Took me awhile to drink... pretty intense brew.
Enjoyed this in bottle in Cafe Vertigo in Amsterdam for after-work drinks. What a wonderful blast. This Trapist is very strong on the alochol, not too sweet and healthy proportion.

This one is a really good Trapist tripel! Hard to describe the taste of it but something like sour fresh green apple...

Its easy to get and Its good..!

pours a hazy light orange with a big off white head.  good amount of carbonation.  Spices seemed to dominate the aroma, with some dry apples and other fruits pushed into the background.  Taste is very spicy up front, with hints of tangy citrus fruit, and a spicy, peppery finish.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2008 pours a hazy yellow with an off-white head.  nice aromas of floral, belgian spices and candies. well balanced malt, spice and sweetness.  a very refreshing brew with a dry finish.
Bottle, at the Trappist Cafe in Westmalle. Really good, happy to bring back a few of these back home.

Bottle-Poured a hazy orange color with a small head and lots of tiny bubbles of carbonation that left lots of lacing on the glass.  Aroma was mostly spice, clove the most dominate.  Fruit and spice flavors most prevalent in the taste.  The alcohol does hit you further along the drink.  Pettys 4.99

Pioneers and trendsetters have through time, and in all domains, been the object of innumerable imitators. In the arts, followers built movements such as cubism or surrealism, but the instant an innovator arises there will always be those who take the concept to new levels. While we sometimes remember the creator, as Picasso has been remembered for cubism, other times history retains the epigone, such as the idiosyncratic Dalí. The same phenomenon emerges in the world of beer and after visiting the tripels of famous brewers throughout Belgium, it seemed that I would ineluctably encounter the original. Westmalle may have designed an idea long ago, but when compared to the eccentric creations of today, such as La Chouffes Houblon Dobbelen IPA Tripel, it is rather clear that evolution means to break stylistic barriers and merge seemingly opposite movements; for better or for worse. With all that in mind, I simply pour Westmalles uvre into the goblet it seeks. The clouded gold body quietly erects a spongy white foam that slowly expands before thickening to a cream. White chocolate and vanilla scents form the principal essence, supported by the salient ester aromas, banana and bubble gum, the sweet malts, toffee and cookie dough and the finely intertwined spices, pepper and clove. Redolent grains and white grapes make an appearance beside a sweet white honey fragrance. At that point, one might sigh and conclude that after all, everything in the world is right. As for myself, I simply sipped from the glass and decided, mid-swallow, that that time had not come. Cereal and biscuity flavors become more apparent in the flavor. Banana and apple share the stage with prompt spices: coriander, clove, pepper and vanilla proceed in file across the tongue. The untactful carbonation and dry palate seal the peppery aftertaste with a lingering thirst. The broken rhythm of this beer leaves me reminiscing of greater examples, and the recurrent pattern of a fading archetype.

Empties into the glass an murky haze thats is near opaque. Orange with yellow contrast and small fizzy head. Aroma is with a greeting of yeast and spice. Flavor is very strong with spicey yeast, alcohol, and perhaps dried out banana. Has a old taste to it overall which im estimating a life of 2 years or even more.
Excellent. Strong in taste, alcohol, and aroma. Some malt, spices. Maybe to much alcohol but still a very good strong belgian beer !

Poured from the bottle to a hazy golden orange with thick, white, foamy head that hung around until mid glass, and left decent lacing. At first, aroma was spicy, fruity (apples and grapes) and a hint of alcohol. As beer warmed, the alcohol became more dominant in the aroma, although fruit was still slightly noticeable. Flavor was similar to aroma, with alcohol presence continuing to strenghten as beer warmed, although fruit, especiaailly apples, remained strong as well. My only critcism of this beer is that the strong alcohol presence influenced the finish more than I would have liked, but still a good beer.

Bottle. Poured an incredible orange hue with a massive, foamy head that left a large amount of lacing. I was a bit surprised with the hopiness that came forth in the flavor so suddenly. Crisp, with a pretty good amount of yeast that had floated around in the glass. Different as far as Trappist goes, IMO.
Another good Belgium beer. Pours cloudy golden with a malty and slight floral aroma. Had a few floaties which was nice. A good malt flavor with a tad of spice.
Bottle. Cyprus @ All about beer. Hazy golden color. Nice malt aromas, floral and fruit aromas, a bit of spice in the aftertaste. Really liked it a lot.

Slightly detectable floral aroma. Apricot color. Good head retention. Maltiness throughout. Overripe banana flavor with rum-like alcohol finish. Significant alcohol but not too overbearing. I havent had this since 2000 while in Brussels. I managed to buy the appropriate glassware whiile there which heightened the experience this time. Just as good as I remember!

Cloudy golden with huge head. Nice yeasty aroma. Sweet and not too yeasty in taste. A little spicy/peppery taste to finish. Big fan. Im really growing into the beligians over the past year and this is a great tripel.

Cloudy orage-amber with a huge puffy white head with impressive retention. Spicy, fruity and yeasty aromas. Big flavours of banana, sweet spice, bread dough, and sweet caramel candy. Smooth mouthfeel with no notable alcohol other than a pleasent warmth in the finish. An excellent triple.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: 11.2 oz bottle dated best by 11/07/07. Pours a cloudy gold with a fluffy white head. Fruity, yeasty nose, some brandylike notes. Lively mouthfeel, yeasty flavors, lightly fruity. Some spicy notes. Gets slightly sweeter and more dense as it warms. Nice.

Bottled. Poured slightly cloudy orange with a persistent white head. Aroma is citrus with a little sourness and a spicy yeast character. Smooth and substantial body with a little carbonation. The taste has a notable yeast character with some sourness. Almost tastes salty. Notes of dark fruits. The finish is spicy bitter.

Bottle. Some uncouth Americans--or, maybe, only me--may not take the same familiar comforts from these amazing Belgians that we take from our favorite domestic ales. Its a different world, brewing under Bonapartes artillery. But this tripel, though, is just astonishingly good (many others, too, of course, just musing on culture shock tonight). Beautiful to look at: orange, dense white head. Bread and oranges on the nose. Some spice, fizz, and citrus throughout the palate. Theres a bit of hop there, but just a grace note.

Wonderful pour... it looks thick, hazy golden with chunky floaties.  Huge head, with a doughy-sweet nose.  Complex flavors here.  It starts with a definite sweet character, fills the middle with a bit of astringency, and finishes with a lightly bitter hop and crisp citrus.  The finish is medium and peppery.  Has a nice, thick(er), slick mouthfeel, and is a very nice representative of the trappist tripel.
Aroma: floral, citrus; appearance: orange, cloudy, white foam; flavor: light-to-medium sweetness, lightly bitter; palate: medium body, oily feel, lively, bitter, long finish. Very well balanced.
Poured a nice golden-yellow witha nice white head.The flavor was slightly sweet and malty with a faint hoppy finish.Very good and highly recomended.
"Poured a cloudy yellow with very nice head and lacin. Aroma was sweet. Flavor was sweet with some apples candi suger and have a hop to the finish/aftertaste Nice beer."

Poured cloudy golden, with a apicy, fruity aroma. This felt dry and thick on the tongue. The flavor had plenty of spice, some sweet fruit, and filled out with the great trappist yeast taste. An all around enjoyable abbey tripel.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2007 Bottle at DØE get-together. A very perfumed smell and taste, also some yeast in the taste. A bit malty, alcohol and dry hop, but to much yeast and perfume for my tastes. (4/3/5/2/11)   ---   Re:Rate. Bottle (Old ca. 2000) at DTE - Ratebeer night (06-01-07). Orange - white head. Aroma: Dusty, cardboard, peber, alcohol, spicy, yeast, wierd. (5/3/5/2/11)

Denne øl smager jeg aldrig igen, det er sikkert.
Aftenens værste indslag.
Ligner en hvedeøl, dufter at frugt og alkohol. Parfumeret i smagen og meget sprittet.
Fy for den......det kan kun blive bedre.

I love trappist ales, and this one is no exception.  The dark color and the fruity aroma are a great beginner for this beer, and the flavor is fruity and somewhat hoppy.  I like this one and recommend it.
user_location: The United States of Texas, Texas, USA

text: Just when you think you know how to describe/review a beer online, you get this, Turned my world upside down, thats for certain. Fruit of some kind is usually the first thing I can relate to in a beer when looking for flavor comparisons. Not in this case. Its all spice and bread and dough and more spice.  Good, different.  A sweetness aftertaste, most likely alcohol. Good, even very good. Different. Great? Not for this guy, but just short. Seems to be getting a lot of hype lately, at least around here. I just dont get it. Sure, it is pretty good, but how does pretty good get into every beer geek hangout in San Diego?

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2007 Gul ufiltreret øl med hvidt højt skum.

Duft af sød frugt og kryderier.

Smag: tung, frugtagtig med let bitterhed til sidst.

Minder om Leffe Blond - bare med mere alcohol - og lidt tungere

Sampled in Ieper, Belgium. Poured a typical cloudy yellow color with a nice huge head that lasted quite well and laced quite well. The aroma was typical of a tripel, with sweet malts dominating. However, the flavor was a bit sweet, the mouthfeel thick, and the finishing flavors mostly sweet (lacking some hops). I think Victorys Golden Monkey is as good as this one, unfortunately. Second tasting, 4/8/06: Sticky sweetness was completely non-existent (relative to the style). The hoppy finish was definitely notable, quite nice, actually. Flavor profile was apples with some candi sugar, v. light bananas, and a tingly hop finish. Excellent lacing. A nice tripel.

Bottle at OBriens. Poured in a Westmalle trapist glass.  Buttery color with a foamy long lasting head. Hints of apricots, yeast and co2 on the nose. The palate is dryish and very well carbonated, lots of malts present. Flavors of apricots, butter, grass,vanilla, green apples and citric hops. Very nice lacing the glass looks as if coated with steamed milk. Very nice and dry finish with a tingly sensation on tounge and throat.
Bottle: Careful, may cuase dependency! Very fruity and spicy with notes of yeast, cloves, bananas, vanila. Finish is dry and plain. Alcohol well balanced not overpowering.

Cloudy, straw in color.  Super carbonated which is normal for the style.  Has that musty cellar aroma that is also characteristic.  Big head, big lacing.  A bit of a perfume taste up front with a spicy, alcohol finish.  The spiciness lingers, the alcohol does not.

Wonderfully thick and chunky head.
Mildly spicy and slightly grassy aroma.
Very solid mouthfeel .  Malty, light caramel, slight clove with a rasin and spice finish.

A

Bottle 750ml w/ cork.  Wow! This is the motherload for me.  Poured a cloudy golden with amazing lacing.  So much is going on,  fruity, yeasty, yummy; warming and smooth.  The spices make it special.  Heaven.

330 ml bottle.  Bottle conditioned.  Drank on 5/20/06.  First thing I notice is the bottle is really full.  The most full bottle Ive ever see.  1" of headspace.  Clear other than some dregs floating.  Nice yellow with a hint of orange.  Big, thick, creamy 2" chunky white head.  Falls to a big thick layer of foam.  Big lacing.  Big, huge banana aroma.  Little bit of yeast character.  Little bit of spice.  Little sweetness, little bit of hops.  Flavor is sharp and bitter as it hits your tongue.  Then smooth and balanced in the mouth.  Really crisp and really dry in the finish.  Then a  ton of banana and yeast flavor after the swallow.  Little spice.  Very tart after the swallow.  Flavor (mostly the tartness) mellows a little as it warms, but not much.  Palate is really light with lots of carbonation.  Really dry finish.  Overall it is good and plenty enjoyable.  Definitely an interesting belgian.  But it is definitely not the best tripel Ive had.  Little high on the bitterness and dryness - and that tartness.  Id like to see some more complex flavors.  Smell makes it seem like there will be more there.  But it is good and I enjoyed it.  Surely hides 9.5% very well.

33 cL Bottle. This is a lost rating from 3/28/2006. Pour is a clearish yellow lemon with orange tinged core. Head of foamy off-white. Luxurious sweet lemon aroma with fresh cut tart granny smith apples. Flavor is a sweet, yet subdued silky wheat, lemons and spiced yeasts. Not a lot of expansive depth or character, but the flavors that are there are very strong and rich, with an appealing side. A touch phenolic. Alcohol is very well guised. Smacks light of plant stems.

Bottle.  11.2oz.  Pours a clear, pale copper color with a big, frothy white head.  Belgian yeast aroma with some fruity notes.  Very dry mouth feel with a sweet, excessively dry flavor.  Notes of spices and apples.  Dry but lingering finish.

Beer of the day at the beer festival.  I was stunned to see that the distributor brought this one out to the show.  Pours an cloudy gold color. Long lasting, nice head. The taste is lightly bitter with a hint of spices and pepper.  Outstanding.
Had a nice head.Aroma was good.Color a medium amber.Tasted pretty good.Would buy again.
Pours a clearish yellow with a white head. Sweet and bitter with aromas of alcohol, yeast, honey, pears and a hint of almond. Very soft carbonation. Fruity finish with a hint of alcohol.

Bottled. Pours a hazy medium golden color. Big foamy white head. Slightly grainy/yeasty aroma. Creamy mouthfeel. Thick, rich yeasty flavor. Some graininess. Creamy and spicy as well with a hint of bitterness. Slight alcohol in the finish. Warming as it goes down.
Bottle. Pours an orange-gold cloudy color. Long lasting, huge head. The taste is very dry, lghtly bitter with a hint of spice and pepper. All in all a pretty good beer with a fair amount of acohol.

bottle .. very yellow pour with a huge head that sticks to the glass all day long . malty aroma with notes of citrus and hops . spicy pepper flavor and very dry . alcohol is noticable and warming , decent mouthfeel . not bad

The commercial description of this fizzy brew fits quite well.  It pours very yellow, with a huge, big-bubbled head that lingers with minimal lacing.  It smells like coriander mixed with other herbs and spices, with a hint of band-aid thrown in.  Someone earlier said it, and damned if its not in there!  The taste is immediately peppery, spicy, and very dry.  This reminds me of the vegetable-type ales, its so earthy and spicy, like the smell of fermented fruit or vegetable peel left in the sun.  Lots and lots of smells and just as many components to the taste.  The palate is a bit heavy, especially when the brew warms.  Considering how complex this brew is, the finish is actually clean with warming alcohol.  I dont dislike this brew, I just dont like it that much, either.  I can see how some people would really like it.   Maybe Im just not a tripel fan...though I thought I liked all things Belgian...hmmm.  I just dont really care for medicinal ale.
UPDATED: FEB 11, 2007 Bottle.  Pours yellow to gold with white head..  Fruity aroma with hints of spices.  A full mouth of meaty aroma with each drink.
This is a hell of a fun beer.  Ive drunk a bunch of this and its always a treasured experience.
750 ml bottle. Large white head. Hazy yellow colour. Complex aroma, citric & fruity with hints of rose pepper. Fruity & slightly alcoholic taste, but still a favourite!

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2007 750. Beer is murky, medium straw-brown colored. Head is largish, white, frothy. Diminishes but mostly lasts.

Rich and fruity. Malty with light notes of caramel, toasted grain, biscuit; Hoppy with moderate herbal lemon zest, light/moderate resinous pine; Yeasty with light notes of dank basement, trace plastic/band-aid; Light notes of peppery alcohol, traces of banana/clove, tropical fruit and peach.

The flavor is light/moderately sweet, light/moderately acidic, lightly bitter with a long, warm, lightly sweet, light/moderately bitter, moderately acidic finish.

The body is medium, the texture is watery and the carbonation is lively.

Solid and enjoyable.
UPDATED: JUN 8, 2008 Pours an orangey-gold color. Long lasting, creamy head. Very dry on the palate with a fruitiness and a smooth finish. Highly drinkable and alcohol is well hidden.

Bottle.
Cloudy yellow, with a very foamy head,
Flavor dominated by alcohol, fruit in aroma.
Cloudy yellow, with a very foamy head. Too-prominent hops flavor with little complexity. Not terrible, but ultimately unsatisfying.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2015 Bottled in Amsterdam.  Dark golden brown pour.  Not exactly excited after finishing this one, too alcoholic and simple.  Dry finish but the beginning sugar puts me off. [2006.04.25: 2.8]What a curiosity that rating was!  Heres a fresh bottle, best before end 08/07/16.  Nose is very sweet, golden and fruity with some strong acetone flying in, touch of spice.  Pour is initially about 70% foam despite my good practices and best efforts [not a gusher or infected], eventually clear golden with a a large foamy off-white head.  Taste lightly sweet with some fusel burn and nail polish remover, extremely phenolic and heavily spicy with golden pils malt and a little earthy character, spice.  Very warming, even a burny, and Im not going fast here, its just freaking rocket fuel.  Very rough medium-full body, medium fruitiness with medium bitterness and a dry finish.  Touch rubbery.  Ive had better results brewing my own tripel with this yeast, wtf are they doing?  Am I supposed to wait two years for this to calm down?  What is it about this one?! [2015. 03.11: 2.6]
Bottle. White and lasting head. Unclear yellow body. Fruity alcohol aroma. Flavor dominated by alcohol, otherwise very spicy and hoppy. Too bad not served cold enough.
Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Fat lasting head, good smell, a crisp smooth taste, pours golden, such a mellow for 9.5% alcohol. This beer is beautiful, i love it.

11.2oz bottle, 02/09/06-not sure if this is a "best by" or "born on," but I fear it is the former.  Pours a pretty yellow golden--hazy and chunky--wit a medium white frothy head.   Aroma of fizzy carbonation, yeast, bananas, green apples, pepper, and some sweet malts. Taste follows aroma well.  Very dry finish, though not really any bitterness. Some alcohol burn noted. Medium bodied, fairly fizzy.  Very good!
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: 375 ml bottle.  Hazy orange with very large head that lasted the glass.  Aromas were crisp lemon zest and sweet pear/apple.  Flavors were very light and fruity.  Very Tripel in nature, but very good.  Nice finish.  Good Tripel

Gold in colour and well carbonated. Pleasing aromas of MacIntosh apple, pear, and a bit of spicy yeast. The fruit flavors become more lemon like on the palate, and mix well with the light malt and mild grassy hop notes. Surprisingly bitter finish... with notes of lemon rind at the end. A bit too dry for the style IMO (if thats even possible). Not bad, but could be better. Merci Lubiere!

Pours an ugly mix of yellow, brown and orange with a decent white head.  Fuller bodied than many tripels, this is dry and yet very malty.  Caramel, roast malt type of mid-palate thing going on.  Spicey and also a strong alcohol presence like a shot of grain vodka was added.  Interesting and more demanding than other tripels Ive had.

Slightly hazy gold with a medium, fizzy, collapsing white head. Sour, yeasty, faintly spicy aroma. Quite effervescent, to the point of being unpleasant for my taste. Tastes of hay, yeast, and bitter citrus. Finishes sour with ametallic bitterness. I wasnt impressed.
The Westmalle has a bitter finish and much more carbonation than I like. It is still a good beer but not up to par with some of its competitors.

Never rated this yet?? Shit I have had a few of these and it beats a lot of the so-called tripels out there. Lots of over ripe pears and coriander. Nose is a little more intriguing than the taste tho. Still sweet and fruity on the tongue.

Dark yellow nearly orange with a nice fluffy white head.  At first the smells scared me, spice, coriander, and oranges...i hate all the above when not done properly.  But one sip and I was very amazed.  They pulled off a great balance of fruits, spices, and a nice bitter taste too.  Fantastic...I think this is a new fav from the trappists.

Hoppy Belgian beer makes me happy, slightly dissapointed when bar advertised having Westy 12 and then said, "no, sorry" or something equivalent in italian, but when youre settling for this, are you really settling?  Pilgrims!
cloudly yellow with white head. Very spicy and strong tripel. Lively carbonation. Filling and has a long warm finish!

Pours cloudy yellow with a fluffy white head. Lots of sediment and carbonation. Herbal, dusty, hard fruit, and spiced aroma. More malty sweet than I had expected. Yeasty, citrus peel, and spicy alcohol flavors. Tangy and acidic on the tongue. A proper and delicious tripel.

Bottle at the Wine Guys in La Crosse, WI.  Pours a hazy orangish-yellow with off-white head that fades quickly.  Predominant aroma of citrus and yeast, but balanced out by the malts and hops.  Flavor follows the aroma - with only a mild alcohol presence.  Clean crisp finish.  Worth a try.
UPDATED: JUN 6, 2006 Pours light amber -very fizzy. Not as subtle as a chimay blue or brune, announces its strength early on. Slight warmth going down, not a bad flavour but its not really for me.
Pours cloudy yellow with yeast sediments. Fruity aroma, sweet and too alcoholic flavour. Goes down moderately well for a beer of this strength.

11.2 oz bottle. Poured a goldish with a pretty big white head. Had a spicy malty head to start. Had a little resemblance to a whitbeer with coriander. Overall a great belgian. Well balanced and not overly strong spice, malt, or hops.

Very dry tripel.  Pours gold with a big foamy head.  Some cloudiness with yeast that quickly settled.  Aroma is yeasty with some spice and mild fruit.  The taste is sharp up front with strong malts, then eases into the sweet sugary finish, but ends dry.  Ive never had anything like it before.
Bottle 330ml. Appearance: golden color with foamy white head . Aroma: Spicy, fruity, yeast, citrus. Flavor: yeast, spice,  hops, alcohol.

750 mL bottle.  Good pour into my Westmalle glass.  Large, thick foamy white head that diminished into nothing within a minute or so.  Murky golden yellow with a few tiny floaties.  Spicy, fruity, and classic belgian yeast aroma with faint citrus, booze and cherry.  Good carbonation with a fairly full body.  Fruit, booze, yeast and spice with faint hops and a whisper of cherry on the tounge.  A good triple now, maybe a very good triple with some more age.
Best before 11/07/07.  Pours gold into a trappist glass with mounds of unformed foam.  Earth notes. Spicy, sweet full alcohol palate with lasting metallic finish.

330ml bottle (bb.17.11.2007). Pale yellow. Big foamy white head that leaves great lacing on the glass. Citrus and cherry aroma. Full bodied. Taste of fruit, yeast and warming alcohol. Strong and powerful. Moreish. (01042006).

Thick bubly head over a golden honey like pour.  Lots of particles.  Sweet aroma with an alcohol tang.  Definate citrus and spices.  Spicy citrus in the taste as well.  Very complex, hard to distinguish distinct flavours.  Bit of an alcohol bite on the tongue.  Warm spicy boozy aftertaste.

this is aged, long enough to bring out the flavours in a balanced classic Belgian style.  over rated? under rated?  who cares this beer rocks its light color baffles the mind but not before the underlying strength of malts & candy sugars take you away.  great beer, best when sat on, very complex and satisfying.

This is my first true belgian ale. I got the 750ml bottle. After opening I could smell it immediately. This was a unique pour, difficult even. A big pillowy head, with lots of carbonation. The beer itself has an interesting feel, carbonated, but smooth. The taste is not of alcohol which I had suspected, but rather light hops with malt to match. Very good, after trying some other belgians I may re-rate.

refreshing and strong, this beer is really good paired with fatty fish like salmon or less heavy meats like pork chops. good all year round it is a great example of trappist balance and non offensive for anyone discovering belgium beers.

Best by 06/04/07. Cherry nose with a wonderful rocky head. Underwheming in fruit and spice-I think all the Westmalles are having a rough ride to my purchase. Couple day old bread and straw and typical yeast. Hops and malt are balanced nice but lacking the x factor.

Pours a cloudy gold color with a 3/4-inch head that lasts a bit. Nice lacing. Aroma of yeast, alcohol, touch of citrus. Flavor is malty, bready and dry with a definite alcohol presence. Bitter grapefruit finish. Nice.

Best by 06/04/07. Hazy gold. Small, fizzy, white head quickly dissipates. Aroma of spicy, musty yeast, candi sugar, alcohol, fruits, rich malt. Great nose. Same flavor. Finish is dry, alcoholic, with a slightly sour yeastiness. Full, well carbonated body. Too much carbonation to fully appreciate the flavors. Otherwise a great brew.
