UPDATED: JUN 7, 2007 Ths brew pours a tawny yellow color w/ a tall creamy froth. Superb head retention w/ a lasting latherous lace. Small Champagne bubbles persist the full duration. Aromas of aged citrus and candy. Medium full nectar w/ ample residual effers. The texture is that of creamy cotton. A slightly sweet style w/ a full malty backbone.  Musty, citrusy sugar cubes and tropical tarts defines this one. Theres a mild peachpit bittering unit that starts midpalate and helps to balance it out. Finish is long and bittered w/ peachpit and some tangy kiwi. Alcohol is well hidden. Overall: a fantastic brew w/ good complexities. It hits the spot. Highly recommended.

33 cl bottle.  Orangy color, cloudy.  Good head.  Spices and fruits aroma.  A strong alcohol after taste.  Light fruit taste with a sour ending.  I was expecting more from that beer (like not having an alcohol after taste).  But, still good.

Another Westmalle brew thats right on style.  LIght malt, light bread and sweet dough.  Off-white, creamy head that was gone in 60 seconds.  A bit haxy with some small particles.  Moderate sweet flavor that lasted a lont time.  Texture was dry with lively carbonation.  There was a moderate alcohol finish.

This beer offers a grainy fruity aroma.  It is a cloudy golden color with a thick white head and good lacing.  This beer produces a smooth wheat and mild orange/fruit flavor.  Caramel can be detected in the finish.  The mildly hot aftertaste leaves the flavor remnants of wheat, caramel, and orange lingering.

[ Bottled ; chilled ; BB 12/08/06 ]

A fully diminishing large frothy white head that tops up a hazy medium amber body. Moderate lacing. No particles. Few small bubbles. Aroma presents malt being light bread while hops are moderate citrusy ... Yeast character is heavy dough. Also, there are evident evocations of apple and candi sugar. Impressions of citrus is evident. Alcohol aroma is high. Initial flavor is moderate sour while development is show some funkyness. Very good triple oriented on balance. Finish is long and alcoholic. medium body... creamy texture... Lively carbonation...
Bottled. Golden beer with a white head.Aroma of yeast, alcohol and cellar.Flavour have sweetnes and apple and alcohol. A good beer.

0.33l bottle, Westmalle trappist glass at Tolkiens House, Zagreb Finally got to try this one. I love Tripels, and you cant go wrong with the first one, right ? Well see about that. It poured a dark golden colour with a medium sized thick white head that went away slowly. Very lively carbonacion, scant lacing. The nose was interesting. White grapes/white wine, acidic in a nice way, some slight fruit (figs?) and a tiny hint of alcohol. Very interesting. Taste...hmm... it struck me as a totally atypical tripel, which is odd considering that its the original... Again, a white wine like taste, only more "noble" than any Ive ever tasted. Bloody great underlying fruity maltiness, that, unfortunately, doesnt show up much. Some alcohol (though I never thought it was really that evident). Some chewy hopiness in the late taste, which I didnt exactly love (it was ok), that goes into the aftertaste and sticks in going from a grape seeds taste to a herbal one clinging to the back of the mouth and mixing with the subdued lemon acidity that shows up around the same time. Interesting stuff, slightly atypical, but good.

Bottle marked 11/07/07. Im assuming thats a best by date. Poured a pale yellow with a tall white head that mostly lasted. Lots of carbonation showing in this one. Some lacing. Aroma of spices, banana, yeast, and a hint of malts. The flavor gave dark fruits, apple, spices, and a light malt background. This palate reminded me a lot of champagne. Lively carbonation, dry, and bitter throughout. Some alcohol in the flavor but not uncomfortable.

Pours a clear pale yellow with a head 100% the height of the beer.  Hops, yeast, wheat and alcohol dominate the aroma.  Tangy and sour, with a bite of alcholol.  Finishes like a shot of grain alcholol.  Did I mention the alcholol?
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: poured a murky yellow with monsterous head and average lacing, visible carbonation, some particles.  aroma of yeast, alcohol, banana, and spice.  taste was of banana bread, slight lemon and bitterness.  these munks sure know how to produce a brew.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2013 bottle.  hazy gold with lively carbo bubbles under a large, fluffy, white head.  dusty, yeasty, pineapple aroma.  flavor has some pineapple notes and a distinct, bottle conditioned, dustiness.  dry finish with lots of carbonation, without being foamy.  keeps a light, dry mouthfeel throughout.  almost seems to evaporate on the tongue.  

fruity tropical  pinapple aroma.  murky yellow with huge flakey yeast chunks... too many.  medium sized creamy head.  slightly lacking in flavor because the alcohol is a bit pronounced.  somewhat bitter and dry.   3/3/06 8/2/7/3/15

Bottle. Hazy golden color with huge, rocky white head and tons of rising carbonation, very champagne-like. Aromas of sour lemon, yeast, light malt, dry hay, bubblegum, and some general funkiness/mustiness. Flavor follows, very dry and peppery with the carbonation, with a tart, drying finish and slightly sour yeast aftertaste. Very nice.

750 ml bottle that says Westmalle trappist with ALE TRIPEL on the front.  On the back it says Authentic Trappist Product and says to serve at 45-50 degrees F.  This bottle came from my fridge which is kept at 44 degrees.  I let it sit out about 10-15 minutes before I opened it.  I left it sitting out while I drank it.

This poured up a cloudy orange with about a fingers worth of a beautiful white head.  The head was made up of very small bubbles with a few large ones here and there.  It lasted about a minute or two and then settled down into a ring around the inside of my snifter.  Small bubbles streamed up everywhere from the bottom of the glass.

It has a light fruity aroma with some notes of caramel underneath.  As the beer warmed up the fruity smell gave way to a pronounced alcohol aroma.

A surprising citrus almost bitter flavor hit me on the front end.  As it strolled around my mouth it got the fruity flavor I was expecting.  A very light caramel flavor as you swallow is then followed up by a sharp tang on the back of the tongue.

The carbonation keeps this one light on the mouth.  It is kind of "spritzy."
This is a very drinkable beer and I will have some more.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2009 Bottled. A golden beer with a huge white head. Yeast, fruit, candisugar, alcohol and cellar aromas. Flavor has candi-sweetness, apples, dried fruits and maybe too much alcohol. A lovely beer. Rating: 7-4-8-4-17-4.0. 060228Bottle. It pours a hazy, sparkling, orange-golden body with some sediments, and a huge, dense, egg-white head sitting on top. Very slowly dimininishing, and leaving nice lacings. Citrus, banana and tropical juice in the aroma, along with a pleasant alcohol touch, a faint spice note and some pale malts. The hops also shines throug in a sort of peppery way. Its full-bodied and effervescent, slightly warming down the throat, and with a fine bitterness. Theres flavors of fresh fruits, lemon peel, pale malts and spices. Some cellar and yeast notes too. Very well balanced, even though the alcohol might be a bit more evident than I prefer. It kinda suits the beer though. Lasting warm finish with fruits, pale malts and bitterness. A dry, crisp and tasteful tripel, but a bit too warming. 090827
Bottled, 2/26/06: Bright and shiny hazy yellow with a towering head.  Just a light citric-yeasty aroma.  Subtly spicy flavors of citrus, corriander, yeast and "goodness".  This is quality.
Pretty mild for the alcohol content, long lasting head.abit of spiciness to it, with abit of citrus. easy drinker for the style. good.

Some aroma of honey and spice as well as a hint of fruit. Nice cloudy orange and gold appearance with a nice tight white foam. The flavor starts sweet and really hits you with yeast and fruit and finished dry and nice touch of bitter.The mouth feel is strong and drinks well and full bodied. Very nice brew

330ml bottle. Poured slightly cloudy honey blonde into a trappist glass with a gorgeous, large, lasting white head. Looks amazing. Aroma is champagne and lager-like sweet malts with a little sourness and definite yeast character. The flavor is a sort of amped-up pale lager at first. Notable yeast character with some sourness. Light hops that mainly show as bitterness. Notes of dark fruits, white wine, tart cherries. The finish is very bitter and fairly short with just a little alcohol present. Smooth and a little bubbly on the palate with substantial body.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2006 Small white creamy head with islands of larger bubbles. Hazy yellow body with ongoing carbonation. Spicy, citric aroma with fruity, bready notes and stale, metallic hops. Taste is powerfully spicy, citric banana flavours with a strong metallic hop background and earthy notes. Spicy, peppery, dry aftertaste. Fantastic! Drinkable, complex, interesting. Deservedly a world classic. (0.33l bottle.)

330mL: Pours a huge white head, lasting, good lacing.  Pa, cloudy, golden yellow color.  Aroma of flolewers, peeled grapes, perfume.  Semi-bitter taste, fizzy, clean aftertaste, slight alcohol.  Not a very complex tripel.

Bottle dated 12/08/06. Pours a cloudy orange colour with a thick white head which disipates to a thin ring. Aroma of fruit and yeast. Flavour is sweet with some yeast but is quite pleasant. The alcohol is noticable but does not take too much away from the beer. Thanks to Jerc for sending this one my way.
Bottle 0,33l.Bright golden. Cloudy. A huge head building up when poured from a distance. A sourish and fruity aroma. You notice the alcohol in the  lasting finish. A lot of sediments in the bottle.

UPDATED: APR 28, 2006 Clear golden with lots of bubbles and a healthy white head on top. Sweet and spicy yeast aroma. Sweet flavours, coriander?, spicy yeastiness, good fruitiness (apples?), dry finish, warming alcohol. Good carbonation, full-bodied. A very elegant beer, the mother of all tripels
A great murky redish colour with a floral, fresh aroma. Slightly bubbly and no alcohol aftertaste.

Floral, doughy aroma.  Bubbly on the tounge.  Spicy and dry, as advertised.  I rather enjoy the chapagne and apple flavors.  Im not as familiar with tripels as many ratebeerians, but I enjoyed this one.

Bottle. Pours golden, yellow with a large head with excellent lacing. The head is off-white. The beer is a bit frothy and cloudy in appearance. Aromas are of citrus, grapefruit and a certain hint of dust and chalk and some mustiness.
The flavor is sweet and slightly sticky. It is veryu complex, I cannot discern a prevalent theme. The palate is very dry with a medium to full body

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2006 Yes, another wonderful beer from Westmalle. Pours a cloudy golden in the glass with a flowering head. Fruity nose of yeast, bread, orange peel and other citrus accents. A smooth drinker. Creamy mouth-feel. Dry with a pleasant alcohol finish. A wonderful beer though I think I like the Dubbel a little more.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2006 Pours a hazy orange-yellow with bubbly white head that fades to a thin but solid cap.
Aroma is light and fruity (banana-lemon) with very little hint of alcohol.
Contrary to the aroma, the alcohol is very predominante in the flavour. Sweet  , boozy, grainy. With lively carbonation.

33cl bottle.  Pours foggy amber with a MASSIVE white head that eventually disappates  leaving a slight lace on the glass.  Aroma is a bit fruity and a bit malty.  The alcohol will smack you hard with the first drink but it mellows as it warms.  Each drink is better than the previous, finishing with the alcohol still present, but nicely combined with the fruits and spices.

Bu au Vineyards Wine Bar & Bistro (Ottawa) en septembre 2005. http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/ontario/ottawa/viney 
Goût fort mais pas trop imposante, un peu fruité et épicé. Très bon!

Peaches and yeast aroma with some must kickin around too.  Poured a cloudy yellow with a white head and excellent lace.  Full-bodied and smooth in the mouth though not bursting with flavours other than alcohol and fruity malt.

Bouteille-Une dorée un peu trouble. Odeur dépices, de malte et dalcool. Mousse blamche dissipante. Goût de malte et de noisette et de fruits.--Bottle-A golden ale a bit cloudly. Odor of spices, malt and alcool. White head fast dissiping. Taste of malt, nuts and fruits.

Tasted 05/02/2006.  330ml bottle from Leuven, Wellington.
Pale orange, hazy, diminishing white head, lacey.  Musty yeast aroma hints at apricot and seaweed before revealing a spicey and phenolic kick.  Flavour is fresh and fruity, more mustiness, alcoholic, tart through the middle, with a hint of absinthe, a crisp dry finish and a quite strong phenolic astringency and woody, clove and cinnamon lingering after.  Mouthfeel is lightweight, without being skinny, and low-medium carbonation.  Interesting ale but it doesnt grab me enough to demand I drink another.
Robe blonde dorée très claire surmontée dune mousse blanche épaisse en dentelle. Arômes dépices, de sucre candi et de malt. Saveurs de malt, de miel, dépices, dalcool et de levure.

Pours a mostly orange with slight yellow to it, very creamy fluffy white head that stayed the whole time. Pretty fruity, apples, and pears, along with spiciness , but the alcohol was very evident the whole time, it took away from the other flavors in the aftertaste. Smooth but alcohol took over this beer.

This pours a light amber/yellow with a big, fluffy white head.  The head dies down rather quickly.  The nose is grainy and lightly of alcohol.  This beer is mostly malts and they are brewed to a light bitterness in the finish that is dominated in the front by an inititial burst of alcohol, a short hint of spice, and then a strong graininess.  Any fruitiness is light and perhaps resembles flower pedals more than fruit.  Overall, this is certainly a great tripple, but even Chimays is better in my opinion.

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2007 Out of the two Westmalles I sampled, I favored the dubel. This was very enjoyable as well! Incredible light/hazy yellow coloring with a fluffy head. The aroma was peppery and yeast, which was awesome. Mouthfeel was a bit thick which I didnt care for, plus you could really tell you were drinking a higher abv. Flavor portion didnt really blow me away, but it was good. It finished crisp. Very good.
Amber in color with a creamy head, Smell of bark and malt with a hint of lemon. Taste is of a sour fruit and a leafy ending. Lasting flavor throught.

Bottle.  Pours a nice golden blond with a medium frothy white head that quickly dissipates.  Very strong aroma of yeast, lemon, apples and something a little musty.  Taste is very interesting, fruity up front, more lemons and apples.  Finish is hard to describe tastewise, but it is very dry like champagne.  There is some nice earthy malt that lingers.  Mouthfeel is unremarkable a slight bit carbonated.
A very nice nose-floral and citrus. Its spicy and dry. Yeasty and crisp with a strong spiced citric character. The finish is peppery and brisk.

Rocky/frothy head which produces very good lacing.  Amber in colour.  Aroma is of grain, grass, lemon, and alcohol.  Flavour is earthy but has quite a bit of alcohol. Medium bodied with lively carbonation.

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy golden colour with a big white head. Sweetish aroma with notes of cereals and remote notes of plastic. Notes of yeast as well. Interesting flavour; sweetish, fruity and slightly perfumy. Also quite dry and it reminds me a bit of white wine. Slight notes of apple in the finish. 28-01-06.

Bottle - poured golden with a fair white sudsy head.  Aroma of yeast, honey, some apple, and a touch of alcohol.  Flavor is a nice blend of yeast, apples, spice, and honey.  Nice somewhat bitter dry finish.  Palate is smooth, airy and creamy.  Very pleasant mouthfeel.  An enjoyable tripel...

Bottle.  Pure honey gold liquid makes me proud.  A self-replesnish tiny fountain of bubbles in the center of the glass.  Very inviting.  Aroma of dry white wine at first, as it warms, morphs into cinnamon apples.  Tastes is tart, with a dry finish, apples, bananas, cinnamon.  Pleasing; complements a fine Italian meal with no difficulty.  Not surprising at all that this has lasted and it needs not my little words to outlast me.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2006 Peppery spices, sour bread, and tart fruitness does not hide the alcohol.  Poured hazy dirty yellow with some carbonation.  I appreciate the appearance more than the taste.  Spicy and harsh bite.  Finishes sharp and very dry.  I will try again once Ive tried some different Tripels to compare.   3.5
Re-Rate:  After having this beer a few times again, I really enjoy the flavor a lot more.  I developed more of a palate for Tripels and I think this is one of the best.  Great hop variety and spicy banana bread.  Love it.  4.5
UPDATED: AUG 11, 2006 [bottle] Looks very nice.. golden color with some nice little bubbles. Excellent spicy flavors; alcohol is very apparent. Finishes tart and on the sweet side.
Very large creamy white head from the pour.  Light body with a crisp spicy flavor.  Light carbonation with a clear light gold color.
pretty solid brew.  Is a bit sweet, tad fruity.  Pretty smooth for the high abv not sure if its worth the price however, or at least what i paid for it.

Murky gold with airy head that dissipates rather quickly.  Nice fruity aroma, notably apple and orange.  Unfortunately the resr beer does not live up to the aroma.  Has some vinegar elements to it. Very lively, heavily carbonated.  Dry finish.  Good but overrated.
Yellow colour with a huge white mostly lasting head. Aroma of fruits and yeast. Lots of taste. Good palate.
Hazy yellow color with a nice white head.  Excellent, very fruity aroma, some yeastiness.  Excellent flavor as well, very fruity and a little spicy.  Nice smooth mouthfeel.  Very good.

Cloudy pale yellow in colour with big fluffy white head. Fruity corrianda on steroids.
Supposed not use to these complex Belgium beers, too many local beers to appricate and not challenging the palate.
Thanks Santa

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2007 Westmalle has long been revered as one of the great six Trappist breweries dotted around Belgium.  It has also long been out of my reach.  Now Ive had my taste.  A bitter, dry, raspy taste like the withered hand of the elder tyrant, a foul and offensive flavor with consummate reviling details.  The Westmalle Tripel is the nadir of Tripels, a shamed nomad who wanders from palate to palate.  Each new tongue marks a new exodus, down the throat and, for me, almost back up.  The appearance is the standard straw colored Tripel shade, bubbling into a laconic but active head of white.  From that mattress of billowing foam emanates a fragrance of apples, pears, butter and bubble gum.  But the taste is horrible, excessively dry and burdened with more alcohol than it can carry.  The label tells another story, of a delicate beer meant for delicate consumers, those tried and true beer drinkers out there plodding around the world who have the genteel knack for tasting quality brews.  To these men and women, the Westmalle is a scoundrel.  It is dressed like a beer of luxury, and smells like a fruit garden, though it reeks of treachery.  The Westmalle Tripel is drier than the sun bleached bones of fallen Grecian warriors, more bitter than the spited prince who lost his kingdom, and burns more than the hell fires promised to lick the heels of heathens.  It is all the worse for its regal coating, but even without the apocryphal robes of the rich the Tripel is just a poor excuse for a Tripel.  Beware this alluring foe of friends, it is only a bottle filled with oft mentioned and fabled assassins dagger.

330mL bottle.  Slightly hazy yellow gold color, towering rocky white head.  Light fruity ester aroma, pineapple and pear.  Sugar sweetness cut with a sharp spicy yeast bite.  Residual spicy/fruity flavors with a highly alcoholic character in the finish.  Mouthfeel is medium, dry, and hot.

pours a standart cloudy golden color. smells of pungent fruity essence, slightly yeasty. taste is quite sweet with lots of pear and some other citrus flavors. not a bad beer but a little to sweet for my tastes, i prefer allagash tripel.

My first Tripel!  Poured from bottle into shaker glass (its about all I have).  An off-white head sits on a murky golden beer.  Its appearance almost reminds me of a lemon-meringue pie.  Highly highly effervescent.  Excellent lacing.  Aroma is light and citrusy with a little yeast thrown in.  A very refreshing beer!  I am usually turned off by beers with abvs over 8% but I didnt notice the alcohol as being strong in this brews flavor.  This one inspired my to brew a Tripel of my own.
Clear blond, average white head. The aroma is sweet yeaste, some peppers. Fruity as well. Full body, creamy palate. Finish is spicy and some light bitter. Excellent Tripel.
Bottled. Hazy light yellow with white head, lacings. The aroma is fruity with yeasty undertones. The flavour is fruity with a bitter sting.

The aroma is sweet, sour, and peppery, with lemon, malt, and yeast. The appearance is very nice. It has one of the most persistent foamy head that I have seen. The flavor is malty, spicy, citrusy, and bitter. The palate is average for the style. This is one solid beer in almost every way.

Bottle. $4.99 for 11.2 oz. Belgian yeast aroma. Murky, dishwatery, orange with a large white, to off-white head that is lasting. This is the only beer I can remember where you can actually see the head continually being replenished by the bubbles coming up from the bottom. The head actually doesnt just "last", it grows just sitting there! Champagne-like steady visible carbonation. Visible yeast clumps float near the bottom of the glass upon settling. A burst of alcohol hits the palate immediately upon first sip as does the considerable, champagne-like mouthfeel. None of the 9.5% ABV is hidden in this one. A lovely brew, but one that is dominated by alcohol, and is therefore somewhat harsh and fairly one-dimensional.
Cloudy, yellow-gold body with a huge white head.  Fruity aroma with some spice.  Taste is slightly fruity with notes of spice and and alcohol.  Not generally my favorite style, but an enjoyable beer.

Orangy blonde with a lot of chunky bits of sediment. Citrusy and had a sharp bitterness Ive never noticed before, closer to the front of the tongue. Could be all the alcohol. The head makes it look great, but taste-wise I really dont see the big deal. Lemon, yeast, a bit of basic spice (black pepper), but not much else. Overrated and dull.
Pours a golden yellow with a moderate white head. Citrus and spice in both the aroma and palate. A solid triple, but I expected a bit more.
Pours with a medium white head on a cloudy yellow body. Strong malty aroma with spices, pine and alcohol. Sweet flavor with spices on a medium body.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2010 Bottle from Once Upon a Vine - South on 07/11/2010. Best before end 19/01/12. Bottled on 19/01/10 - 05 03896. Slightly hazy pale golden body with a moderaterocky white head. Sweet spicy and perfumy hop aroma on a light malt background. Sweet fruit, candi sugar, and spicy/perfumy notes with a very dry finish. Medium body with moderately high carbonation. 7/3/8/3/14 - 3.5

12/31/2005 - Very frothy white head on a hazy blond body. Very spicy aroma and a very fruity flavor. 6/4/7/4/15 - 3.6

Very fragrant, fresh and citrussy.  Cloudy peach brew with a thick "shaving cream" head.  The alcohol is noticeable, but so are an array of spice flavours as well.  Very bubbly, very warming and nicely intoxicating.

Not earth-shattering, but a very nice brew to begin New Years Eve with.

Pours slightly hazy and golden/orangey, thich white head.  Looks great even with the floaters.  Aroma of citrus peel.  Flavor is very sweet, more citrus peel, ginger, pine.  Lots of carbonation, like a soda. This just didnt do a lot for me.
Poured out a great white head, nice yellow color.  Im used to darker ales, so maybe Im a little biased - but I thought lacking in flavor and complexity.

750 ml bottle  Pours cloudy golden yellow with a good white head, mostly lasting and good lacing.  Aroma is of purfume, spruce,  pine and soft malts.  Dry smooth texture.  Taste has a smooth light acidic with a good aftertaste.
Its just o.k. Not as good as most of the tripels out there. It didnt do much for me. Cheers !!!!!

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2006 Golden/yellow colour with a light white head that rises and falls quickly. Runs smoothly on the tongue, this beer gives the impression to be thick and liquorous. Sweet (honey?)  and spices (pepper) aromas, but leaves a somehow strong alcohol taste.
Drink it along spareribs or eventually chicken tandori.

Slightly hazy golden yellow with large white head that falls quick and leaves a nice lace on the top and sides of the glass. Aroma has a mustiness to it honey fruity light black cherry. Syrupy palate very sweet. Alcoholic hints that are more noticable then most I have had but dont take away from the flavour and enjoyment of this beer.

yellow pour.  strong alcohol smell and taste.  i didnt enjoy this at all, and among tripels this would be the lowest one ive ever had.  victory golden monkey is way better.  westmalles dubbel is outstanding, this is not.  i couldnt even finish a 750
This doesnt hide the alcohol very well at all. It has the tripel characteristices, but what makes something trappist? Nice, of course, but many better Belgians out there.

Cloudy orange-amber with an average foamy head and fair amount of unfiltered particles. Yeasty and floral aroma. When sipped, hides the alcohol very well. Comes through in the finish with less dainty swigs though. Aftertaste is a bit perfumy.

Best beer in the world !
Body - Hue
Orange
Head - Color
white
Nice cloudy orangeish pour...big fluffy white head. Spicy aroma, yeasty, coriander, orange zest
Brewed in one of the only five Trapis brewerys in the world 
And

One of my favorite tripels....the first I ever had in The Netherlands.  Nice cloudy orangeish pour...big fluffy white head.  Spicy aroma, yeasty, coriander, orange zest.  The spicy coriander and yeast are all over the flavor with a nice alcohol kick.  Give me some more.  Nice earthy dry finish goes well.  A hint of pepper is there too.  I can always drink this top-notch ale.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2007 Bottle poured a slightly clouded sparkling golden ale into my trappist chalace. Modest fluffy cap and wonderful lacing. Lively effervescence. The nose is greeted with a musty-spicey-honey-apricot aroma..alcohol well hidden here. Mouth feel is peppery from the carbonation. Flavor is not overly complex with the dominant sweet brewers sugar mingling with the caramel malts and yeast to give a sweet spiced cider tone, the hops are there but sit in the background providing a tartness reminiscent of sour apple..short dry alcoholic  finish where the alcohol becomes very apparent. Not my cup of tea....not very drinkable and too sharp to be savored slowly. I echo Oakes sentiment: " what the hell is so special about this?"

Pours hazy light gold with a big white bubbly head. Nose of spice, bread dough, mustu apples and something not unlike bananas, but kind of like sour-sop(guanabana). Hot with alcohol and sweet with ripe white fruit. Remarkably dry finish. About as text book as you could possibly get in the tripel arena. Not my favorite but welcome.

Pours a light golden yellowish color with a thick creamy white head, which fades quickly.  Smells of sweet spices, with hints of banana, pepper, and other fruits.  Tastes very much like Golden Monkey by Victory.  Is slightly sweet with an abundance of spices.  The alcohol is hidden well.  Very enjoyable.

330ml Bottle - Pours a very hazy, yellowish gold with a fair amout of particles floating around and a nice creamy, three finger head that never completely dissapated. Lacing was considerable. Aroma is mostly yeast with flora notes and fruity nuances and maybe a touch of honey. Flavor offered more hops than I expected, lots of yeast and malt and many fruity nuances. The alcohol comes to the front every now and then, although most of the time it remains well hidden. Mouthfeel is rich and smooth with very modest carbonation. The finish is long, dry and a tad bitter! This is a very well made beer, a real treat.

330ml brown bottle. A careful pour yielded a very clear, golden hued beer with a small lacy, creamy white head. Yeast plays a big part in the aroma, floral hops are noticable, fruity with faint oranges. Creamy mouthfeel but effervescent. Flavour was bready and yeasty, with a nice burst of orangey hops in the middle. Long dry finish with a nice note of bitterness.

11.2 oz (350 mL)  brown bottle  purchased from David Copperfields, 74th Street and York Avenue, NYC. ABV 9.5%. Hazy golden yellow Belgium ale having a diminishing large white head with good lacing. Soft carbonation. Intoxicating fruity and sweet malt aromas.  Light-to-medium bodied that starts dry with light sweet malt and finishes dry, crisp and clean.  No discernable bitterness.  Notable alcoholic warmth. Resembles Duvel but with greater flavor.  This is a good drinkable dry Belgium ale.

floral, dough, alcohol, golden, cloudy, frothy, light sweetness, very bitter, medium sourness, medium body, thin feel, soft carbonation, bitter, long finish, 

Meget bitter, tydelig alkoholsmag. Flot skum, men ikke en øl jeg vil gå ud og købe.

Cloudy yellow pour, huge white fluffy head. Lots of sediment and flaties all over the place. Bready yeast aromas, matched and balanced by sweet spicy fruit. Very enjoyable aroma. Sweet bready flavours, lots of spices, yeast, and a great amount of hops. I dont remember the last time I had a tripel that was so hoppy, and balanced. Silky smooth, alcohol not really noticable. If I had to guess at the ABV, I would have said 6 or 7%. But not 9.5%. This is a great brew, and in my mind, the difinitive tripel. Well done.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2005 Bottle (330ml).  Poured a murky deep orangey-yellow with a large creamy white head and lots of tiny white floaties at the bottom of the bottle.  Aroma is of masses of bready yeast, followed by rich fruity/spicy sweet malt and mild citrus - this is incredibly appealing and balanced, Tripels are not my favorite belgian, but *this* one ...  Taste is still balanced, but the alcohol asserts itself and the malt moves into the background with the citrus zest coming closer to the forefront but this is mostly about the spicy, lively, fruity alcohol - decent body and surprisingly bitter on the finish.  Very Nice, high quality brew, I must get more and cellar them.

Hazy straw pour with 1-finger, uniform white head.  The aroma was funky Bretty, with hopcit, candi sugar, some spicy florals.  The flavor was a tad dry, yet somewhat fruity and spicy and floral, but it never went over to the sweet side.  Complex on the palate with more floral spicy notes as it warmed.  Nicely done.  Its really nice seeing that North Carolina hasnt become a monument to drunkenness and debauchery since the 6% beer cap was repealed.  Heres a big F U to all the baptists and other Jesus freaks who opposed the repeal of this archaic, idiotic, unconstitutional law.  This beer kicks ass and takes names.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2013 Complex aroma with toch of banana, this is a golden beer with a strong Co2 sparkeling in the mouth. Strong aroma, milde fruity estery and strong hopcharacter. No diacetyl and ablanced bitterness. Long ever lasting after tast and nice perfect body.
Pours hazy amber golden color with even white head.  Smells sharply of yeast and alcohol.  Taste is just as sharp, but not too harsh.  You can taste the 9.5%.  A nice trappist beer.

Bottle.  Pours cloudy hazy yellow with a medium foamy white head with creamy lacing.  Wheat malt (meal, hay, straw)yeast (dough) aromas with fruity (banana, pear) notes.  Mild light malt wheaty yeast flavor, medium acidity with a fruity finish.  Medium body with a fizzy and lively carbonated palate.

Bouteille de 330 ml obtenue via les Importations Privées Bièropholie. Malheureusement ma bouteille semble contaminée. Arôme: Odeur de fleurs et de gomme baloune. Apparence: La couleur est paille légèrement voilée avec une faible densité de bulle. Présence dun énorme col mousseux et dune large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de solvant qui donne vraiment mal à la tête. La durée de larrière goût est longue. Palette: Le corps est plein avec une texture minérale. Leffervescence en bouche est forte. Présence de solvant et dalcool en arrière goût. (Rating #350)
Smells like a nice strong belgian, and thats exactly what it is. Strong alcohol, and nice fruity flavor. Lighter than expected, thin head.

Bottle. Pours a somewhat cloudy honey yellow with whitish head. The aroma has a lot of lemon, and some banana and sweet grain. Lemon dominates the flavor, also. And the alcohol certainly does not hide. There are a lot of sweet notes in there, too, something like fruity wine, and some hints of bread/yeast. Dry finish.  I like it.

(BJCP Class)  This beer came with its own press agent.  So I will leave that aside and judge for myself.  Golden color cloudy with a nice head.  Strong fruit aroma slight malt character. Strong in alcohol.  Very sweet in taste good balance of flavors.  Has a great dry finish and seems to still come off tasting very light.  IMHO: This was a very good beer.
Dark blonde colour.Good scents on fronts, sweet taste with a notice of liittle alchol.Creammy top stays not so long but taste awsome.Strong but tastey beer.

Clear, brilliant, magnifying orange with audible fizz and an admirable half inch creamy white head and lacing from the get-go.  Pale and staunch aroma of sourdough, corn meal, coriander, starch, pepper and lemon rind scrapings.  Paling, curt and distantly sweet flavor intersession is met with a lemon shortbread - crossed with cornbread profile.  Love this dirty little yeast strain.  Spicy hop accentuations and generous spice contributions (in the form of coriander and pepper) meld well with a sodden leaf complexity to impart an earthen edge.  Theres no shaking the starch and muskiness, and perhaps the fact that its 13 days away from its day of reckoning, we have aging to thank for mellowing the sugar and balancing the abbey ale, carbonation levels included.  Admirable mouth feel and restrained candi sugar and fruity esters.  Some dactylic alcohol, but its bygones, because what we have here is a lovely tripel all-around.

Pours a hazy golden/orange with some floaties and an average bubbly white head with great retention.  Aroma of yeast, belgian spices, sour apple and slight alcohol.  Taste is sweet and fruity (more apple) up front with a nice hop bite at the end.
This is a pretty fair beer, for a trappist. Good and strong, with a good palate and pretty fair flavor. Good malt representation.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2005 A 750ml bottle with a synthetic cork.  Pours a hazy gold color and is topped by a frothy two-finger thick pale tan colored head.  The aroma is quite yeasty, despite the beer resting unsettled for two weeks in my beer fridge.  There is also lots of spicy yeast driven notes with pepper, ginger and lemon being most notable.  As I get used to the aroma some fruit notes begin to pick up, with notes of green apple and tart pear being evident.  The green apple note really becomes quite apparent after a bit.

The beer is full and peppery after my first sip.  The beer almost has a creamy consistency and the spice notes give it a piquant sharpness that I like in a good Tripel.  The spiciness hold throughout the taste profile of this beer, finishing with a sharp ginger like note  at the end.  This has a fairly full body to it, yet still remains quite dry on the palate, mainly I think because of the yeasty spiciness.  As I mentioned this tastes quite yeasty as well, it gives it a sharp yeast bite to it.  The beer has a light tartness to it that plays up the fruity aspects of the beer; mostly I get notes of green apple but there are notes of pear and a bit of tart plum as well, it also plays up the ginger note that is found in this beer.

<font size=-4>Purchased: <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Tucson, AZ<font size=-1>

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2006 One of my my favorite tripels. Pours with a medium white head that is mostly lasting. Deep golden and cloudy colour. Wonderfull aroma of yeast, hops, alcohol and fruit. The flavour contains elements of yeast, caramel and citrus.The finish is sweet/ bitter with an alcohol touch.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2005 Holy Re-Rate, Batman. Big, sweet floral hoppy and complex aroma, worth it for the smell alone. This was a fresh sample and, er, I went back for a case! the taste and feel just glides over me lazily showing off a caleidescopic complexity of warm spiciness, bready yeast, dry pale frut, and a little citric bite, all words that are helpless to explain caleidescopic complexity really. So sod it all. Its just really good! Drink slightly cool, for heavens sake dont keep it in the fridge. That ruined the one I had at the bar.

Old ratng Hop-bitter taste, lacking balance and integration, however patiently I warmed & swirled the glass. Alcoholic-dry palate. Not awful beer but for me theres just better. 6/4/6/3/12 = 3.1

Bottle. Hazy gold body with a thick foamy head. Aroma-citric zest, dust, very light spice. Taste-high CO2, lavender, chamomille, black pepper, bitter backend. Very, very clean. A very good representation of a style I dont really dig.

Hazy and straw-colored.  Bubbly white head that disappeared except for lacing around the glass.  Earthy smells.  Yeast, banana, citrus, spices.  Heavy, carbonated mouthfeel.  Bitter finish and slightly more alcoholic than it should be.  Still, a wonderful brew.

750 bottle from Colorado Springs.  Pours a lush amber with a head that takes quite a while to settle but once it does, it leaves abundant lacing.  Aroma is very citrusy, almost like a mixture of orange juice and mango.  Flavor is, as advertised, rather spicy.  Hints of coriander, grapefruit, orange, and a bit of grape are noticeable.  Finish is dry, but pleasing.  Palate is watery but full and rounding.  One of my favorite Trappist ales by far.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Pours a lovely golden color with the expected massive whipped egg whites retained head.  Aroma is hoppy, yeasty, estery, and also has notes of cobwebs that reminds me of a good saison.  Flavor is yeasty, spicy and finishes bone dry.  This is a quality drinking experience.

33cl bottle. pours a hazy golden with a nice white head. Yeasty fruity aroma. Flavor is dominated by spicy fruit, with a sharp (but not bad) alchol kick. Finishes dry and bitter. Leaves a great feeling in the mouth, but I was hoping for something a little more complex.

33 cl.
Great nose, nice head
Wonderfully balanced flavors. 
Best Tripel Ive had yet and my favrot Trappist Beer

Pours with large head, lots of carbonation.  Head dissipates, but not really quickly, it is hanging around a while for me.  Lots of suspended particles in this beer make it very hazy looking.  Definately has some major yeasty/malty and spicy flavors.  Yes, a bit of citrus too, perhaps lemon?  Can definately tell there is an alcoholic bite in this beer.  Its not bad, but it definately lets you know what kind of beer you are dealing with.  Bitter bite for the finish.  Im going to need to try another one of these at some point.  :-)

An attractive trade dress and unique (fake) corked and caged seal welcomes the Belgian Triple lover.  This ale (in 750 ml bottle) pours a brilliant, hazy light amber bodied ale with ample, tight white and quickly dissipating head.  There is little lacing.

The nose is light-roasted malt, citrus, and bread yeast.  Theres a touch of alcohol in the nose, too, as the ale warms.  Highly drinkable and dry from start to finish.  The light malt sweetness quickly yields to orange citrus, ginger and clove flavors in the mid-palate.  A swift and smooth finish is belies the relatively high alcohol content of this ale.  Very good.

Very robust aroma as it pours a thick, light-looking brew along with a medium, white head that lasts for a little bit. Taste is a bit spicy if you will. A bit harsh for an ale and also a bit thicker than normal. Alcohol is very prounounced. Not too bad but definitely could do better.

To begin, I must say that my low rating is due to the fact that I did not enjoy the style, but this is clearly a quality beer.  The golden color and long-lasting head is close to perfect.  However, I think the problem lies with the fact that the alcohol flavour, especially as an aftertaste, slightly overpowers the other flavours.  This certainly wouldnt be my first choice for a trappist ale.
Bottle:  Poured a golden color with a lasting white head. A cloudy gold. had a citrus aroma with a hint of yeast. Malty sweet flavor.  Bitter finish with a lasting aftertaste of yeast. Great 9.5.....
Great nose, nice head which dissipated quickly for me. Wonderfully balanced flavors. Best Tripel Ive had yet.

Bottle: overall not bad. Dark hazy brown with lots of floaties. Small tan head dissipating quickly. Nose of sweet bread, strong malty and slight candy essence. Flavors are a little to subtle but balanced nicely. Overall a decent trappist.

Beautifull golden color with a slight double shine in the appropriate glass.  A dense white rocky head reavals the spicy fruity esters in the aroma.  Light in body with a slightly sharp metallic character simular to a finely aged sharp Gouda.  Extremely well balanced malt to bitter quality for an exceptional overall finish.

The mother of all tripels. A great-looking orange brew with lots of creamy foam, a characteristic aroma of fruits and an impressive malt taste for a beer this light coloured. Westmalle tripel is one of those beers that will be gaining on you in the long run. When I first tried (some 4 years back) I was not convinced, but slowly it has been growing on me... If you´re only going to taste one tripel tonight - try this!
A decent tripel, but I found the flavors to be too subtle. Cloudy golden color with a white head.

Hmmmm, very nice, pours beautifully thick cloudy orange/tan with a slowly dissipating head. Initially sharply bitter/dry, but as the palate adjusts, the flavor smooths out to a yeasty citrus. I really liked it, not excessively complex, but the more I drank the more complex it tasted.

Cloudy brownish-tellow in color. Fruity aroma typical of a triple.  Flavor is fruity spicy. For a 9.5% ale, there is very little alcohol flavor.  The finish is dry, with a slight apricot flavor trail.  A very fine ale

Pours a beautiful cloudy yellow color with a thick white head that lasts. Lots of apple and citrus in the aroma. Spice comes out in the flavor to compliment the aforementioned fruit. Fizzy mouthfeel but not overbearing. A real thirst quencher that has an intangible quality that pushes it from good to great.

Pours a mostly clear and brilliant light gold with a sparkling head that quickly fades but never goes away and with a nice amount of lacing. Orange and Tangerine  heavy in the nose when swirled to let some of the carbon monoxide you also get a burring sweetness. There are hints of orange peel and an earthy spiciness that come mostly from the yeast. Im glad to know I can pick it up more often(for now)..

bottle. hazed straw gold pour with a huge clingy white head. spiced aroma of lemon grass and and nutmeg that is nice. yeasty flavor that is dry. there is a sweet flavor in the middle of this that i am having a hard time placing. i keep thinking graham crackers while drinking this. citrus finish  with a sharp bite at the end. holy shnikes i just saw that this is 9.5%.!! i would never have guessed that.

This beer pours a cloudy yellow with a white head that laces down the sides.  Smells of sour oranges.  Flavor is very light considering the heaftyness of this beer and has flavors of sour oranges and spices.  This is a well made beer and very drinkable!  Cheers!

Nice pour from a bottle with a rich lasting head that laces all the way down the glass. Sharp nose with bitter orange and some peppery yeast. Well balanced flavors with just enough sweet to balance the citrus. This is an excellent beer and even still refreshing for such a big ale. Gob bless the monks.

Bottle, from Rileys.  Poured a clear straw-yellow.  Nose of sweet carmel and yeast, with an almost cherry-tree smell on the finish.  Very warm and medium to heavy bodied in my mouth.  This beer continues to grow on me as it warms up, revealing more flavors including a nice blend of hoppy flavors.
nice,. but be carefull,..4 of these and you speek only russian

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2013 Bottle. Clear goloden colour with bubbly thin white lasting head. Orange and yeasty nose with some cereal and some alcohol. Good in mouth  slightly caramel flavour and some orange rind. Leads to a very hoppy finish . Not too many flavours but they are good and subtle. Nice tripel. 2005. Man was I dumb back in 2005. Bottle at Kipps Alehouse Folkestone. Clear gold lasting white head.  Good peach and apricot.  Just lovely in the mouth.  Stupidly drinkable some hop bite on the finish.  Excellent.  Stand out tripel.

I find this the best trippel in Belgium, his taste is full. Its a very strong beer, not only in percentage but also in taste. This was the first tripel ever brewn, i think it was in 1936 and its still the best in my opnion. But i havent drank trippels from out of belgium...

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2008 Served in Westmalle glass.
Warm yellow appearance, sligthly dim.
Nice, perfect head.
Aroma is wonderfully hoppy and spicy, refreshing.
This beer I liked to describe as royal or lordlike. It is the prefect tripel.
Palate is overwhelming (not because of a huge body but because of a dry cider-like, orgasmic sensation of perfect acidity), completely wonderful drieness and a flavour that reminds me of green apples and grapefruit.

butterscotch color.. small head, but remained for quite awhile.  was served a littler colder than I would have perfered.  Aromas of champagne grapes, citrus fruits, malt, grass/hay, and alcohol undertones

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2006 Absolutely flawless beer. Meringue-like Belgian head, apricot/apple/lemon nose, fairly hoppy for Belgian ale, perfect body for a tripel, stunningly drinkable for the ABV. I try to be a critic with every beer, but this is as good as it gets.

butterscotch color with a quickly diminishing off-white head. low to moderate carbonation. a nice cloudy golden color.  sweet fruity lemony smell with some apricot and other fruit in it. some nice alcohol smells. lemony citric with a fruity alcoholic kick. Oh wow! Nicely balanced malt and hop flavor. Dry aftertaste. Man this is good.  Mouthfeel is perfect for the style. good carbonation.  Alcohol is unnoticeable.  This is the nectar of the gods. I love this beer.

The second of the Westmalle beers, and a rating I have missed doing on many occasions. I drink this one quite often at a café in the city but never had a pen handy to write down some notes. Tasted from the bottle (at home) and poured into a wide-lipped chalice, cool and not cold. A dense creamy pad of white foam formed atop a hazy orange-gold body. Head remained for the length and left overlapping patterns of lace down the glass. Spicy, almost bitingly zesty, citric, pear, vanilla and yeast aroma with a hint of guava and mango. Remaining quite fruity, the aroma began to show some alcohol as it warmed a little. Lighter than expected body, zesty and similarly fruity in the mouth, it was very smooth in the back with a high amount of carbonation upfront that failed to make it past the halfway point before drying out and becoming lightly bitter. Subtle flavours of ripe and tangy soft fruits, yeast, peppery spices and a good whack of fresh herbs. Finish is long, dry, tangy and warming, with a mix of orange-peel, alcohol, grassy herbs, vanilla and spicy, yeast and alcohol phenols. A discerning beer, refreshing yet good only for a slow sip, it is one I enjoy all year round, no matter the weather. A lovely Tripel!!! (33cL, BBE 15/07/06, Intl Beer Shop, W. Leederville)

Orange clearly color, hazy and much dense one. Fine and compact foam, long persistence. Determined and powerful scent of alcohol and caramel. A lot perfumed and complex. Sweet and sticky like molasses  and sweetish taste, single bitter in the end. Wrapping and solid, densely and slightly dried. End of long persistence. From drink slowly.
Yeasty components very prominent.  Maltiness expressed as bread, dried fruits, caramel, and balanced by the weird belgian spicing.  Alcohol very obvious.
A golden color with a nice light tan head.  A pleasant malty aroma with hints of spice and fruit.  The beer has a medium body with a taste of spiced fruit.

Out of a bottle.  Aroma bready and slight perfume.  Poured a nice hazy gold that had a nice glow to it.  Flavor was spicy and fruity, slight lemon and pepper.  Palate was nice, medium bodied and light on finish.  Overall good, although Im not sure I liked this one quite as much as other trappists.

Pours translucent gold with a large head that leaves some lacing. The silhouettes of bubbles seem a swarm of ascending locusts through the haze. Very bready and clovey aroma. Also some unripe banana and pepper. Flavor is spicy and alcoholic with a strange metallic, yeasty finish. Turns fruity as it warms. Not bad, but the alcohol detracts somewhat and the finish moreso.
Nose has plenty of pineapple, alcohol, cloves & yeast.  Flavor is pineapple, slightly peppery, alcohol, cloves, yeast, lemon & other fruits.  Funky (brett?) dry finish.  YUM!

Poured a light amber color with a thick white head with lots of lacing. Looks great.

Smelled of bananas, alcohol and slightly grassy with some cloves. 

Taste of bananas, cloves, yeast, phenol. Everything was on more of the mild side. Was expected more full flavors from this one. Mouthfeel was a bit thinner that I expected, and I could really taste the alcohol.

Not quite as good as I thought it would be, not sure if this sat out in the light to long. I liked the dubbel more. Still a good beer.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: UPDATED: JUN 15, 2007 Poured cloudy golden orange, with a fair amount of yeast. Decent head, and good lacing. Aroma is full of spicy pepper and bready yeast. The alcohol comes bursting out on tasting - not contained at all!! The flavour is predominantly sweet, and it is quite fizzy, attacking the tongue like hundreds off tiny needles. The finish is slightly bitter, with a bit of a metallic yeasty taste. (7 4 7 3 14 3.5)Re-rate: Had a few bottles of this now, and Im rather underwhelmed. Aroma off honey and cow-shit seems most common to me. Alcohol way too prominent. Spicy and dry like Orval, but it seems to bite off more than it can chew. An over-rated tripel

A hazy golden color with a huge white head. Crisp aroma of fruit and malt. There is a wonderful spicy fruitiness to it that ends with the fullness of the alcohol. This should be sipped slowly and enjoyed.
Small but active head.  First impresion is sweet and perpery. Can this be a tripel but then the alchol comes thru.  Great does it live up to the hype? Not sure.

bottle-pours a slighly hazy peach hue with a small sudsy white head.  Big flavors here of lemon, banana, floral citrus, funky yeast, dusty esters, candy sugar, slighly fussel in its delivery, but it works here.  the flavors showcase that funky yeast character more than i was expecting, showing that this beer may have some age on it.  I assume about 1 year.  This beer has a numbing affect on the toungue throught the drink.  This beer has awesome aging potential i think.  I would love to get more to put away for a while!
strong but perfect balanced aroma - golden color - one of the best tripels
Golden color, with lots of acid. Creamy medium-sized head. Aroma of bread, yeast and citrus. Lightly spicy flavour with a warm finish. A very well balanced beer.
Creamy head at about 1 inch when poured.  Aroma of bread.   Taste was bitter with a slight hot edge at the end.  A good beer, but a bit disappointing.
UPDATED: JUL 15, 2009 maybe a bit too harsh i think, the alcohol and yeast seem to obvious, maybe aging will help but a little dissapointing. RERATE: Too alcoholic, far to carbonated.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2007 I have managed to try this one only a couple of times. Sampled from an 11.2 oz brown bottle this beer poured a slightly hazy pale yellow color with a medium sized white head. The aroma is sweet sugar and citrus. The flavor is lightly spicy and fairly dry with  a nice malty undertone but a bit of alcohol burn on the finish.
Bottle.  A good triple, but a bit on the alcoholic side for my taste.  Nice hints of oak in the nose.  Sweet and almost sticky.

Slightly hazy golden body with a frothy white head.  Coconut and desert bread aroma, slight soapy finish.  Pretty hoppy flavor - orange citrus, sharp stemmy hops, fluffy dandelion sweetness.  Big bitter assertive flavor.

Poured from a 33cl bottle per my boss from overseas.  This beer pours to 100% head that eventually gains a body.  Straw colored body with a huge lasting white head that laces well.  The aroma is a ton of banana and spicy (clove, mace) butter and a light pear.  The flavor is spicy and yeasty.  A weird hop flavor too.  I think this one is a bit overrated.

15 Feb 2005 - Spiritous, sweet, complex and light malt aroma. Cloudy yellow-copper-golden colour with reasonable lacing but this could be better.  Light malt flavour with heaps of orange fruit and strong hops flavour.  Light fruit aftertaste with lingering hops.  The appeal of this beer is that it is subtle and well balanced.

Poured a semi-clouded with a light amber color. Lovely aroma of yeast, hops, sweet citrus and a touch of vanilla. Drinks bitter, yet smooth, light and dry with just a hint of fizz and warmth on the way down. This may not be the favorite of all tasters, but definitely the benchmark of Belgium Tripels. Easily better, IMO, than the Chimays and Duvels.
pours a hazy gold with a thin white head... has a very crisp taste of yeast with the abv% makes itself known with a warm finish.  good brew
caramel, alcohol, butterscotch, vanilla, golden, clear, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium sourness, medium body, sticky, lively,

Absolutely, my most favorite beer; theres only one unfortunate drawback: It does contain a minimal amount of alcohol, youll notice after a couple of bottles (on your way to the toilet)..
It has a full body, thin feel, average carbonation and a long finish.. The beer has a golden colour and theres supposed to be a white head on it.
Most bars in Holland have special glasses for this beer (which look like rather big whine glasses with the Westmalle logo printed on the side). Also, on the bottom of the bottle, theres supposed to be some residu of the fermentation process (which should have taken place in the bottle after shipment). Thats the reason good quality bars fill the glass for you (so you dont have to worry about spilling some of that residu out of the bottle, into your glass; you dont want it, it tastes bitter and gives you a headache, the day after..). Theyll also take care the separation between the white head and the golden liquid is exactly matched with the middle of the logo printed on the special Westmalle glas. Some bars even have little pieces of round paper with a hole in it which have the logo on them and which are put at the bottom of the trunk of the glass, preventing any wet stuff reaching the table top ;-)
If youre preparing the drink yourself (you can buy the beer at supermarkets) and like rituals: Have fun! Its even better than rolling a joint..

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2005 A major disappointment, and the worst Trappist beer I have tasted.  Very light fruit and malt aroma.  Yellow, with a very large white head.  Lacking in flavor, especially compared to Karmeliet.  This is like a plain Belgian ale; reminds me of the unimpressive Unibroue 04 with a simple malt and alcohol flavor combination.  At least the price was marked ridiculously low by mistake, but I wont look for this again.  750 bottle.

My favorite Trappist after Westvleteren, much easier to find. 

A very nice subtle taste and a great body. Very nice collour. Be aware to drink it at the right temperature( 8°C), otherwise it wont taste as rich.

This was a bottle-conditioned beer. The bottle poured a cloudy apricot colored beverage with a small white smooth head. Although small, the head lasted throughout and left nice lacing. The aromas here are not shy or hard to find but almost overwhelming. There are sweet fruits and strong spices with notes of brandy. The body was quite full with good carbonation and an oily texture. The flavor highly complex and starts off with strong dark sweet fruit. The middle is slightly bitter and the presence of alcohol makes itself well known. The finish is long and sweet, loosing its bitter edge but the alcohol warmth continues.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2006 33 cl bottle, bbe March 2007. Amber with peach and straw hues and pretty cloudy. The glass is filled by plenty of middle-sized bubbles which climb to the surface in irregular paths. A quite stable head, leaving thick lace. Hoppy, flowery, spicy and light creamy aroma. Rich honey sweetish flavour with alcohol unassertively in tune giving a hint of cherry liqueur. Also fruity and hoppy, although the hops are less pronounced than in the nose. Full bodied, satisfying palate; tongue caressing, decent carbonation, too. Strong and subtle.

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2006 Rerate: Bottle. Pours a clear, very bubbly dark gold with lots of floaties and a huge fluffy white head. Aroma is yeasty and fruity along with some malt, spices and faint hops -- quite nice. Flavour follows the aroma, its a little boozy but its really good. Medium bodied. Another quality Westmalle beer.
Original rating: 7*4*6*4*12=3.3
Bottle at beerbistro. Pours a murky golden with a small white head. Yeasty aroma of banana, cloves and a strong alcohol presence. The alcohol is too present in the flavour as well, making it a tad unpleasant and brings my rating of it down a bit. Flavour is yeasty and spicy. Nice amount of carbonation. Plenty of trappist beers that Id get over this.

Cloudy golden pour with light white head.  Decent lacing.  Spicy aroma with notes of Belgian yeast, candi sugar, and plums.  Bready and spicy flavor with banana, some citrus, and some dark fruits in there.  Quite complex and well-balanced, with a rather heavy malt backbone for the style (well-done, though).  Alcohol warms a little as it goes down, and there was a nice long spicy banana finish.  Well done!

Bottle. Sample at beerbistro Summer Beer Festival 2005. Hazy golden colour with a pillowy white head that leaves lots of lace. Warm aroma with notes of yeast, peaches and spice. Creamy mouthfeel. Flavour starts fruity, and a little spicey, and finishes pleasantly sharp and warm. Nice stuff.

Clear golden color, puffy white head, tons of lacing & loads of beautiful bubbles from below that keep a steady 1 finger head. Slightly spicy yeasty flavor. Very smooth palate. Light & extremely drinkable. Id never guess this was 9.5% ABV. A very high quality beer. Possibly the best Tripel Ive tasted thus far.

Golden pour, bubbly but quickly dissipating head.  Lots of alcohol in the aroma.  Malt and spices/dried fruit as well.  Alcohol is very strong in the flavor, too.  Unpleasant, even.  Malt is complex and complimented by a lot of nice esters, but you have to seal your mouth to get to it through the alcohol.  Full bodied in spite of the alcohol issues.  Just needs some aging, I would guess.

Another great Belgian. Pours a darker golden color, slightly cloudy. Head is fairly large. Various spices in the taste, dry finish. What made this interesting was the alcohol percent. As it warmed some sips it was easily noticeable, and others not at all. A very enjoyable session.
Fat lasting head, good smell, a crisp smooth taste, pours golden, such a mellow for 9.5% alcohol. This beer is beautiful, i love it.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2005 Bottled.  Pours a cloudy golden yellow with a small quickly dissipating head that leaves a ring of head around the snifter.  Aroma is of sweet malt and bready yeast with a substantial ester profile.  Some irritating alcohol vapors hit the back of your throat if you inhale too deeply as well.  Flavor is very hot and alcoholic upfront with develops nicely into a floral ester profile (banana, citrus, spiciness) with adequate sweet malt (not cloyingly sweet though) and yeastiness for balance.  A slight sourness lends a refreshing character.  I found that taking  a faster and larger sip bypassed the alcohol edge in the begining and got right to the complex middle and finish.  Finishes fairly dry with a bit of tannic astringency.  Body is fairly full for a Tripel with  more than adequate carbonation.  If only the alcohol wasnt so overpowering upfront.
A tastefull golden trappist ale, with a nice head, wondefull aroma and a lot of taste, a really good beer.
Bottle.  A very enjoyable tripel with a good deal of foamy carbonation for a beer of 9.5%abv.

Dark orange, little carbonation, foamy head. Taste is yeasty throughout with a slight bitterness at the end. Very buttery and full palate is the highlight of this beer. Not great, especially for its price. I could get two or three micros of the same style for the price ($5)

A good strong and wery tastefull trappist.
The falvor is good and strong and very awakening.

11 oz bottle.  big white foamy head.  Color is a cloudy straw when bottom ½ of bottle is swirled & poured to blend the yeast back in.  Aroma-light,  grainy&apple.  Taste at 1st is dry, alcohol then the hops comes thru.  Good beer, just not my taste.

Dark yellow with very nice and lasting head. In fact, the creamy head blocks some of the noseparticularly when I inhaled the white frost up my nasal passage by accident. Still, I smelled a slight floral waft, maybe a little lemon. Taste suffers a little from the hot alcohol vapors. Very nice malt taste, honey, faint banana and other fruits. Yet, amongst this heavy malt, it somehow finishes like a pilsner. Its price was actually not that bad, 4.99 a bottle. Beats shelling out 10, 12 bucks for one. Great beer!
Drank this at Het Elfde Gebod in Amsterdam.  Yellow color and reminded me of lemons.  Wasnt crazy about the slight bitterness but otherwise it was good.
Pale yellow bubbling body with a large white foaming head.  Sweet aroma with a touch of spice.  Surprising full body palate with a taste of light fruits and light peppery finish.

clear, golden with huge white bubbly head...conglomerations of yeasties throughout.  aroma spice, clovey, a bit sour.  taste is yeasty, a little sourness, with some hops and alc only at the very end.  I have been drinking so many big sweet beers lately, this is really nice and crisp,simple yet some complexity,.damn i need to drink more tripels,,damn me broadening horizons, life wasnt so bad when all i knew was chimay, duvel, etc...this stuff rocks.

Bottle, at No. 5.
Yellow with large white head. Aroma very sweet, light of hops. Flavor first very sweet of malt, then very hoppy, but in perfect balance. Long duration. Medium to full body, sirupy. The alcohol is felt.

Classic Belgian tripel. Poured a cloudy marmelade colour with a huge frothing head. Aroma has orange zest, spices and peppery alcohol. Big syrupy body, fruit at the front of the mouth with a hefty alcoholic kick in the follow-through. For my money, it just doesnt quite carry its 9.5% abv. Cant wait to try the dubbel, which is more in my favoured abv range. (33cl bottle)
Bottle.  A sweet apple and spicy aroma.  A light yellow color with small head.  A sweet apple and pepper flavor with strong alcohol finish.  Very nice flavor with a well hidden alcohol content.

Pours a cloudy straw gold with a fluffy white mirangue head. Nose of clovy esters, lemon grass and phenols. Firm palate with the alcohol really sticking out. (Only major flaw) Mouth filling CO2. Sweetish flavors with a great deal of phenols mixed in with some peppery spiciness. Nice dry grassy hop finish.

Pours a hazy yellow with a huge frothy white head. Very lacy. Big white chucnks of lace throughout. Smlells lemony, peppery. Spicy and fruity, maybe nutmeg or allspice?

Taste is also lemony and spicy. Hints of cinnamon, black pepper and nutmeg. Yeasty. Some serious alcohol bite. Lightly fruity with bitter finish. A tripel with a distinctive hop profile? Very dry. Body is big and bold. Bitter, peppery aftertaste and damn dry on the tongue. Lots going on here and probably needs to smooth out with age a bit but a really bold beer.
On tap at a really cool beer bar in Amsterdam.  Fizzy golden color with a carbonated head.  Very dry with a bitter lemony taste.
pale yellow in color with a white head with decent retention.  A spicy malty aroma.  Taste was initally malty with a bread notes and a bubblegum background.  Slight hoppy finish.

Pours a cloudy golden color with a nice tall white head. Excellent crisp dry spice in the nose. This brew manages to balance a heavy, strong body with a lively carbonation that lightens it up on the palate and really makes it very smooth and drinkable for its size.
Hazy pale yellow, thick white rock hard head. Acidic, yesty nose. Slight vinous, Fruity, flowery and citric flavour. Excellent bitterness. Spicy hints. Full bodied.

Lemony, citric, hoppy, "Belgian" aroma. Cloudy, yellow/orange color with thin white head and minimal lacing. Some yeast sediment in glass. Dry, acidic, bitter, spicy flavor. Lemon, grassy and alcohol flavor components present along with a "Belgian" yeasty flavor. Flavor is very complex overall. Effervescent palate with light/medium body and a long finish. Initially, seems dry from bitterness, but theres some body and slight sweetness backing it up. Complex aftertaste shares the same components as the flavor. Excellent.
UPDATED: JAN 8, 2006 (Bottle 33 cl) Very hazy, orangey colour. Lots of yeasty sediment. Very spicy, very bitter all the way through. The alcohol is quite dominant. 150793
This dark golden ale pours with a short white head. The aroma is of yeast and fruit. There is a noticeable alcohol flavor initially, with a hoppy finish. This is a nice example of the tripel style.
Poured a goldish hue w/ a creamy whit head, aroma was yeasty as well as the flavor, heavily yeasty, but went down very smooth, i liked it.
I love triples and westmalle is one of the best.. Heavy alcohol, yeasty, like a triple should be....

Cloudy golden with a bubbly white head. The head left lacing all the way down the glass. Highly carbonated. Aroma: bread, orange, bubble gum, and floral notes. Has a heavy mouthfeel and you can taste the carbonation as the bubbles dance across your tongue. Flavor is mostly yeast, with slight fruit notes. Apricot sticks out over all of them. Spicey with a dry finish.
Bottle. Hazy orangey golden color with medium rocky off white head. Aroma and flavor were very complex hop, citrus and spice. Full body with creamy sweet texture. Enjoyed.
If you like strong Belgian ales, this is one you need to try.  Perfect golden color with a very sizable head.  You definitely taste the yeast.  Very good.

Golden with a white head.  Sharp alcohol presence throught the aroma and flavor.  In addition to the alcohol, there are grapes and spices in the nose.  The flavor contains orange rind and yeastiness.  Nice finish - very dry and hoppy.
cloudy golden color huge rocky head. lots of puffy lacing in the glass. aroma is musty and bready. taste is lightly apricot and spice has a dry and slightly bitter end. very good.

Bottle. Very nice aroma and beatiful golden appearance. Somewhat disappointing flavor and mouthfeel, however. Much too dominated by the alcohol.
All in all a very mediocre trappist.

Cloudy golden color with large white head.  Aroma of yeast, banana and spices.  Sweet malt, fruit and yest notes in flavor.  Spicy , dry hop finish.  Very smooth and creamy body.  Alcohol not noticable until the finish. Very nice.

Appearance: Golden with a bright white head. Initial aroma is floral, with a slight ester. Very belgian. Over time it looses some of the floral character, and I noticed more yeast and grains. First tastes are bright and rich. Some banana and some tropical flavors too. Alcohol isnt terribly apparent. Body is thick and rich, numbing after time. Finish is estery and slightly sour. Quite delicious overall, though the finish seemed not as good as some belgians. Still, at 9.5% ABV, thats quite good.

A cloudy, lemony-yellow with a huge white head and a few fairly large particles floating around at the bottom. Complex aroma contained a doughy yeast quality, banana cookies, and tart berries. At times it smelled like a bagful of Halloween candy. Flavor started sour but held a floral quality. As it warmed, I could swear it tasted like a Kamikaze shot. A very intriguing beer that kept me guessing.
<font size=-4><a href=
http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.as DiCarlos Armanetti, Willowbrook, IL<font size=-1>

The color of spun gold in the glass with a fizzy white head.  Aromas are cobwebby and bananas, definitely highlighting the yeasts in this tripel.  I notice the smooth creaminess of this tripel moreso than others of the variety.  Wonderful dry finish.  A warm breadcrust flavor is brought out by the astringency.

Bottle. Good thick head with an amber orange tone, very cloudy. Had a lifted and bright nose which was very attractive and enticing though not as deep and meaningful as others of this ilk. Nose had a little bit of medicinal note and the body was lighter and less forceful than expected. menthol and bandaid followed through on the palate and these menthol characteristics were a little off putting. This lowered the tone of the whole thing for me, though it had obvious attributes that kept its rating a little higher.

Pours a rich golden color with a thick, white head.  Smells of fruit and yeast.  First taste is complex with citrus lingering on the tongue after swallow.  Quite heavy for a light colored beer.  A nice change from your run of the mill domestics, but nothing incredible.

Great Belgian brew! This one finishes nice and dry, has the classic HUGE Belgian head and is nice and creamy. Fruity notes such as Bananas and candy sugar. This is a great brew! it has a lot going for it.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2005 [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Cloudy look. Light yeasty aroma and a bit of fruit. Taste strong and alcoholic. Gets the heat on...
Bottle @ Hotell Simonkentää, Helsinki Finland Backlog 1 April, 2005Refreshingly full bodied, nice acidic taste and sweetness combined. Complex taste of dark fruits and tropical fruits.

Bottle: Clear to hazy gold with a big creamy head. Plenty of medicine, band-aid, and cloves in the initial aroma. Some cellar malts (dusty, musty barley) with a spicy hop element. Banana, cloves, and hot spicey flavours with a nice toffee-like sweetness and pointed hops. Very nice. Quite hot but also very hearty. Loses a couple of points for having slightly harsh bitterness. Excellent.

Tripple the burn. Tripple the buzz. can i get a hell yea? First half was heavy on the alchy and cirtrus. Mellowed out into a fluffy mouthfull with  banana and sweet clove. Snowfall throughout the glass. A damned winter-wonderland of yeast in whats supposed to be spring. for fecks sake.

Bottle: Straw coloured with a big fluffy long-lasting head; impressive fruity nose (banana); even thogh not low carbonated, very smooth in the mouth; thie initial orangey fruitiness, accompanied by hints of candy, switches over to soft but clear hoppiness. Very "warm" and complex brew.
UPDATED: MAY 20, 2005 pours a murky honey colour. nose is yeast, apricots, spice and a fair bit of alcohol. well bodied has a dry, warming finish.

orangey golden color, slightly hazy with very large yeast chunks.  pillowy white thick creamy head.  nose is yeasty, deep malt and candi sugar.  raisin too.  creamy mouthfeel.  high carbonation.  deep malt flavor.  alcohol too.  pretty dry for a tripel.  a little dried orange peel flaor and bitter finish.

Super nice brew! Poured cloudy yellow, with a thick rocky head that lasted and laced! Carbonated with bubbles coming up from the bottom of the glass for a very long time. Aroma is yeasty with some leather, barnyard action going on in there. This one gets better by the sip. Flavor is strong and to the point. The carbonation makes a great play on the tongue with the flavor (good wheaty, hoppy, and yeasty). Its definitely worth the money, and I am terrible about justifying taste for cost. I will Westmalle again!

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2005 Bright yellow with LOTS of sediment and a bright white frothy head. Lemony, citrus. Hints of alcohol in the taste and aroma. The main flavors are orange, some lemon and alcohol with a slight bite in the end.

Highly accessible tripel which definitely went against my expectations for a Trappist ale.  Pours a deep gold with a fizzy head.  The aroma is spicy and fruity, and the flavor is clean and dry, with a spice bite followed by a more mellow and fruity finish.  Tastes like a very good, clean, strong ale--youd have no idea the abv is so high.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2007 A slow, steady pour generates a rich, golden-peach hued beer--hazy and obviously bottle conditioned--with a mountainous, milk froth white head.  Slow to recede, light lacing.  The aroma is big, even at cooler temperatures, full of grains and pepper.  Forceful undercurrents of mandarin oranges and lemon zest rush past.  White grapes, sourdough bread, peaches...all working in harmony.  Faint traces of caramel can be detected, and even some coarse wool as well.  The flavour begins bready sweet, with hints of caramel, along with a robust orange acidity.  Tart fruits--lemons, grapes--emerge midpalate.  The finish brings a peppery spiciness and alcohol dryness.  Long, warm, peppery, herbal aftertaste.  Enjoyable, soft mineral compliment throughout.  The body is just over average, the texture dry yet velvety, carbonation very aggressive.  Bizarrely intriguing, an eclectic mix of soft and spicy, dry and sweet.  All ingredients make themselves pleasantly known; minerality of water, pungency of hops, richness of malt, esters and doughiness of yeast.  Quite an experience, but it feels lost in itself from time to time, spread too thin over so many aspects that it seems more like an amalgam of quality Tripels rather than a Tripel of its own.  33cl bottle, Duvel tulip, bbe 13/09/09.

750 mL, Chimay chalice.  Tall, creamy, white head is well lasting and sits upon a thoroughly hazy peach hued beer.  Spicy hops, lemons and pepper come across first.  The doughy yeast blends well with breadish and, at times, candyish malt aroma.  White grapes, pears, yellow raisins, peaches and a touch of Braeburn apples seamlessly integrate.  Strong sweetness upfront is matched by tart acidity and light spicy hops.  The backend is shallow of sweetness and really brings the tart and spice on in full.  Very dry and almost leathery finish.  Alcohol is burried in the nether regions of I know not where.  Medium full bodied with a silky texture and perky carbonation.  Original rating: 8,4,8,4,16 = 4.0.

1st Trappist Ale, Smelled grassy and spicy.  Appearance was a nice semi-frothy head and amber color.  Has a spicy and dry mouthfeel.  Slightly bitter and citrusy it has a lingery sweet mouthfeel.  I can almost taste green grapes after the swallow.   As high is the ABV is you dont taste the alochol very much.
Rather fresh and light for such a strong beer, also a bit sweet, just the way I it. One of my favorite trappists. Not hard to come by and not so expensive as some other trappists.

Cloudy golden yellow, somewhat lasting white head, medium sized bubbles in the head.  Could hear the fizzle of carbonation on the pour, bubbles running through the beer top to bottom the entire glass.  Aromas of champagne grapes, citrus fruits, malt, grass/hay, and alcohol undertones (scotch?).  Flavor standing out mostly were the malts and the alochol bite at the finish.  Alcohol bite was gentle and not over the top.

11.2 oz bottle
Pours cloudy orangy/yellow with large chunks of yeast floating about.
I had this bottle sitting undisturbed for three days and poured carefully, yet I still ended up with a lot of yeast.
Head was a decent size but it was short lived.
Aroma was fruity and yeasty and spicy.
A little orange peel.
Flavor is spicy, with some floral hop and some citrus zest in the finish.

Bottled. Pours a cloudy amber colour with a big head. Aroma of spices, cloves, yeast and citrus. As carefull as I was, some huge yeast chunks made their way into the glass and thus the apearance was far from appealing. Nice full body. Great mouthfeel, some tingling on the tongue and a nice alcohol warming. Some banana in the taste but mostly spicey with some hop bitterness. Way too many chunks to finish off that little bit at the bottom of the glass

(bottle) Straw coloured with big frothy head. Aroma of flowery hops and yeast. Dry and spicy start with a well balanced hoppy and non-disturbing alcoholic finish. Really good but also not worldshaking Trappist beer.

Nice though maybe not at the same level as St. Bernies Tripel.  Light grassy aroma, lots of head, crisp, bubbly, creamy mouthfeel/finish.  Very drinkable.  Something I can only think to refer to as "tart."  Somewhere right around 4/5 = 8/10.

[bottle in South Africa]
Hazy gold with pristine foamy head thats like a fog cover, the bubbles are so fine.  Sour citrus, vanilla, candy, coconut, and some perceptible hops are all detectable in the aroma.  The flavour is spicy and sweet with subtle banana and peach notes and bitterness that I dont think comes from hops.  Higher alcohol and "buttery" flavour that ends with a well-balanced hop bitterness.  Interestingly, this beer does not feel warm, despite the high alcohol flavour and the high alcohol percentage.  The body is medium to full and the carbonation is substantial.  This beer is very good.
This is one fabulous beer. This was overall not quite as enjoyable as the Dubbel. The spicyness of it was a nice change from all the fruityness of American style beers.

Bottled.  Smells of light yeast, alcohol, fruit and citruy hops.  Initial flavors are slightly sweet but are quickly (simultaneously?) blended with a light lemony hop flavor before passing into a lightly bitter, spicy and alcoholic finish.  Seems like a large amount of candi sugar was used given the fairly light body and dry finish.  Cloudy golden-yellow color with a huge, finely beaded head with nice lacing.  Very enjoyable.
UPDATED: JUN 30, 2005 bottled.  it has a large head and nice aroma.  my bottle is clear.  it feels hoppier than most triples.  the alcohol is definitely there.
