Bottled. Cloudy deep orange colour with big foamy head. Leaves lacing. Fruitish aroma with hints of malt and yeast. A bit weird taste, sweet and bitter at the same time and also very spicy. Alcoholic notes can also be found. Sweetish aftertaste. Very nice balance and palate.

Poured a very cloudy deep orange - amber with a great deal of sediment and a big frothy head. Floral, yeasty aroma with herbs and alcohol tingling the nasal passages. Very complex flavour  sweet with a mild bitterness  long, sweet aftertaste with hints of cinnamon. Overall this beer has so much complexity that it is hard to find the right descriptors but this beer is beautifully balanced and perhaps even more importantly  it is INTERESTING!

A world classic the first ever triple. Yeasty spice nose light grassy hop overtones and a perfect malt backbone with a touch of tart acidity green apple and lemon zest with a little sea salt air for good measure.

Drity orange-yellow in color with small foam. Aroma of oxidized fruit, yeast, malt and some spices. Malty, fruity taste and spices and hop in the end. Complex afthertaste with a bitterness of hop in the end.
Poured a dark golden color.  Sweet and yeasty aroma.  Flavors of brown sugar, raisin, and spice.  Medium bodied with a semi-dry bitter finish.

Murky dark gold to light brown.  Doughy, yeasty aroma.  Very complex flavor of light fruits, spice, pepper.  Good carbonation.  Lots of yeast in the glass.  Alcohol warmth is a little much, but a very nice Tripel.

Smells strongly of lemon, curacao, musty basement/ clove hops.  Body is a sunny yellow with slight orange hues and floating yeast clumps. Head is gorgeous beaten egg-whites, stiff peaks and all  very long lasting! Commanding flavor that really fills your taste buds. Healthy amount of malt flavors: caramel, apple, grapes and raisins. Taste bitters toward end considerably with citrus and cloves. Nice beer, quality crafted.

Dark cloudy gold with a voluminous rocky head, aroma of freshly baked bread laced with nutmeg and currents, flavor a blossoming dried apricot/orange rind/biscuit with a long dry complex finish like a langorous ellipsis...

Light brown color, big yellow lasting head. Cloudy appearance. Peppery, fruity, mild citrus and medium alcohol in aroma. Full bodied. Flavor starts with strong citrus and fruits, ends with spicy and dry aftertaste with notes of anis. Alcohol comes up too much, drops the score little bit.

Hazy orange-gold hue, big foamy head, fruity,yeasty aromas leading through some orangy notes and alcool. Well rounded on the palate with fruity, acidic and malted-caramel flavors with a bouquet of bitterness on the finish

Let me just say....I love this beer, a weekly if not daily drinker of mine for years.  This beer sits in the chalice at room temp, golden, frothy white head, always gives off wonderful yeasty sweet aromas.  The taste is subtle and elegant, with a pefect dry finish.  We have spent many a great lazy Sunday afternoon together.

Bottled & from The Alex in Derby.

Straw yellow in colour.

Very pungent aromas off thi one. A good strong flavour, though not over powering in alcoholic taste, despite its 9.5%. Nice & wheaty. One of the most drinkable of the bottled Euro beers Ive had.

Refreshing nose with spice and citrus overtones.  Excellent for about 80% of the taste, but overly bitter at the finish.  Will re-rate, as I purchased a Westmalle Dubbel at the same time that Im taking back due to off taste.

Bottled. Rating #500. And a deserved half century marker it is, too. Carbonation keeps this a hazy pale yellow with a massive pillowy white head. Really refreshing aroma, like freshly zested lemons with a slew of yeast mixed in. Has that light sweetness carried off by sorbet, could be cloying but avoids it with a hop nip and rapid dryness. Some beers are made for sitting outside cafes watching bicycles go by. This is one of them.
typical, very well-known belgian beer. as we can brew them the best. one of the best abbey beers of belgium

Yellow colour with a huge white head.
Spicy acidic aroma with notes of alcohol.
Spicy flavour with notes of yeast, banana and alcohol with a nice and well balanced bitterness.
Nice tripel.

Hazy orange color with a less than fully developed head.  Fantastic spice, yeast and malt aromas.  Coriander and orange zest are clearly present beside the yeast and s syrupy malt aroma.  Spices balance the malt flavors - which are a little sticky - quite well and provide the intrigue in this beer.  Im just fascinated by the orange zest/coriander interplay.  Nice body.  Clean, if maybe a little sticky, in the finish.  Very nice.

Lovely gold, with only a slight haze. The white head  lasts well. There is an AMAZING aroma of malt & spice. Not as full bodied as I expected, but still a big mouthful, fantastic flavour, I found it a touch sweet, but very well balanced. A refreshing acidity comes through on the l-o-n-g finish. A fine ale that is dangerously easy to drink for a 9.5%er.

Bottle:  Very nice fruity and sugary nose.  A little citrus in the background.  Pours a hazy yellowish-orange with a little sediment.  Huge white head with great retention.  Lacing is pretty good.   Fruity up front (light banana and citrus) with a light hop finish with some spice and alcohol.

Pours hazy golden with big white head. Lots of sweet banana esters is this one. Some spices in there, possibly cloves. Flavor is sweet with a bit of bite from carbonation. Alcohol is present. Aftertaste is of rubber, Im thinking garden hose. Decent but not spectacular.
Excellent beer served in a mad glass. One of the best beers Ive ever had. Might pick up a few bottles from the booze boutique tomorrow.
Bottle from Hotel Ibis, Brugge. Hazy yellow, persistant rocky head. Aroma of citrus hop, spice, yeast, candy sugar. Good mouthfeel and long lasting bitter finish. Still love it.
Bottle. Nice hazy orange-honey color. Nice well lasting and laceing white foamy head. Initial sweet yeast, honey, sweet grass, nice slight bitter finish. Very good beer.

Bottle, Beer Bistro, Toronto.  Dark yellow colour with tons of rising bubbles.  Very small sort of murky white head.  Strong sweet and alcohol aroma - very inviting.  Wow, theres a ton of strong complex flavours right off the bat here, very deceiving given the simple look this beer has.  Crisp, yet thick mouthfeel a tough combo to pull off (and describe) but it does it well. Lots of malt and fruity sweetness to the taste - lots of alcohol too, you know youre drinking a strong beer but that doesnt detract - it is part of the whole package.  Slightly bitter at the end as well.  I quite enjoyed this.

Poured a golden color with a lasting white head.  This looks like a wheat beer.  Very cloudy gold.  Citrus aroma with a hint of yeast.  Malty sweet flavor with a hint of citrus.  nice bitter finish with an lasting aftertaste of yeast.   The alcohol in this one is hidden well.  Those monks sure know what they are doing.

Aroma:yeast and lemon 
Appearance:gold -amber good white head.
Flavor:lemom,spice,sweet malt
very sweet for 9.5%
Great triple, nice pale color, mousse like head, Killer aromas of Bread, bubblegum and bananas. Malty flavor, subtle sweetness nice carbonation. The monks know what they are doing

Bottle. Hazy amber with a nice white head. Yeasty aroma with a little sweet malt/sugar. Aroma not too strong. Smooth mouthfeel. Warming alcohol presence. Yeast and banana esters - a light sweetness and a bit of orange. Its nice to have another triple that isnt cloyingly sweet, but this beer is just wellput together - nothing really stands out.

This the best triple to available.
In its class this trappist tastes the best.
Thats probably why this is the most sold triple in Belgium.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2010 11.2 oz bottle - pours deep yellow color with big fluffy white head, hazy. Aroma has notes of wildflower honey, coriander, toasted oak, lychee fruit. Flavor has notes of toasted apples, coriander, continental malts, wet stone, honey. Finish is faintly sweet. Always a great triple.

Excellent looking ale. Opaque buff in color with a rocky bright white head. Assertive aroma of minerals, yeast, alcohol, pear. I get a little cherry also. Extremely well balanced and elegant in flavor profile. It starts with a delicate fruit basket, moves to some barnyard and grainy flavors and finishes crisp and yeasty with  some orange sherbert. Very satisfying.

A small, persistent white head sits above the very cloudy golden body. Tons of floaties. Aroma is bananas, honey, bubblegum (I think), and lots of alcohol. Sweet with a nice dry finish and awesome mouthfeel. Very solid tripel.

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2005 Poured golden from the 11.2 bottle. Nice foamy head, but it does not look like anything great. Smelled crisp and fruity, with a yeast hint. Nice sweet dry malt with a good fizzy. It makes the roof of my  mouth tingle. There is a sour hint as well, warming nicely with a still tingling mouthfeel. This is an easy drink for a 9.5%. Very good. Try this.
7-25-05 re-rate. The head was huge and steady. Nose was malt, sour, and yeast. Wow, big dry mouth. Lots of dark fruits and a strong port taste.  This is better, I have aged this one since 12/04 and, 7 months later is ven better. Damn Good.
Damn good.  complex flavors, kind of dry, and nicely spicy.  Very well balanced.  Great Trappist in general.  Highly recomended.

I like this one much more than the dubble although I think the dubble looks better.  So this one had a quickly diminishing creamy white head on a coppery orange pour.  Great fruity aroma with a little alcohol carried on a yeasty waft.  Alcohol is well masked in the flavor however a nice balance of sweet and bitter spice.

This pours out a murky light orange with plenty of floaties swimming around in the body. It has about 2 fingers high of white foam covering the top and leaves nice sheets of lace about the glass. The aroma is made up of yeast, spice and a slight sweetness. There is also a lemony zest coming from the aroma as well. The taste is spicy with a nice mild sweetness that gets balanced by a slight bitterness. The after taste is a bitter with a peppery bite to it. Mouthfeel is great with a very filling quality about it. This is also highly drinkable and goes down fairly easy for the style. Excellent all around beer that is one of my favorite triples.
Pours cloudy gold with visible fermentation. Floral nose. Flavor is sweet, malty and spicy. Nice alcohol kick. Dry aftertaste without a hop bitterness. Good Beer.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2011 Bottle. Cloudy yellow colour. Big, semistable head. Alcoholic fruity aroma. Very peppery flavour. Distinct bitterness. Flavour is a lot drier than the aroma suggests.

Bottle, 9.5%. 4 years past BB date. The aroma is a little papery, but also mildly malty. Dark amber colour with small black pieces floating in it. Small creamy white head. The flavour is a good mixture of distinct alcohol notes and a good bitterness. A little spicy sweetness in the finish. Well-rounded and holds up fine after four years.

pours hazy and golden opaque. foamy head, very frizzy at the beginning, crisp and light, but the flavors evolve as it warms and becomes smoother. has a tangy yeasty and flowery taste...slight clove or cinnamon? taste. great ale
Very nice beer, nice glazy golden colour. Very nice aroma, and a very nice taste. Sour in the beginning, sweet in the end. Dry in the end.

A much less quality beer than its little brother the dubbel.  A[pearance is nice with a frothy off white head on a golden body.  Aroma is heavily of yeast and flowery hops.  The initial taste is failry sweet and the finish bitter and a little harsh.  Lots of better tripples out there but drinkable none the less.

Cloudy orange pour, huge head, initial aroma was yeasty bread dough and malt,the first taste has a tart sourness immediately evident, then a nice satisfying sweetness settles on the tongue.Has sort of a rough feel on the palate. Alcohol makes its presence known, not quite as sweet as other tripels, and noticably drys out at the end. I like the Dubble better

Bottle...wonderfully hazy orangish pour with a generous white fluffy head.  Yeastly citrus nose, with some spice.  Grapefruit start with a hint of banana and clove.  Nicely peppery with some spiciness also.  Great bite.  A nice tripel.
High white head that disappears slowly, on top of an orange-gold body. Very nice aroma, pretty spicy. Flavour is spicy too, with a bitter aftertaste. A blonde with an attitude!

Bottled. 11.2 oz. Yellow/Orange color. with exuberant head. Fruity aroma. Full mouthfeel. Spicy but a little too peppery with an astrigent bitter taste which I do not find appealing.  Still good for its style. Multiple tastings.
Fruity, spicey, and some alcohol. A very enjoyable beer. Nothing to go absolutly nuts over, but still a great solid beer.

Light gold, cloudy, looks like a wheat beer. Strongly flavoured nose with herbs and nettles. Powerful and sweet palate but seem a bit alcohol driven and fraction disjointed. Finishes with a lick of cinamon.

In 750 mL. Hazy blonde with an extra thick bubbly white head. Yeasty lemony aroma with light orange peels. Sweet alcohol gin, with good sustained hoppiness. Creamy and complex mouthfeel. Pleasing, as I remembered from last drinkng this nectar. Thanks to Dumdum, via Capflu.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2006 Hazy yellow with tight lasting head. Nose is fruity and spicy with some sweetness. Sweet, fruity and malty flavour, with some powerful bitterness in the end. Powerful carbonation. A wonderfully balanced beer.

8-3-8-4-15

Rerate22/7/06 I realized that this is a beer, that I keep coming back to, no matter the mood or time of year.

In the bottle. A delightfully large frothy long-lasting head, but not of high-end Belgian gargantuan proportions. Beer is a cloudy yellow color. First aroma is of yeasty bread dough, followed by a perfume. Slight citrus aroma at mid point. A medium palate with a strong alcohol burn. Average carbonation level and a good bitter aftertaste. Much better than the dubbel. Cheers!

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2005  Nice beer.  The orange taste is very apparent.  The smell is very impressive.  Similar to the Dubbel, but more fruity.  The idea of a beer with an orange taste turned me off at first.  But it ended up working really well.  The alcohol content is high, but well hidden.  I had this again and was even more impressed.  Tastes better warmer.  Very good.  I call it a tie as far as comparing this with the Dubbel.

A hazy orange beer with a huge white head. The aroma is very spicy with notes of yeast, coriander, and orange peel. The flavor is very sweet and very spicy again with notes of the yeast, coriander, orange peel as well as the alcohol - the end is a little dry and woody. But the alcohol is not as present in the sample Im rating since it is more than 2 years old as it is in a fresh bottle - I like the more subtle alcohol presence in the aged version best.

Pours cloudy amber with a huge white head that quickly dissapates.  Alcohol is dominant aroma, with fruits on the side.  Flavor: mostly alcohol., very yeasty and bready with fruits of banana.  Dry finish and creamy mouthfeel.  Yummy!

Bottle.  Sweet, fruity, bananas in the nose with a spicy pepperiness.  Much more faint and subtle aroma than the dubbel.  Hazy blonde/orange color with a huge frothy white head.  Yeasty and spicy to start with coriander and notes of honey along with the banana flavors from the yeast.  Nice body. Enjoyable.

Orange and hazy.  Has a quick big head, but dissipates to a leave a decent lace.  Great aroma ... yeasty, citrus, banana, floral hops and alcohol.  Flavor is powerful with alcohol, bitterness and little more alcohol.  Its dry and not sweet, and theres a little citrus in there.  Overall, its rather unbalanced as the alcohol and bitterness take away from the other aspects
(Bottle)  Pours a cloudy orange body with a large white head.  Aroma of heavy yeast, leather, cheese, and mustiness.  Flavors of fruit, strong yeast, and alcohol.

Light Gold.  Dry, spicy and very yeasty aroma with scents of sweet fruity pale malts, herbs, bubble gum, lemon, tropical fruits,  and noble hops.  Strong bubble gum notes continue on towards the flavor profile, especially on the finish, along with notes of cotton candy, lemon and fruit.  A nice beer.  But there are so many better example of the style.

Im a little new to rating beers. I am too busy drinking and enjoying them to write I suppose. I am sampling one of these at the moment. Strong alcohol taste and what I have come to expect from a trappist triple. I expected a darker ale but this is a golden brew that would deceive the uninitiated with its benign appearance. I just returned from Brussels and had a short opportunity to sample as many local gems as possible before staggering back to the Eurostar for the trip through the Chunnel back to London. They serve Duval and Chimay on thre train. Excellent day...if I could only remember if I had a good time!

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2007 330 ml bottle, best before 09-05-2002. Pours a cloudy orangey amber color with a thin white head. Warm alcohol aroma with coriander and moldy yeast. With aging this beer becomes very smooth, gentle, subtle, I taste coriander, yeast and alcohol, the flavors are less prominent than the flavors of a younger Westmalle tripel but what it lost on flavor it gained immensely in palate. Full body, very mellow, smooth, comfortable texture, its a soft bed for the tastebuds. This beer always amazes me as it ages incredibly well.

33 cl bottle:  pours a nice golden orange color with a nice virgin white head.  teh aroma is very sweet amd spicy.  malt, fruit, pepper, slighty yeasty with a lil bit of farmhouse scent.  kinda remenescent of a sasion.  this is with out a doubt the best tripel i have had yet.  the falvor is quite sweet up front but fades to a well balanced dryness.  nice fruitniess and spice.  alcohol adds to it nicely.  there are some nice citrus notes as well. delightful.

Poured golden yellow with a huge white head that left a thick lacing on the glass and film on the beer.  Aroma has a mild fruitiness with a little bit of spice and some alcohol.  Taste is typical belgian fruit but very, very dry, with a prevalant alcohol character.  Nothing is hidden here.  Fits its commercial description well.  A decent sipping beer, but not nearly as drinkable as other belgians Ive had.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2006 Bottle. Pours a hazy yellow color. Not really any floaties in this one. Decent head, white color. This head not as big as other Belgians. Nice lacing. Aroma is spicy and yeastish. Drying qualities in the mouth. Crisp, a little tart. Flavors of malt and yeast. Alcohol is noticable. Lively carbonation. Not bad.

750cc bottle with a "newcork" cork. Clear, medium to deep amber colored with a large, retentive white head. Great lacing. Aroma is grapish, yeasty. Light to medium bodied, a touch drying. Peppery, yeasty tastes with some white grape characteristics. Nice.

Great Belgium beer!  The consistency is smooth and mostly clear, but from the minute  I poured this into my glass, I had a small geyzer of head streaming from the bottom, creating a thin but  suitable head.  The taste is very refreshing and smooth despite the high alcoholic content.

Cloudy golden white body is topped by a billowing white head. The aroma is classic Belgian, with the farmhouse like smells of hay, horse blanket, and dust, along with pepper and mustard like spiciness. The taste is delicate, and a lot drier than others of the style. The alcohol is quite hot and spicy, and there is a fair level of hop bitterness as the beer laps the tongue. This Tripel does not try to hide the strength it possess, but instead tries to sweep you off your feet with it. Smooth and crisp mouthfeel only invites you to drink up and feel the magic.

10.08.04  33cl Bottle.  The pour is a clouded, hay-colored gold with long, snakey yeasty globs slithering about the glass.  Giant head so typical of a tripel.  Aromas of pineapple, lovely Belgian yeasties, band-aid, canned fruit salad.  Thick, sticky brew.  Acidic dryness to finish after ample yummy, juicy-fruit sweetness coats the mouth.  Wonderful example of the style, the extra aging is evident. Maybe a bit on the syrupy side, and the alcohol could have a greater presence...perhaps thats a product of the trappist aging.   Im surprised that Ive not tried this one before.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2007 (on bottle)First of all, the ale gets my wife drunk after one bottle; every time. Great ale allready here.
Has a very fresh alcoholic, fruity nose to it. One can reallt sent the 9%. Fruits follow in the taste, not much malt in it, has some sweet ´n ´sour vinegar notes. Ends with lots of warmth from the alcohol.
RERATING Ølfest.´07: 1999-2000 brew Big on the sediment in the bottle. Semiyellow, white head. Stil high carbonated, very sweet, almost cloying and gets both too alcoholic and sweet in finish too.
UPDATED: OCT 18, 2004 really big white head,dark murky color with bit of something in it???very smooth and full of flavor.very good tripel.

What a full flavoured beer!  Cloudy gold colour with a crisp white head.  Subtle toffee flavour with a clean finish.  Didnt look at the abv till almost finished the glass...that explains the fuzzyness marching across my forehead.
Cloudy yellow beer with a good sized white head in my snifter. I just didnt find this tripel to my taste. Good flavours of yeast and spice, but not the fruit flavours I love in tripels.

This pours out a hazy golden color with a frothy, small bubbled head.  Theres a strong spicy aroma and a touch of citric hops.  Very carbonated.  This has a nice, full-bodied feel with a tart malt, spices, some fruitiness, and a doughy yeast feel.  Plenty of alcohol presence.  tangy fruit & spice finish.  A good one.

Medium cloudy golden with a lovely head. Aroma of clove, banana, alcohol, and other spices. Heavy on the alcohol in the tatse, but its offset by spices, including clove- which it could use  abit more of. Nice.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2005 Poured straw with thick white head...smelled of cloves and yeast...the body was much thinner than I expected...tasted yeasty, grass, and quite spicy...pepper and cloves all the way...dry yeasty finish...quite awesome...sweet alcohol just before the finish...

APPEARANCE:Bright with slighly hazier straw yellow hue. Taller head that laces much more elegantly than most.AROMA:Much more Earthy, salty (which hints me to believe it is the Westmalle), slightly soapy FLAVOR/BODY:
 Much thinner than led to believe, immediately zestier, acidity is more pronounced. Very grassy at first swallow, toasty dry and hay-like aftertaste. Saaz-like hops (whatever hops it is that they use) is quite strong and dominates this beer. Orange peel and faint clove (the hard type that you push into a turkey...I always chew on those) flavor as this really gets warm. Doesnt match the intensity of flavor as beer Zatte or Mad Bitch, mostly due to the overpowering grassiness.

(Best by 12/June/2005) (33cl bottle) This beer is picturesque in my Chimay goblet. The head and lace are thick like whipped cream. The nose is a bit restrained showing a little hop and yeast. However, the palate is exploding with complex flavors. I taste tropical fruit, both pineapple and banana sprinkled with coriander, ginger, and green cardamom. The finish is equally as exciting as the palate, it is full of rich candi sugar flavors that lasts for several minutes. Overall, this beer is top notch and would pair nicely with a vindaloo or madras curry.

Beer pours in generic chalice glass a cloudy light orange golden liquid with a generous amount of virgin white head that dissipates quickly to leave a thin film.  Aroma is of fruit, citrus, sweet, and hops.  Flavor has a strong citrus bite followed by a medium sting of hops.  Probably a decent tripel, but too strong of hops for my tastes.
Golden and medium hazy.  Strong alcohol flavor that mellows a bit when it warms.  Some citrus and spicy notes and a slightly bitter finish.  Crisp and warming.

330ml bottle with "Westmalle" around the neck. Use by date: 22/01/05
Pours a golden color with good carbonation and a fluffy white head. Cloudy with a lot of chunks floating around. The amount of sediment is extreme, so it is difficult to leave it out of the mix. The lacing is light and slippery, and the head lowers to a fine film. The aroma is fruity, doughy, hops and yeasty, with some astringency -- very fresh. Flavor is very tart and peppery with a sweet middle and a bite at the finish. Mouthfeel is full bodied and creamy with a lingering hop finish.

With it?s high ABV, it is important to let it warm a bit. I had a few of these in Amsterdam. The one I had at the Reichsmuseum was a mystical experience. The ones I have had in the states, however, have been a lot harsher and, by comparison, a disappointment.
Very crisp and refreshing. Golden body and frothy white head. Effervescent aroma of citrus complimented by a bitter flavor. Quite good.

in amsterdam at boom chicago: we had a pitcher of wieckse wit and then this after....this was so alcoholic tasting you could hardly drink it....i had just been in belgium and drank several begian beers so i wasnt being a woosie...but this thing burns when you drink it. might as well order yourself a wiskey. the dubbel is much more complex and well rounded. maybe if you sit on this for a while it would mellow but my mouth is still burning. i gonna have to pass on this westmalle. maybe this one should come in a smaller bottle and would be  good for a sipping at last call.
UPDATED: JUL 22, 2007 Pours a hazy orange with a large fluffy head and a beautiful citrussy/orangey aroma. Lovely dark tripel taste....a classic.

Cloudy golden with a very white head. Lots of bubbles. Full wheat beer aroma of hay, lemon and banana. Complex flavour that begins bitter/sweet and ends with a long bitter/acid aftertaste. A bit too much alcohol flavour though.
A crisp and tasty white head and golden body on top of a grassy, wine and chocolate finish.  This beer finished near tops for a night of beer that included a chimay and a victory stout!  Excellent@!!

When many a brew are lauded for their boldness and brashness, its wonderfully refreshing to sit down and savor a perfectly balanced product that soothes and mellows. Westmalle triple is just such a delightful ale.
Color is a hazy orange, and the heads a full, towering stack of crackling, lacey, creamy foam. Aroma is led by sugar and spice, followed by everything nice. On my first sip: sublime! Utterly heavenly! Light, smooth, uplifting, dazzling in every way.
Some fruitiness comes through in the middle, peaches, orange, slight citrus. Hops are lively, malt is solid, and delivers more than sufficient sweetness.
My satisfaction grows with each rewarding sip. I feel that I ought to re-consider every beer I deemed "perfect" prior to this. Soft, smooth, mellow, with a dominant and delightful finish.

My god this was a tasty beer.  It looks so pretty in the glass.  A small white head atop a golden body.  The head gets really small but stays even after a few sips.  Goes down very smooth.  Great beer.  They will probably see a lot more of my money.

Cloudy golden color with big head and good retention. Lots of lace on the glass. Aroma of citrus, candy and spice. Flavor reminiscent of a bavarian wheat on steroids. Noticeable alcohol and a lingering bitter finish. Thick, creamy mouthfeel. Pretty good, though not what I expected.

Pours very cloudy yellow with white long lasting head.  Nose is spice - coriander and lemongrass.  More citrus in the body, as well as grapefruit and a sweet flavor Im not sure of.  Finishes very strong, mildy bitter with definite alcohol notes.  Very creamy mouthfeel.  Great beer.

Perhaps my expectations were too high.  I can see what a lot of brewers here in the States are trying to copy, though, after trying this tripel.  Fuller bodied than I expected.  Maybe it was a bad beer day and I should have stuck to session beers.

330 ml bottle, best before 09/03/06. Hazy golden yellow colour with a lasting creamy and frothy head. Orange, yeast, herbal, grassy, and perfume aroma. Cookie, light citrus (orange and lime), and yeast flavours giving way to an herbal and perfumed bitter finish. Full bodied, creamy and fizzy mouthfeel. Reminded me of Unibroues anniversary line (10, 11, 2004), but a bigger mouthfeel.

My new favorite Tripel. Thank God it is finally in Oklahoma. Huge fruitcake spice aroma that liiks abosolutely great in my DeKoninck Glass, with a white compact head that stays to the end. Not as sugar/ sweet as other Tripels, with a great texture and a crisp alcohol snap. Love it!!

Bottle conditioned. Huge pear like alcohol aroma along with spicy yeast, mild citrus fruit and faint herbal aromas.  The alcohol just batters any subtlety of the other aromas into submission.  Full bodied with a drinkable texture. Alcohol continues in the taste with a touch of sweetness and hint of spicy bitterness in the finish. An after dinner drink with the spicy alcohol flavours similar to a grappa.  However it falls short as an after dinner drink, on the one hand being too alcoholic and full to cleanse and refresh the palate and on the other not rich and complex enough to satisfy the appetite for depraved gluttony.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2004 330ml Bottle. Not as good as the Westmalle Dubbel in my opinion, but a superb beer none the less.
Golden yellow in colour. Spicy, citrus aroma, and taste. A healthy hit of alcohol as well.

11.2 fluid ounce brown, European shaped bottle. Bottle has a glass donut ring around the lower part of the neck. Neatest looking European bottle Ive ever seen. I think Ill keep it for a bud vase.
Anyway, look, this beer rocks from the time its opened onward.
Poured out a beautiful, hazy golden yellow color. It has a humongous white head that wont quit. Served in my Chimay chalice, excellent choice for this particular beer. Aromas are of fresh malts, sweet Timothy grass, Belgian funk, horse blanket, leather, tobacco, yeasty sourdough bread, and slight whiff of citrus, most likely lemon. Lychee fruit, and candi sugars round out the aromas. The tastes are exactly as the aromas are. Full of fruity esters, slight smoke, alcohols, and sugars. Man, the good Brothers at Westmalle sure did their homework on brewing this nectar. This beer is an experience, not just a regular old run of the mill brew. It sure gives Westvleteren a run for the money, that much is certain. At 1/2 the price of Westy, this could easily be my everyday beer. But, that would spoil the entire experience for me at least. Finishes sweet, dry, and fruity, all at the same time. A wonderful triple from Belgium. Seek it out at all costs, Grasshopper.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2006 Cloudy golden color with a large dense white head. Aroma of coriander with a hint of pine. Flavor is hops and citrus
with a nice balance of malt.

Bottle.  This is a good tripel style.  Pours hazy golden orange with a few floaties and nice white head that lingered fairly well.  Love that belgian aroma.  The smell  is dominated by yeast and spice, with sweet maltiness and citrus in the mix.  Flavor is sweet with a balancing sour-tart character, yeasty bread notes, noticible alcohol and a mild hop finish with hints of pepper as well.  Medium to full body, mildly creamy carbonation make for a good mouthfeel.

Pours golden, a little cloudy, with a significant head.  Aroma is of yeast, lemons, orange peel, and roasted malt.  Flavor is more of the same from aroma, with the peel coming through strong.  Soft mouth feel, with a bite in the aftertaste.  Alcohol not noticeable.  Excellent.
33cl. Bottle.  Wow.  Great Belgianyeasty aroma.  Taste is right on the mark; rich, full, complex.  Lotsa flavors to play with.  Highly enjoyable, a fine, fine tripel.
UPDATED: JAN 21, 2005 Bottle. Hazy golden color, fruity, spicy aroma, sweet and bitter taste, full body, wine finish.

Nice goldenblond color with a large creamy head.In the nose there are fine complex aromas of fresh stonefruit,exotic spices and well selected hops.It has a dry malty taste with a fine complex unthertone of noble hops and spices. It ends in a soft bitterness.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2004 Poured a hazy golden color with a large white head. Large particles. Aromas of fruits, spices, candy and light alcohol. Starts of a little sweet and ends in a nice bitter taste. Fruity and spicey. Very good tasting beer. Dry finish with light alcohol (but not 9%).

Slightly hazy golden with a large pillowing head. Aroma is of fruity yeast: peach, red apple, a little cirtus and a little grassyness. Full in body, with a huge spicy, peppery, herbacious, a little sweet malty biscuity flavour. Warming alcolhol, whiskyish, fruity, passionfruit and lemony grapefruit, followed by a nice lingering bitterness(earthy and citrusy hoppiness) a bit of astringency.

Bright golden orange, mildly hazy. Aroma has a strong alcoholic presence, plenty of yeast, a good foreshadowing of what is to come in the flavor. Initial sip is potently bitter, or strong, not sure, just unpleasant. Hints of pepper, but the alcohol dominates. Dry finish. Smooth carbonation, lacks the complexity, fruit, sweetness, and hops of some of the other greats in this style.Disappointing...
Some food pairing notes not incorporated into the rating numbers. Makes a decent complement to sushi (tuna roles), especially the ginger, and a nice green salad. Helped to temper the alcohol and bring out some of the peppery, and sweet, flavors.

Citrusy smell with some spice. and i mean spice, as in pepper or something along those lines. Same thing with the taste. very malt ascertive with a pepperiness and tingle to it. mellows out as your taste buds become accustomed to it. not a whole lot going on.

I find this to be a pretty disappointing Tripel.  Quite surprising, actually, considering all of the acclaim it gets.  Poured with a massive foamy head that lasted for several minutes.  Brew was surprisingly pale, looking almost like an unflitered hefeweizen. Smells a bit sour.  Initial flavor is pretty citrusy with more hops than most Trappist ales, and more bite as well.   Sour, burning finish.  Asprin-like taste.  Not what I expected.  I hope this is just a bad bottle.  I had many more hopes for this one.  I wont just hand out points for this one, simply because it is a Trappist ale.  Karmaliet is better than this one.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2014 Bottled.  Ive always thought this was one of my favourite beers but then Ive only ever drank it in decent Belgian bars or at the side of the river in Holland and sometimes I feel the location and ambience make something seem better.  It is a good beer but not like I remember.  The aroma is spicy but also a bit off.  The colour is quite disappointingly yellow/orange.  The flavour is big and spicy and as the description says "dry" but it is too dry and a bit unbalanced.  Still good and I have rated as if Id never tried it before, but its certainly scored lower than I expected.Score 3.4Subsequent ratings scored 3.8 and 3.8. Average becomes 3.7

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2005 Pale cloudy apricot color with a huge white head. Aroma of white grape champange.  Peppery white grape wine start, fruity with a long dry bitter grape skin finish. spicy with a foamy mouth feel. Alcohol, while not overpowering  is definately present.   : )

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2008 [bottle - Great European Beerfest 8, Sharp Edge Tavern - East Liberty, PA] Poured a hazy orange color with a fizzy white head. Strong and spicy aroma with a hint of citrus and alcohol. Strong and potent flavor of citrus with dry and floral notes and a dry yet creamy finish. Very well blended.
A stronger more alcoholic version of the Westmalle XX.  Strong and spicy and slightly dry trappist.  Hints of pepper and orange.
Cloudy amber colour with good head and malt fruit spicey aroma. Spiritus malt hop flavour with fizzy grassy palate.

Bottle: Hazy golden hue with small floaties that produced a soft frothy white head and very good lace. The aroma has notes of lemongrass, orange zest, banana, pepper and spice, barnyard yeast esters, oak, and moderate phenols. The taste starts very twangy with minor fruit liqour notes. Bitter and yeast undertone throughout. The finish is very spicy, woody, and has a noticeable alcohol presence. The feel is aggressive and biting with an asprin like finish.  This tripel lacks the depth and complexity of the best in genre. Right at the "best before date", so its not too young or old.

Spicy smell, lemon with a hint of vanilla.  Looks like apple cider. Nice frothy head, even after a careful pour. 9.5% alcohol and cannot taste a lick of it. Spicy, fruity and bitter to taste. Very happy after this one!!!
Tried in Blois, France.  Gold Coloring.  Spice. Remember as a great introduction to Abbey Tripels..

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2008 Wow - super bretty nose at first - love it! Farmy and spicy and piercingly pungent, some light anise notes, peppery, but a little sugar. The taste is perfectly bodied, not too sweet, a bit licoricey. A tad too highly alcoholic, but I had no idea it was 9%. I am soooooooo glad this is being reimported. I will get this again and again. My second fave tripe of all?
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: 33cl bottle, dated 12/08/05.  Pours deep golden bronze, big creamy white head, not much lace.  Sweet malt aroma, banana, vanilla, not hugely aromatic, but subtle nuances abound.  Full bodied, bitter finish, bit fizzy.  Fruity, malty, bitter brew, well done, my only complaint is the boozy alcohol in the finish.  Overall a nice, complex Tripel, amongst my favorite in the style, but it does lose a point for the alcohol burn.

Lemony, yeasty aroma.  Nice yoked bottle, citrine beer with a poofy head and a silty sediment.  Nice alcohol and hop bittering.  ABV evident.  Tart and fruity, but not sweet to my taste.  Finishes with a nice aspirin bitter.  This was a good bottle of beer.

Bottle pours a cloudy golden, small yeasty bits floating about, two finger frothy white head, nice lacing, with light carbonation.   Fruity, sweetness, clove, and some banana on the nose.   Forwardly spicy, light alcohol, with some floral esters.   Finishes slight strong, slightly bitter.   Gonna let this warm up a bit first..   Some fruity flavors, flora, and alcohol on the finish.   Body and mouthfeel are decent, but nothing exceptional. &nbsp A good triple, but a bit too strong for my taste.

As much as I hate to say this and as much as I was looking forward to drinking this, I was just not overly impressed.  This was just a very averave Belgian trippel in my opinion.  The pours is very nice and cloudy, and amberish orange color with a nice two finger head.  The lacing is also really nice.  The aroma is sweet and has a bit of mandarin orange zing to it.  The flavor is just kind of sloppy and all over the place.  Some nice acidity though.  Finish is bitter.  I will have to try it again when I am in a better mood.

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2005 3-6 year old bottle into tulip glass.  Smells of orange peel, melon and yeast.  Huge fluffy creamy head is white over a hazy yellow-orange beer.  Malty and creamy in the mouth, fuller than expected, this tastes like malted milk and the white pulp between an orange peel and the fruit, only better than that.  Slightly caramelly also.  Finish is soft and slightly dry with some flabby sweetness.  Warm and spicy in the middle, this has a perfect mouthfeel and hard-to-describe goodness.  Words like "pulp" and "flabby" dont give the right impression, but Im at a loss for a better spin.  Really, the best triple Ive ever had.

duvel tulip glass: initial aroma of the locker room, but then i poured it... huge and frothy white head than turns rocky and airy. the body is hazy and golden with yellow tint and yellow/orange highlight. great crystal laces. how about a real whiff? average; bread pudding, grapefruit/grass, musty. palate: lively, smooth, a slight sharp but very nice. the flavor is citrus, bread, spice, alcohol. its slightly acidic. the aftertaste is yummy, a bit chalky. its a good beer, but yes i expected better. i should spend more time with it.
Hazy golen, great head. Aroma from citrus and grapefruit. Flavor from sourapples and citrus. Not very complex and quite a disappointment.

Hazy golden, with yeast floating around in the glass. Nice white head. Aroma from citrus and apples. Spicy. Flavor is spicy as well, and the spices get a little too dominating. I expected more of this one, especially since it is a tripel. It was a good beer, but it does not make it to my toplist.

What an abby tripel... head for several minutes with lacing for days.Spicy and sweet to start working toward bitter finish. Love the yeast (strong like bull). Overall a nice complex tripel with lots of character.

26th beer of the 2004 Montreal Mondiale. A nice golden, hazy beer. The head, quite large is white, and stuck around for a while. The aroma is yeasty and presents and interesting amount of spices, with some citrus flavours. In the flavour, I like the fact that the yeastiness is balanced by sweet malts, making for one delicious beer. Damn those monks can make beer.

Wow an abbey that I actually liked quite a bit. Cloudy amber orange with a big white thick head, frothy and big bubbly. Lots of wheat and yeast with some citrys. The taste is pretty darn good malty and sweet creamy but that wheat or yeast is still there but not that bad. Medium body.
Small white head. Golden color and a spicy and yeasty aroma. Same for the flavor, add some alcohol taste and some fruits and you got it !! Great beer ! I would definitly like to buy some !

Pours a tan color with a nice white head. Aroma is yeasty and fruity.  Flavor is yeast,banana and cloves with a nice spicy bite.  Alcohol is present.  It fact it kind of numbs the tounge and burns as it gos down.  Very nice and complex.

Thanks for sharing, Gasspasser!  This was a good one.  Poured cloudy amber/orange with thick, frothy white head.  Sweet, floral yeasty aroma.  Evident alcohol.  Creamy texture.  Flavor was candy-like.  Very good and very refreshing.  A surprise to me.

Very attractive pour, hazy yellow-orange with a tight white head, good lacing and streams of bubbles flowing upwards throughout. Spritzy aroma, light banana, pears, and alcohol. Not a very complex flavor for a Tripel. A little bit of yeast, some cloves and alcohol. A little too much carbonation for my liking. The finsih is rather bland - loses all of its luster - rather dull and dripping with alcohol. All in all, color me just a bit dissapointed - expected much more.

Much better than the flemish sour I had before it. Great aroma, full bodied potent beer. Im glad I had it at the Belgianfest because this is something I would have otherwise probably not tried for a very long time.
A fruity savour in the beginning with a bitter aftertaste. A truly great trappist beer.

2002 Lots of spiced banana, very carbonated to the point of almost numbing the tongue.  Strong alcohol noticed throughout the nose and tasting.  Pretty darn good.

2001 Less carbonation that the 2002, missing the bright spiced banana of the 02 as well, more subdued... I like this one fresh rather than aged.
One of my favorite beers. Spicy heavy triple. Spicy and sweet to start and bitter after. Since that is what I seek in a triple this rates highly for me. A classic triple.
Pours gold, and a bit hazy. Aroma is spicy. Taste is both spicy and slightly fruity. Turns a little bitter in the end.

Mildly fruity and somewhat spicy cookie dough-like aroma. Straw coloured with white head that diminishes to cover. Lovely spiciness up front. Plenty of yeast - breadlike. Some fruity wine-like notes. Restrained effervescence on the tongue balanced very nicely by creamy smooth feeling and chewy body. Complex and exciting - heres a beer you can really get into. Flavour evolves as temperature increases. Bottle (at Le Bistro des Bieres Belges).

Pours with a two finger, rocky head, golden color; banana, pinapple/citrus,  and slightly yeasty aroma...similar to a Duvel or Achel, nice; the taste, however, is dry, phenolic, peppery/spicey, with some hints of medicine and solvent; dry and lingering aftertaste.... a little disappointing, and not worth the price. Many others are better, even if this *is* the gold standard.

Not a good tripel.  Pours a golden color with a white head.  Smells of alcohol with a hint of fruits/spice.  Tastes deep but the alcohol flavor - maybe it needed more aging, but then again 9% isnt the biggest beer around.  Better luck next time.
Very much an evolving beer with complex fruitiness in the nose and almost bitter aftertaste in the beginning. A good trapist but not my favorite.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2006 Art of Beer 04:  Golden yellow color with some haze and a big fluffy white head.  Aroma is dry peachy and citrusy.  Taste is lightly fruity with lemon and spice.  Very dry and crisp.  Damn good beer.

Color is of melted lemon or banana popsicles, thickly set and murky with a largely tall, whipped smooth white frothy foam on top. Lacing all over the snifter in thick sheets and a very hefty skim (basically a small cap of smoothened white foam) remains present the entire glass. Impressive cap and beautiful thickset color. 

Aroma is simple yet delicate with a pleasingly dry yeasty edge darted with some lemon peels and sugary sweetness. 

Taste is well mannered with a soft fruity front, well rounded and pleasant to the buds. Drops of lemon, maybe some tidbits of white or green grapes skins in there add some interesting little drying additions to the finish where the yeasty dryness floats off any reminiscent fruityness left over. Nice fading dry finish thats a bit complex and softly yeilding.

Feel is nearly full with a soft well rounded fluffyness thats really nice. A bit of sparkle in the carbonation and yeastyness really keeps a great attraction to thee lips. And the drying finish is alluring with very late spices making an appearance across the far back of the palate.

One finely put together triple. A trifecta, or trifold, if ya will, of an ale. Has a soft pleasing presense in each sip with just the right amount of everything to keep it interesting.
Dark golden tripel, unclear, white head with some laces. High carbonation. Powerfull sweetish flavour dominated by the strong ABV. Overall a powerfull tripel.

Very nice hazy apricot color with a fluffy white head. Sweet bready bubblegum and clove aroma. Very nice balance of sweet and spicey flavors. Sweet malt, banana, bubblegum, clove, and pepper. Very crisp, tingly feel with a dry finish. Most enjoyable!

Slightly hazy golden body, lively carbonation and frothy white head.  Aroma of banana and bubblegum with moderate yeast/breadiness as well.  Flavor is quite alcoholic with some acidity.  Clove, spices and citrus fruit are all there.  Palate is dry and sweet.  Its much more alcoholic in flavor than other Tripels Ive had.  Good.

A world class beer. Champagne to my mates. Chewy yeast, and creaminess weight and barley malt. What Unibroue strives for. Get the right glass. Great with food. Balanced but alcohol is there. Carbonation, significant fruit and some spice.
Complex aroma and taste.

A wonderful tripel.  I recommend allowing this to sit a while.  Right out of the fridge and just poured the carbonation is distracting and the alcohol causes a distinct booziness. Allowed to warm and shed carbonation it turns into a sweet, spicy and complex tripel.  Wheat, banana and candied malt.  By the end all the parts were blending beautifully and there was a seamlessness about it that marks for me the difference between just having the right ingredients and processing them expertly. I would not have minded a bit more spice.
Fuerte cerveza, sabor especiado. Bastante espuma. Color oscuro. Yo creo que tiene una mala calidad/precio bastante mala. O sea es bastante cara

A hint of flowers in the aroma. Finishes rather bitter, but fruit, malt and hop is what you taste before that.
Nice beer.

Bubbles in the lacing seem bigger than in most belgians.  This beer has a little more bitterness than I would like when I'm in the mood for something sweeter.  There is a little sweetness here, but it's much more general and not as deep or interesting as others I've had.

Just picked up a bottle of the new stuff (I mean the stuff Merchant du Vin now imports).  To me, it seemed a bit too fresh, and the hops were too aggressive for a Trappist ale.  I had this a few years ago, and it was a much more mellow, well-rounded drink.  Still a good beer, though.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2004 Apr 23, 2004 Bottled, This is a really tasty trappist.. Not the best but certainly up there. 
Rerate July 12, 2004: Dry and spicy, this is what Orval wants to be.

Bottle: Poured a hazy yellow/brown colored brew with a huge bubbly head with better then expected retention. Aroma is quite complex with some different spices that are quite hard to identify and no trace of that high level of ABV. Carbonation is great with an above average body but still lighter then expected, I also noticed a lot of less or sediment floating around. Taste is quite refreshing with again the mix of spice overshadowing the malts and hops. Overall, a very good tripel but still not enough to make this the best Trappist.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2004 Bottled (BB 04/2005)
Golden yellow color, steady creamy white head. Aroma is parfumic, citron. Taste has malts, hops and it is very bitter. Not alcoholic bitter but like a grapefruit. Excellent. (8/4/9/4/17 4.2)
Re-rate, bottled (BB 12/2004)
Golden yellow, hazy. Cloudy white head. Aroma of citrus and grapefruit. Bitter, citric and malty - perfect palate. Long bitter and warming aftertaste, I like this more than Orval. (8/3/9/5/17 4.2)

Yeasty, phenollic, apple and banana aroma. Clear golden color with a large white head. Dry yeasty flavor, smooth mouthfeel. Finishes rather bitter, with some alcoholic warmth coming through. Good, but a little dissapointing. I'd take an allagash over this anyday.

Lighter aroma of honey, pear, and yeast. Poured a hazy golden color with a foamy white head and some floaties. Flavor is quite yeasty, sweet, and there is a considerable amount of alcohol. Finishes dry. Soft and smooth mouthfeel, some alcohol burn though. A nice tripel, not necessarily up to Trappist standards but good nonetheless.

Poured golden with a huge white head, which subsided to a long lasting small head. Lovely spicy yeast aroma with some citrus notes and a touch of alcohol there. Full bodied smooth palate. Sweet clean fruity start with a spicy dry peppery finish. Well balanced.

Pours a dark hay color and has lots of lacing, lots of carbonation and a huge white head. The aroma had a slight skunk with peach and grass. The taste is pear, grass and a little alcohol. This is inferior compared to other Trappist ales.

Bottled. Pours a big white head that takes up half a tulip glass, then settles to a half inch of meringue. Body is dark yellow with some wit-like cloudiness. Smell is "clean," with a citrus and yeasty highlight. Alcohol is very upfront in the taste, and low level carbonation gives it an asti spumanti feel. Sweetness is vinous rather than malty. As others have suggested on the forums, this may be a hard style to understand. I certainly like it, but I keep expecting more of a "big beer" taste. But with this, I finally got to celebrate Easter with some beer made by monks (Oooh... I coulda had a Salvator, too!)
Gold with a large head and tornado like carbonation.  Looks very nice.  Aroma is of yeast and ripe fruit.  It's tasty with fruit flavor and a very full feel in the mouth.

3/26/04:  Bottle. Thick, creamy white head.  Golden sunshine body; translucent.  Strong alcohol nose with hints of crisp apple and pear.  Phenolic and astringent characteristics.  Wheat and yeast tastes dominate.  Clean and dry finish.

Pours a light golden color with the most beautiful head I've ever seen.  Tiny white micro bubbles that are exactly the same size emerge from the brew for about 7 minutes after poursing.  Aroma is of mild bananas and the wonderful belgian yeast.  The flavor is more of the same with a lasting bitterness and dryness.
Gold beer with white head. Fresh fruity taste. Alcohol only slightly tasted unless high percentage. Very turbid though with is the negative quality. Maybe this was just the bottle I drunk...
Hazy golden colour with nice lasting head. Malty aroma with some spices. Flavor is malty with a good bitter finish.
Everything have been said about this one after more than 300 ratings...a great beer !

Hazy golden color,small white head that had a nice hangtime then faded to a very nice lace.Very nice fruity aroma with hints of maybe bananna,citrus and yeast with maybe a mild spicy side.Nice flavor of fruit and spice with the taste hanging on the pallate.The hops are fairly well done and the brew is decently carbonated.This was one hell of a surprise,i was thinking this would be another copy of the dubbel with maybe a little bit more of this and that,but i have to say that i honestly prefer this one just for the flavor alone.Nicely balanced and well done.Thanks go to Nexxus for another great brew.

Deep gold with a lasting frothy white head.  Malty and spicy (peppery) yeast aromas as well as fruity with a very light floral hop and sugary sweetness.  Flavor is malty and well balanced at the start, but turns pleasantly bitter toward the middle and finish. Some alcohol fruitiness, clove, pepper spice and a dry bitter finish.  There is also a hop flavor and white grape juice in the aftertaste.  Lighter medium body w/ higher level of carbonatoin, warming alcohol, and dry mouthfeel.  I prefer tripels on the malty side and this is to bitter, but it's a well made beer nonetheless.

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2004 Re-rate Multiple bottles have made me more of a believer. The taste is tangier and the palate rounder than originally rated.

Spicy and dry define this well. Sadly, both elements are too pronounced. It poured a nice murky blonde, but the joy ended there. This may be the standard-bearer, but in pure flavor and palate many tripels have exceeded it.

Bottle pours a nice golden color with a monster white head and lots of cobweb lace.  The aroma is of subtle malts, hops, and yeast.  The flavor is malty, somewhat yeasty, and hops that are quite floral and special.  There is a good spice component that provides perfect harmony to the notes played by the malt, yeast, and hops.  The palate is quite carbonated, all the while with quite a backbone that holds everything together.  The total effect is a refreshing and dry Tripel.  Yes, this one is good.

33ml brown bottle poured into my usual "rating when at work" Hoegaarden tumbler. It spilled over on opening and for an instance I got a buuble-gum aroma.This foam-over probably explains the cloudy appearance, the colour of which was light gold. Later the aroma was fruity like stewed apples.The head quickly diminished to a fizzy white with some lacing. The flavour was sweet and malty with a strong organic solvent finish.
I'll try this beer to accompany a treacle tart and custard pudding.

This beer pours a light amber/orange color with a thick head and leaves some lacing on the glass.  The aroma was fruity with alcohol hints and some spices as well.  The flavor is filled with spiciness, fruits, and malts.  Not too strong for a tripel.  This is a pretty well made beer and I got a lot more enjoyment out of this than their dubbel.
Intense gold color fairly clear with intense head retention. Somewhat fruity with dry finish. Subtle alcohol presence. A very nice trappist!

Westmalle produces a huge creamy head that floats on a hazy medium yellow body. Lightly malty with a a spicy, clean, lemon scent. The flavor is slightly sweet followed by a touch of sour bitterness. Typically light bodied with a dry finish. Clean and refreshing.

Cloudy gold with big lasting head. Quiet subdued aroma, light fruit juice and yeast. First taste sends alcohol fumes to cleanse the sinus. Heavy spice, pepper and cloves are very sharp on the tongue and in the finish. Some sweetness and light grape quality. They may not be monks but the brothers at Unibroue do a better take on Belgian beers.

Aroma of alcohol, spices, a yeasty combination of fruit juice and alcohol. Pours a golden yellow, cloudy, thin head and lacing. Commercial description is bang on. Strong alcohol presence. Spices dominate and a dry finish. For a trappist ale, a disappointment. Not very complex, much better beers in this category to sample.

Pours light golden yellow with a huge white head. Vanilla, yeast, and orange on the nose. Spices, orange, banana, and lemon zest on the tongue.  Nice job of covering up the alcohol. This was a good tripel.

I haven't had one of these in at least 4 years, so here we go.  Golden, with billowing head.  Light yeast spice in the aroma, a touch of hops, and not much in the way of alcohol.  Some very light phenolics are low and lurking.  Bright and clean malt, stunning really.  Alcohol is present, but superbly integrated.  Well-attenuated, but definitely not thin.  Hop flavor is low in intensity, but quite nice.  I'm stunned by this one.  This is without a doubt the gold standard when it comes to tripels.

Glowing gold in the glass, with a pillowy white head. Spicy aromas of clove and spearmint, tropical melon and coconut, marshmellow, and ocean breeze. Upon further reflection, I could also describe it as urinal puck. Flavor starts with a flash of spiciness and quinine bitterness, then yeasty sweetness, and explosive fizzy carbonation reveals bitter citrus rind (the white part) and searing alcohol. Dry finish with a carbonized sugar aftertaste. Interesting beer, but the truck stop mens' room smell and blatant alcohol are a turnoff.

Medium golden color. Small head. Aroma is malty, fruity and sweet. A medium bodied triple. Malts are sweet and rather spicy and earthy. Kind of hoppy, but the floral tones goes well with the malt earthiness. The 9% alcohol is evident, but doesnt really detract too much. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is dry and crisp. Aftertaste is slightly spicy, with a noticeable alcohol bite.

Very nice golden orange cloudy body with a white foamy head that could be thicker. Amazing and unusual cherry, banana and bubblegum aroma that perfectly hides the alcohol. Carbonation feeling in the mouth. Complex fruity, spicy and moderately bitter flavor. The final is long and bears some hints of alcohol. Deserves to stand in the Tripels top-ten.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2004 (Pizza Port Belgian Beer Party in Carlsbad, CA) Sweet and spicy flavor is balanced by a moderate bitterness and this balance remains consistent to the finish; Spicy, banana nose is fairly light; Dark golden color and completely cloudy; Very carbonated mouth feel, and the palate is fairly sticky and heavy, and a bit cloying; Off white head has very good retention

Medium sized white head, good retention. Hazy gold color. Fruity, yeasty nose, do i smell onions? Medium body, over carbonated. Malty, earthy, Spicey, cinnamon with hints of dark fruits. Finish is medium dry with a touch of alcohol.
Yeasty, salty aroma.  Little note of spice also.  Large foamy head.  Slightly murky, pale orange in color.  Taste is sweet up front with a dry, stinging finish.  Not the best Trippel out there.

A smooth tripel, great rebound with mixture of sweetness, spice and a bit of carbonation (perhaps from the import?).  More spirited than the Chimay blonde but more sugary than the average belgian blonde.  Perfect combo with a caesar salad, anchovies, flatbread and a hot spring day.

I've had the import and the real westmalle brought back from belgium from a friend.  Both are very similar except for the label.  This was a very yeasty and complex beer.  NIce golden color with complex and rich head whcih lasts and leaves nice lacing.  Very malty aroma and flavors with spicy, yeasty and slight hay and leather.  One of the better Tripels out there.

Bottle. A huge sized head with a white hue that was frothy with fine-small sized bubbles that mostly dissipated. The body was cloudy with a yellow hue. The nose was malty, hoppy, sweet, fruity, spicy and some clove notes. The flavor was sweet and of alcohol. The mouthfeel was smooth and alcohol was detected. The lacing of this beer was sparse. This is definitely an Abbey Tripel worth trying in my opinion.

Whoops, should have been more careful pouring this, loads of yeast clumps. Dominant alcohol in aroma. Nice spicy sharpness in flavor, strong alcohol flavor as well. Not as creamy and full a palate as I like.
UPDATED: APR 5, 2004 Malty with a bold alcohol taste, tons of sediment in the bottle. A good beer but a little overrated.
This is a good Abbey Tripel nothing special.  Pepper, spicy, and alcohol flavors.  Finishes dry, clean, and crisp.
Cloudy orange color with a huge white head. Yeast aroma. Flavor is yeasty and acidic, and pretty warming.
I couldn't get much of a nose in this one - maybe some bubble gum, maybe some citrus, maybe some yeast. Smooth w/ evident alcohol in aftertaste. Not bad but not outstanding.

Walked into Toronado and they had bottles of the dubble and tripel.  The tripel has a floral and citrus aroma with a bit of yeast funk also present.  I thought that this funk would also be highlighted in the taste, but this tripel is very smooth.  The strong citrus and floral flavors persist along with a nice creamy prescence.
Bottle w/exp 12/08/05. Hazy golden with minimal head and no lacing.  Spicy, boozy, tripel with great yeast funk.  Excellent, but up against La Fin Du Monde, LFDM is better value.

Wonderful lacing, long lasting head and a  straw colored hazy yellow. Wonderful aroma-phenolic-clovey, some bubblegum as well.  Tried alongside a St. Bernardus Tripel and I preferred this. Nice to have Westmalle back in the states.

This is better than the Dubbel to my taste, although some might find the alcohol a little intrusive. There is probably little I can say that others have not said already, so I'll resist the temptation to wax lyrical. Suffice to say a damn fine beer.

Kinda foggy yellow color with a fizzy white head. Earthy aroma. Spice and some zest. Interesting flavor. Very spicy. Malty as well. Some alcohol in the taste as well. Good dry finish. A good brew to say!

From a 330 ml bottle that is best before Jan, 2005.  Deep dark yellow colour with a thick white head that collapsed to a nice long lasting lace.  Large yeast flocs throughout the beer.  Smell is quite yeasty, with strong notes of clove and black pepper alongside some light orange citrus.  Taste was quite sweet, with a fair amount of light brown sugar taste.  The alcohol was very well hidden behind fruit and floral aromas, but as it warmed, the alcohol started to sneak in there.  A nice long slightly bitter finish rounds the whole thing off.  This was quite pleasant, but not as complex as others I've had.  Still, for the price it's tough to beat.
What a wonderful beer.A beautiful big head and a lovely cloudy body.There is a amazing complex range of taste which explodes in your mouth and lingers there for ages.A thoroughly enjoyable beer.
Dark yellow color with a really appealing smell of flowers and fruits. Heavy alcohol but it does not hide a complex and enjoyable taste worth of any trappist ale.

Huge head of fine bubbles which lasts the duration of the drink.  Good carbonation.  Spicy, yeast aroma with a hint of orange.  Cloudy golden orange in color.  Wow, what a multi-layered flavor.  Soft and fruity up front, hits with a bit of spice in the middle and ends with a big alcohol kick.  Nice and warming.  Soft and slightly dry finish somewhat remisicent of a white wine.  After drinking for a while leaves a interesting "butter rum" icecream flavor on the tongue.  Maybe because it has warmed a bit and more of the hidden flavors are coming out.  A top quality triple at top shelf prices.
Very strong aroma to this very lovely tripel... lasting taste and aftertaste... Simply just lovely

Strong leafy nose, hint of bananna and some slight yeast aroma.  Color is a nice golden with a decent head to it.  Flavor is crisp, not terribly present in the malt department, but indeed has a fine grassy feel to it.
A really good tripel, somewhat more bitter finish than most tripels I've had.  One of the better ones.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2004 malty an spirity on the nose with fruit and spice also influencing the aroma.
dark golden with a nice head and light carbonation in the glass.
nice complex flavours with dried [apricot, apple] and fresh fruit [pear, hint of cherry] and spice the most dominant, with bitter chocolate and malt also present.
lightly bittered as is the norm with belgian ales, nice body and flavour on the palate.
very nice, reaffirms my love for tripels.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2006 bottle. dark orange body with a large fluffy white head and large yeast specks in suspension. the aroma is pleasant - full of cereal, honey, lemon, and apple notes. well, my impression of this beer has certainly changed since the first time I had it about two years ago...changed for the better I might add. quite dry, yeasty, and liberally spiced with some sweet fruit in the background. carbonation is lively and the alcohol is masked quite well. a good choice for the LCBO to bring in at a very nice price.
Pours golden in color. not one for abbey tripels, but it was a good beer. Malty and fruity. A little citrusy and spice with som alcohol. Pretty good.

My bottle was dated 12-08-05, and said 9.5%ABV. This was one fine looking beer. The bottle also looked rather new and fresh. Poured clear (suprisingly enough) and golden, with a couple of floaties, and that perfect trappist head. Aroma was not what I expected, rather was more like many abbey tripels that I have had. A little citrus and spice, and some alcohol, not the musty tobacco earth notes I expected (like the Achel Blonde). Flavor was malty and fruity, with a pleasant alcohol bite, and once again reminded me of its cousins. If the price wasn't only $4.35 a bottle, I may have complained, but this beer was what it said on the bottle, a Tripel.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Cloudy golden in color, nice fluffly white head that laced around the glass, lots of bitterness in the flavors, full in body, nose full of alcohol, fruity tones to the flavors, spicy finish, excellent tripel
Bottled(750ml). -hazy golden orange coloured, yeasty and some fruity(orange) aroma, good spicy finish, very drinkable and quite refreshing beer for such high alcohol content

Bottled. 1yr. old from time of purchase . Pours a cloudy pale orange with a 1inch head that quickly fades to a thin sheet that never goes away.Estery. Smells of pears, green apples and alcohol.The balance in the flavour is a bit skewed as the alcohol dominates over all else, however their are hints of pear and pineapple. O.K. but so far I like unibroues' style of "triple."

Sampled at From The Vine beer tasting Jan 9th, 2004: The beer is a hazy golden orange color with a thin white head. Thin lacing and a little sediment was noticeable. The aroma is very fruity, along with some yeast. Nedium body with a lot of alcohol initially, and it gets smoother very quickly. There is a nicely complex blend of fruit, spice, vanilla and hops. The finish is dry and fruity. I liked this one more than the Dubbel.

Label states best before 5/16/04.  Spicy, fruity nose with notes of banana, apple, and white wine.  Yellow-orange body with plenty of yeast sediment, topped by a thick, creamy off-white head.  Definitely on the dry side, with alcohol, sweet fruits, and crackers/bread comingling.  A spicy beer enhanced by the tight carbonation and warming alcohol.  Nice.  I am somewhat partial to the sweeter Tripels though.

UPDATED: APR 24, 2006 Dark honey-lemon and yeasty body with swirling carbonated jets and a thick spumous white head. Yeasty aroma of oranges, coriander, mellow esters, and honey. Great malt-sour-bitter balance here. Peppery citrus flavor with elements of wheat and a dry mead. Nice even palate. This beer has great synergy... the whole is greater than the sum of its parts. My favorite tripel, hands down.

Hazy dark orange appearance. Big fluffy white head. Aroma of apricot, spices, grapes, pepper and alcohol. Yeast, honey, yellow plums and spices in flavour. long spicy finish, small notes of citrus and alcohol.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2004 Another nice beer from the trappist monks. Cloudy orange golden body with a nice white head. Nose of fruit specially figs and citrus. Alcohol is also present. Flavor is sweet fruity with tones of figs, yeast, hay, citrus and alcohol. Nice soft palate. One of my favorite tripels!

Very nice bottle, date stamp says 16/05/04

Pours a golden color with a very large head that lasts the entire beer while leaving a beautiful lace down the glass.

Smells fresh and spicy! Lightly fruity.

Tastes...heavenly. I'm trying to nail down the spice but it eludes me. It's very light but oh so complex. Very fine fruits hide behind the a wonderful spice.

Mouthfeel is *very* full, but somehow light. Lots of carbonation.

Drinkability? At this alcohol level, not many a night, but *man* would it be great to enjoy several.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2004 God, I love blonde Belgians! Some fruit to the aroma, but mostly it's sweet - perhaps candy sugar? - and alcoholic. 

Fairly strong tasting, sweet, but with some bitterness. Alcohol is noticable, but not in a bad way. Not particularly complex, but likeable nonetheless. As you drink it the fruitiness/yeast gets more noticable.
Pours with a massive head. Full fruity taste with citrus and orange notes. Medium body with a nice hoppy aftertaste.

Light orange body, medium-sized head. Fresh aroma with white wine, hops, a citrus note and hints of yeast. Good hops character, especially in the finish; a trace of alcohol comes through. Medium body. I liked the Dubbel, and this one may be even better.

Massive alcohol nose with tiny bits of apple and toffee. Cloudy saffron colour. Mmm tiny amounts of citrus and malt with lots of alcohol present but still full flavoured in a beer kinda way. Aftertaste is hoppy which compliments perfectly.

White large thick head. Cloudy deep golden-orange color. Aroma is moderately fruity with citrus notes, balanced by a few hoppy and spicy notes. Flavor is moderately malty with hoppy and light alcohol accents, ending in a candy but slightly bitter finish. Full bodied.

What a beautiful beer.  Cloudy golden body with gripping white head.  Lilac subtle aroma.  A nice malty flavor that is degraded a bit by a rustic edge.  Nice clean finish and a beautiful beer that is quite well made.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2007 deeply clouded but pure yellow --like, i dunno, wild llama butter or something.  every pour is decorated handsomely with a rich dollop of lingering foam.  gorgeous aroma of clover and candied apple, with a solid discharge of alcoholic vapors that slightly resemble airplane glue. notes of freshly split kindling wood, chalk and peeled apples floating in a bubbling starter of bakers yeast. the aroma is disceptively sweet, because the flavor delivery is starkly dry with micro carbonation, and enough grassy substance to feed a small herd of bison. a huge flavor that wanders at will around the palatte, brisk here, unctuously creamy there, finally yeilding traces of  faint citrus sweetness and the bitterness and spiciness of sipping bay rum (not that ive ever done that).  the alcohol was quick, powerful and nimble, because-- although i dodged and tried some karate moves on it, it still managed to kick my ass.  i dont even like beers this dry, but i know when im humbled by great complexity. this is a serious beer. thanx and praise be to indra.

rerate: no change in score, its still delightful, but i couldnt help but notice this time around its elegantly subtle sweetness, and it suffers no hint of harsh alcohol aromas.

As expected, beautiful head like a pillow I'm going to sleep on outside when my wife won't let me in.  Grassy aroma.  Quenching, wonderfully watery palate with a ton of grass and citrus flavors.   Amazing light fruit.  Yeh, good.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2004 I too am not sure what all the fuss is over this selection. Strong alcohol taste, large head when poured, with big bubbles. Flavors of honey and citrus. Not many other tastes except for some phenolic character. I love the dubbel much better.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2007 (Bottled, 0.75l) Hazy, dark orange color, large, foamy and lasting, lacy head. Yeasty, fresh-orangey, spicy and alcoholic aroma. Alcoholic, dryish, fruity (orange peel), bitter, sour and very spicy flavor with fresh, crisp hopping. Long, bitter, somewhat alcoholic finish Crisp, medium to full-bodied, smoothly foamy-carbonated palate. A nice and quite complex, very spicy tripel, but could hide the alcohol a bit better.

Light orange and slightly cloudy. Big frothy white head. Lacing is quite nice. Aroma is sweet and yeasty. Flavor is heavy alcohol and not a whole lot else. Body is medium and dry, alcohol is prominent. Disapointing.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2005 Hazy dark yellow beer. Thin but lasting white head.
Aroma of alcohol, rubber, mineral, fruit, apple and almonds.
Flavour of cookiedough, almonds, alcohol. A bit sweet and quite bitter, especially in the finish.
It is too unbalanced for me, I like the Dubbel much more
PAle, hazy gold, with a huge fluffy head. Aromas of fruit, yeast and candy. Medium body, with flavors of yeastiness, malt, subtle hops, spice and candy. Great Belgian traditional beer.

Thanks to jcalabre for this. Misty gold, white foamy head. Light aroma is fruit/yeast. Medium body with complex array of sweet malt and fruity flavors topped with  subtle spice notes. Balance is excellent, everything fits together perfectly to make up the best belgian I have tried to date.

Fruity, subdued aroma. Light sweetness of malt. Bit of bitter, gassy aroma. White frothy lacing head over honey amber cloudy liquid. Med watery body & med heavy carb. Slight sweet start, malt, honey, fruity esters. Finish presents a rounded yeasty-hops bitter. Alcohol deceiving. Light bitter-nutty after.

Nice frothy, rocky white head. Nice lacing. Hazy butterscotch color. Lots going on here! Lovely balance of banana fruit, hops, malt and yeast in the nose and the taste. Upfront fruit disappears behind fairly robust hops. Yeast and malt finish it up. Plenty of fruit on a repeat. (Excuse me!) Smooth, creamy texture yet nicely carbonated. Very nice!

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2005 Nice white head and fine lace. Clear, little dark golden body. Aroma; little sweet, fruit, quite yeasty. Sirupy sensation on the lips. Alcohol, little sweet, little acidic, citrus and pepper. Dry, bitter and little sour finish. Nice.... Just gets better and better!!! ... well in a recent blind tasting I found this "full flavored, alcoholic and dry" and thought it might be a more commercial tripel (which isnt good) (3,6) ... ambivalence is a good thing!?!

Pours a cloudy medium golden/orange, large white head which laces decently.  Aroma is vinous, lot's of grape, sugar cookie dough, and honey.  Flavor is sweet (candied sugar?), doughie, and vinous, with alcohol also playing a decent part in the flavor front.  Medium-full bodied, too much alcohol present, IMO.

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2003 Bottled. Hazy amber with sediments. Heavy smell when I opened the bottle, so I thought i was into something good.
Niche white head. The first few zips were quite okay. Herbal, alcoholic flavor with hints of banana and weizen in general. But then the finish: It was so bitter, I couldn´t believe it. And it was not the hopbitterness like in a Pilsener, it was more like the bitterness of rotten nuts, if you know what I mean. Maybe the beer was rotten, although it should be fine till 2005. It was hard to finish the beer and it didn´t became any better. I guess I´ll have to retest it. I´m open to comments, maybe I just couldn´t appreciate the bitterness, maybe it was rotten. RE-TESTED:
This time I drank it at 7-9 °C. This was clearly better. The first time, on room temperature, the bitterness was prevalent over everything else.

Hazy orange-amber beer with chunks of sediment in it. It pours with a thick, white head that lasts the entire glass. The aroma sweet and fruity, with yeast, apricot, clove and banana notes prevalent. It is a very complex aroma that is reminiscent of some weizens as well as the standard triple smells. The taste is dominated by alcohol up front, which gives way to a very strong clove flavor. Sweetness fills in behind the alcohol fumes, which has hints of carmelized sugar and banana. A robust bitterness finishes off the flavor profile. A unique lingering aftertaste is also pleasant, and reminiscent of alcohol-laced bubble gum. The mouthfeel is very rich, and coats the tongue while still having a lightness to it due to the fine carbonation.

Pretty golden blonde color with nice huge wispy head and excellent lacing. Aroma is spicy and citrusy with very tripelish smells. Flavor is very mild and smooth, alcohol is excellently well hidden. I don't know how those trappist monks do it, but this has some subtle qualities to it that just feel world class; like they've been making this beer for centuries before I was born. hmmmm.
Cloudy gold pour, with some head and lace. Sweet malt and caramel nose.  Starts off pretty mild with some small malts and fruits. Ends with a small sharp alcohol nip. Nice tripel.

Hazy golden, full of floaties and topped with a fluffy island of head.  Flavors are sharp, with alcohol, sweet sugars, white pepper.  I started off not liking it, then halfway thru, enjoyed it, but at the end the alcohol was coming on too strong.

Bottled, at Bierodrome, London.Murky golden colour, bold, fine, white lacy head. Full bodied and complex, the Belgian malts blend the beer together well preventing any one character from dominating. It hides it strength well, a definite requirement for refined drinking. Lovely Trappist ale that largely lives up to its rating. This rate is dedicated to my good buddy Wally, who, as part of his triumphant departure from London, had his leaving bash in Brugge. He loved this beer and regularly drank his Belgian brews from one of the 6 glasses he acquired on that trip. Cheers to you brother!!!

Perfect appearance, pretty hazy gold, magnificent white head, a few exciting chunks of yeast floating about.  Aroma strongly of wheaty grains and something a tad pungent.  The flavor has layers of depth, a bit of orange, some pepper, Connecticut shade wrapped cigar, and a warming alcohol finish.  I've seen this for years and never picked up a bottle, which I'm kicking myself for as I type.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2006 Beautiful clear gold colour, good lacing but lacking the head I know should be there.Aromas of orange, clove, alcohol and a hint of oxidation. Flavour is malty, peppery and alcoholic. Beautiful mix of hops and alcohol in the finish to give that typical Tripel dryness. Id still rather a Karmeliet though. Aged bottle - BB Nov 04, drank Jul 05: Interesting. This beer had changed quite a lot - I wouldnt say it was much better, but it had some very interesting elements and was definitely worth aging. Firstly there was a bunch of yeast all caked around the top of the bottle which was very weird - the bottle had been stored vertically. The aroma had developed a beautifully layered caramel aroma quite distinct from the typical crystal malt or caramelised flavours - really nice.
