The other thing of note is that the balance had skewed definitively towards bitterness - malt was there and quite nice but it was probably the most bitter Belgian Ive had (not that thats a particularly big claim - even XX Bitter isnt all that bitter really.) An interesting experiment - I wonder if the recipe has changed since this bottle was brewed.

Pours a deep hazy golden with a large pillowy head.  Aroma is a complex mixture of bready Belgian yeast and grapes.  Body is full, lightly syrupy and smooth.  Mostly sweet and dry, it finishes crisp and hides its alcohol well.  A finely crafted and very drinkable beer.  Another great Trappist ale.
Orangey gold colour with a full frothy head, good lacing and yes I can taste the dried fruit and the spice. Good beer but not in my top 10.

Cloudy straw color, ridiculously abundant head which seems to be typical of tripels. Aroma of yeast, dried fruit. Lots of dried fruit in the flavor, also some fresh apple and spices. A litle bit of hop bitterness on the finish. Outstanding.

Bottle best by 16-5-04. Poured without the yeast sediment and clear gold, added a bit of sediment which clouded slightly and gave it a tint of light orange. Aroma is sweet and fruity with notes of grapefruit, berries and white grapes. Alcohol also present in aroma. Mouthfeel is crisp and effervescent finishing a bit dry. Flavor is yeasty and malty with citrus overtones. Alcohol also making an appearance giving a nice warming sensation. Overall a nice complex tripel with lots of character.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Clear golden yellowforms a respectable head and stays bubbly. Fruity aroma with tinges of vanilla, wine. Hints of toast and hay, and  grape/white wine flavors finish it off with bitter but not too dry enend. Covers the strenght well. Price is a groin kick however. Still these men are doing the Lord's work.

9.5%. Pale yellow color and huge aromatic snow-white head. Peppery and fruity aroma, medium-to-full bodied. Yeasty, fruity (peaches, pears and apricots), spicy, hoppy (and more) taste. Finishes dry and bittery. World level.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2008 Original Rating, August 6, 2003:  Nice golden color.  Very fruity and spicy.  Not harsh at all, very well blended. 7/4/7/4/16  Re-rating, Sepetember 9, 2008:  Gold color with a small head.  Sweet caramel and a little marshmallow in the aroma.  Sweet and strong grain taste.  Little yeasty.  Not overly strong alcohol.
Hazy light yellow. Yeasty, fruity aroma and flavor of banana. Alcohol feel. Fizzy. Full-bodied finish.

HAzy golden.
A fresh yeasty aroma.
A quiet bitter flavour at first from some herb.

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2013 fruity, sweet and little plummy aroma. Complex taste, very sweet with some hints of spice. A little heavy... [re-rate]well, I got a case of this for good money from the importers over here.. the magnificent aroma fills the room when it´s poured into the stunning westmalle glas, very golden body, firm white head, fruity, plummy, yeasty and a little citrus aroma. This is a serious brew, very complex, a little heavy but a joy to drink
Nice hazy golden color with a nice white head. The taste is fruits and yeast with a complex finish of spices.

Light vanilla, apple, pear and some yeast aromas. Initially light on the tongue, this has a very pleasant and rounded vanilla character, with spicy hop flavors and a touch of alcohol. Malt notes are also buried in there somewhere, but chiefly come across as light fruit. Clean, crisp finish. One you really need to sip to enjoy.
Yes...that's awesome!...YAY!...Better from the tap than from bottle...would drink it every day if I could...

Light orange straw, with a very persistent soft creamy head.  Light white wine aroma, with some hay, yeast, pears and raisins. . .  Peppery flavour swirled into dough, with fairly heavy alcohol on the tongue . . . Palette is dry, but soft, sweet and warm.  A wonderful lingering flavour of soft fruits and flowers leaves me very satisfied.
Poured an orange yellow color and had an aged aroma with a rocky white head. Initial bite in the taste with an alcohol character in the background.  Smooths out as it goes down.
The billowing head is amazing. It was a foamy ediface of flavor. Can I have another please?

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2005 For this tripel you can wake me up, day and night, summer and winter. At first it is a little bit overwhelming but with the second bottle the richness of the flavour is taken more easily. Alcohol seems to be a little bit strong in the first sip but gets less. Complex aroma.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2006 November 2006 Bottle from NSLC. Hazy yellow body topped with a fluffy white head that fades surprisingly quickly. Aroma is quite alcoholic with just enough pale sweet malt emerging beyond that. Sweet malt is initial whisp of flavour quickly giving way to dry alcoholic malt and a fair dose of bitterness. Medium to full effervescent palate (3+). It is pleasant and a solid example of a tripel, but it does not go above and beyond, and I doubt I could drink a second glass. 6+/3+/7/3+/15 - 3.5

June 2005 - Beer Bistro Summer Festival. Hazy golden yellow body yiels a fairly small white head. Sweetly alcoholic aroma with mild spice. Very dry, effervescent with a spicy pepper quality that lingers in the finish. Medium body. A decent tripel but underwhelming. 6/3/6/4/14 - 3.3

May 2001 - I wasnt overly thrilled with this one, it tasted alcoholy, and a bit spicy. It was a nice tripel, maybe that just wasnt what I was in the mood for... Will have to try it again. 6/3/6/3/13 - 3.1

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2004 From "Bistro des bières belges" on Montreal's south shore (bottle was 9,5% rather than 9 as shown here). The glass looks somehow oldish and interesting, looks even better once the golden beer is in it. It smells hmm.. perhaps yeasts and some hops too along with spices. The taste is more sour than most trappists I've had, alcohol level becomes obvious, spices stay on the tongue for a little time.  Re-rate: Very cloudy, huge head is slowly diminishing and asks for a 5 as far as appearance is concerned instead of the previous 4. Quite hoppy aroma (only a few months old 750mL). ALcohol gets more out as it warms. Floral, mellow yeastiness, hard to put a name on the flavors, but truly well blended. Balanced dryness, hoppy, lots of bready yeast, warming hay character, fieldish. Yep, this is the archetype of tripels, a perfect reference. Huge fluffy body, big carbonation, chewy.

I must send a big thanks to herbjones for giving me this one. 
Appearance: This Tripel pours a hazy golden color with a big, foamy white head. 
Aroma: The nose has a lot of spice & yeast in it. It is a very pleasant smell.
Taste: Westmalle Tripel tastes great. It's medium bodied, tingly on the tongue & a delight to enjoy.

pale, slightly hazy straw body.  lots of carbomation and a HUGE rocky head.  Yeasty and light aroma.  pale malta, light grain character and bubblegum esters.  Some lemony tart tomes.  alcoholic and dry in the mouth.  Full mouthfeel, but biting and astringent. Very warm.  spices and some fruitiness emerge later.
Lovely golden color, with a great lasting head. Dry and fruit taste for this little number. The ABV is poorly masked though.

Westmalle Tripel is clean and beaufiful.  It has some light fruitiness and combines this with a dry finish.  Ther is a bitterness lingering on the tongue for some time.  Perhaps some citrous, sour undertones.

Golden with a dense haze of tiny particles. Nice huge, foamy head. Thin sheets of lace. A piney/hoppy aroma--unexpected but pleasant. Extremely smooth and creamy. Perfectly carbonated. Alcohol well-hidden, you'd never suspect 9.5% (as was shown on my bottle). Soft, subtle, and delicious. I find myself nearly speechless. Just a beautiful, beautiful beer. Perfectly balanced. Leaves a tear in my eye.

This brew pours a medium head of fine to large sized bubbles that left an excellent lacing and a cloudy yeasty light orange brown body.  It has a mild yeast-malt aroma and a strong yeast bread flavor.  The mouthfeel is initially tingling but soon diminsihes.  This is indeed a very nice well rounded brew.

My bottle (from Belgium) says that the alcohol is actually 9.5%.  But anyway, holy geez!  What a damn fine beer!  This is the most complex brew I have ever had, with a fair amount of maltiness and a great hop finish, and it hides the alcohol DANGEROUSLY well.  Truly an amazing beer.
Aroma is slightly fruity and sweet. Dense malt palate. Appearance is hay coloured with very nice head and lacing. Flavour is fruity with a lsight alcohol finish.

Not as good as the double from Westmalle.  Aroma was very yeasty, barnyard, almost unpleasant.  I could tell what this beer was gonna taste like just by smelling it and I was right on.....ripened banana, clove, generous taste of alcohol with a spicy finish.....sour throughout with a lingering feeling on the tongue....pretty good after the aroma.
Bottle.  Golden, average head, a few black yeasties.  Floral-apple aroma, taste was a bit sour.  Inferior to Chimay White but not too bad of a specimen.

ligth bland looking body, but huge head and you can see the yeast pouring into your glass. The pour was an awesome sight and the reason that it gets a 4. I smelled so many different things: orange, flowers, zesty tangy, yeast, citrus, nutty, candy, hint of chocolate. Taste was really surprising. It was very fragrant, flowery, zesty and zingy. alcoholic, good body, and mild carbonation for the palate. An awesome beer.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2003 Congratulations on having both women's finalists in the French Open. Aussie Kim didn't win but thats OK. So, Belgium wins again. Yes they do. Pours beautifully (into a Chimay glass, sorry) and maintains the head the way through. Clove and banana dominate with the balance once again a true victory. A fantastic pale beer with so much presence. My ratings are starting to be skewed towards this beer as an occasional delight. Down here a six pack is a loan from dad and a carton a mortgage.
user_location: Potts Point, New South Wales, AUSTRALIA

text: Deep golden body topped by a thick foamy head with good lace.  Sweet yet sour and citrusy aroma with a touch of spice.  Slightly sweet and a touch citusy with spicy notes and a bit of clove.  Full bodied, tingly on the tongue and warming.

very foamy, frothy, sudsy head on a cloudy yellow body.  Palate is fairly sweet for a tripel, and it's flavor is highly fruity and candy-like with a hint of yeastiness.  It has a touch of sourness with a brief alcohol bite.

Damn, this has a hugh, thick head on it, and the beer has so much carbonantion that the head actually GROWS as the beer is sitting!  Citrus, yeast, melon, spices - crisp, dry finish.  A very good example of a tripel.
Light color, head that crosses the glass.  Yeasty, Belgian smell.  Fruity, bread taste.  Moderate for a triple, but very tasty.  Cheers!

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2003 Pours a golden brightness with a long lasting white head...plenty of sediment floating around. The aroma was difficult for me to get at first, but then it came to me...green beans! Plenty of alcohol, green beans, yeast/bread/biscuit, and some clove (or bubblegum.) The flavor was similar to the aroma, but with no green beans, and a significant bitterness. Perfect bubbly, crisp feel with a dry, champagne-like finish.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2005 This beer has a pale yellow body - hue apperance and a coarse light brown scum collar. I have drunk the beer from the bottle and it had a lot of carbonic acid. The initial flavor taste is fruity with a light bitter afther tast.

Aroma is of spiced fruit. Appearance is a murky orange. Flavor is quite good. Alcohol is noticeable but not overwhelming. Tastes mainly of oranges. Mouthfeel is creamy and you can feel this one going down your throat. I liked it!
fresh yeaty aroma, dark cloudy orange hue, fruity taset orange like, sage-like tones, quite complex, moderate palate, superb

1999 bottle! Alcohol has mellowed with time and it has aged well. Still nice dry finish but the aroma is not as bursting as the younger bottles but the flavor seems to stay with you longer. Very enjoyable, great way to end the day.
I bought a case of this and man is it great. Pours a gold color with a thin white head the faded quickly. a fruit/ yeasty aroma and a big deep flavor.
UPDATED: AUG 22, 2003 Poured a low but firm head.very nice aroma, great fruity, crisp taste, with a nice fruity and little hoppy aftertaste.

Well, finally had to order this one since I still haven't seen show up in our stores. This beer poured a cloudy gold color with some sediment present(but the road trip might account for that). If formed wonderful foamy/puffy white head that stayed the lace stuck to the edges like glue. You could white wash your walls with that stuff. A huge amount of carbonation was present, which may account for that. An aroma of malt, bannana and cloves. A flavor of malt, clove, bannanas and bread/yeast. A medium finish with slight hint of the alcohol present. Worth the trouble getting, but hopefully less toublesome in the future. Ohio needs to quit being ignored!

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2008 Cloudy golden appearance with a big head a-la Belgium style.  Yeasty nose.  Complex yeasty taste with orange, toffee, date, caramel and spicey falvours .  A master piece for sure.  Massively enjoyable beer strong, yet it is not over poweringly alcoholic on the palate.  Not the best trappist beer ever but among such great company its not easy to stand out.  Still a massively good beer though
Extremely fruity aroma, which I loved. Peppery wheat taste, but not overly so. Really really dry finish. Creamy head that diminished steadily.

Pale amber colour, thin, but creamy and very persistent head. Vanilla and peach in the aroma. The flavour is very complex and delicate: spicy, yeasty, quite sweet and sour, with traces of apple, peach, vanilla, citrus. The aftertaste is hoppy and gives to this beer the right amount of bitterness. Good balance and the alcohol is well hidden. I prefer the dubbel, but this is definitely a very good beer!

Ahhh, the first of the Belgian wheel of destiny! I got to be the first to spin the belgian wheel this week and this was the first beer poured! It pours a very light goldeny yellow with some massive white head and a very lively carbonation. The aroma was just wickedly nice... with a barnyardy mix as well as lemon, definite spices and almost a smell of brettanomyces in there...there arent of course...but it sure had that smell. The flavor is definitely yeasty...with a souring tart finish...citrusy qualities with a nice peppery dry finish. It had an almost apple cider like quality to it as the carbonation literally took over this beer. A bit hard to really enjoy the flavors given the carbonation, but definitely a world class beer. Nice dry finish, finally a beer that uses pepper spices nicely...a classic tripel!
A cloudy golden color with a foamy head. A slight sour and yeasty aroma. A yeasty and bready taste with citrus and sour. Some bitterness and a slight taste of Nickel.
Light, cloudy afternoon horizon yellow with a medium to low white head.  Very, very full of pepper and spice upon first sip. Has an interesting veggie smell with the slightest amount of cirtrus.

(Bottle) Pours a thin, frothy, white head and a clear, golden-orange body. Aroma of fruit, citrus and spice. Initial alcohol and spice upfront with a mellow malt mid-section and floral finish with nice, smooth burn. Very good.
Peppery alcohol, flowers, cobweb permeating the nose and mouth.  Not as dry as expected, slightly nutty finish and fairly light overall.
A big long lasting head you would think it was a wheat beer. Dry flavor hops stand out but the alcohol dominates. Champaign like flavor. Not a great Belgian beer but a good one

Cloudy orange body, effervescent head that settles loose and lasts.  Some fruity aromas, with subtle spice and caramel malt underlying.  Bittersweet, sour flavors, slightly spicy. Finishes dry and bitter, with the alcohol showing at the end.  Easily enjoyed, but relatively unremarkable.

Gigantic head that is frothy and white.  Hangs around like that annoying neighbour.  Aroma is malty and spicy with citrus smell.  I swear the nose is somewhat pineapple?  Also hints of cookie dough.  Body is hazy medium yellow with dense tiny particles. Flavor is moderately sweet with citrus notes but the alcohol is quite powerful. Finish is bitter and acidic and leads to a dry finish.  Very unique beer that I will enjoy drinking again.

Really looks the goods, nice gold colour with a vanishing head. Big yeasty nose and full body. Quite a complex array of flavours but let down somewhat but the noticable alcohol. Then again the guy I was drinking it with stated that it was the best beer he'd ever had.

Pours a golden brown with a slight haziness. Strong generous off white head. Initial odor is of candy and alcohol notes with some spiciness. Definite spiciness and tartness in the taste. Finishes bitter but slightly dry. Alcohol is somewhat strong but not overwhelming. Recommended, though.

A very nice and strong beer, with a sweet alcholic taste.
One of the very best in the Tripel class.

My first Westmalle, and from the raves I've heard concerning the dubbel I am a bit thrown off by the tripel here. The 9% alchohol level is very apparent and I believe it's hiding some very interesting flavors. There's the typical belgian yeast esters and a tinge of sweetness in the malt complimenting this well, and there is a sort of "dingy" flavor in the yeast that adds some unique appeal - very yeasty. I really do wish the alchohol weren't so blatant here, other than that the beer is pretty tasty - although there is some citrusy bitterness annoyingly poking at my tongue.
Nice aroma and good color and head start this one. A LOT of alcohol apparent in the flavor which, despite this, is still nice.
This hazy golden beer has a light, fizzy, white head. The nose is citrusy (grapefruit?) with light malt. The palate is toasty with continuance of the citrusy hops. The finish is malty and rich.

The Westmalle dubbel was less interesting than I expected, given my preference for dubbels.  This, however, was a surprisingly good tripel.  The beer is a beautifully clear gold with a wonderful white head, though the yeast in a top-off pour will create significant cloudiness.  The beer is spicey, citrus, very yeasty, and has a very clear alcohol taste, almost like a Piraat.  All of the flavors were clear and pronounced, but the balance was good.

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2003 I didn't fancy to be the 161th of rating this beer. So I collected a brand-new 33cl bottle from the shop (BBd:01/05), a 75cl bottle from '99 (bbd: 12/04), 1 1/2 yr. in my cellar, and the oldest bottle I could find there: a, yet unlabeled, 33cl, bought 8/87 for 30 BEF (1Eur=40.34 BEF). Unless otherwise indicated, the tabel-marks are from the youngest bottle.
Colour '02:golden with slight orangey shine. Thick, white-creamy head, lacy, collapsing. '99:much finer head, stable, colour ident. '87: (dark8)amber; fine, small head, larger bubbles.
Nose: '02: grain, chaff, chalk, malts - not only pale - candi (?) -by warming: more hops; '99: much more worts, typical brewery-smell- yeasty and grains by warmingup (8p) '87: some grains, but lots of port&madeira notes (9p).
taste: '02: first hops, but then unpleasant taste of scorched sugar, disappears to leave sweet taste and bitterness, more hoppy, at mouthsides. English hops? '99: sweeter. definitely some oxidation (biscuit-madeira) but retronasal quite hoppy and dry (8p) '87: very fine port&walnut aroma, more sweet than '02, but sweetness strengthened by portarom. Still a lot of bitterness (9p)
Mouthfeel '02: quite chewy, strong hint of alcohol. Aftertaste more bitterness. '99: more creamy, and fine CO2 gives champenoise - Alcohol more masked. Creaminess gives less sharp aftertaste (4p) '87 mouthfeel chewy, syrupy, oily, not cloying. Esters and even higher alcohols give much more balanced finish (5p)
Overall : '02 lacks finesse, compared to the other two, but certainly to the '87 ('99:17p '87:19p)

Golden color, slight haze, very effervescent.  Frothy whipped cream head, left thick, Guinness-like lacing.  Light fruity aroma of orange and pear.  Spicy flavor, a bit of warming in my chest from the alcohol.  The finish is spicy, slightly bitter, and dry.  Very good overall.
UPDATED: FEB 15, 2003 This stuff is like a triple tag team bout. Usually one or two at the end of the session is good nite.

Aged 3 yearsHazy golden-brownish-amber color; beautiful lace.Malty, lightly fruity aroma; flowery hop, developing in a wonderful way as the beer gets warmer in the glass; light, fragrant bread. Delicate and complex.Full body, smooth, warming, a bit alcoholic; not syrupy but almost sweetish Tripel, with a lot of malt, light fudge; harmonious.Very good, classic final, with fine old hops; equilibrated, persistent.A wonderful example of Tripel.
Nice head, orange colour, smells sweet and you can taste the sugar in it. Dry, bitter finish. Very good, but not very complex.
Pale orange with a sturdy, white head. Lots of floaties. Grainy, Citric odor. Mild fruit flavor, but a very spicy, peppery finish. Not nearly as heavy as most Trappists.
Pale blond colour with a thick foam. Aroma of fresh cream. Rude bitterness with a touch of acidity.
the dubbel is better
the dubbel is better
it is a bit bitter

light golden color and a huge head..this Monstrosity had a sour yeasty, bananaish aroma..the flavor ran rampant in yeasty & creamy oblivion..yet was a tad harsh in the back of the throat..there was a tart lemony yeastiness that paralleled the warming effects..this was quite drinkable for a triple

Possibly the only beer i can think of where the alcohol flavor has just ruined the beer for me. Very harsh on my tongue, too dry. Couldnt really taste anything distinct about the beer. Some sweet flavor, maybe citrus. And alcohol... and alcohol... and alcohol.

Rerate; I had this one last christmas and I was quite impressed by the superb palate, which is better than the dubbel. Furthermore; fruity and spicy nose. Golden yellowish, cloudy colour, lasting head. Typical tripel taste; spices. Spicy mouthfilling aftertaste. Great!

Spicy, fruity nose with some banana, hazy golden body with suspended yeast, big head. Soft, fruity body with spice; noticeable alcohol in the finish. The alcohol presence knocks the score down a bit, but this is very good.

Beautiful gold color. Yeasty, toasty, spicy nose. Shows up Westvleteren 12 that I had before it with its yeasty folds of citrus and cheese (camembert, brie) on the bright side and spicy and tobacco on the other. Like Affligem but much brighter. A top 3 or 5...
Creamy white head. Brilliant golden-yellow colour avec sediment.  Light fruity/yeasty aroma.  Alcohol is slightly apparent at the finish.  More full bodied and not nearly as dry as Chimay Blanche.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2003 Pours a very cloudy, pale yellow color with chunks of yeast floating around. Has a very big white head and leaves a good lacing effect. Strong aroma of hops and spices. Starts out sweet, has some hop flavor in the middle, and finishes sweet with a slight hop twang. The first couple of sips have a warming alcohol effect. Great beer.
To be honest it doesnt rate highly on the Trappist Scale but still beats most beers hands down.
Nothing wrong with this tripel. Hits it right on the head
i´ve only recently come around to liking westmalle. i probably prefer the double, but this feels like a real indulgence, so rich

for evaluation of this grand beer, one sould consider the 75cl. version.  not only is the beer - oxigen rate different, this trippel is also selected from the best casks in the brewery. 
it tasts softer and is more agreeable
i like the small bottles too, anyway

Bottle.  A day for celebration, so why not have a Westmalle Tripel!  A big white foamy head on a cloudy yellow/orange body.  What I enjoy about this Tripel is everything it does not do.  A lot of Tripels just overwhelm the senses and make it hard to drink.  The nose has orange, clove, citrus, and grass.  A nice smooth flavor.  The best Tripel I have had.

<font color=#ff0000>Starts with peach-heavy tinned fruit-salad, watermelon on the palate, gin to finish. A weird beer that gave me a head spin after I was drinkin Eumundi all day.</font> <font color=000099>Sam reckoned it tasted like a bit of fruit you fish out from the bottom of the punch bowl.</font>
Not as tasty as I thought it would be.  There was a funny off-metallic note.  Other than that, tho- yeasty and spicy.
Beautiful thick head.  Complex nose.  Wonderful flavor, complex, but subtle.  Note:  bottle was a 750ml bottle conditioned version that I picked up across the street from the abbey.
Tooo bad they dont export this beer to Canada.
Not one of my fav trappist. I dont know, did nothing for me. Maybe ill try it again and re-rate.

Cloudy golden with a healthy white head.  Aroma is fruity and spicy/yeasty, with alcohol noticeable.  Flavor changes from sweet and winey, to fruity, to yeasty, and back again.  Still, the floral hoppiness is always there.  Its fairly smooth, with the alcohol fairly well hidden.
Very nice combination of bitterness and fruitiness. Very nice head, especially for the older ones. This is the definite version of a tripel. No bullshit, just basic.

Nice golden color, characteristic huge head, surprisingly carbinated. Slightly floral smell. Tastes a little of orange, and strongly of alcohol. Think I taste a bit of clove in there too. Interesting, but not great. Cant say Ive been impressed with the Belgians so far, and this is on the lower end of the ones Ive tried.

RE-rate: had this yet again, like a lot of other people have said, to much alcohol noitced. Strong, spicy and dry as the description says, but too much alco burn on the nose and palate, otherwise its OK. A bit citrusy aswell.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2003 Perfect golden color, with beautiful thick creamy lasting head. High carbonation. Aroma of spices, grain. Good spicy, grainy taste, with some orange and citrus, soft but a bit alcoholic. Only slightly alcoholic bit dry palate. Like the Karmeliet Tripel, this is a more grainy tripel, very good though.
Hazy golden yellow w/ big fluffy head.  Fresh, fruity, yeasty aroma w/ grassy hops notes. Sweet, citrusy (orange) flavour; strong alcohol presence; dry somewhat bitter, peppery finish.
UPDATED: FEB 10, 2003 I quite like this. Decent colour and terrific head.  Lots of flowers in the aroma as well as taste. Good beer.

Beautiful hazy golden appearance. Nice white head which lasts. Lovely combination of slight carbonation, mild spiceiness and hints of fruit on the palate. I didnt find the alcohol THAT dominant as others have. Overall pretty well balanced (probably more so than say Chimay White) and a really top beer. You cant really say anything bad about it other than the aroma cold have been more present.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2005 Bottle  Blond, clear body.  White, creamy head.  Nose of sweet malts (straw and sirupes).  Moderately bitter, moderately sweet initial flavour.  Lightly sweet, moderately bitter finish.  A very well-balanced beer.  One of my all-time favourites to drink now and then.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2012 Cloudy golden coloured, thick lasting head. Spicy and fruity nose, some yeast, really nice. Smooth sweet and round flavour, alcohol obviously presetn but never annoying. One of the best classic Tripels.
light and fruity aroma, creamy finish, bubbly and fruity and very alcoholic

Orange in color with a graceful white head.  This beer exhibits that unique Belgian characteristic yeastiness.  This defines the tripel style because it is the originator.  Although some may be better than this, this is still a winner.

A very good example of the blonde. Beautiful yellow colour with a great and long-lasting head. Strong taste of both alcohol and yeast combined with a fruity, hoppy aroma and a sparkling body. Very balanced.
Blond beer with a big head. The aroma is fruity (pears) with some old shoe sole. Sweet taste with a sal amoniac and yeasty aftertaste. There is also a hint of port wine. Nice.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2007 Sept, 2002The abv is now 9.5%, and it certainly is becoming more available in supermarkets and good off-licences. I bought mine in Oddbins which keeps a good selection of Belgium beers. The high alcohol content certainly makes itself felt and in my experience overwhelmed the subtle flavours. I did try this at room temperature so will try it again cooler when the alcohol will be more subdued, but I didnt experience the joy others obviously have with their screams of "best beer in the world!" [2.6]
Nov, 2007 Theres elements of a strong lager about this - pale, light and with a strong alcohol that shows its plastic, solvent face. Yet theres also a delicate freshness, and some yummy qualities of spice, vanilla and orange. The warm brewing method and the powerful, hungry yeast develop some great character out of the pale, pilsner malt and the lager hops. There is much to be enjoyed in this - a dry, light strong pale ale. [3.5]

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2010 Bottle... This beer rocks!... Very nice. The aroma shouts MALT, YEAST, MALT! The hops are an afterthought. Also detected a hint of black pepper in the nose. This sparkling beer has a nice, dark golden hue. The initial sip is moderately malty and lightly hopped. I detected a little apple and black pepper. Fizzy. The finish is just a touch sour, but mostly crisp, clean and dry. Very nice belgian beer. Im looking forward to trying the dubbel as well. World class brew!

I had two bottles of it tonight.  One that was dated 24/04/04 and the other one that I had cellared was dated 05/09/02.  The younger one had a golden yellow colour with a smalle head while the other one was more amber-like with a creamier and longer lasting head.  I found the young version quite agressive.  Alcohol, yeast, candy and my wife says citrus aroma.  The alcohol mostly masks the flavors but gives it a spicy character.  The cellared one was more about caramel, grapes and honey.  The alcohol flavor and aroma became a lot smoother and the beer felt very round.  If I could rate them as separate beers, the young one would be a 3.5 and the old one a 4.5.  Ill probably hold on to the ones I got left for a couple of years.

Maybe I got a bad bottle.  This one didnt seem to measure up to the other Trappists to me.  Still a great beer with complex and distinctive aroma and flavours as youd expect, but not in the same league as the others IMO.
A smooooth golden ale with nicely hidden alcohol, very finely balanced flavour that stays with you til well after youve finished. Mmmmm.
An excelent brew from the Abbey of Westmalle. One of the best triples out there.
A most afforadable and easy to find Trappist.  Very typical of the Trappist.... malty, aroma, spice and all from the yeast!  No spices added in this Trappist.

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2005 750ml:  Pillowy white foam clings beautifully to the side of the Westmalle chalice.  Serious Triple aroma boasting lemon, Saaz, grass, Sauvignon Blanc  notes, fresh flowers, and bready pale malt.  Spritziness, fluffiness, transitions to creaminess; reminscent of Hapkin as having the best feel I can recently remember.  Predominant flavors of pepper, dough-like chewiness, grass, metallic tinge, and clove.  German hop and spice round out the balanced/dry finish.  I love sweet Triples; and this is a sugary delight.  Alcohol perfectly evident; provides a tremendous warmth to the gullet.   Whenever I see this beer in 750s I grab a handful.  Im glad I have five more in the cellar.  Arguably the quintessential Triple; and a showcase of a greatly ruling Trappist ale.  Ages like a gem!
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Hazy straw gold with a fluffy white rocky head that soon subsides and good condition. Initial peppery hop note is soon hidden by the perfumy esters and alcohol. More esters  and fruitiness in the mouth along with a bready malt character. Finish is acoholic and sweet with a dry bitterness in the background. Overrated IMHO.
Initial taste had a strong alcohol flavor. Not very well hidden IMO. A decent tasting Belgian Ale but not my favorite.

I must compare this with the double, and I like the double better.  This one seems thinner, although higher in ABV.  It is also more astringent and fizzy, lacking the caramel brown of the double.  Still pretty good though.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2004 Rerate:  This time around things were much better.  I noticed some sweetness from the malt, but also a sort of grassiness and certainly some spice.  Definitely better than last time.  7/16/02:  After reading others views I'm beginning to think mine was perhaps too cold or something.  I noticed almost no distinguishing characteristics.  It was pretty but didn't taste like anything.

Head doesnt last to long. Bitter yet fruity. I didnt like this one at first, but after pouring another glass from a 750 ml bottle it seemed to get better as it neared room temperature. Ive had better and worse.

A huge but not very lasting head. Light transparent golden color. A bit yeasty smell. Bitter and fruity flavour with quite a strong alcohol presence. A hint of yeast. Not my favorite tripple and not my favorite Westmalle (the double is MUCH better IMHO). About the very up/down ratings of this beer: i have had 4 of this beer during the last month, and all was the same. It just shows how different peoples taste are in beer :-)

Rerate: 16 August 2002  Hazy honey gold colour. This time the light beige head was huge and lasting and produced some great lace. Aroma included faint hay fields, some citrus, faint spice, woody hops, malt and candy, yeast and more fruit as it warmed up. Flavour overall still not quite as complex as the dubbel. Start is faint sweet with full hoppy bitter  medium body and lovely dry clean finish. Alcohol more pronounced this time that previously but its still a great beer. First Rated April 12 2002: 3.8
This one was quite a disappiontment for me, there is better trappist out there...

Has a hazy lemon color.  The head was massive and thick.  Has a nose of candy malts.  Good fruity textures.  A good laid-back beer with nothing really outstanding, but yet still delightfully interesting.
UPDATED: AUG 15, 2005 hazy gold, big white head.  aroma of yeast. pepper, mild pear, honey and biscuits. spritzy mouthfeel.  flavour is very dry and spicy with yeasty alcohol finish.  very nice

One of the best triples or tripels.
A tastefull beer.

Blond appearance, nice fluffy white head over a mostly clear golden body.  From the aroma, I expected to find some bitterness in it, and indeed, a dry bitterness does emerge in the mouth.  Balanced and smooth, esp. considering the high alcoholic content.  Some citric bite on the tongue, with a yeasty complexion mixed with sourness.  While balanced nicely (esp. the subversion of the alcohol) I didnt find the flavor particularly engaging.  Still an beer easy to enjoy.

A little herb and spice in the nose with a strong alcohol presence thats also noticeable on the palate. Some sourness and astringency in the finish. Hop flavors noticeable with a touch of orangey lemon citrus.

Sweet yeasty nose with hints of spices (nutmeg?) and alcohol. Cloudy yellow-orange color and beautiful Belgian lace. Sweet initially, then the flavor seeks the sides of the mouth quickly where it turns slightly dry and bitter in the finish. Medium bodied with an edgy palette. Complex but balanced. Smooth and mature. Excellent beer, but I thought it would have more power overall - I found this quite mellow considering the 9.5% alcohol.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2004 Yeasty, apple-cinnamon aroma. You taste moderate alcohol flavor with hints of brown sugar. It has a light initial flavor. Rolls over your tongue and give a nice moderate finish. I expected more and was a little bit disappointed, but still a nice one. I liked the Dubble more! (3.7)

Rerate: Way to much carbonation, kind of cardboard taste too.
I sure wish the bottle was bigger... more malty than the usual tripel, definitely can feel the alcohol fumes in every sip, hops and spices jump out towards the finish

Dated 05.10.02. Gloomy peach with tons of flaky chunks. Thick sticky vanilla head. Gentle carbonation. Aroma of cookie dough, yeast, tropical fruit, grapes and Styrian hops (most notable). Alcohol esters as you swirl. Quite...different. Winey and sweet and tropical and hoppy, and then the sweetness falls out leaving a dry fruity taste in your mouth. Medium body, quite thick for a Trippel. Alcohol is tasted at times, wine like, yet not intrusive. Thins a bit as it sits, where the alcohol becomes more apparent. Lots of spicy and floral hops in this, in the aroma and flavor and long aftertaste. FruitIer, more alcohol tasting and yeasty than I would prefer but very good overall. Finishes sharper, spicier and less alcoholic. This brew is a good example and has its moments.

Medium golden pour with a nice white head reducing to lace.Typical belgian tripel citrus nose. Highly carbonated so it dances on the palate. Flavor hints of citrus with very little hops coming out. Really want to try the dubbel to see what this brewerys about.
the nicest beer in the world

Its a cloudy color between gold and copper with a thick foamy, lumpy head. Aroma is really nice, juicy oranges with a faint bite of alcohol underneath it. Unlike some Belgian strongs Ive had, the mouthfeel isnt fuzzy. Instead its on the light side of creamy. The flavor is not very strong. Most tripels seem to be firework displays on the tongue, but this one is much more subtle. Slightly malty and fruity up front with a dry, slightly bitter short finish. While there are some floral notes in the nose, it seems more floral on the tongue, tasting nectarish, but not as sweet, at times. Im enjoying this much more than I have most of the other Belgians Ive had.
Good trappist ale but the alcohol is too dominant. Nice honey-sweet and slightly spicy.

After trying so many lagers in Germany we went to Amsterdam and got this one . It was rainy day (heh) and only plus 10 C outside in the midlle of summer .To srong for may taste .... and not my favourite style as well but 12/20 it is .

Corked bottle.Best before end 2005. Ive had this sitting for about a year and a half in hopes of mellowing maturation.Cork easily removable with little life in removing.Pours shiny,golden ale with the whitest,frothiest,head.Acidic,spicy-hop,grassy aroma. Head is going nowhere but I can tell this beer is.Flavors of orange pulp(acidity),fruity yeast,and sweet malts.This is followed by a very soft appetizing spicy hop character.The best head retetion I have seen in a long time.Wish I had more.

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2013 Flowers and piney hops floating on a foamy moatPillowy honeyed biscuit malts and green bitterness surround the castleThe most peaceful kingdom with about 18 months on it In its first year though, its brimming with life (with a healthy dose of alcohol heat)...
The alcohol cant be missed - its front and center in this whopping Trappist ale.  Could be better.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2004 Cloudy brownish orange color with floating yeast particles, has a foamy off white head that clings to my glass. Bready yeasty aroma of bananas. Sweet and malty fruity flavors with a slight bubblegum yeasty taste. Medium-full body with a dry finish, alcohol taste comes out as it warms, I like the Dubbel a little better, a bit more balanced.
The alcohol tends to come out in this one.  Great bubbly head, but as it goes away, but by the end of the bottle most of the flavor is gone.
Citrus/ floral malt flavor. Smooth mouthfeel but little spice, making it seem a tad bland compared to world class tripels. Finish is subtle but slightly off.
Citrus/floral malt flavor. Smooth mouthfeel without a whole lot of tripel spicyness. Nothing really outstanding when compared to the better tripel of the trip.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2006 RERATE:  Had to try this again.  Pale orange colour.  Aroma is yeasty, and fruity.  Flavour is sour, of alcohol, yeasty, fizzy, acidic, bitter, complex.  Finishes bitter, citrusy, with hints of alcohol.  Much better the second time around.  

(Original rating 2.5)
I dont know whats so great about this.  Heavy alcohol taste and it smelled of rancid apples and pears.  Really dissapointed with this one.

Pours with a huge, frothy head.  The beer is light looking and golden.  The smell is fairly light, but typically characteristic of the style.  After the head drops down slightly the taste is definately dry, and lightly spicy.  Not my personal preferance, but its good all the same. Try the dubbel instead of this one.

Re-Rate 06/08/02: Orange and cloudy, head huge and long lasting, the lace is in sheets, that clings to the glass. Nose is sweet, malt, and a hint of Bubble Gum. Front begins sweet, the top light, the finish is quite acidic, dry, fairly well hopped and a quite drinkable beer.
UPDATED: APR 5, 2011 Bottled:Pours a hazy, golden colour with a large and thick head. Yeast, citrus peels and alcohol on the nose. Flavour is lime, marzipan, yeast and alcohol. Long, bitter finish.
A strong, slightly acidic bite, with a very noticeable alcoholic taste. Its certainly good, but go easy on it since it sneaks up on you, if you know what I mean.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2014 750mL (June 2014 bottling).  Head is initially large, frothy, white, mostly lasting. Body is hazy medium yellow, bottle conditioned. Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), lightly hoppy (herbs), moderately yeasty (basement), with notes of fusel alcohol (acetone, gasoline), concrete, pineapple, rubber. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter, slightly unclean. Medium to full body, velvety texture, lively carbonation, moderately alcoholic.

Sadly, this batch is very phenolic and fusel. Some pleasantries in the nose are mostly drowned out by the gasoline and concrete.  Pretty damned sad when a usually decent beer is a drain pour, especially at the 750mL price tag.  Arrggh.

The best triple Ive had so far.  A big frothy headed beer with a typical belgian beer aroma and a fruity taste.  The 9.5% alcohol percentage is ever present in the bitter yet spirted flavour of the beer.

Re-Rate:  What a great Tripel.    I am more impressed with every sip.  Much lighter than expected, and quite dry.  Beautiful golden color with a think and creamy head. The alcohol is very noticeable, but not to the point of detracting from the beer.  I also find similarities to champaign.  Not as estery as I expected.  Simply a great beer.
Rich, spicy and refreshing.  A rare combination of qualities.  Strong, but extremely drinkable.
Nice spicy flavor, dry finish covers alcohol very well.  Nice Irish Lace, fluffy head with fine bubbles

Nice creamy head, lightly aromatic. Orange-gold color. Nice mouthfeel; excellent balance. This beer, with its spicy, lightly sweet, citrusy flavors - and notes of anise, bread, and pepper, among others, seems like a template for many of the N. American (excellent)knock-offs of Belgians by the likes of Unibroue and Ommegang. Nice clean, lightly dry finish. Classic.

Large milkshake like creamy head, pale golden appearance, steady flowing beads as they say. Thin palate, dry middle, and a very dry acidic finish, and this is where I tasted the alcohol. I have to mention it...this doesnt compare to their dubbel, and maybe it shouldnt because they are different styles, but after just having the dubbel this brew seems tame.
Why does everyone have to mention the dubbel when this beer comes up? Its the original Belgian Tripel,Westmalle may not have perfected the style,but they INVENTED IT!

Excellent golden trappist product. Beautiful head that sticks to the glass. Fruity and pale trappist, unlike the other trappists around. Aromatic and creamy taste. Not very bitter. Complex fruity palate.

Seeing this triple beat out by many just unpalatable beers on this site leads me to take many of these ratings with a grain of salt. Not to mention being blown away by the Dubbel! But I wont bother to go there. This is good stuff. The first sip reveals a wonderful spicy bite along with a perfectly balanced euphoric complexity that is followed by an aftertaste that is just oh-so-nice! Simply put, in the overall beer world, this one is in the top percentile. Although, I do admit, I have yet to experience more Belgian tripels before I comment on how this ranks in its own category (theyre just impossible to get here).
surprisingly light for a strong beer, nice body. But I allways say to my self: You should have bought the dubbel!

Light gold color.
Sour taste, with a flavor of lemon.
Pours with a good head of foam.  There are hints of citus fruit in the nose but what really impresses are the powerful alcohol and hops flavours.  Heady stuff.

In the glass (and it is a must to drink Belgian beers in their matching glass except perhaps for the more ordinary and interchangeable blond pils like beers), the triple looks a bit more alive than the double (which I think is the greatest possible beer). The triple is more overwhelming , therefore I drink it less often but it is distinct and full, making for an enriching taste experience - but then I feel this remark goes for many Belgian character beers.

Spicy hop aroma, cloudy gold body with strong white head. Sweet & spicy flavour yet with some lemon and apple as well. Strong warming, alcohol presence in the aftertaste. Quite complex & made me tipsy.

I didn’t care for this flavor so much with the first sip, slightly bitter, but I loved it by the last sip, mildly overwhelming, as the flavor seemed to keep evolving, this beer creates such an incredible warming feeling, so beware:  this is a beer to sip, not swig, a beer that comes in a sturdy, thick brown bottle to keep out the light so that it ages well, this bottle was best before 2005, it comes in a beautiful, bright gold color with a very white head that lingers, an interesting aroma, with a fullness of flavor that blankets the palate, each sip grows more interesting than the last, is it oranges, apples, lemons, pears, hell I don’t know, but there’s a mildly sweet, malted character with a very crisp finish, in my view, one of the more unique flavors on the market.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2004 As far as I remember, the alcohol content (in Holland) was 9,5%? This is a beer that (as you Americans so subtly put it) 'kicks ass'. Had this after Duvel - do I need to say more? Lots of flavour, the yeast is a bit too dominant for my taste. Mighty stuff!
aroma of hops and yeast. Yeasty taste with hopbitter and citrus. Very complex beer with a long bitter finish. I love it!
Smells of honey and yeast. Golden amber, slight head. Strong, almost sweet rye whiskey taste. For such a high alcohol content, very complex. Wonderful
pretty decent head, sweetness in the aroma and the taste..not one of my favorite Trappists

Faint sweetness in the aroma. Pale tangerine in color and hazy.  Alcohol, candi sugar up front, with a very dry spicy/peppery, and definitely hoppy finish. Far too hoppy for my taste. Nice on the palate.  Less than medium body with lots of carbonation. Tingles the tongue.  If it werent for the flavor, which I really didnt care for, this would rate much higher.

Pale orange coloured, slightly hazy. Pours very lively with big airy head. Flowery yeasty aroma. Sugary, sweetish nose, funky mouthfeel, alcohol-peppery bitterish finish. Leaves a lingering candy sugar flavour in your mouth. Good? No doubt! World classic? Maybe not.
Citrus aroma and flavor.  Fairly smooth, though a little over-carbonated.  A good trappist, but not my favorite.
An overrated beer. As usualy is the case with Trappist. A romantic idea that this sort of beer is allway o.k. The strong bitterness of this beer makes it lack subtleness.

No mistery from my ratings that this is a fave of mine. The sample Im enjoying now is several years old, but Im not sure just how old. I prefer it fresh. If I was drinking it fresh in Belgium (as I have done before) I would rate it perfect across the board. The subtleties continue to delight throughout the drinking experience. Aroma is clovey, spicy and slightly cloyingly sweet with alcohol. The flavor is not cloying at all but is rather spicy, crisp and rich at the same time (can it be so? yes it can!). God Bless these monks.

Got clove/lemon peel in the nose.  Huge, huge rich head.  Flavor is primarily of ginger, sweetness and citrus.  Finish is reminscent of cola or possibly cream soda with a drying hoppiness.  Lots of floaties in this one, too.

Strong beer with a bit of bite, very fine, persistent, but not abundant head with tight bubbles coming from the bottom of the glass.  Alcohol a bit strong and slightly evident in the taste, a bit bitter down the back of the throat but thats just the hops talking.  Pleasant spicy/caramel remnants.

a balanced, with good looking and perfect taste belgian beer. It is a tripel white, so the taste is somewhat complex and comes with some sediment.
If you like the complex and strong belgian beers, youll definetely love it :)
A great trappist beer, the alcohol hits you a bit but suits the style, spicy fruity aroma with hints of yeast. It comes together beautifully with all the componets in harmony.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2007 Clear gold with a a medium white head. Flavor is citrus, spice and yeasty. Strong hoppy character, spicy dry finish and very pleasant to the nose.  Ill take one of these anyday.
Good head and light spicy aroma. Alcohol evident but blends well. Finish slight sweet and vinous. Wheres my keg?

Man that alcohol aroma was the first thing to hit my nose.  The initial malty flavor was overcome by alcohol, but for me the alcohol did NOT ruin this beer.  I didnt think this tasted anymore like alcohol than Chimay Grand Reserve.  Very peppery taste with a heavy mouthfeel.  Probably one of my favorite tripels.

very nice tripel from the trappist Westmalle brewery.
surprisingly heavily sedimented. but the yeast gives it a nice citrus like tang.
also has a very herbal  quality to it.
I bought 2 of these last April and, like the Rochefort 8 I bought at the same time, this too improved with a few more gray hairs. I agree with Volgon though, s little too much sediment.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2004 I liked the Westmalle dubbel much better.  The chunks of sediment were strange, and not in a good way like a 6 year-old bottle of Bigfoot; it was in a bad way, like finding chunks of dirt you tracked in.  Alcohol/wine aroma, light fruity alcohol taste, crisp ending.  If I wanted to smell and taste alcohol, I would drink scotch.

Maybe all the detractors here have gotten bad bottles, as mine was marvelous. Very little oxidation in the bottle I had. Though high in alcohol perfume I found it light dry and fruity. Much like a champaign. Much lighter than many tripels.
Dry hop aroma. The alcohol in this is everywhere. Not my favorite Trippel.
A lot of things going on in this brew.  Hops, malt, alcohol, more hops!  A lot of herbal and orange flavors.

Snow-white foam over a clear golden brew, but NO bubbles.
Very fine hoppy, fruity nose, but no ways as intense nor fresh as Orval!
Fine foamy mouthful with excellent hoppy bitters, quite aromatic, but not particularly full-bodied.
Long in length, clean, with a moderately bitter aftertaste.
Not unlike Orval, but less intense and fine, a bit in the style of Duvel (would that be unTrappist behavior?).  Whilst I usually prefer the Brown Trappist ales, this is yet more proof of Trappist rule!
I havent had one since my last trip to Belgium in 1990.  But it definitley made a lasting impression on me.  I havent had a better Trappist Ale since.
My favorite trappist-ale.
Bit disappointing aroma. Some fruits can be recognized but not much. Golden colour, bit cloudy. The flavors are much better - some maltsweetness, bit hop bitter, dry, alcohol.

I like and agree with most of flemishchars statements, have little new to add.  A great tripel; I tasted brandied raisins and some subtle smokiness.  Palate seemed a bit harsh & alcoholic at first, but eventually just seems warming and invigorating.  Beautiful.
Dry, hoppy, burnt aroma.  Cloudy, light yellow appearance.  Some sweetness and a little bitterness.  Good alcohol presence.  A fairly average tripel.

Had a two year old bottle. Tasted like port wine, intense and overpowering. All the fruitiness you expect of a tripel. Thick and syrupy, definitely not refreshing but intensly satisfying. Good to finish you off in the evening.

Pale straw,slight cloudy, has a lighly spiced nose, orange primarily. Big white rocky head that will not quit. Strong, spicy,citrusy.  Nice array of hops to finish it up.Fairly complex and dry. Its good but its no monkey. Alcohol is all over the place.
It has a superb cloudy golden colour with a nice head. The aroma is floral and fruity. The flavor is well-balanced with a big, pleasant bitterness. The finish is long, fresh with a depp bitterness.
Enjoyable. A bit heavy on the alcohol taste for me.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2006 i think the average above of 3.84 is about right for this one. a very good beer but without the mouthfeel or complexity to get it into the 4s. nice smell anyway, 60% alcohol, but once you get past that theres flowery saaz, orange zest, and perfumey duvel-like yeast. head has heaps of different size bubbles which is nice, always a good sign. tastewise this divides into two: first of all theres creamy malt sweetness, then tangy, peppery, medicinal hop and yeast flavours with bitterness and alcohol burn both competing for the aftertaste. lots of nice spicy hop flavour is a definite plus. but the alcohol dominates - maybe a black n tan with the dubbel would be nice. rer8: (bb08/06, drunk 04/06) a year in the cellar does nothing for this - it tastes exactly the bloody same. which is all right. i just thought it would lose some of its edginess but maybe it needs 3 years for that.
Good
Very complex; heavily sedimented. Possibly the model for New Belgiums Trippel, but far more to this one. Enjoy slowly.
A fine trappiste.  Very aggresive and refuses to quite.  Finishes well.
Concerning taste, this is one of my favourite.  I can overlook the easily dissipating head.
Excellent beer, however, pours with no head to speak of.  No real noticable aroma, just a great taste for this Belgian beer.
orange color with a monster head, hints of fruit in aroma, used to getting my ass kicked with alchohol on tripples, this one was nice, Very Warming

Pales in comparison to its Dubbel cousin. Dark yellow to light orange, with a very white head. Alcohol in the aroma that masks most anything else in there. I was not thrilled with this but I have one more bottle and am going to try again.

This is like the leftovers from the dubbel. Contains all the bad qualities that were missing from its sister brew. Orange-brown color, slightly cloudy, with a nice, white head.  Pervading alcohol aroma makes it difficult to detect anything else.  Unfortunately,  the flavors that I know are there just bursting to get out cant quite overcome the supressing alcohol taste. I detected some hops, but found it impossible to identify any specific flavors.  I swished this around my mouth once...not too pleasant.  Drinkable, but barely.

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2012 Slightly cloudy, with a golden/apricot color underneath some tightly packed white bubbles. Full, smooth and silky texture; prickly carbonation; somewhat cloying. Has a curious vodka-like alcohol flavor. Cobwebby yeast. Earthy, herbal and doughy. Definitely a throat warmer.
Too much alcohol practically destroys the flavor, but try to make a half and half with with a Westmalle dubbel!

Big head. Strong Taste.  
A good amount of bitterness with a dry finish.

Decent Tripel, but not outstanding.  It seemed
to lack some of the complexity of the style, very pronouned dryness.

Brother Oakes hit the nail on the head with this one: this beer is way to alcoholic tasting, the hops are subdued and unimpressive. Just not much going on here. Maybe I got a bad bottle, but this is not a good beer.  Disappointing for a supposed world-classic.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2004 New rating: cloudy golden, large fizzy head that dissipated somewhat rapidly.  Very nice aroma, mildly yeasty and spicy with phenols - a tad of banana, some clove.  Light malts are clear in the nose.  Flavor is nicely sweet, with pepper and phenols, palate is wonderfully light.  This seemed a fresh sample, as I could definitely detect some grassy and herbal flavoring hops skirting the edges of this.  The complexity added by the hops was astounding.  The finish was semi-dry, with hops and only a kiss of alcohol, which was overall very well masked.
The original Trappist Trippel this beer always rates well when I have it in Belgium.  Doesnt travel well however.
UPDATED: NOV 10, 2003 The best tripel I have ever had.  Delicious and complex blend of fruit, yeast, malt, and alcohol, with a body and palate that hold up perfectly.  A gorgeous offering.
UPDATED: MAR 2, 2012 re-rate pending.  Default numbers used.  I will write good notes next time this crosses my desk, I swear!

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2004 cloudy pale orange colour, giant foamy head, strong hoppiness with notes of cream, bitter ornage and anis, bready, oily and very bitter, endless bitter and dry finish with reminiscence of bread and orange - the mother of all tripels remains -THE- reference
